column1: "Dramatic Prairie Dog - Where Have I Been?";"personal/blog/animals/dramatic-prairie-dog-where-have-i-been";"I happened to be served up the following video
column2: which is by definition "cute"
column3: and I highly recommend it. However
column4: what it led me to was the Dramatic Prairie Dog phenomenon. It's a simple shot of a prairie dog from a Japanese kid's show
column5: but someone added a dramatic flourish of music. Here's the original video:

column1: And here are some of my favorite remixes:
"Crash Diet Weekends - pt. 1: Dairy Free";"personal/blog/diet/crash-diet-weekends-pt-1-dairy-free";"David is now traveling every weekend until February. Since I've been on a weight-loss kick
column2: I've decided to take his absence to try a month of weekend crash diets. Every weekend
column3: I'll pick a new theme. I should say that some of these are not crash diets but legitimate lifestyle choices. However
column4: they are choices that I never thought I'd make
column5: so I'm trying them out for a weekend since you can stick just about any diet for a weekend.

column1: This is the first weekend and I've chosen to give up dairy. If I had a normally bad diet
column2: I don't think giving up dairy would make a bit of difference
column3: but I'm already on a pretty healthy and restrictive diet
column4: so this is just the icing on the cake. It's a chance for my system to clean itself out. I tend to think that dairy slows down our digestive system and I think a good part of healthy eating is getting your body to be able to process food faster and more completely. I have also heard that people with dark circles under their eyes have a low-level dairy allergy
column5: so I'm hoping to see a difference in my complexion.

column1: I don't have a lot of dairy normally
column2: but the dairy that I have is heavily ingrained in my routine
column3: so I had to be able to substitute. For instance
column4: I have milk in my morning protein shake and then my coffee. I'd have to change both of those things. I had tried soy milk several months ago and while I liked the taste
column5: it was definitely not making my digestive system happy. So this time around I'm trying almond milk. I had some last night and was surprised how good the unsweetened kind is. At first it seems pretty watery
column6: but the aftertaste has a delicious
column7: nutty tang to it. So that's my substitute for milk.

column1: I have recently gotten into a daily dose of yogurt. That's going to have to be replaced as well. I may try soy yogurt in the hopes that the enzymes in yogurt will balance out the issue of the digestive problems of soy. I've also stocked the refrigerator with watermelon
column2: which is another healthy snack that I'll have in place of my usual yogurt snack.

column1: I think the hard part will be salad dressing. I've been getting into salads a lot lately. Even a non-creamy cobb salad has blue cheese in it. I suppose that my salads will have to have oil vinegar dressing for the time being. Anyway
column2: it's just for a weekend.

column1: I'll be sure to do another entry next week to discuss any changes with a dairy free diet.";"1200071518";"textile"

"I’m Not as Much Into You As You Are To Me";"personal/blog/politics/i-m-not-much-you-you-are-me";"I wish I had started keeping track of all the calls I've been getting from political candidates lately. It was at least five calls yesterday. They've all been democratic candidates. It makes me wish I had signed up as a republican
column2: so I could have compared the average republican call to the average democratic call. Although
column3: now that I think of it
column4: why bother. They're all going to be the same.

column1: The Clinton calls go like this:
This is Hillary Clinton. In my XX years of EXPERIENCE bringing about CHANGE blah-blah-blah CHANGE blah-blah EXPERIENCE.
The Obama calls go like this:

column2: vote for HOPE and CHANGE blah-blah-blah HOPE blah-blah CHANGE

column1: It really seems aggressively anti-substantive. I guess it's foolish to expect that they could say something of value in a 1 minute recorded voice message. But if they aren't going to say anything actually relevant or important
column2: why bother me?

column1: The whole thing is making me feel very...used. And creeped out.

I got an email from Obama yesterday that was titled: "One Last Thing..." Did he not get his message in the previous 2 emails he sent me that day? He starting to sound like someone that can't end a telephone conversation for fear I'll never call back.
I wish political candidates realized that they should be following dating rules. When you're in that initial dating phase and you aren't sure if you're going to go all the way
column2: you would NEVER call someone that twice in one day! That would sound way too desperate and needy. I would have been happy to have a call on Friday from the candidates that went something like: "Hey. It's been great getting to know you. I hope we can continue our relationship. Have a great weekend. Call me if your bored." And then nothing until primary day.

column1: They should let me have some time to sit and think about it
column2: chat with friends at Sunday brunch
column3: etc. The soonest they should call would be the eve of the primaries with a "Happy Primary Day. I've been thinking about you a lot lately. I hope you had a good weekend. Think of me at the polls."

column1: The candidates have crossed over from courting me into stalking me. At this point
column2: I'm looking for anyone that knows how to not sound desperate.";"1202225195";"textile"

column1: "Am I the Lisa Simpson of Gay Men?";"personal/blog/television/am-i-lisa-simpson-gay-men";"One of the hardest things about getting older is that you can't tell if you're turning into a grumpy old crank or if you're just starting to notice how irritating the world actually is.

I just saw this commercial on Comedy Central. I found it offensive on so many levels. The most obvious and irritating thing about the commercial is that they equate meeting people with picking out clothes. They might as well be advertising crystal meth.
And I love the guy that they picked for "smart". I think I must have very different standards for what constitutes "smart".

"Astrophysicist";"personal/blog/comedy/astrophysicist";"Okay...just to even out my feelings about gay culture from my last post: here are some clips from a very funny drag queen movie: Girls Will Be Girls.
"My Tired Feet";"personal/blog/dancing/my-tired-feet";"I guess I have to face the fact that I'm not going to have my new site up any time soon. At this point
column2: I think hitting January 15th would be a tough deadline.
here's a video of our latest dance performance. Yours truly is the one shaking the finger at the dancer playing the little girl in the beginning. Then I re-emerge later.

column1: This was a great performance. I had a lot of fun because there's a bit more acting
column2: the choreography was not quite as demanding
column3: and it had a creepy Halloween theme to it.

column2: Renee
column3: has been talking about raw food restaurants here in New York. She turned me on to one in particular
column4: Pure Food and Wine. There's a little blurb on their website describing raw food.

column2: we were looking for a restaurant to take a kosher friend to and I suggested that we try this place out. They had a sample menu online and everything sounded delicious by the description of things.
Sarah
column3: upon hearing that we were going to a raw food restaurant said "Aren't there a lot of articles about raw food restaurants making people sick?" When we pressed her for more information
column4: it turns out she was talking about a Sex and the City episode.

column1: So we got there and I ordered a cocktail. It was good
column2: but definitely felt light on the alcohol part. They use sake and prosecco for their main alcohol. I don't know what it is about sake that makes it more organic/raw than other alcohol.

column1: The menu was different than what was on the web
column2: but still as tasty-sounding.
I was blown away. You would never be able to tell in a million years that there was no dairy - the food was so rich and creamy. I really don't know how they did the things they did.

column1: Both the appetizer and the entree were extremely good. I was thinking that I might not fill up from eating there and was fully prepared to get dessert on the way home. But halfway through my entree
column2: my stomach said "I'm filling up! Slow down!"

column1: David and I decided to split a sundae for dessert. It was amazing. I never never never would have known that it was vegan. In fact
column2: I preferred it to a regular dairy sundae because I didn't feel weighed down and bloated from eating it.

column1: Even the kosher doubter had a great meal. She confessed that she was ready to harass me about the meal. But she left with a changed attitude and a happy palate.";"1199017646";"textile"

column2: the Musical";"personal/blog/movies/saw-musical";"I just saw Sweeney Todd. I loved it. The filming is impeccable. The scenes of 19th century London are stunning. The story is captivating (they made some changes from the stage version that tightened it up).

column1: I had read a review in The New York Times that said that it is as gory as Saw. I haven't actually seen Saw all the way through
column2: though I think I can safely saw that it is not nearly as gory as Saw. In fact
column3: the blood is too bright red to be realistic. It's meant to be over-the-top Grand Guignol. There are some big gross-out moments
column4: of course
column5: but it's always in Tim Burton style - meaning that it's effective
column6: but cartoonish.

column1: The acting is great. The singing is not as good as you'd like
column2: but it's no surprise. Johnny Depp had a bit of a rock-and-roll flair to his singing
column3: which I expected. He hit the notes better than I was expecting. But his acting is just so good
column4: you have to forgive him.

column1: I had seen a revival of Sweeney Todd last year on Broadway that was excellent. I really shouldn't compare the two
column2: because there's no coming close to how talented the cast was in the stage version; however
column3: the movie has one thing that I've never seen in a stage version of Sweeney Todd - it's creepy fun.

column1: I really can't think of anyone that I wouldn't send to go see it.";"1199060394";"textile"

"Mac Attack";"personal/blog/mac-os/mac-attack";"I wish I were a stronger man. I wish I had more resolve. I wish I didn't get obsessed with buying the latest something and then spend my time pining away for it.

column2: a few weeks ago
column3: I got obsessed with getting a Macintosh. I think it started with my interest in going open source. As I read programming manuals
column4: I began to notice that the installation instructions for Mac were very brief. Many of them said - "If you have Mac OS X
column5: this software is already on your machine". I had experimented with putting Linux on my machine
column6: but when I saw how limited the software options were
column7: I ran screaming. No Photoshop? No Illustrator? No iTunes?

column1: Then it dawned on me...now that Mac OS X is built on top of Unix
column2: you get all the benefits of open source development
column3: with commercial software options and a really cool OS.

column1: This started a period where I noticed everything that bugged me about my PC. I started to notice how poor my video and audio playback was on my PC. I would wait forever for the hard drive to finish spinning before the computer would come to life. A couple of weekends ago I tried to set up Drupal (open source content management system) on my home machine. I spent a better part of the weekend and couldn't make it work. It drove me crazy.

column2: I was completely decided to get a Mac. It was just a matter of time. I felt like a consumate addict - every morning I told myself that today was really not the best day to get a Mac. Just be patient. Rise above your desires. You still can get everything done that you need to get done. None of it was working.

column1: Eventually I got the call from my pseudo-employer that they would reimburse me for a Mac and the associated software I would need to get. Needless to say
column2: I was off to the store to get my new Mac.
MacBook Pro. I spent extra for the faster processor
column3: more memory
column4: and bigger hard drive. I spent almost as much money on the software as I did on the hardware. By the time I got home
column5: I was giddy with anticipation. I hate to admit it
column6: but the Mac exceeded my expectations. I must have said "that is soooo cool" to myself three times in the first 15 minutes. Some of the cool factors are:

column1: <li>I was trying to figure out where to plug the power cord in
column2: when it leapt out of my hand and into its socket. Why? It's magnetic! All you have to do is get close to the slot! That way if someone trips over the power cord
column3: the cord slips out of its slot without bringing the laptop crashing down.

column2: it takes a picture of you to use with your profile.

column1: • It automatically finds a nearby wireless connection during startup. It was downloading software updates in no time.

column2: I started to get feel like that Mac snobbery descend upon me. I had become part of the computer elite. I envisioned that all Mac users would someday settle our own planet like a Star Trek colony of peace-loving
column3: creative
column4: intellectuals.

column1: It's sad that Macs will probably never break the barrier of market share. I think it will always remain a niche product. Maybe that's not so bad. But I feel bad for all those people out there that are missing out on a super cool computing experience.

column2: remember how I spent a weekend trying to get Drupal up and running on my Windows machine and gave up? I had it up and running within an hour on my new Mac.
Please";"personal/blog/dancing/may-i-have-some-privacy-please";"As it turns out
column3: there were two people making videos of our Charleston performance at Frim Fram. No one in our troupe knows who took these or how they got posted on YouTube. It's kinda creepy. Am I being filmed right now without my permission? Probably.

column2: this one has a slightly better angle to see the whole dance routine.

column1: "A Furrier Keith";"personal/blog/oz/furrier-keith";"David was taking a nap this weekend. He looked over at my side of the bed and Oz was in my exact position - head on the pillow
column2: stretched out on the bed. He was being David's "Keith Substitute". So he took a picture with his cell phone.

column1: "A Summer Breeze…Came Blowin’ In…";"personal/blog/beauty/summer-breeze-came-blowin";"It appears that summer has hit here in NYC. It was in the 80's today.
I had to get my hair cut
column2: and I was in one of those crazy moods. I decided to get it totally buzzed. I had been thinking about doing this for a while. I have a lot of friends that have their head shaved or closely buzzed
column3: and I often think that they look best on the first day of the haircut. So I went to a barber and asked for a buzzcut - not completely shaved
column4: but short. And I didn't look at it until he was done.

column2: too. I had those five minutes to prepare a look of stony optimism to not to reveal to the barter that my world had crumbled on the inside.

column1: I took a glance in the mirror at the end. It looked FAR WORSE than I would have imagined. Somewhere after paying and stepping out of the barber shop
column2: I felt better. I caught a look of myself in the window
column3: and it didn't look chemo-inspired
column4: it looked military. I looked like a bad-ass.

column1: I went to Whole Foods and no one pointed and laughed. No one came up to ask me what type of cancer I had. The breeze felt fantastic on my head. Why - I may just keep this haircut for a while!
I got home and wondered if the pups were going to sniff my head
column2: wondering what happened. Oz was fine. Gogo took a look at me and went nuts. She got all excited and even gave me TWO KISSES! Maybe girls dig military haircuts.

column1: I was feeling pretty gosh-darn great about the haircut when I took a serious look in the mirror. It's not good. It's somewhere in between escaped mental patient and just-got-home-from-the-hospital. I'm hoping in a couple of days it will have grown out enough to be passable. For the time being
column2: I'm going to have to wear a hat - at least when I'm with David.

column1: I was planning on taking a picture for this entry
column2: then chickened out when I tried to take a decent shot. I finally decided to be brave
column3: but so as not to horrify people when this page loads
column4: I've hidden the picture.

column2: I've decided I'm not brave. I took down the photo.";"1180128537";"textile"

column1: "Only for the Prurient at Heart";"personal/blog/comic-books/only-prurient-heart";"A friend sent me this link the other day. WARNING: you really have to have your mind in the gutter to find this funny.

column2: that's where my head is 80% of the time and I laughed quite hardily at almost all of these. I read it a second time after working until midnight. Working late definitely helps put you in the right mood to find this funny.
you can chalk up my lack of recent blog entries to laziness. Well...maybe that's too harsh. Distractions is perhaps a better word. Anyway
column3: I have a reason this time.

column1: I had written a nice long blog entry about a movie that I had been hunting down on DVD for a long time. It took me about a half hour to write. I click "post" and the browser-busy icon kept spinning. After several minutes
column2: the server timed out and I lost all my work.
this is not the first time this has happened. My blog software is Wordpress
column3: which is pretty good
column4: but it's PHP running on Windows. My hosting company hasn't quite worked out the kinks and unfortunately the server hangs from time to time. You would think I would finally get in the habit of writing posts in a separate application so as not to lose any work. Alas
column5: no.

column1: So when I lost that entry
column2: I vowed to re-do my site and put it on a Linux server. The new site is going to be pretty great. It will be divided into three separate sections: Business
column3: Personal
column4: and Creative. The content of the current site will be moved into the "Personal" section.

column1: To make sure that I don't take forever
column2: I'm telling everyone that the new site will be live by August 15th! Be sure to come back on the 15th for the new site. There will still be a lot under construction
column3: I'm sure
column4: but at least the current site will be completely migrated.

column1: "Dream Donuts";"personal/blog/food/dream-donuts";"I'm always looking for an excuse to make donuts. I love donuts and I think they're highly underrated. I want to really experiment with donuts and make some fun ones.
So I'm planning a donut tasting party. I want to come up with several different recipes to try out on people. So here's what I'm thinking of:
• Vanilla Donuts - I'm going to use the family recipe from Grandma Fern

column2: but using raspberry glaze

column1: • Pistachio Spice - One of my favorite aspects of donuts is that bread-y
column2: cinnamon
column3: goodness. This recipe will combine middle-eastern spices with pistachios in a cake donut.

column1: • Chocolate Banana Cream - I love chocolate and banana together. For this
column2: I'll make a banana cream to inject in the center of the donut and put chocolate glaze on the outside.

column1: • Tangerine Filled - I wanted to do one curd-filled recipe. I keep waffling between tangerine and grapefruit. For this
column2: I was going to use a brioche dough for the donut.
but using a jam. Strawberry is the classic filling. Maybe I'll use blackberry instead since I think it's an under-rated flavor.

column1: • Chocolate Cake - I think I need another cake donut
column2: and I'm missing some chocolate. Maybe I'll make it Mexican chocolate for fun.

column1: If you have any ideas for flavors
column2: please let me know. I'd love some ideas or feedback on the flavors.";"1173103156";"textile"

column1: "Your Flight Has Been Re-routed Through Hell";"personal/travel/your-flight-has-been-re-routed-through-hell";"We've all heard the horror stories of people being stuck in airports for days because their flights were delayed. Somehow
column2: it never really sunk in how bad that would be. I guess it was too far removed from my own experience.

column1: Last week I visited my Mom and Dad in Oregon. Mom just had knee replacement surgery
column2: so I went out to be helpful. Unfortunately
column3: I wasn't so helpful because I had a major site launch to finish and the day before I went home
column4: I threw my back out. I guess I had not been too careful in terms of sitting in the office chair with good posture - combined with helping Mom move things around the house. So I went to the Portland airport with a bad back
column5: thinking I would be home soon enough and could see someone to help me fix it. Then the following chain of events happened:

column1: <li>The flight was delayed by several hours leaving Portland. I had to connect in Chicago and was worried about missing my connection. They told me that all flights were on hold
column2: so I should make my connection fine.
they put us in a holding pattern.

column1: <li>Then they said that they couldn't land in Chicago due to weather (it didn't seem bad at all - a few scattered clouds)
column2: so they were going to take us to Indianapolis.

column1: • We landed at Indianapolis and they made us sit on the tarmac for an hour.
<li>We got off the plane and stood in line for an hour to get hotel rooms. At this point
column2: it was 1am.
which I nicknamed "Hotel de Standing Water". It smelled of mold
column3: was remote
column4: and had some sort of weird heated indoor pool area from the 1950s. It had the air of some creepy middle-of-nowhere hotel that you see in horror films. I expected to see someone in a halloween mask holding a machete.

column1: <li>Four hours after getting to my room
column2: I got up
column3: showered
column4: and packed.

column1: • Stood in line for an hour at check-in.
<li>Waited at the gate for two hours past the departure time. While this was happening
column2: all of the scheduled flights (including one to Chicago!) left on time.

column1: <li>Sat in the plane for another hour. They counted all the passengers 4 times. Apparently they were confused as to how many people were on the flight and couldn't get the computer to agree. At this point
column2: I was trying to console myself that I might not get home and may have to spend another night in a hotel. I was just hoping that it would be Chicago and not Indianapolis.
of course
column3: the flight to New York was delayed. But only by an hour!

column1: By the time I got home
column2: I almost felt like crying - both from relief and because my back was killing me. Thirty hours of lines
column3: airplanes
column4: and carrying luggage is not the best remedy for back problems. I couldn't even stand up straight.

column1: Now when I hear reports that people have been stuck in airports for days
column2: I can't even comprehend what that must be like. It took me about 30 hours to get from Portland
column3: Oregon to NYC and it seemed like an eternity.

column1: I think the lesson to be learned here is to not travel over spring break. I think that was the main problem. The weather was not so bad
column2: but there were so many flights at full capacity that when there was a bit of a delay
column3: all hell broke loose.";"1175085359";"textile"

column2: Virginia…There is a Spider-Man";"personal/blog/comic-books/yes-virginia-there-spider-man";"There's a certain part of my brain that is eight years old
column3: is happy to be eight years old
column4: and will always be eight years old. For instance
column5: I am eternally grateful that I was eight years old when Star Wars came out. If I had to be born at any time
column6: I'm glad that I was alive to be a kid when those first three Star Wars movies came out.

column1: I have had another one of those moments. For April 30th - May 6th
column2: New York City is having Spider-Man Week in NYC. Be still my geeky heart.

column1: My friend Sara originally told me the news. I simply replied "Every day is Spider-Man day in my head."
There are banners all over town and in the subways advertising it. Yes
column2: it's a big corporate marketing event. But at least it's better than tried to get everyone talking about say
column3: some new fried hamburger from McDonald's.

column1: I've looked at the list of events and sadly I will have to steal someone's kids to participate in most of them. As an adult
column2: I just don't think I can run through the Bronx Zoo looking for clues to Spider-Man's location. Is this why people have kids?

column1: I'll definitely have to get a shot of the giant inflatable Spider-Man at the Sony store.
And the New York Public Library's exhibit of never-before-displayed
column2: original Spider-Man comic books at the Humanities and Social Sciences Library sounds somewhat age appropriate.
I'm just hoping to catch glimpses of people in Spider-Man costumes throughout the week.

column1: "David Reich: Spoiler Alert";"personal/blog/television/david-reich-spoiler-alert";"I am a late new-comer to Lost. I had downloaded it for David's iPod a while back because I thought he'd like it for travel. It took me a while to getting around to watching it myself (like until I got a video iPod
column2: for starters). I started watching the show recently and really like it so far. I watched the pilot episode on a plane. I must say - that was therapeutic. Watching a show about a plane hitting really bad turbulence and splitting in two while you're on a plane and flying in turbulence was a new one on me. At one point
column3: I was sucked into the show and watching a moment between two characters right before the crash. Our flight was smooth as well. Then our plane hit turbulence at the exact same moment the show's plane hit turbulence. I must admit...I made an audible noise.

column1: The other day I commented that I couldn't figure out which one of the cast members was Michelle Rodriguez. David said that he didn't know who that was and I explained that I remembered reading news reports that Michelle Rodriguez had been pulled over for drunk driving while in Hawaii filming Lost.

column2: David could have put two and two together and realized that there's a major plot point that I hadn't yet seen. Instead
column3: he blurted out "Maybe she's one of the people from the back half of the plane". At which point it became really obvious that there's a major plot twist coming up involving a bunch of people previously thought dead.

column2: David.

column1: I immediately chastised him for revealing something I didn't want to know about future events and this was his brilliant response: "Well...there are lots of websites with plot spoilers on the web."
Yes. And I don't visit them.
I hope that we meet these characters soon
column2: because now this is hanging over me as I watch episodes: when are we going to meet the people from the back half of the plane?

column1: FYI - If you haven't seen Lost and you were expecting to watch it someday
column2: you shouldn't have been reading this blog entry.";"1176321150";"textile"

column1: "Your Star Wars Horoscope";"personal/blog/astrology/your-star-wars-horoscope";"Nothing exceeds at wasting time like the internet. And I'm glad of it. I recently found these pages that tell you your personality by combining your astrological sign with Star Wars characters.
Star Wars Horoscope for Capricorn
You have a ton of ambition and inexhaustible desire to reach your goals.

column2: going to great lengths to help someone out.

column1: You are a very social unit
column2: winning the hearts of many with your cute personality.

column1: Star wars character you are most like: R2D2
"Lecture Musical";"personal/blog/comedy/lecture-musical";"This video needs no introduction. Make sure you have the sound at a moderate level.

"It’s Showtime!";"personal/blog/dancing/it-s-showtime";"Last night we had our first performance of our Charleston dance routine. It's been a long 8 weeks of rehearsal and there were times when I was worried that I'd never get the choreography. Then shortly after I got the choreography
column2: I was worried I'd never get it up to the speed of the music. I'm actually at the point now where everything seems pretty manageable
column3: and it's a matter of everything being sharp and tight.

column2: last night's performance was called a dress rehearsal
column3: but there was an audience of about 30 people. I seemed to be the only with jitters
column4: but I think some of the other troupe members were not letting on how much their nerves were affecting them.

column1: The performance went great. The parts that I saw of it looked really hot. And the audience went wild. They started cheering about halfway through the piece and by the end
column2: there was consistent cheering and applauding and by the time we hit our final pose
column3: the audience went wild.

column1: Here's a shot of the final pose.My face is blocked
column2: but I'm the one in a center with a female on my back.

column1: We have two more performances left:

column2: Apr 26th
Apr 27th

column1: We perform as part of the Guest Night

column2: we bowed as we were being showered with applause.
the Charleston performances have come and gone. I had a blast. It was very well received.

column1: It's sad that I feel like I was just getting it down solidly by the last performance.
And I lost 3 pounds in the last two weeks alone with all of the rehearsal. Why don't more people dance for exercise? I get better results and have a lot more fun than any exercise machine.
This video was posted less than 24 hours after our performance at Frim Fram. No one knows who recorded it or who posted it.

"Google Analytics (not really) Hacks";"business/blog/analytics/google-analytics-not-really-hacks";"I've been using Google Analytics for myself for quite a while. I generally put it into all the sites I build for clients.
Since it's driven by JavaScript calls
column2: I figured that there had to be hacks so that you could report on more than just which pages were being visited. Theoretically
column3: you could see if people were getting confused by a particular button
column4: a form entry
column5: anything. I did a search for "Google Analytics Hacks". I found what I was looking for
column6: except it wasn't called a hack. The information I wanted is in the Google Analytics support section. That was easy.

column1: The information that I was looking for is right here: http://www.google.com/support/analytics/bin/answer.py?answer=27229&topic=2978.

column2: I don't really have any need for this on any of my sites now
column3: but it's good to know it's there.";"1172594412";"textile"

column1: "Oscar Night";"personal/blog/celebrations/oscar-night";"David and I threw a small Oscar night party.

The Oscar's website had handy download-able ballots that we printed up for guests. We put together a betting pool to see who could see into the collective mind of the academy - $5 per person. I started handing out ballots and a couple of guests got so serious and driven about filling in the ballots that I wondered what I had gotten myself into. I foolishly thought this was for fun. One person entered his dog so that he could fill out two ballots.
I wanted to bake something fun
column2: so I made an old family recipe that I have re-christened Sea Foam Cake. The crunchy gold exterior and the pristine whiteness of the cake felt very "oscarish".

column1: At the beginning of the evening
column2: David took a clear lead. Everyone felt a bit disappointed - what would be the fun of David winning? He was going to be asleep before the Oscars were over. Luckily
column3: I caught up with David and eventually took the lead for myself. Our friend Jeff was beside himself with competitive envy. At one point
column4: it looked like the dog's ballot was going to beat out Jeff's.

column1: All turned out well in the end. The two truly competitive people in the room
column2: Jeff and myself
column3: tied for first. We could all live with that.";"1172596147";"textile"

column1: "Charleston Performance Class";"personal/blog/dancing/charleston-performance-class";"I signed up for a Charleston Performance class taught by Evita Arce and Michael Jagger. It's eight weeks of classes. Each class is an hour and a half. There are two performance at the end of the class. Here's the flier:I had taken classes with Evita before and felt somewhat assured that I'd be able to keep up. But no matter how much you think you're prepared
column2: it's quite intimidating to think that you'll be performing in front of strangers in 8 The decision to go ahead really came down to the fact that this is going to get me in shape better than any aerobics class and it's going to be a hell of a lot more fun.

column1: We made a significant amount of progress in the first class. Enough for me to realize that I'm not going to flat out embarrass myself when it comes to performance time.
And the music is fun. It's two pieces: the first is "I'll Build a Stairway to Paradise" performed by Rufus Wainright. The second is "Happy Feet" performed by The Manhattan Rhythm Kings.
Since we go through material very quickly
column2: we're expected to write down the moves after class so that we don't forget. And it's amazing how quickly all of it leaves your head. So in the interest of putting this somewhere where I won't forget
column3: I'm writing down the sequences in my blog. This is going to be absolutely meaningless for the general public
column4: but if there are others in the class that want to compare notes
column5: this is a handy resource.

column2: bring follow in
clap hands
suzie
column3: suzie

column2: good news and mixed news.
I closed on a condo in Memphis Tennessee. It's a property I found through the infamous Mr. Rosenberg. He's had friends snatching up real estate in a development for the past few years
column3: so it was my turn to get a piece. It's managed by a company that we know and trust
column4: so there's very little to do. And since it's so cheap
column5: I paid all cash for it. I'll get a nice little check every month for it.

column1: I had other good news earlier this week. I saw a building in Park Slope
column2: Brooklyn - before a listing agreement was even signed. It was on the nicest block out of the buildings that I had seen
column3: was in the best condition
column4: and was a 4-unit building instead of the typical 3-unit
column5: and was rented out. The owner needed money to sell it to start building a hotel in Park Slope. It was significantly under-priced
column6: and I jumped on it. Well
column7: as most things that are too good to be true
column8: it had a problem lurking under the surface. Once the lawyer started putting together the contract
column9: we found that it was a "single room occupancy" building - not a 4 family. That's bad. It's very similar to having a rent controlled building. It's hard to get a mortgage for an SRO
column10: and there's no guarantee that you could ever change the certificate of occupancy to a 4-family unit. If you could change it
column11: then the sky's the limit
column12: but it's not a gamble I'm willing to take right now. I decided that if the seller hid this from me when I saw it
column13: that it's a sign to walk away from the deal.

column1: So we're somewhat back to the drawing board. My broker took me to a place in the Fort Greene neighborhood of Brooklyn. We're preparing to put an offer in on it. The first floor is totally renovated and the top two floors are full of students from the Pratt Institute. The rent is good and Fort Greene is a great neighborhood. The students are apparently being difficult about letting prospective buyers into the top two units. Personally
column2: I'm very happy that they're being difficult
column3: because it scares other buyers away and doesn't really worry me all that much.";"1163853720";"textile"

column1: "My cruelty knows no bounds...";"personal/blog/family/my-cruelty-knows-no-bounds";"I posted this photo as an experiment. Does my mother ever visit my site? My hope is that she starts hearing "nice photo" from her brothers and sisters before she finds this. It is a good photo of Lorenz. And just to help her out
column2: I bumped the date up to something more recent.
Mom
column3: and I'll be happy to take it down!

column1: I have a slew of photos from our visit to Springfield that I just discovered. Here's the whole set:
"Resolute";"personal/blog/comic-books/resolute";"I just looked at my blog page. My last entry was November 19th? Yikes!
New Year's has passed and I have made three resolutions for the new year
column2: along with a bunch of minor ones. The big ones are:

column1: And one of the minor ones is: a blog entry a day. So here I am. Part of the "blog entry a day" resolution is understanding that blog entries don't have to be major revelations - just little notes about books read
column2: movies
column3: seen
column4: etc. I think I got myself into a habit that every blog entry had to be a novella. Well - no more!

column3: I am a few pages away from finishing the lettering on my first comic book. It's a horror story with a  title that keeps changing. The current title is "The Four Last Things". The artist did an amazing job. And I've learned a lot by doing the lettering myself. There were times when I changed the dialog to fit both the panels better or to better match the flow and characterization. So once that is done
column4: it's time to send it to publishers. Yikes. I am dreading that.

column1: And I have a second comic book that is being penciled now. The artist is about a third of the way through it. So that one has a ways to go yet. It's more action/comedy and I suspect I'll have an easier time getting it published.

column2: I have a couple of strong leads for more work. I should really set some goals for myself in this category so I can track progress and make changes when things aren't going according to plan.
this is going to be a tough one. I've been lifting weights a lot lately which means the scale has not budged. I've been getting compliments from people about looking better
column3: so I should pay attention to the spirit of resolution #3 and not so much the actual weight. I think a big part of that one
column4: though
column5: is finding more outlets for aerobic activity. I go dancing which is fun and a great way to burn calories
column6: but it's hard to find the time to go enough. We shall see.

column1: What are other people's resolutions for the new year?";"1169045334";"textile"
"Extras";"personal/blog/television/extras";"For those of you that have never heard of it
column2: "Extras" is a TV show produced by HBO (http://www.hbo.com/extras/). It's co-written
column3: co-directed
column4: and starring Ricky Gervais who was the writer
column5: creator
column6: and star of "The Office".

column2: I saw a few episodes of the original UK production of The Office and never really got into it. It had it's moments
column3: but overall it felt to realistically sad and mundane for me. Perhaps I was just spending too much brain power getting past the accents to process the humor. I tried watching the first episode of "Extras" and found it a little funnier
column4: but you really had to pay attention. For some reason
column5: I kept with it. If I didn't really enjoy an episode
column6: I'd wait a while and watch it again in a couple of weeks. It was usually funnier the second time around.

column1: They just started the second season and the season opener was one of the best episodes of a comedy I've ever seen. Not only did it have several "bust a gut" moments
column2: it was oddly sad and touching without being depressing.

column1: They usually feature at least one major star in each episode playing themselves. The first season had Kate Winslet
column2: Ben Stiller
column3: Patrick Stewart and a bunch of UK stars that I didn't recognize. Episode 8 features David Bowie and he is amazingly funny. I had to watch the episode again the next day because I couldn't get it out of my head.

column1: I highly recommend the show. If you don't immediately get into it
column2: give it a few more tries. You have to actually watch it - not have it in the background while you do something else.

column1: "Wedding Photos?!";"personal/blog/celebrations/wedding-photos";"You know how you have those things that you think "I should really do that thing" and you just never get around to it. And eventually that thing reaches some ridiculously late point of completion. And your procrastination almost becomes fascinating to watch. You begin to wonder "will I ever accomplish that task?"
Well...our wedding photos have been sitting in the library for almost 4 years now. We had a set of proofs and all the negatives. For some reason
column2: the black and white proofs were very washed out. The photographer insisted that it was the proofs - not the negatives that were washed out. Anyway
column3: I knew that I wanted to get digital copies of everything
column4: so I had a task on my to-do list for years that said "wedding photos" - meaning that I should scan the proofs and post the photos. I did one page one day and realized that it was going to takes hours and hours of tedious scanning to transfer the proofs to digital copies. I tried all sorts of mantras to motivate myself: "A journey of a thousand miles begins with one step." Nothing worked.

column1: I finally just took the negatives to a photo store and had them transferred to CD. It was expensive
column2: but at least it was done. So I posted the photos to a Flickr set. You can view them here:

column1: "Visits from the Open Source Angels";"business/blog/open-source/visits-open-source-angels";"Some angels visited me in a dream and told me to get off my Microsoft high horse. They told me to go to http://www.rubyonrails.com. I think I may have seen the light. I was getting really tired of the .NET framework being either ridiculously high-level with widgets that made your page look and act like a dorky .NET site or ridiculously low-level where you had to write a bunch of code for pretty standard database/middle-tier transactions. In this day and age
column2: why should developers have to hand-write the code for moving simple form data to and from business objects and then to the database? It was all just seeming really tedious. Ruby on Rails (at first glance) does an excellent job of managing all that tedious code so you can write relatively clear
column3: readable logic.

column1: So after getting excited about open-source web development
column2: that led me down the obvious path of full open source-ness: Linux
column3: mySQL
column4: Ruby on Rails. Or perhaps just go buy a Mac which has Ruby on Rails installed already. I started to investigate Linux about a year ago and when I got to the part of the article that said: "the hardest part is tracking down all the Linux drivers for your computer" - I ran screaming. I know that you can get Ruby on Rails and mySQL on Windows
column5: but I did that for PHP and I get an error on my server every time I have to use it.

column1: I was able to create a Virtual PC and installed Linux (I used Ubuntu)
column2: mySQL
column3: and Ruby on Rails (this article was indispensable: http://www.rubyrailways.com/getting-ruby-on-rails-up-and-running-on-ubuntu-dapper/). I have yet to make a custom project with it
column4: but it was actually not as hard to get going as I thought. I think I may make a dual boot on my machine. My install of windows is feeling really bloated and sluggish lately. If I really do switch development over to RoR
column5: I may consider getting a Mac for my next machine. The Mac OS has RoR installed by default.

column2: but everytime I looked at it
column3: I hated it. It really seems like it's a major step backwards in terms of good development tools
column4: intelligent language
column5: etc. But it turns out that most major interactive web sites are built using PHP these days.

column2: I was seriously considering an Apple for my next machine
column3: when I was cured by reading this article: http://www.russellbeattie.com/notebook/1008631.html.";"1169337500";"textile"

column1: "The Spammers Are Here! The Spammer Are Here!";"personal/blog/spam/spammers-are-here-spammer-are-here";"I occasionally bemoan the fact that my website is not more popular. God knows why. Do I feel like I should be getting the attention of people that I'll never meet? I have fantasies that I'll someday get a comment from someone I don't know - something along the lines of:

column2: but I ran across your blog a few months ago and I've been reading every day since. I just want to let you know that you have one of the most interesting blogs I've ever seen.

column1: The fantasy sort of goes along the lines of a typical New York fantasy
column2: that as you pass by a production team filming a movie
column3: that you hear the director shout "That man over there is PERFECT for our film! Someone get him a script!"

column2: I can say that I'm one step closer to my blog dream: at least the spammers have found me.

column1: I have a plug-in on my blog called Akismet which stops spammers from putting comments in your blog like links to Viagra or cheap loans. For months
column2: not even the spammers bothered with me. But with the new year
column3: I've all of a sudden been discovered by them. Akismet has kept them out
column4: but it's nice to now that I'm gaining some level of popularity.";"1169605479";"textile"

column1: "Gogo the Snorer";"personal/blog/gogo/gogo-snorer";"I never knew that dogs could snore so loudly. I'm in the kitchen watching TV. At one point
column2: the sound got a little soft. Not silent
column3: just soft. I heard the gentle sound of snoring. It was Gogo who was in the other room
column4: underneath the piano
column5: curled up asleep. I thought snoring was just for dogs with shortened snouts - like pugs or bulldogs. I'll have to go wake her up and tell he how cute she is.

column2: we went on a canoing trip with some friends. On the ride back
column3: my friend Jeff was listening to my favorite iPod songs and commented that I would probably enjoy a Brazilian band: Os Mutantes. Later on
column4: he sent me an mp3 file of one of their bigger hits "A Minha Menina". It was psychedelic
column5: pop fun
column6: so I got their "Best of" CD
column7: "Everything is Possible". This launched a huge Os Mutantes obsession for me. They have been my go-to band on my iPod for months now. They even helped me with my fear of flying!

column1: I recommend skipping "Everything is Possible" and going right to the actual CDs. There are fantastic songs that didn't make it to the best-of compilation. And "Everything is Possible" has about a third of each of their first two CDs. It's more fun to go right to the source material.
Start with their first CD "Os Mutantes". You might recognize some of the songs. I had heard "Bat Macumba" before from "The Nuggets" boxed set. And "Baby" rang some far and distant bell
column2: but I couldn't tell you for sure if I had actually heard it before or if it's just one of those songs that feels familiar. There's plenty more on the CD to enjoy. There were certain songs I didn't connect with at first
column3: but then started sounding like pop icons on subsequent listenings.

column1: Next on the list is "A Divina Comédia". This is my current favorite album of theirs. It feels like a concept album
column2: but since I don't speak Portuguese
column3: I can't tell you if there's any cohesion to the lyrics.  I found some sites that translated their lyrics
column4: but they made even less sense in English. This album ends with two great songs that feel like a descent into pop madness. I was listening to this on a very turbulent flight over Spain one day. My fear of the turbulence completely disappeared. I tried listening to this song on other bumpy flights and it still works. There's something about the infectious madness of the music that puts me totally at ease.

column1: I describe Os Mutantes to friends as The Beatles of Brazil. I don't know if that's really apt
column2: but there is something about the psychedelic pop nature of them that feels very similar. And they certainly smoked enough pot...

column1: "Guinea Pigs: A New Comic Book";"guinea-pigs-new-comic-book";"Sitting on my desk
column2: is a completely finished copy of my first comic book: Guinea Pigs. For a while
column3: I changed the title to "The Four Last Things"
column4: but I think there's something fun and weird about "Guinea Pigs"
column5: so I'm keeping it for the time being.

column1: It's a horror story about a group of children that were involved in an experiment at an amusement park many years ago. I won't go into a lot of detail about it here.
So it sits on my desk and I'm trying to work up the nerve to put it into a submission package to send to publishers. For some reason
column2: this is the hard part. Actually
column3: getting the comic book drawn
column4: inked
column5: colored and lettered was easy. I hired people to do the drawing and coloring. I did the lettering myself. Now I'm frozen in anticipation of sending it out. How do I package it for editors? Who should I send it out to? Should I include a box of cookies with the submission? Should I follow it up with phone calls to talk to them about it in depth? It feels like I'm just throwing a note in a bottle into the ocean in the hopes that someone stumbles across it.

column2: while I ponder these questions and tasks
column3: I thought I'd post the first few pages of it. The color got a little washed out when I exported the images to JPG. Try to see past that. Here are the first 6 out of 22 action packed pages!

column2: I bought a copy of Winzip. This is before the days that zipping was built into the Windows OS. Occasionally
column3: I get promotional email from them and I'm too lazy to unsubscribe. Well
column4: I'm glad I haven't
column5: because I got an email from them about a new service.

column2: and they perform online backups of your system. They offer $49 a year for unlimited backup space.

column1: I tried the service for free for 15 days. It took almost all of that time to finish backing up all the files
column2: but now they're there. The install didn't take long. It took me a few minutes of reading instructions to figure out how to tell it what to back up. I kept looking for a dialog within the application to specify what to back up
column3: but it's integrated with Window explorer - so you specify it by browsing files. There's a toolbar icon that tells you if it's idle or if it's actively backing up files.

column1: I've had an external hard drive for performing backups
column2: but that doesn't protect me if the house should burn down (knock on all wood present). I have periodically looked for an online backup solution
column3: but could never find one that was worth the price. However
column4: $49 per year is something I'd happily pay for the peace of mind of having files backed up.";"1171926828";"textile"

column1: "Abs-solutely sore";"personal/blog/exercise/abs-solutely-sore";"A friend of mine has a big event coming up in April and wants to look his best. We often see each other at the gym in the morning
column2: so we decided to work out together to keep us motivated. It's worked out great. However
column3: I'm sore all the time these days. I think I just went a whole week of going to the gym every day. I've had different muscle groups sore every day of the week. I usually go light on a few muscle groups - like back or legs. Having someone else there makes sure that I hit everything equally hard.

column1: And the best part of having a workout partner is having two person abs exercises. I've pulled out a few abs exercises that trainer used to have me do. I find that what I don't like about most abs exercises is that you have to push yourself to get the most out of the time. Having a two-person exercise with someone that's a little mean-spirited and competitive actually makes it easier to do abs.
• The exerciser sits on a decline bench (knees are at the top) and sits up
• The trainer stands behind the person and hands the exerciser a medicine ball on the left side

column2: holding the medicine ball
column3: twists and hands the medicine ball back to the trainer on the right side

column1: • The trainer then hands the ball back to the exerciser on the left side
This one is really good for oblique muscles.  The twisting motion combined with the medicine ball makes it a great workout. Be sure to switch sides on the  next set (right to left).
The other one is really diabolical:
• The exerciser lays down on a mat
• The trainer stands over the exercisers head or chest

column2: keeping legs totally straight throughout the exercise
column3: raises their legs

column1: <li>As soon as the legs are perpendicular to the floor
column2: the trainer pushes the legs out and down forcefully
has to stop their legs from hitting the floor
column3: and so need to use their abs to put on the brakes

column1: <li>As soon as the legs are up again
column2: the trainer pushes them down

column1: It's not so much painful as it is infuriating because it's so easy for the trainer to push the legs down. I guarantee you will be sore the next day from doing these.";"1172078283";"textile"

"Apple: Aggressively Cool";"personal/blog/music/apple-aggressively-cool";"I've been seeing the new iPod commercials a lot lately. The new song is quite catchy. I thought I'd do a search and see who the band is. I'm never surprised when I don't know current bands - I stopped being impressed with popular music a long time ago. I barely ever recognize the music acts on Saturday Night Live anymore.

column2: the band playing in the iPod commercials is "The Fratellis". And get this - their albums aren't even released in the U.S. yet! There's an EP of some of their songs that you can get on iTunes
column3: but if you want the full CD
column4: you have to wait until March. It's a band from Scotland and they've apparently hit it big out there. According to a reviewer on Amazon
column5: all of their songs are ridiculously catchy. I pre-ordered the CD on Amazon.

column1: How aggressively cool is Apple to select a song for their new iPod commercials using a CD that isn't even released in the U.S. yet? It's almost frightening.";"1172328019";"textile"

"Seder at the Adelson / Kloepfer House";"personal/blog/friends/seder-adelson-kloepfer-house";"My photography class got me out of the first night of passover. I made a stunning pistachio macaroon cake for David to take with him (more on that recipe another time).

column2: to be a good goyishe husband
column3: I agreed to go to the second night of passover at our friends' Sara Adelson and Curtis Kloepfer. They have two sons
column4: Jonathan and Joshua. I decided to bring along my new camera. I think I got some good shots in.

column1: I was sitting next to Jonathan. He asked to see the photos and noticed that I had taken a lot of his brother and not many of him. I told him that it's easier to get a shot of Joshua because he sits still. It worked like a charm.

column2: the Wii won out and the kids ended up playing Lego Star Wars instead of finishing the seder.

column1: "Reap What Your Sow";"personal/blog/garden/reap-what-your-sow";"As many of you may know
column2: I keep an herb garden in our backyard. Most of the time
column3: I let the plants do what plants do and just try to make sure they're watered enough. Last year
column4: I lost a few plants with my cavalier attitude to gardening. And my tomato production seemed a little low. This year
column5: I decided to do it right. I bought several seeds
column6: got a seed starting kit
column7: and started growing seeds on the top floor.

column2: they're all growing! This is the first wave. It includes
column3: a lot of basil
column4: tomatoes
column5: peppers
column6: thyme
column7: mint
column8: and parseley. I also have seeds for tomatillos
column9: cilantro
column10: and pumpkin
column11: but they either start later or go directly in the ground. I actually read the instructions on the seed package. Amazing what a difference that made!";"1143132047";"textile"

column1: "A Passage to India";"personal/blog/dreams/passage-india";"I've been having a lot of dreams over the past several months that involve traveling to India. Last night
column2: I had my most vivid dream yet about traveling there. It was broken up into three major sections. Each section was in full color and crystal clear accuracy. I even remember the feeling of touch at some parts of the dream.

column1: The first section centered around buying property in India
column2: although the location was a cross between Mexico and India. I was with Sara and another woman that I did not recognize. She knew Sara
column3: but was more of a local guide. She was going to take us to a building that I was thinking about buying. We walked through a jungle to get there. The guide told us that there were some people that were bitten by the animals in the jungle and died. I suggested that we hurry up and get out of the jungle because it sounded dangerous and I could see the little animals scurrying around our path. Sara stopped to say that she wasn't worried and as she was talking
column4: some thick tree vines came down over her head and started to wrap around her hair
column5: pulling up. I reached over and grabbed the vines (I remember actually touching them) and entwined her hair. She then agreed that it was time to get out of the jungle. We went to go meet the people at the building that I was thinking about buying. They weren't much interested in me and held some resentment because they liked the previous landlord. I wished them well
column6: understood that over time they would appreciate me
column7: and let them be.

column1: The next phase of the dream was clearly in India. I was with my family and we were wandering around. Sis had the guidebook and suggested we go to a park nearby that was somewhat secluded and had a meditation retreat in it. We found the retreat. It was beautiful green park with a terraced landscape. Scattered on the tiers were various people meditating
column2: some were Buddhist monks and some were westerners. At the bottom of the park was a rectangular
column3: stone pool of water about 10 feet deep. Also on the terraces were small clay pots with incense or with red powder. I saw and meditated. Someone in my family got lost and disoriented (it was getting dark and there was a lot of incense smoke and mist from the pool) and wandered into the pool creating a large splash. I came out of the meditation
column4: helped the family member out of the pool and we left.

column1: The next phase of the dream was with David. I believe that we were leaving where we were to go someplace interesting. We got in a car with a driver that we did not know who was going to take us to this place. We started driving through the jungle on a very bumpy and winding path. At some point
column2: I started getting disoriented. It seemed as if the driver was driving without his lights on
column3: but when I looked closely there was a light that we were heading towards. It felt as if we might be traveling through a tunnel of some sort. I was getting worried
column4: but I trusted the driver and decided to relax and let him take us where we needed to go. He took us to his home first
column5: to meet his family
column6: before we went the rest of the way. We was a foreigner that had relocated from a western country. For some reason
column7: David and I thought he was Dutch. He had a small daughter that we met and then his wife. The dream ended shortly after that.";"1143220623";"textile"

column1: "Private: Post #17";"personal/blog/dreams/private-post-17";"Two sets of dreams last night
column2: all around the theme of terrorism. The first dream was set in a high school type setting. Someone was going to blow up a school or office. I vaguely remember thinking that they were trying to get Jason from D&P to set off the bomb
column3: and I felt better knowing that he wouldn't give in to demands. However
column4: they tortured him and he gave in. For some reason it was going to be up to me to set off the bomb. I think Jason was coming after me to force it to go off. I felt better knowing that I was in control and that there was nothing that Jason could do to force me to set off the bomb.

column1: The second dream was a bit more military. At one point
column2: I was in a video game like setting and trying to figure out how to defeat this tought guy in hand-to-hand combat. I had a small cell phone device that could throw blows or spells at him. I think he morphed into my teacher at one point and the dream finished with me being a disciple of his. Me and several others were going to be in some sort of performance
column3: but everyone was concerned that we were going to be attacked by terrorists. Once again
column4: it was going to be up to me to diffuse the situation and I was confident that I would take care of it.";"1143547019";"textile"

column1: "You know it’s spring when…";"personal/blog/celebrities/you-know-it-s-spring-when";"I'm seeing the real signs of spring in New York. It's not tulips on the sidewalks. It's not birds chirping in the air (although we have some really vocal ones in our backyard this year). It's movie crews. I always forget every year how much filming goes on in New York in the spring and summer. I've perfected my look of disdain when some overly pierced intern with a clipboard asks me if I could please walk on the other side of the street so as not to disrupt the shot.
I never see the actual stars
column2: either. I tend to think a lot of the filming is for commercials or music videos. Either that
column3: or the celebrities hide in their mobile home and only come out for the 10 seconds that they're needed.

column2: I saw Sarah Jessica Parker on the street the other day. She blended in with New York quite well. Many celebrities try so hard to not be noticed that they call attention to themselves. She seemed nonchalant. Didn't wear a hat.";"1143658199";"textile"

column1: "Private: Back to School";"personal/blog/dreams/private-back-school";"I had a dream last night that I had to go back to Knox because I never technically finished my last year. God I hate those dreams. I've had them frequently the past year or so. Last night
column2: I remember attending some sort of farewell dinner with everyone in New York. I usually spend the dream thinking if I'm going to audition for a theater production again or if I'm  going to do my own thing.

the dream reflects how uncomfortable I was to go back to Knox a year after everyone else had graduated. It also brings up issues of feeling like things are out of my control - that there is some mistake in my past that I have yet to resolve. I spend most of the dream thinking about how I'm going to survive without David
column3: Oz
column4: and Gogo and all my friends.";"1144006223";"textile"

column1: "The Road to Nirvana";"personal/blog/buddhism/road-nirvana";"Those of you in the know have heard that I've been shopping religions. I think it all goes back to when I read Life of Pi by Yann Martel. The first quarter of the book talks about the main character as a boy in India getting equally excited about Hinduism
column2: Christianity
column3: and Islam. I realized that I don't know that much about religions outside of Christianity and Judaism. I tried a few "Introducing..." books to get to know some of the basics of Islam and Hinduism. Although Introducing Islam was good
column4: I was still totally lost after reading Introducing Hinudism. I bought a Qur'an to read
column5: but the real thing proved extremely dry and dense - sort of like reading the Bible!

column1: Then I saw Lama Surya Das on The Colbert Report and thought that I should give Buddhism another try. I had dismissed Buddhism because I read some Buddhist books by Chögyam Trungpa and decided that it was just too intense - thoughts like "life is emptiness" and "reaching Nirvana through boredom" turned me off for some reason. I gave Buddhism another try and had a similar experience for different reasons. This time
column2: I read Awakening the Buddha Within : Tibetan Wisdom for the Western World by Lama Surya Das. At first
column3: I was really connecting to the book and finding it incredibly transformative. Eventually
column4: I started getting really down on myself. I started seeing just how far I have to go to resemble anything Buddha-like. I hit a chapter that was talking about not talking about other people when they aren't present - even if it's good! That whole week I noticed just how gossipy I was and not particularly interested in changing. Subsequently
column5: everything I read started feeling like an unattainable goal and more excuses to beat myself up.

column1: I met with a former co-worker
column2: Uma Natarajan
column3: who said that many people (herself being one) consider that there are only three major religious texts in the world: The Bible
column4: The Qur'an
column5: and The Bhagavad Gita (Hinduism). I believe she was making the point that Buddha was raised a Hindu and reached enlightenment in India
column6: so he's really a subset of Hinduism. (I suppose this is the same thinking that middle-eastern terrorists employ when they lump Christianity and Judaism as essentially the same thing. When Uma reads this
column7: I'm sure she'll chastise me for missing the point of what she was saying.) Anyway
column8: I took her larger concept of the Bhagavad Gita as a major religious text
column9: so I put Buddha on hold and started reading it. It's fantastic
column10: but you can only read it a page at a time. It's incredibly dense - like a religious version of desne chocolate cake. You have to savor each bite before you can move on to the next piece.

column2: I went back to reading the Lama Surya Das book. I noticed that my life had changed since reading it and that I shouldn't feel discouraged from feeling so far away from Buddha. For one
column3: I had started being far more communicative
column4: complimentary
column5: and optimistic with other people (not a small feat living in New York City!). I never noticed that I didn't ever look people in the eye before. Now
column6: I say hello
column7: smile
column8: and ask them how their day is - with sincerity. It's incredible to see people in New York perk up just a little bit. The barrier of "Us vs. Them" that most New Yorkers walk around in dissolves. I've become far more tolerant of other people. A lot of my judgement has washed away. My thoughts directed towards myself have been much more encouraging instead of just rants or internal criticisms.

column1: So I guess I'm on a dual path right now - read a little Bhagavad Gita
column2: read a little Lama Surya Das. The real test
column3: I think
column4: will come when looking for a community or sacred place to visit.";"1145357361";"textile"

column1: "Private: Notes for issue #1 revision";"creative/private-notes-issue-1-revision";"The goal is to make this sell-able or pitch-able. Therefore
column2: ew need to stop stepping around the edges of things. Don't let things unfold slowly
column3: bang it into place. The goal of any good horror movie is to show that the interactions of the characters is the true horror.

column1: • Start and end it with Dr. Lamont watching outside of the NYU building. We have to know that this is a controlled experiment from the very beginning.
<li>Possibly show the drug deal to Peter's friend at some point. Perhaps at the beginning
column2: perhaps at the very end.

column1: <li>When Joe tries to warn Amy that a monster is in the building
column2: they try to escape out the window. Dr. Lamont sees the unfortunate result of that from the outside.

column1: • Forget Officer Bradley as a major character. He's gone after the first episode.
• Let Dr. Lamont explain what went on with the experiments. Let him spill all the beans.

So that leaves the second issue as a little dry. We see more of Dr. Lamont with Audrey. There has to be a watcher. Perhaps Peter sees the watcher from the balcony. The issue ends with the watcher telling Dr. Lamont that the second one has been a success.";"1145557455";"textile"

column2: Gogo has floating patellas - which means that her knee caps don't stay where they should. We had one of the knees fixed last September. The recovery was pretty bad (she just laid there and cried the saddest sound in the world for the first two days)
column3: but she moved much better afterwards. Well
column4: the other knee started showing signs of problems and her movement started to go down again
column5: so we scheduled to have the other knee done. I took a picture of her inncoently sleeping this morning
column6: unaware that she was scheudled to go in for surgery.

column1: She woke up soon after the camera flash started going off and was a little ticked off about it.
She didn't seem too bothered once we got her leash and took her out. And even at the Animal Hospital
column2: she wasn't freaking out like I thought she would be. She did poop as soon as we walked into the hospital
column3: but that was more my fault for not giving her enough time out on the street.

column1: So now I'm at home and Oz and I are whimpering until Gogo gets home. I think Oz is more traumatized than I am by the absence of Gogo. I keep trying to focus on the fact that this will be over soon and she'll be able to run and play more without pain. It's hard to see the forest for the trees right now
column2: though.";"1146145463";"textile"

column1: "Private: Being Accepted and Loved";"creative/private-being-accepted-and-loved";"I was reading a review of "Bulgarian Lovers" and the reviewer pointed out that pretty much every gay movie has the same basic theme of "wanting to be accepted". I think I would extend that to "accepted and loved". So I thought about writing an anti-play around that theme. How do you push that so that it doesn't make sense anymore? Maybe not everyone should be accepted and loved? Maybe we should have some sort of discerning tastes?

And then it occured to me that that is what I'm really trying to write with The Cock Cage. You can't accept everything. You can maybe love everything. And when you through yourself into a situation of accepting everything
column2: perhaps you throw yourself in too deep.
I was attending a reading of "An Uncertain Hour" and started brainstorming allusions. San Francisco
column3: the city by the bay
column4: drenched in fog. Where are its literary parallels? I thought perhaps The Old Man and the Sea or Moby Dick. God
column5: I'd hate to have to read Moby Dick. Perhaps a better analogy is The Flying Dutchman. Yes
column6: the leather master is from Amsterdam. He's the one looking for his mate.

column2: the Flying Dutchman is a ghost ship that can never go home
column3: but must sail 'the seven seas' forever.

column1: This goes along with my notion that San Francisco is not home.

Bernard Fokke was a 17th century Dutch captain for the Dutch East India Company. He was renowned for the uncanny speed of his trips from Holland to Java. This caused speculation that he was in fact in league with the devil because of it.
This also caused many people to believe that he was the captain of the Flying Dutchman
column2: a ghostly ship doomed to sail the seas forever.

column1: "Gogo’s Recovery";"personal/blog/gogo/gogo-s-recovery";"We're on the fourth day after Gogo's surgery and doing well. When I picked her up
column2: she was hobbling on three legs quite well. When we came into the waiting area of the animal hospital
column3: she was wearing a cone
column4: had her complete lower right side shaved
column5: and was hobbling on three legs desperate to get out of the hospital. She got a universal "awwww..." from the waiting area.

column2: there were times that she had a wide eyed terror look in her face that I assume was the last of the drugs wearing off. There were times when she would simply whine about nothing in particular. The first night of sleep was fitfull and we had to get up every few hours. I think she was mainly feeling pain and the effects of the opiates. Despite all of that
column3: she was much much better this time around for the surgery. She was able to go to the bathroom outside without any help. Last time
column4: she stumbled and fell over and couldn't figure out how to move. She drank water right away this time and she has the typically abundant Gogo appetite.

column2: I completed underestimated how much work it was to care for her in recovery. Although Oz has been very respectful of her state and never leaves her alone
column3: he still wants his walks. And I underestimated how hard it would be to leave Gogo alone. I called Rodrigo
column4: our dog walker and general helper
column5: and asked if he had any time to walk Oz over the weekend. He helped out tremendously.

column1: The second night of sleep went much better and Gogo didn't make much of a fuss at all. In fact I think I woke up before any of the dogs which is a rarity - believe me!
I did leave them alone for a few hours on Sunday afternoon. Gogo didn't seem too bothered by wearing the cone. Rodrigo said that she was asleep when he showed up.
This morning I noticed that Gogo's "hospital grittiness" had disappeared. When I picked her up
column2: she had a lot of dandruff where she still had hair and just seemed to feel sort of gritty. This morning her coat is feeling strong and smooth again. I assume it's a combination of being allowed to sleep in the sun and getting her omega oil supplements.

column1: I think the big challenge on this recovery will not be helping her through the pain and disorientation
column2: but trying to slow down her recovery. Now that she's more awake and aware
column3: I can see her little devious mind trying to figure out how to get the staples out
column4: how to lick wounds without getting caught
column5: how to jump up on the furniture
column6: etc.";"1146484036";"textile"

column1: "One of the Joys of Adulthood";"personal/blog/piano/one-joys-adulthood";"I've been taking piano lessons this year. It's one of the skills I always wished I had. Also
column2: I used to plink around on the piano all through high school and college writing music. I miss it
column3: but this time I'm going to learn to play correctly in the hopes that I can write something more than just chords and a melody.

column2: I have run across one of the great joys of adulthood. When I was a kid
column3: I always felt bad about not practicing enough (well
column4: not bad enough to actually practice). As I got older
column5: I got to see that the kids that practiced a lot were significantly better musicians
column6: so I practiced maybe a little more than when I first started - but still not really "enough". Now that I'm an adult
column7: I realize that I don't have to feel bad when I don't practice! It's my responsibility! No teacher is going to give me a bad grade
column8: no parent is going to scowl
column9: my instructor doesn't even really get that upset (I think because he has other clients that almost never practice). What's the result of my not practicing? I'm not as good at doing the thing that I chose to do.

column2: I practice every day and enjoy it. However
column3: there are times when I don't practice because I've been too busy or travelling. I relish the freedom I feel at knowing that there's no one around to admonish me. It's one of the times that I can suddenly appreciate being a responsible adult. And sure enough
column4: I get back to practicing when my schedule frees up.";"1146575836";"textile"

column2: David and I went to the Mount Sinai Crystal Ball. It's the hospital's annual really big fundraiser. I have to admit that I don't usual look forward to going. I had been to two already
column3: and they are usually kind of fun but largely dull. It's very dependent on who you sit next to.

column1: This year's I was having a slightly better than usual year. I saw next to my David and David Nudo. We were having a good time and I remained entertained while David went to press the flesh. During dinner
column2: David was sitting next to me
column3: so we got some visits from his colleagues - one of whom is the vice president in charge of public relations. She mentioned that Martha Stewart was there and David suggested we go meet her. So before I could say anything
column4: we got up to visit Martha's table.

column1: I sort of imagined that we would get within viewing distance and say "Yep. That's her. Cool." I also thought that if we got introduced
column2: she would say hello and go back to hanging out with her group. What I did not expect was a full introduction and a few minutes of discussion. When we were introduced
column3: she smiled
column4: stood up from the table
column5: and started talking to us. She asked me what I did and I told her that I was an aspiring comic book writer and told her that she is the inspiration for a comic book that I'm working on. David added
column6: "Don't worry. It's tasteful." And laughingly she replied with "It doesn't bother me if it is or if it isn't."

column1: We chatted for a few minutes. She was extremely cordial and personable. And she looked very good for her age. Someone should get the number of her plastic surgeon.

There was a bit of star-struck in my eyes. A big part of me hopes that this is a good omen in terms of my comic book. I thought of the people that would hold out screenplays or novels for the Pope to touch in hopes of getting a blessing. So let's hope that some of that Martha Stewart magic rubs off into Betsy Stevens and the Domestic Godesses.";"1146852462";"textile"

column2: but after South Park did an episode featuring "The Dog Whisperer"
column3: I dediced to watch the show. I've been hooked ever since. For those of you that haven't heard of the show
column4: it's on the National Geographic Channel. You can also go to Cesar Millan's website: http://www.dogpsychologycenter.com/.

column1: I started using his tactics at home on Oz and Gogo. I have to admit
column2: they've worked very well. When they decided that they didn't want to behave
column3: I used to give them a very loud and aggressive "HEY" to get them to pay attention. It worked
column4: but I really didn't like looking that out of control on the street. So I switched to Cesar's "PSST" which I don't have to do as loudly for them to react to. And I taught them that by doing a gentle but quick hand-claw on the their throat while I made the sound. The first time I did it to Gogo
column5: she threw her ears back in shock and stared at me in disbelief. I only had to do it twice with her. She now knows that "PSST" means business. Gogo no longer waits forever on our front steps before coming down for a walk. Whenever she stubbornly pulls towards a doggie store
column6: I give her a "PSST" and she gives up. Oz has been a little slower about picking up a reaction to "PSST"
