column7: but it still works wonders. He's much better on walks.

column1: I've also been able to significantly cut down on their dog aggression on walks. For a while
column2: it was getting pretty bad. I was crossing the street whenever I saw a nother dog coming because i knew they were going to lunge and snarl at another dog. I changed my behavior so that if another dog is coming up to us
column3: I put both Gogo and Oz behind me and make sure I stay in between them and the strange dog. Their aggression is almost none existent when I do that. I've now let them say hello to other dogs and I carefully watch Gogo (since she's usually the instigator of dog aggression). If Gogo starts to growl at the new dog
column4: I give her a "PSST" and move her behind me. It's worked wonders.

column1: I just read the following link: <a target="_blank" title="http://www.newsday.com/features/printedition/ny-etlede4743494may17
column3: 1617948.story?coll=ny-features-print" href="http://www.newsday.com/features/printedition/ny-etlede4743494may17
column5: 1617948.story?coll=ny-features-print">http://www.newsday.com/features/printedition/ny-etlede4743494may17
column7: 1617948.story?coll=ny-features-print. I guess it's not surprising that everyone wants to sue Cesar Millan or talk about how he's "set dog training back to the middle ages". There are too many people in this world that only know how to take aim at other people rather than create success for themselves. Positive reinforcement works for training tricks
column8: but there are some behavior elements that just cannot be addressed with positive reinforcement. We've given Gogo a lot of positive reinforcement
column9: and she often uses it to walk all over us.

column1: It's also a shame that people have reduced Cesar Millan's tactics to "being abusive to your dog to get it to pay attention". There's nothing in his show about being cruel or physically abusive. When I went to do the "hand-claw on the neck" with Oz and Gogo
column2: I barely applied pressure. They understood what I was doing without me having to be physically harmful.
thank God the South Park guys gave Cesar some room in the spotlight to Cesar.";"1148073918";"textile"

column1: "McKee Transformations";"personal/blog/writing/mckee-transformations";"I recently took a seminar with screenwriting professor extraordinaire
column2: Robert McKee. The seminar was a weekend long about four different film genres: Horror
column3: Thriller
column4: Comedy
column5: and Masterpiece. I signed up for two days: Horror and Comedy. The horror day was for a comic book script that I had written that always got a somewhat lackluster response and the comic day was for a play that I'm about to start work on.

column1: I'm not going to go into a huge amount of detail about the class and McKee as a teacher other than to say that it has really transformed how I think about writing dramatic material. I went back and re-read his book
column2: Story.  I have since changed how I go about writing.
I thought I could get away with a few edits to my horror comic book
column3: but leave most of the whole thing in place. However
column4: as I started to notice scenes that didn't work and have an understanding of why they didn't work
column5: I realized that I had to start over with an outline. Then
column6: as I went through the outline
column7: I realized that my problem ran deeper than just the outline
column8: it was the scene structure. Then as I started to write out more detailed scene information
column9: I realized that I needed to start over with the characters. In the end
column10: I gutted everything and started over. I created a Word document along the lines of McKee's "things to watch out for" as I put together the scenes.

column1: I created some character maps in Microsoft Visio to show who the characters are
column2: what their dimensions are
column3: and how they play against each other. (However
column4: I re-read McKee's section of characters this morning and realized that I need to revisit the character map to make it clearer.) Then I went through each scene in the story of the first issue. For each scene
column5: I had the following information:

column1: • Who is the protagonist of the scene? What do they want in this scene?
• Who or what is the antagonist? What's stopping the protagonist?
<li>What is the subtext of the scene? In other words
column2: what are the characters trying to communicate to each other without actually saying it? For instance "I'm smarter than you" or "I don't feel safe around you".

column1: • What's the progression of values in the scene? Does the protagonist get closer to their goal or farther away?
There were often modifications to characters as I went through this
column2: because I would discover a character that had no real motivation. I had left them completely static and therefore uninteresting. Either that or their motivations were so generic as to be a non-entity. Once I gave them real motivations
column3: they started becoming real people.

column1: I also noticed as I was putting together progression of values that sometimes the scene didn't move forward at all. I would think that I had a nice scene
column2: would get to the progression of values and notice that nothing changed. The protagonist of the scene didn't get any closer or further away from their goal. All of a sudden
column3: I would mentally snap out of my writer's mind and approach it from the mind of a generic reader and I would see the scene as dull. This usually meant that I would go back and modify the character a bit throughout the story so that the scene in questions could be interesting; or it meant that the scene got cut as unnecessary.

column1: I found huge scenes that were dull and lifeless as pure exposition that could easily be made dramatic. Since I had a solid character map that told me what made the character tick
column2: I could easily add a force to an expository scene to make that scene dramatic.

column1: Most of the changes were very subtle but will hopefully add to a much more compelling issue. I have not written any dialogue yet
column2: but I can already see that the dialog will largely write itself. If I'm particularly uninspired
column3: I have enough notes in the scene breakdowns that I can write the dialogue without any need for creativity (that sounds bad
column4: but it's true!).

column1: I should also point out that this was excruciating at first. I hope that this gets easier over time. I've been spending the past week looking at other things that I do well
column2: and there is always this "outlining" approach. Especially when writing code
column3: I often write all of the function calls first
column4: so that the structure of the code is in place before I write the working code.";"1148649807";"textile"

column2: pt. 2";"personal/blog/writing/mckee-transformations-pt-2";"Okay. So I had the McKee seminar
column3: re-read his book
column4: and found myself full of great ideas
column5: renewed spirit
column6: and totally unable to write.

column1: I was completely weighed down by all these various thoughts that my writing was coming out forced and awkward. I talked to my coach
column2: Kevin Creedon
column3: about it and we went back to the drawing board about writing.

column2: I was going to try not writing from beginning to end. Instead
column3: I was going to work more or less backwards
column4: or at least write the passages that I "knew" in my gut first and then would flesh out from there. (I used to write like that all the time and somehow got in the habit of writing start ot finish when I took a comic book class).

column2: I was going to write scenes/character actions on index cards and arrange them in a way that helped communicate the story to me. (I had been doing this on the computer
column3: but there's something about printing something out and re-arranging it that is much more clear than typing it into an outline on screen.) I went to Staples and got a package of Avery business cards (since there are more per page) and types up very brief character actions on the cards. I spread all the cards on the kitchen table and starting re-arranging things. I realized that I had left out some important elements. And it really helped to see how each character action had to lead into the next.

column2: which I have yet to do
column3: is break the witing into a series of "passes". There will be NO EDITING on the first round. Whatever is typed stays there. Then I will come up with a series of editing passes. For instance
column4: perhaps the first pass
column5: I will focus on more robust panel descriptions. Perhaps the second pass will focus on communicating subtext. I'll come up with a series of passes and then I will change the order of passes as I work through each page of the script. The point is to experiment to find the correct order of editing passes that works best for me.

column1: I'm about 1/3 of the way through the first draft of the new script
column2: and already I feel things going much better. The "bones" of the script feels like it's in place. I can see the flow of character and action in a way that wasn't there before
column3: and I'm focusing on the essentials of the script and not getting side-tracked with clever
column4: but unnecessary nuances.

column1: The thing that was kind of bugging me was the fact that I didn't have any room to spread out my business cards of character actions. So I went back to Staples and got cork wall tiles. I've attached them to the back of my office door.
On the right side of the door
column2: you can see the little business cards that map out the story for issue one. You will also see a color drawing on the left side of the door. That's a little technique Kevin taught me for keeping motivated on another script. Each time I work on it
column3: I add another line to the "puzzle". My brain gets a little adrenaline rush at completing the puzzle and ensures that I keep working on the script to finish the puzzle.

column1: This photo makes it look like the cork job wasn't very good. Damn this expensive camera! In reality
column2: the tiles look very even.
my white board which has my weekly schedule.
my home office is really taking shape. It's like a little creative coccoon.";"1149470468";"textile"

column1: "The New Piano Teacher";"personal/blog/piano/new-piano-teacher";"One of my New Year's resolutions this year was to learn piano. I started with someone that I had found on craiglist. It started off well. However
column2: I felt like I outgrew him rather quickly. All of the pieces that he picked were frenetic finger exercises and I often grew bored of the pieces. One of the first pieces that he had given me was a Back minuet. I liked the piece
column3: and got the fingering down realtively quickly. However
column4: the more I practiced it
column5: the less like music it sounded. It kept sounding more and more plodding
column6: forced
column7: and "scale-like". I asked him a couple times and he always said that it sounded uneven and would make me practice with the metronome more.

column2: the lessons were extremely critical. I would play a measure or two and he would provide constant on-going criticism like "3rd finger on the D"
column3: "that wasn't staccato enough"
column4: "you didn't hold that note long enough"
column5: etc. No surprise - I eventually started to dread piano lessons. David has noticed an improvement in my playing
column6: but I felt more like I was learning fingering exercises rather than learnign to play piano. I picked up some music from books that we had in the house and the thought of playing something other than what he was teaching was daunting to say the least. He wrote out all of my fingering
column7: so how was I supposed to figure out which fingers to use?

column1: There was one day in particular that he was hyper critical. I had arrived already quite proud of the progress I had made on a piece. Considering that I couldn't play any of it the week before and I had put it together in a week's time
column2: I was excited to show off. He started in with the constant criticism and I started playing worse and worse. I felt terrible by the end of the lesson. I decided to give him a couple more weeks and see if that was just a fluke week for him. Really
column3: though
column4: after that lessons my heart just wasn't in it anymore.

column1: I had been talking with a former co-worker
column2: Joy Ellen Snellgrove
column3: about piano teachers. I told her stories about my current teacher and she suggested that I contact her former teacher (she had moved to Boston) Robert Cowie (http://www.robertcowie.com/). She told me a bit about the technique that he uses
column4: but it didn't really sink in until our first lesson. She described the approach as thus: You're learning a new piece. Most people teach that you should slow a piece down to a point that you can play it and then try to bring it up to speed. The problem with that is that you don't really understand the piece at the point in which you learn to play the notes. You really only learn "technical proficiency"
column5: but you don't really understand the piece much because you're playing a much slower version - and usually ignoring the musicality of the piece. Instead
column6: start by just playing the down-beat notes. When you can do that
column7: add in the notes at the quarter beat
column8: etc.

column2: I ran this around in my head and went to my first lesson. First of all
column3: I have since realized how much bad programming I had been under from my old teacher. I was constantly saying "sorry" as I would mess up notes. I was hitting the keys very hard (he insisted that if you play a new piece forcefully
column4: it will get in your muscle memory better). And overall
column5: I was just very down on myself about my piano playing.

column1: The new teacher has been trying to break that down. I've had several lectures about not being so hard on myself about my playing. Some general statements have been: "There are people dying in Iraq. They are suffering. You are not." At one point
column2: I could not get my fingers to do something I wanted them to do. I was getting extremely frustrated and he actually burst out laughing at me.
there's the teaching technique. We started with the Bach minuet that I said never sounded like music to me. We started off playing just the down-beat notes. Mentally
column3: I was trying to play all the music in my head and just press the keys on the downbeats. He said it doesn't work that way. I had to play the notes as if they were the only notes written. With some repetition
column4: I could hear what those notes were doing and it started sounding like music. Then we added just the quarter beat notes in the right hand. Once again
column5: I had to start hearing the notes lead from one to the next. (I'm making this sound easy
column6: but if you've never looked at a full page of music and tried to isolate out just a few notes
column7: it's quite hard.) Eventually
column8: I started adding in more of the notes. At each point
column9: I played as if it was a completed piece.

column1: At the end of the first week
column2: David heard me practicing and said that it was the first time my practicing sounded like music rather than fingering exercises.

column1: Now that I've had the introduction
column2: he's started throwing more variations. Some of them are:

column1: • Playing the bass clef in both the right and left hand
• Playing the treble clef in both the right and left hand
• Playing the bass clef with the right hand and the treble clef with the left hand
• Clumbing notes together as chord instead of runs of notes
• Playing only one hand a half-step up
They are all very bizarre exercises. I never really understand what's going on when I do the exercises
column2: but when I go back and play the piece normally
column3: it's like a brand new piece. The music comes pouring out. I've never experienced anything like it.

column1: That's all well and good for a piece that I already knew
column2: but I really wanted to see how it would work with a piece I didn't know. I went to a music store and got a book of Harold Arlen songs and picked out a piece that didn't look to demanding: "This Time the Dream's On Me". It's very slow going
column3: but the piece is coming together. We started off just playing down-beats. Even though you're playing a small fraction of the song
column4: you still hear the progression of music. Then I added in quarter-note beats
column5: etc. I can play just the melody and bass clef right now and if you didn't know that I was omitting the harmonies
column6: you would think I was playing the whole thing. It's pretty amazing after just two lessons.

column1: So the piano has really come to life for me. I no longer have the feeling that it will be at least 4 years of arduous torture before I'll be able to enjoy playing piano.";"1149526557";"textile"

"The Piano is Blowing My Mind";"personal/blog/piano/piano-blowing-my-mind";"Just had lesson #3 from Robert Cowie yesterday. The lesson hit me as particularly profound. We did a lot of the same types of exercises that we had done before
column2: playing clumps of notes together
column3: transposing up a half step
column4: outlining phrases. But this week the general theme of the lesson was playing with your ear
column5: not your mind.

column1: I suppose a lot of my attitude towards the piano comes from being raised with a wind instrument. Especially with a trombone
column2: you spend most of your mental energy listening to what you're playing in relationship with everyone else. So much so
column3: that I found it extremely frustrating to play the trombone. (Plus
column4: I never got the hang of the "PPHHHTT" thing of playing a brass instrument.) Saxophone was a bit easier
column5: but still
column6: you could bend notes with your mouth
column7: so you had to be aware of what you were playing in relation to everyone else to stay in tune. With a piano
column8: there's no question as to whether you're in tune or not. And if you are out of tune
column9: you can't fix it as you play.

column1: I always thought that I had to "calculate" where my fingers were supposed to go. Many of the exercises that we did focused on playing with your ear rather than with your mind. THe big shift in my head would come would I stop trying to calculate wher my fingers were supposed to go on what beat and just play with my ears - trust that my musical brain was going to put the fingers where they were suppsoed to go and if they didn't
column2: let themselves correct. It's a very bizarre experience because I feel as if I'm letting a part of my head do the work that I'm not consciously aware of.

column1: The other big lesson that he gave is that the goal is to play the whole piece free and easy. Therefore
column2: I have to learn the piece free and easy. I can't practice the piece tense
column3: frustrated
column4: and calculating and expect that at some later point I'll be able to drop the tension
column5: frustration and calculation. So the process is to break the learning of the piece into segments that always feel free and easy. To always practice in the mannerin which I want to be able to play it someday.

column1: Ah-hah. A lot to process. It's been just over 24 hours since the lessons and there's been a dramatic improvment in my playing and my enjoyment of my playing. THe Bach minuet that has been haunting me is like a whole new piece. I t completely opened up to me this afternoon.";"1149798312";"textile"
"Private: Writing Tests";"creative/private-writing-tests";"I'm working on an exercise to better understand the various editorial passes one takes on a script. Let's put them down in two categories:
I can easily identify elements of the second one:
The first one's a little harder. It's based on good content.
• Desperation - are characters truly going for what they want?

"The Cruelest Daddy in the World";"personal/blog/gogo/cruelest-daddy-world";"It's been about 8 weeks now since Gogo had surgery for her floating patella. About three times over the course of her recovery
column2: someone suggested I consider getting hydrotherapy for her. We live just 5 blocks from a canine hydrotherapy place in the city (http://www.thedogrun-nyc.com/)
column3: so I took it as a sign from God that Gogo should have hydrotherapy.

column1: I had been resisting because I know how much Gogo hates water. She doesn't like going out in the rain
column2: she doesn't like going out when it's still from having rained recently
column3: she doesn't like walking on a sidewalk that's been recently hosed down. I couldn't imagine anything crueler than to make Gogo have knee surgery and then make her swim during her recovery. But so be it
column4: it would be for her own good
column5: and that's part of being a good parent
column6: right?

column1: We went for our first session this past week. I asked the girl at the front if they're okay with dogs that despise water and she said that the therapists get the dogs acclimated in about 5 minutes. I have been watching "The Dog Whisperer"
column2: so I can believe in canine behavior miracles.

I put Oz in the bedroom by himself and took Gogo for a walk. She was ecstatic to be walking with just the two of us. She would often look up at me with a huge smile to say "I'm so glad we're rid of that other one!" As soon as I walked up to the door of the hydrotherapy place
column3: she started pulling to go home. I don't know what she was reacting to
column4: it could have been the fact that she knew it was a day care place from the smell
column5: or she could smell the water
column6: or any number of things. We went in and I sat down on a bench next to the pool while Gogo growled at the other dogs (there were about 20 other dogs there for daycare - none of them swimming). I got to see the therapist with another dog before our appointment. It happily and lazily paddled in the water with not a care in the world.

column1: We got "John" for the first session. I've since talked to dog store owners in the neighborhood and they all seem to know John or at least have heard of him. John's process of getting Gogo acclimated to water was to pick her up (she ran from him)
column2: and take her in the pool and let go. Gogo absolutely panicked. She paddled furiously towards me. She struggled to keep her head up. John grabbed her waist so that she couldn't make any progress but had to continue swimming to stay afloat. Here are some pictures:

column1: She kept paddling with no end in sight. She kept staring up at me with pleading and terror-stricken eyes. Every five minutes
column2: he would lift up her torso so that she could pant and catch her breath. He also stretched out her hind legs at the same time. After a short break
column3: it was back in the water for more swimming. Time has never felt like it crawled along at a slower pace.

column1: I have to admit that I wanted to leave. I didn't want to be witness to Gogo clearly having a horrible time. I smiled and encouraged her and tried to let her know that this was all perfectly normal. (Somewhere in the back of my mind
column2: I have memories of mother doing the same to me
column3: but I must have done a good job repressing them because none spring to mind immediately)

column1: I noticed at the beginning that Gogo was not really using her hind legs. She would move them only an inch or two. I think that's part of the reason he was stretching out her hind legs during swimming. Sure enough
column2: by the end of the session
column3: she was using more of her back legs (though still not normal). And she eventually got used to swimming. I wouldn't say she enjoyed it
column4: but she at least looked calmer:

column1: We went two days later and had a different therapist. This one was a female. Gogo was happier because this meant that she was much more manipulable. Gogo spent much more time in "recovery" mode - a.k.a. being held in the arms of the therapist. She twice pretended that she was getting used to swimming by swimming circles around the therapist. The therapist would praise Gogo for her good swimming
column2: Gogo would gradually increase the distance between her and the therapist
column3: and would then bolt for the stairs to leave the pool.

column1: I'm hoping to see a big change in another couple of weeks. Hoestly
column2: it seems like she was walking a little straighter after the first session
column3: so I'm pretty hopeful. They say that only about 1% of the dogs never quite enjoy swimming. I'm pretty sure Gogo is one of those
column4: but I'm willing to suspend disbelief.";"1150494673";"textile"

column2: I decided to take Oz with me to Gogo's swim therapy. He paced aorund the edge of the pool the whole time. Then at one point
column3: he got crowded by dogs and decided to jump on in. Boy was that a mistake. He splashed around in a panic and tried to climb out the wrong end. He soon realized that he was trapped and couldn't get out. The therapist and I eventually led him over to the edge with the steps and he made it out. He kept trying to shake water out of his ears and sneezed for about 10 minutes.

column1: "Some Bad News";"personal/blog/gogo/some-bad-news";"I took Gogo to the vet that did her knee surgery today. He said that the second surgery was not fully successful and that her patella is still luxating. Ugh. That means he'll have to take her for another surgery and another recovery period. Ugh.
I was so extremely saddened to hear that news. On the trip to the vet I kept saying to Gogo that all the surgery is done
column2: this is the last trip - just to make sure you're okay. Luckily
column3: she doesn't understand English.

column1: After they told me the news
column2: they kept her for x-rays. I walked around the block a few times and called David and then Sis. A big part of me kept saying that I didn't have the strength to put her through this again. Having to get her up at 6am and take her to the animal hospital and leave her there for a couple of days and then trying to get her home and getting her to relax and sleep. It all seemed like a daunting task for which I had not reserved the emotional strength. I took some deep breaths and reminded myself that I shouldn't wish for life to change or for me to change - I should wish for better tools to deal with the things life throws at you. Anyway
column3: it's not the end of the world - it's just one more surgery and hoepfully that will be the end of it.

column1: I felt guilty about taking Gogo out to Fire Island for a week. I thought about having her surgery before we go. But no scenario made sense. I certainly didn't want to skip Fire Island and kiss $2000 goodbye. The doctor was encouraging. He said to let her go to Fire Island
column2: run around
column3: have a good time
column4: and then try to have it done soon after getting back.

column1: I also felt bad that I didn't bring her in for a check-up sooner. I kept thinking that if we had caught it sooner
column2: we wouldn't have wasted all those weeks of recovery.

column1: That means the first week of recovery will be when Sis and Lorenz are here
column2: so we'll have lots to distract ourselves
column3: and lots of excuses to hang out at home with Lorenz and the pups.";"1152910287";"textile"

column2: Oz
column3: and I are in day 4 of our week out on the island.

column1: David and Rodrigo joined us on the first night and day
column2: then our friends Kevin and Jeff came for the next two days. I really appreciated the company
column3: because it took me a while to adjust to island life. Also
column4: I like their company.

column1: The cell phone reception in the house is spotty
column2: there's no land line for phone
column3: and there's no internet connection in the house. It's kind of a blessing because it gives me the isolation that I wanted
column4: but I have to admit that it's a little more isolated than I was expecting.

column2: the dogs were a bit on edge. They didn't sleep so well because they were growling at all the strange noises. Every time they hit the beach they ran around and played non-stop. Last night was a shift: they slept thorugh the night
column3: didn't wake me up
column4: and when we walked on the beach
column5: they primarily just trotted along. I think they finally got their "crazies" out.

column1: So we've finished the phase of the vacation that's fun
column2: running on the beach
column3: walking to the pines
column4: being social
column5: etc. Now we're relaxed and ready to get some reading and writing done.

column1: It's odd that it really takes a while for one's head to unclench and enjoy the lack of responsibility and schedule.";"1153831528";"textile"
"The End of the Good Puppies";"personal/travel/fire-island/end-good-puppies";"Up until yesterday
column2: Gogo and Oz had been great on the island. I could let them off leash without any fear of them running away.

column1: I had noticed that they were starting to wander a bit further away from me on our walks
column2: so  for our afternoon jaunt
column3: I had decided to go through a path that's not usually travelled. It's open
column4: sandy
column5: and has little bushes and trees along the edge. They were great at first
column6: a bit slow in fact - smelling every little leaf. Then they found something off the path that they liked and checked it out. I tried to keep walking hoping that they would notice me gone and follow. It didn't work. I wandered back to where they were
column7: and they kept sniffing and wandered farther away. I tried various games to get the them to behave. None worked. Eventually
column8: I got them back and put them on a leash.

column1: I felt a little foolish because when I looked around
column2: I saw that they hadn't really wandered far at all. They don't know the difference between walking on the path and wandering around the bushes. And no one was around. What's the worst that could happen? I let them off-leash again in the same area.

column1: As I'm sure you can guess
column2: this time they really took off and in opposite directions. I was fine until Gogo climbed up over a hill and disppeared. I waited for a minute for her to come bck
column3: but she didn't. I ran up the hill and looked for her. There was a large grassy field
column4: two more hills
column5: and no Gogo. I panicked. Oz was in the opposite direction. I decided to try to get Oz first
column6: since he was closer. Luckily
column7: he cooperated. I put the leash on him and took him to where Gogo had last been spotted. I couldn't see a trail of her foot prints anywhere. Oz picked up her scent immediately and started pulling me
column8: although we still didn't find her for a couple of minutes. She was on the beach
column9: sniffing some seaweed and looking calm and happy.

column2: so lesson learned. The dogs have gotten brazen in their explorations.
I was having brekfast at the house. There's a big deck in the back that the pups had been laying on to suin themselves
column3: so I always leave the back door open. When I called them inside
column4: Oz was nowhere to be found. I calmed my rising panic and started calling for him. It turns out that he wasn't far - just the neighbor's yard. He had squeezed through an 8 inch space behind the tool shed to get there. But he was having trouble getting back. He couldn't make it back and had somehow ended up in the stagnant swamp underneath the house and needed help clearing some old wood. I helped him the best I could
column5: but it mainly came down to his determination to jump. His legs were covered with black swamp water. I hosed and dried him off.

column1: I know I'm going to be tempted to take them off leash
column2: but no more. They are now untrustworthy.";"1153919688";"textile"

column1: "Practicing Fun";"personal/blog/nlp/practicing-fun";"I had been stuck on my latest writing project. I spent a couple of months working together act breakdowns
column2: scene breakdowns
column3: character analyses
column4: etc. I had all the pre-work done and ready to go
column5: all I had to do was starting actually writing. I kept putting it off. So clearly something was wrong. I told myself that after I get the first couple of pages out
column6: I'll get over my "fear" of writing and the rest will flow easily. I got myself to agree to only write 2 pages - to help me get over the initial hump. Those two pages came somewhat easily
column7: then there was another delay. I found myself putting off work on writing.

column1: My next strategy was to set aside one hour in which I could work uninterrupted. I did some NLP exercises to clear disctractions. I realized that I had a goal in my head that the writing had to be "good". I told myself that was ridiculous - it was a first draft for a whole play. The only goal is to get the whole structure down on paper. How could I expect to write in the wonderful details if I couldn't get my hands around the whole thing first? The deal I made with myself was that I had one hour to work. I didn't have to accomplish anything
column2: but I wasn't allowed to be distracted. No checking email
column3: no practicing piano for "just a couple of minutes"
column4: no checking the news. I was allowed to do whatever I wanted as long as it had to do directly with the script.

column1: That went well and I got a few pages out of that hour of work. Then there was another several days where I could feel the act of working on the script turn into a "chore". Try as I might
column2: I couldn't make the writing come any easier.
it hit me as I was practicing piano. I was working on Bach's Invention No. 4 and trying to get the last quarter of it. I kept thinking about the words of my piano teacher
column3: Robert Cowie
column4: that if you practice a piece in frustration and tension
column5: you will have a hard time getting that out of your playing when you have learned the piece. It's much better to make the practicing easy so that you always have an experience of enjoyment and ease as you learn the piece. Ah...sage advice.

column2: the goal was to make writing fun! Make it easy! If I'm belaboring the writing
column3: then only write the subtext. Write nonsense. Let the characters have emotional outbursts. Do whatever it takes to have fun.

column1: "Private: Why Can’t You Take it With You?";"personal/blog/religion/private-why-can-t-you-take-it-you";"David and I are in Prague (which would explain the inevitable typos - the keys on the keyboard are often not where you expect them to be). He has a conference. I love Prague. I would never pass up an opportunity to visit. There's a wonderful mix of old European extravagance and communist era solitude.
We skipped the boat tour with the other anesthesiologists and had dinner last night
column2: just the two of us
column3: at a place called Palffy Palac. The building is literally a palace. We climbed a tall and wide marble staircase to get to the restaurant. During communism
column4: the palace was used to stock propaganda. Now it's both a private residence and a restaurant.

column1: We had our choice of sitting inside or outside. The night was cool
column2: the back was covered
column3: so we ate outside. The back looked out over a beautiful garden. The setting was not ornate
column4: it was stately. It's one of the things I love about visitting former communist areas - it's all very simple
column5: clean
column6: and quiet.

column2: the meal was out of this world. The service was so good
column3: you feel as if the waiter would invite you to stay with him at Christmas. And halfway through dinner
column4: I was overcome with a sudden sadness that there might be a point in time where I wouldn't remember this.

column1: I believe in reincarnation. And I suppose that along with that
column2: we somehow get our mind erased when we start the next life. Perhaps it makes it easier to enjoy the next life for its own sake to not carry around a bag of memories that no long matter. It all of sudden seemed so unfair that I couldn't have this memory with me always. Who's design was this? Why can't I at least keep my memories? Even if I could hold on to the impression of the memory
column3: it's the sort of thing that I could take with me forever.

column1: I got a little choked up at dinner. David didn't notice. The waiter showed up with our next course. I moved on. The whole night was really wonderful. And I wasn't even hung over this morning. This morning
column2: I'm no closer to wrapping up my thoughts from last night. I guess it's not the sort of thing that gets answered. At least not in this lifetime.";"1156748491";"textile"

column1: My sister got me a Kakuro book a few weeks ago. It's a more complicated version of Sudoku that involves some basic math skills. I was very glad to get it as Sudoku was becoming quite boring.

column2: I took an Ambien for the flight to London
column3: although I only slept for a couple of hours. The rest of the time I tried playing Kakuro. And I played some that night at the hotel. In a day's worth of travelling
column4: I could only finish three games. On each game
column5: I made at least one mistake and I eventually screwed up the puzzle so much I had to abandon it unfinished.

column1: The next day we flew from London to the Czech Republic. In a matter of a couple of hours
column2: I finished three puzzles without any errors.
kids.";"1156774925";"textile"
I've been making a fair number of changes to my diet: eating healthier
column3: trying to eat a greater variety of foods
column4: not baking extravagant desserts
column5: and eating less red meat and more fish. Although I felt better
column6: I didn't lose any weight.

column2: I had been taking swing dance lessons
column3: but not really at a level that would cause a major aerobic revolution. I had been staying away from exercise machines because they're boring and I always have a joint ache somewhere in my legs after all of that repetitive movement. I had also been taking yoga once or twice a week.

column2: I all of a sudden hit a big revolution. At the suggestion of my coach
column3: I started lifting weights. I have had a personal trainer on and off - some good and some not so good. I once had the same personal trainer for about two years. Although I gained a lot of weight in muscle
column4: I never lost as much fat as I wanted. My appetite would go through the roof after a workout. I'd feel like I literally couldn't eat enough. Plus
column5: I never really liked going to the gym with my trainer. It was hard! I felt as if I was always on the border of getting an injury and I was constantly sore and stiff. To counteract all of that
column6: my coach (who was a dancer and also practices Feldenkrais) gave me some activities to do to warm up my joints to avoid an injury. He also gave me a solid plan for working out that:

column1: • Does not require hours a day at the gym
• Involves only three weeks of intense work outs followed by 9 weeks of maintenance
• Gives me a framework for what to accomplish and leaves room for some creativity so I don't get bored.
We also did some NLP work to help me get the best results from a workout.
I was quite surprised how quickly the changes took place. Within a couple of weeks
column2: I could feel the difference and was getting compliments. However
column3: the runaway appetite problem re-emerged. Which launched me on to my big discovery: portion control.

column1: My coach had been talking about portion control for a while
column2: but he really brought it home to me with a discussion of "internal frame" vs. "external frame" vs. "false internal frame". Let me try to summarize.

column1: An "internal frame" is when you have your own set of standards
column2: criteria
column3: guidelines
column4: processes
column5: etc. on a particular subject. An "external frame" is when you find those things through an outside source - like a subject matter expert. And a "false internal frame" is when you think you have an inner set of standards
column6: but really it's coming from somewhere else.

column1: There are a lot of different ways that I could compare this to my personal experience. I think baking makes a good analogy. I spent many years putting myself through my own little "baking school". For instance
column2: learning how to make croissants. The only thing I had in terms of an internal frame was that I knew how my own perfect croissant should taste
column3: feel
column4: and look like - but I didn't know anything about ingredients or technique. It took a few tries before I could internalize that process enough to say "I know how to make croissants". Now I have those skills and standards and I'm not looking for someone else to show me how to do it. Another good example is when I went through a macaroon phase last year. I made macaroons incessantly and tested about 10 different recipes. I made my own adjustments to the recipes
column5: I learned how to make the recipes work with ingredients I knew I could easily get and with my own kitchen equipment. I now "know" how to make macaroons and I know how to judge whether they turn out well.

column1: This also applies to computer programming. I "know" when I've written something sloppy and when I've written something solid and I have the skills to get me there. For a while
column2: I didn't
column3: so I read books and took advice from mentors until I could internalize that process.

column1: So when it comes to eating
column2: I see now where I hit a lot of limitations in diet. First of all
column3: there's so much "diet" information out there that's just a list of foods to eat to lose weight without any regard for a maintainable and healthy way of eating (such as the Atkins or Scarsdale type diet books). I could never really internalize what I learned from those sorts of diets because they weren't anything that resulted in day-to-day food strategies.

column2: I have a lot of "false internal frames" about diet. I think they're part of my own process
column3: but really
column4: they come from some outside source. For instance
column5: I went to pick up fish for David and me recently. I almost always say to the fish monger "2 of your larger steaks" or "2 good sized steaks". And my thinking behind that was always
column6: "David and I are men and larger than average
column7: so we should be eating larger portions." When I saw that thought for what it was - an false internal - I ordered one steak and split it in two after I cooked it. It still ended up being too much food
column8: but not by much.

column1: I should say that this discussion came after I had spent a couple of months checking in with myself as I was eating. I was no longer aiming for "full"
column2: I was aiming for "not hungry" or "sated". It's amazing how much sooner one can feel satisfied with food when you stop aiming for "full". The combination of my own empirical research and discussion of "internal frame" completely transformed my diet. All of a sudden
column3: I was in charge of my diet. I know what I should be doing and take as much care with it as I would if I were programming or baking. I know how much I should be eating. There was no more guess work or feelings of guilt or doubt. Even if I have dessert
column4: I never have enough food to cause a lot of damage. And the weird thing is
column5: I don't feel like I'm depriving myself at all.

column1: • Decide on the correct portion before you start eating
• Eat fresh veggies and salads first (they help you fill up)
• Eat only until you're no longer hungry
<li>If the part of you that wants to over eat seems to be winning the battle
column2: envision everything else on the plate as animal fat (because that's what it will become)
eat!
clothes are much looser
column3: but the scale hasn't gone down. That's to be expected because I'm gaining muscle from lifting weights. I'm trying to patiently wait for the day that someone that doens't know I've been trying to lose weight looks at me and says "oh my god
column4: you look great"!";"1156925448";"textile"

column2: it will have been six weeks since Gogo had her knee surgery. By the end of six weeks
column3: the scar tissue is supposed to be in place and the majority of the healing is over. It was time to take her to the doctor to see if the latest surgery was successful.

column1: I couldn't help but let my mind wander to what we would do if it wasn't successful. This has been the second surgery on the same knee and Gogo's third knee surgery overall. The recovery is awful. I feel terrible for Gogo
column2: I have to carry her up and down stairs
column3: I have to watch her like a hawk
column4: and Oz doesn't get all the long walks that he wants. David had said that if this surgery wasn't successful
column5: he didn't want to try again. I definitely see where he's coming from
column6: but it would have been a hard call for me to make - especially if we saw her condition worsen over time again.

column1: So it was with great anxiety that I took Gogo to see her surgeon
column2: Dr. Fusco today. Well
column3: good news
column4: he said that the position of the knee is perfect! Yeah!

column1: He said that we could increase activity
column2: but to be on the safe side
column3: don't do anything outrageous for another six weeks. He checked both knees and they both felt great.

column1: I can't tell you what a huge relief it was to hear. I feel like a humungous burden has been lifted.

column2: God
column3: please let that be the end of poor Gogo's surgeries.";"1157734073";"textile"

column1: "It’s the Most Mommie-less Time of the Year";"personal/blog/children/it-s-most-mommie-less-time-year";"We live next to a children's nursery and it's that time of the year when school starts. Which means for the next week or two
column2: from eight to eight-thirty
column3: I listen to the sounds of inconsolable children crying for mommy from the neighbor's backyard. Their suffering is bottomless. Most of the time it's a constant moan or wailing. Every now and then
column4: one of them does a "I CAN'T TAKE IT ANYMORE" sound. It goes on for so long
column5: I can't help but laugh. I don't find their suffering funny - I find their vehemence funny. Some of the people that work there are trying to get a game of "Duck Duck Goose" going or trying to teach the kids a song. I think some of the kids are totally fine saying goodbye to Mommy and Daddy
column6: but they are outweighed by the loudly inconsolable right now.

column1: My favorite mourner was from a couple of years ago. There was a kid that
column2: for two solid weeks
column3: spent every morning for a half hour crying "I WANT MY MOMMY. I WANT MY MOMMY. I WANT MY MOMMY."

column1: I mentioned something about the kids to the nun next door. Something like
column2: "Boy
column3: the kids sure don't like the first week."

column2: "The children get over it soon enough. The parents never get over it."

column1: "Applicious";"personal/blog/food/applicious";"Friends Kevin and Jeff invited me to go apple picking. I had never been. People talk about it all the time here in the Northeast. I sort of viewed as some quaint attempt to stay in touch with nature. On the west coast
column2: most people either have an apple tree on their property or know someone that does. The idea of going out to pick apples always struck me as a bit silly. However
column3: a fall day spent driving out to the country to hang out in an orchard sounds like a day well spent to me.

column1: We went to a place called "Outhouse Orchards" in Westchester. Jeff said that it was not initially named after an outhouse. It had a Dutch name originally that sounded like "outhouse" that eventually morphed into the English. Jeff and I were both skeptical of that explanation.
Kevin had directions printed from Mapquest. The way to the orcahrd turned out to be very straighforward
column2: but you would never know that from the Mapquest directions. We took a total of 4 wrong turns
column3: each one put us about 10 minutes out of the way. I was starting to lose my sense of humor on the final wrong turn. But once we got there
column4: all of our mis-steps were forgotten.

column1: Jeff got us three 1/2 bushel bags and we headed up a hill to the orchard. Once I got my bearings
column2: I let the dogs off leash. They mostly stuck with us
column3: sniffing and inquisitive. Eventually
column4: they got comfortable and so started to wander away a bit more
column5: so I put them back on leash for a bit. Once they calmed down
column6: it seemed safe to let them off leash again. As soon as I did
column7: they both took off running as fast as they could without looking back. They were heading towards some people that had entered the orchard with kids. I had to get them back on leash. Oz was relatively easy to get back
column8: but Gogo totally disappeared from view. Kevin helped in the hunt and he found her. He said she was quite proud of herself for getting so far away. I had an apple as we were walking around. I have to admit
column9: they were delicious - much better than anything you get at a grocery store.

column1: We finished picking apples with the dogs on leash and headed back to the storefront. There were goats
column2: geese
column3: ducks
column4: chickens
column5: roosters
column6: and rabbits on the property. Gogo and Oz were a bit tentative at first
column7: but then decided they wanted a chicken.

column1: Kevin and Jeff picked out a couple of pumpkins to take home and a homemade pie. We also got some homemade donuts for the trip home.
Getting home was relatively easy and uneventful. The pups passed out and didn't make a peep until we pulled into Chelsea.

I guess now seeing how much I enjoyed it made me realize that I do live in the Northeast and I don't have a lot of opportunities to hang out on a farm. And the puppies always enjoy the chance to run free in nature for a bit
column2: as long as they can come home to a warm house and The New York Times chair.";"1161701739";"textile"

I decided that I wanted to make chocolates this year to give out to friends and co-workers. I've done some small experiments over the past couple of years with molded chocolates. They turned out reasonably well. But what I really wanted to do was to use chocolate transfer sheets to create designs on the tops of the chocolates. Transfer sheets are essentially colored chocolate printed onto acetate in a particular design. When you put melted chocolate on the transfer sheet
column3: it transfers from the sheet to the chocolate.

column1: Next up was to decide on flavors. I got the idea of doing different flavors representing different parts of the world. I brainstormed with some people to come up with the following list:

So now I'm testing the difficult recipes in preparation for the final production. The first difficult one was "Green Tea". I went to an Asian grocery store and got powdered green tea. Here's a picture of how they turned out:

column2: they taste great. I was worried that I put in too much powdered green tea
column3: but the outside of the white chocolate blends nicely with the filling. It's excellent.

column1: I think my next test will be the Brazillian - passion fruit and guava. I can't decide if I should make a white chocolate based filling like I did with the green tea or whether I should try a fondant filling.";"1163213620";"textile"

"Chicken with Dried Fruit and Almond Stuffing";"personal/recipes/main-ingredient/chicken/chicken-dried-fruit-and-almond-stuffing";"This chicken is different from any I have ever tasted. The special flavor comes from the sweet
column2: tart taste of the dried fruit
column3: combined with the crunchy almonds. Stuff two chickens and don't worry about leftovers-it tastes just as good cold or reheated.";"1204380256";"textile"

column1: "A New Photography Class";"personal/blog/photography/new-photography-class";"I came home from Israel with several goals. Most of the fitness goals are well in progress. I had also decided it was time to take a new class. I loved the photography class that I took at NYU
column2: so I looked for a new class along those lines. I narrowed it down to a photographic lighting class and a portrait class. The lighting class seemed to have a more broader application
column3: so I signed up for that.

column1: We've had 2 out of 10 classes. The class is great.

My previous teacher definitely taught along the lines of "rules" - such as not to go over 800 ISO on the camera. Having those rules definitely helped me understand how to make better photographs and why one would make certain decisions. The new teacher
column2: Don Penny
column3: is the opposite type of teacher. One of the first photos he took in class was at an ISO of 1250. His basic philosophy is to first get the shot. He said there were photographers in the 70's that always shot at a high ISO because they wanted "grain the size of golf balls in their film".

column1: So the class is much more experimental and free-spirited.

In the first class he showed us a technique for checking our white balance. I had one of those "ah-ha" moments as I have occasionally had a whole batch of photos with a bluish tint that I just couldn't figure out why. Now I know why and how to fix it.
Why set up several lights in the class
column2: took photos of each other
column3: and compared the quality of the light on the subjects. It was amazingly fun and educational. He also knew the rough prices of all the equipment should we decide we're redy to start setting up a studio.

column1: Our first assignment was to take photos in three different lighting situations: in noon-time sun
column2: during the "magic hour" (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_hour_(photography))
column3: and indoors where we control the lighting.

column1: Here's my homework. I actually only showed the 8 best at class
column2: but I posted a slightly larger set on flickr.

column1: "Dogs & Spring";"personal/blog/gogo/dogs-spring";"Our front yard has been completely re-done this year. In the past year or so
column2: I put some potted flowers on the front steps. It makes a big difference to come home and see some flowers welcoming you.

column1: I told Benji that he should put some plants in the front yard. So he went all-out and lined the front with boxes and planters
column2: expanded the watering system to take care of the front
column3: and then flooded them with flowers. Our daffodils have been in full force. People have been stopping us on the street to tell us what a wonderful thing we've done for the block. I think people in New York really understand the preciousness of making some natural and beautiful in the midst of all the urbanity.

column1: I took the puppies in the front yard for some nice photos.
"A Day at the Central Park Zoo";"personal/blog/jeff/day-central-park-zoo";"Kevin had just started radiation. We wanted to do something special on the weekend. Our plans were to go to the Bronx Zoo
column2: but the weather was not good and neither was Kevin's energy level. So we decided to go to the Central Park Zoo instead. We invited our friends Bob & Larry.

column1: Jeff happens to know someone that works at the Central Park Zoo
column2: so Nicole got us all in for free
column3: which was nice.

column1: This was my first visit to the Central Park Zoo. It was small
column2: but surprisingly nice.

column1: This was also the debut of Kevin's blond mohawk. He had decided that if there was a chance that he was going ot lose his hair during radiation
column2: that he was going to go out with a bang.

column1: "The Birthday That Keeps on Giving";"personal/blog/celebrations/birthday-keeps-giving";"It's about ten days after my birthday and today has somehow turned into my great birthday celebration. I got a package this morning from Sis. It had the following:
• A book of dog treat recipes with three cookie cutters

Then I met Sara in Union Square and we walked around to some second-hand stores looking at clothes and furniture. I predicted that fashion next year will be all about the Brokeback Mountain look - rugged suede coats with fleece lined collars. We wandered up to Little India for lunch and had some of the best Indian food I've had in a while. The place is called Copper Chimney. The chef came out to talk to us during lunch. And Sara said that lunch was on her - it was my birthday present because she couldn't find the original gift she had in mind.
So I came home and there was another package waiting for me: gift certificates at Barney's from Mom and Dad! Whoo-hoo!
Not bad for ten days after my birthday.";"1138218240";"textile"
"The Joy of Picasa";"personal/blog/google/joy-picasa";"I think I had downloaded Picasa once upon a time
column2: said "that's it?" and uninstalled it. After a very strong recommendation from Sara
column3: I gave it a second chance. It turns out that I didn't know I needed it.

column1: It's software to help you organize your photos. That's really all it is. But they've put in every little feature you'll ever need. You can resize
column2: crop
column3: and re-color photos. You can have it make web-ready versions
column4: automatically add it to a blog
column5: create a CD
column6: etc.

column1: I installed it last night and let it do a scan of my hard drive for photos. First of all
column2: I found photos that I had completely forgotten about. David and I spent a half hour reminiscing on shots of Gogo as a puppy and trips to Mexico. Secondly
column3: I found out that I had been scattering photos all over the place. I thought I had been pretty good
column4: but I found about 6 different folders dedicated to Gogo photos. This morning I finished moving files around
column5: consolidating things
column6: and touched up a few photos.

column1: I can already see that this is going ot change the way I work with photos. I used to spend a very long time converting camera photos to web-ready versions in preparation to post on my site. Now I'm thinking I'll leave them in their native size from the camera
column2: and do the conversion to web just when I need it.

column1: I highly recommend Picasa. It's free. It's made by Google.";"1138278720";"textile"

"Friday Night Ticket Scalping";"personal/blog/nyc/friday-night-ticket-scalping";"David is in Paris and we were scheduled to see "The Magic Flute" at the Metropolitan Opera. Since we ran out of time to exchange them
column2: we had the choice of donating them to the opera for a tax-deductible donation or scalping them. I decided it would be fun to try scalping.
it was quite an adventure. As most things in New York
column3: you show up and realize there are people that make their living in front of the opera house scalping tickets. I would not classify them as opera lovers. I also discovered that having really good seats is a liability in the scalping business. At least 20 people said they were interested until they saw the location and price of the ticket. Some people just walked away from me without a word. Most people laughed and said "I'm looking for something MUCH cheaper
column4: thank you."

column1: There was a woman there that was dressed like a homeless person. She was very short
column2: pushy
column3: and spoke with a craggly voice. She came up to me at least 5 times. The first couple of times she would say "I'll give you $40 for it." I told her no way. On the third time
column4: she said "What do you want for it?" I gave her my price and she walked away in disgust. She came up a couple more times to say something like "What did you say you wanted for it? I'll give you half that." It was clear that she was just trying to re-sell the ticket and was hoping that I was gullible.

column1: There was another man there that I was convinced was trying to steal the ticket from me. He came up to me very amicably and said that he was trying to sell a ticket too. He did not seem part of the "opera crowd" - more like the Port Authority bus terminal crowd. He started off by saying "There's a bunch of moochers out here tonight. They don't want to pay f-ing anything for a decent ticket. What ticket are you trying to sell?" I held up the ticket and he quickly tried to pull it out of my hand. I held onto the other side and wouldn't let go. He looked and walked away. A couple of times I noticed him showing me. At one point I had the ticket in my hand by my side. I turned around and he had apparently been right behind me. He quickly turned and walked away as if he had been minding his own business.
I ended up getting lucky. I sold one of the tickets for full price within the first 15 minutes of being there. It was another 45 minutes before I sold the other one and I only got half price. Still
column2: it beat the price that we would have gotten if he had dontated the ticket.";"1138491389";"textile"

column1: "Google Strikes Again";"personal/blog/google/google-strikes-again";"For years I've been complaining that there are no programs that map public transit systems. It's great - especially travelling abroad - to be able to see where nearby subways are
column2: how to get from one place to another via bus or train
column3: etc. I was poking around Google today and ran across this...(lucky Portland)...http://www.google.com/transit ";"1138573413";"textile"

column1: "Why do I care about del.icio.us?";"business/blog/taxonomy/why-do-i-care-about-del-icio-us";"If you browse the web
column2: I'm sure you've heard about del.icio.us. It's a site for maintaining links on the web. Like most of the sites out there that claim to be the hottest new technology
column3: I shrugged my shoulders
column4: said "meh"
column5: and forgot about it. Clever URL
column6: but I don't need it.

column1: The other day I was switching from my kitchen PC to my office and realized that I had lost a URL that I had bookmarked. Okay
column2: I could see the advantage of having my bookmarks someplace central. So I set up an account on del.icio.us and converted my bookmarks. I was blown away. The product itself is great - not amazing. They've thought through a very simple
column3: clean interface. The impressive part is to realize that you are participating in a world-wide effort to classify the web. The product gets really amazing as you "tag" your links. No more folders - just tags.

column1: At first I was having a hard time coming up with a tagging scheme. I was taking my best guess at coming up with tags
column2: but I wasn't entirely sure if I was naming them something useful. Then I started getting to some URLs that I shared with other people. If your URLs are in other people's account
column3: you can see how other people have tagged them. You immediately plug yourself into a global organization scheme. It's really quite ingenious. Not to mention fast and efficient.

column1: There are other great little things about the interface. For instance
column2: no complicated tree structure for your tags. Instead
column3: you can view your tags in a list or as a cloud. The cloud view is really cool and honestly helpful.

column1: So then I started thinking about how this applied to various projects I had creating intranets at companies. I'm still sorting through my thoughts and wondering if it's a valid comparison. In intranet projects
column2: there's usually some sort of problem coming up with a common language. Companies often complain that there is no central language - their keywords are a complicated mix of synonyms and double-meanings. There is an effort - and usually one person at the core of it - that comes up with a taxonomy that the system is built around. The tagging effort is never left to individual users of the system for the following reasons:

column1: • Individual users can't be trusted to do any tagging whatsoever
• The taxonomy is too nuanced and complex for the users to understand

column2: seeing del.icio.us in action proves all of that wrong. If the general public can agree on a list of keywords to describe any page on the internet
column3: maybe a company's taxonomy is not as subtle and convoluted as they'd like to admit? Maybe users are not as helpless and/or destructive as previously thought? Maybe it isn't worth maintaining a taxonomy so complicated that the average user can't automatically tag content?

column1: A user would use the global taxonomy rather than create their own special language for things because it's in their best interest to do so. By adhering to the global taxonomy
column2: you make it easier to find related content - both for yourself and the other people that use those tags.

column1: In fact - why WOULD you trust all keyword tagging to be done by someone else? You know what a piece of content means to you - you should be able to use your own subset of keywords to describe that content. When I was tagging my own URLs
column2: I would generally only use a subset of all the recommended keywords. My own set of tags has many to me
column3: while also being applicable to other people with interests in those tags.

column1: I don't think del.icio.us applies to all intranet metadata efforts. However
column2: I've seen months spent on projects to come up with taxonomies that were frought with problems: the taxonomy was too confusing; items were either too broad or too detailed; it didn't address the needs of an individual; it was too cumbersome to maintain. There's a lot to learn from this system and they've solved many problems very elegantly. The real benefit is the trust and power that it gives its user to make a rich and meaningful experience.";"1138900785";"textile"

column1: "Batman Returns Again Another Time";"personal/blog/comic-books/batman-returns-again-another-time";"I was re-reading Grant Morrison's "Bulletteer" yesterday. His "Seven Soldiers" is a lot of fun for the most part. I wish more people had picked it up. In the latest issue were two advertisements for upcoming Batman stories. The copy of "Bulletteer" is upstairs
column2: so I'll have to paraphrase them for you.

column1: One of the advertisements is for a mini-series called "Secrets". The ad has a beautifully drawn Batman and Joker. You can see a preview here: http://comics.ign.com/articles/677/677819p1.html.

The other ad is for a mini-series called "Batman Year 100". Wired magazine did an article about the artist and author: http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/14.02/pope.html. I wish I could find an image of the ad
column2: because that's really what I'm going to rant about. The ad has a drawing of Batman and says "Gotham 2039. Fromt the shadows of a tortured city a forgotten champion rises again."
let me say that as soon as I read a little bit about both of these
column3: they both sounded interesting. The artwork looks fantastic (especially on "Secrets"). These people spent a lot of time making something they thought the public would want to buy and I wish them all the success in the world.

column1: I'm so sick of Batman. Haven't we seen all these stories already? Several times
column2: in fact. The only Batman stories I would find interesting at this point would be stories that get him to stop acting like a mopey
column3: angry teenager. I came up with the following storylines.

column1: <li>The Scarecrow finally figures out that he's been going about this all wrong. Instead of trying to poison Batman with fear gas
column2: he posions him with anti-depressants. Batman gets over the death of his parents
column3: his obsessive/compulsive disorder clears up
column4: and realizes that it's a little silly to run around in a bat costume fighting crime. He takes up tennis instead. Eventually
column5: he builds a resort town in Nevada.

column1: <li>Gotham City goes through a real estate boom because it's the most affordable city in the country - due to years of crime keeping real estate prices low. Eventually
column2: Gotham City becomes a bastion of art
column3: culture
column4: and nightlife. It becomes so expensive
column5: that the criminals have to move someplace more affordable - like New Mexico. Batman finds himself living in a city that doesn't need him anymore. His attempts to bust up crime anger the now upper-class citizens of Gotham City. He spends his days dressing up as Batman and running around his own house pretending to solve crimes.

column1: <li>Or how about something as simple as "Batman gets a steady girlfriend". He's had a few affairs
column2: but for someone that keeps himself in such good shape
column3: he clearly has pent up sexual frustration. In fact
column4: I'm becoming very suspicious of super heroes that clearly don't get much
column5: if any
column6: sex. The more I think about it
column7: the more I like this one. The Gotham City villains conspire to get him married off. They discover Batman's secret identity and somehow trick him into going on "8-minute dates". Bruce Wayne meets someone and falls in love. Eventually
column8: the Batman thing kind of falls to the side. He has kids. Twenty years later
column9: at suburban cook-outs
column10: he contantly tries to tell people about the good old days: "I was Batman! Did you know that? Yep
column11: that was me. Still got the costumes somewhere. We had to turn the batcave into a nursery for the kids."

column2: but when the next Batman movie comes out (as long as it's directed by Chris Nolan)
column3: I will be first in line and salivating. Who am I kidding? I'll be the 1000th person in line behind all the people that buy anything that says "BATMAN" on it. The thing is
column4: I still look forward to quality Batman stories. It's possible that these two new Batman mini-series wll be amongst those great stories. My point is
column5: maybe we can all think about something that's not Batman? Maybe we can let the poor character take a break for a while? Maybe we can recognize that he's severely decompensated for a single tragic event in his life?";"1139230236";"textile"

column1: "Baby Plaything";"personal/blog/lorenz/baby-plaything";"It's a shame that most babies don't realize how entertaining they are. I'm in Minnesota taking care of my sister and her husband while they attend to the baby. The baby is just now starting to look at his surroundings. It's still firmly in the "cry
column2: eat
column3: and poop" phase. However
column4: the baby has provided us with endless amusement.

column1: Sis was telling us last night that our mom had created little business cards with a picture of him and his vitals. We expanded it into a playbaby centerfold. Lorenz's turn-ons include "exposed breasts" and his turn-offs are "sleeping in my own poop" and "the hiccups".
We are endlessly amused at listening to him burp
column2: which he does quite freely
column3: or an audible poop or
column4: as Mark calls it
column5: a rocket fart. I tried to imagine what it would be like to burp so freely or - god forbid - poop my pants with abandon. I can't imagine. Maybe Freud has something there...

column1: I stare at him and wonder what it must be like to exclusively make vocal sounds describing what's going on with my gastro-intestinal system. Besides the crying
column2: you know when a burp or a fart is coming from the facial gyrations that he goes through and his grunts and moans.";"1139782143";"textile"
I picked up my sister's copy of Camille Paglia's "Sex
column3: Art
column4: and American Culture". I flipped randomnly to a chapter called "Sexual Personae: The Cancelled Preface". I read the following section:

column1: <blockquote>Personality is at the heart of the West. Governing its representation in art are principles I call Apollonian and Dionysian
column2: in a theory elaborated from passages of Plutarch
column3: Nietsche
column4: and G. Wilson Knight. These terms were used by German scholarship in a sometimes vague or portentous way. I fine-tune them for practical criticism. I see the Apollonian and Dionysian as a cyclic pattern of expansion and retraction
column5: of the shapeless and the definite.

column1: I have often used the model of Apollonian and Dionysian sides to art
column2: long before Camille Paglia discussed it so fully in her writing. However
column3: this phrase of hers resonated with me: "a cyclic pattern of expansion and retraction
column4: of the shapeless and the definite".

column1: I could apply that same notion to describe what it is I love so much about any piece of artwork or writing that has grabbed me: the ability to be at one point ineffable
column2: and then to return to a state of something knowable. The best example I could give would be the X-Files at the height of the writing. The beginnings of the episodes seemed unreal and unknowable. The rest of the episode was about pinning down the edges of what was happening; giving shape to the events in unexpected ways.

column1: I could also make the same case for sci-fi or comic books. My favorite books always start with something unreal
column2: fantastical
column3: and profound. Slowly that grandness retracts into something we can understand; something that is familiar and concrete.

column1: I'm on the lookout now to see if this theory holds true and when it breaks. I'm trying to think of movies that might break this pattern. Even something like "Heavenly Creatures" perfectly captures this sentiment. The girls have wild flights of fantasy and we
column2: as viewers
column3: are taken into their surreal and bachannal flights. At the end of the movie
column4: though
column5: we are left with a very concrete view of what happened. It's really an amazing and transforming process.";"1139982166";"textile"

column1: "Where is ritual in modern American culture?";"personal/travel/mexico/where-ritual-modern-american-culture";"I am just finishing up a week trip through Chiapas in Mexico. We attended two very important festivals
column2: one was the "Pocho" dances in Tenosique and the other was "Fat Tuesday" in Chamula. If I don't have a full travelog posted now
column3: I will soon. However
column4: this post is more about my own thoughts and ramblings and is separate from the travelog.

column1: The festivals that I attended where somewhat choreographed in that there was some sort of dance to be done that the townspeople knew and participated in. There were some sort of group of directors that would wave a flag
column2: beat a drum
column3: and somehow direct the action and the dances. And the festivals generally had a lot of references to animals
column4: fertility
column5: and the passage of death. They were profound to attend. I haven't had such vivid dreams in so long as I did after attending the festivals - and that's only as an outsider. I can't imagine what it would be like to actually participate.

column2: it got me thinking
column3: where are the modern American rituals? And by ritual
column4: I don't mean people's daily personal rituals like "I come home
column5: open a bag of corn chips
column6: and watch Roseanne reruns." Where are these group festivals? The best I could come up with was Puerto Rican Day or Gay Pride Day. I've seen these
column7: though
column8: and they don't even come close to stacking up. These seem to be more about getting drank
column9: waving a flag
column10: and shouting a lot. There's no group dance. There's no director.

column1: I also thought about sports. I couldn't make the connection though. There's no real imagery
column2: there's no real story being acted out
column3: and there's really nothing for the audience to do.

column1: I suppose the ritual is part of what always attracted me to Jewish/Israeli events like a wedding or a bar mitzvah. There is a dance and there is some form and story to it. Granted
column2: there's nothing primal
column3: so it's a little tame.

column1: I suppose most religion was supposed to take the place of the rituals
column2: but modern religion is so antiseptic by the standards of the festivals that I attended. It's a shame.";"1141432408";"textile"

my friend";"personal/blog/nlp/be-water-my-friend";"I was watching a documentary about martial arts movies and caught an interview with Bruce Lee. The following quote of his rang in my head like gospel:

column1: <blockquote>Be like water making its way through cracks. Do not be assertive
column2: but adjust to the object
column3: and you shall find a way round or through it. If nothing within you stays rigid
column4: outward things will disclose themselves.

column2: be formless. Shapeless
column3: like water. If you put water into a cup
column4: it becomes the cup. You put water into a bottle and it becomes the bottle. You put it in a teapot it becomes the teapot. Now
column5: water can flow or it can crash. Be water my friend.

column1: This is my new theme. I'm carrying this around in my head and savoring it like hard candy for the soul.";"1141432542";"textile"

column2: Vertigo!";"personal/blog/comic-books/yeah-vertigo";"I was lamenting (to myself) a few months ago that Vertigo Comics had really let itself go. It seemed that the majority of their publications were re-hashing past successes like The Sandman or Swamp Thing. And a lot of the new stuff was fairly realistic crime comics like DMZ
column3: 100 Bullets
column4: or The Losers. Basically
column5: stuff you could find elsewhere. I thought Vertigo was about pushing the envelope and providing an outlet for high-end alternative comics?

column2: Vertigo has recently released three new titles - all of which are worthy of picking up:

column1: American Virgin - This is fun and is the most different from the average comic fodder. There's only been one issue so far
column2: so it's hard to judge. I liked what I read so far and the author started a lot of threads that can go somewhere interesting.

column1: <blockquote><span class="display_copy">Adam Chamberlain is a 20-year-old youth minister
column2: a best-selling author
column3: and most important
column4: the head of a rabid national virginity movement. But practicing virgin or not...Adam is about to lose it.

column1: Just a few weeks shy of marrying the girl of his dreams — the only woman God has said he can ever know sexually — Adam's fate
column2: future and sex life are cast in direct opposition with God's Word.

column1: The Exterminators - If you can handle it
column2: this is a fun and twisted series. It's definitely not for the faint of heart. But it's also not pointlessly mean-spirited. By issue #3
column3: it starts to poke its head out of the murky angst that it's mired in.

column1: The series centers on a dysfunctional group of bug killers prowling the barrios and bungalows of Los Angeles — the thinnest point on the shaky borderline between civilization and the violent chaos of nature.
Testament - It's a little too soon for me to be able to say what this series about. So far
column2: it's taking stories from the Old Testament and applying them to a sci-fi future based around issues that we see in play today's government - privacy
column3: war and recruitment. Here's the DC blurb about it:

column1: <blockquote><span class="display_copy">From the imagination of best-selling author Douglas Rushkoff (<em>Coercion
column2: Club Zero-G)
column3: one of the most iconoclastic and acclaimed minds of our era
column4: comes a series that exposes the "real" Bible as it was actually written
column5: and reveals how its mythic tales are repeated today.

column2: interesting
column3: and alternative comics. Go for it. Buy en masse.

column1: I've often thought the problem with the modern comics market is that everyone associates comics with costume clad superheroes. There's no reason to think that:
