• Just because the characters are superheroes doesn't mean it's vacuous
• Not all comic books are about superheroes
If the comic industry is to grow to its next step
column2: it's getting more people to buy comic books by convincing people there's more out there than just kid stuff.

column1: So congratulations to Vertigo for pushing the boundaries. I hope they get the support they need to continue.";"1142349764";"textile"

"The Great Migration Begins!";"personal/blog/technocrat/great-migration-begins";"How many years have I had my old site? I think it's been at least 8 years. It's been time for an overhaul for a while now
column2: but the task was much bigger than I could have imagined. I did a quick page count of my site and found several hundred pages that had to be migrated. Some of them I could migrate automatically
column3: but the vast majority would have to be ported over by hand.

column1: This was mainly due to the fact that I had significantly upgraded much of the technology. I wasn't just copy and pasting text over
column2: I was moving pictures to my flickr account so that it easily went into an automated slide-show
column3: I was re-tagging content
column4: recipes were being put it into a database so that you could easily double or quadruple amounts
column5: etc.

column1: So not all of the content is over yet. Everything that was once under "blog" is moved over. In some cases
column2: I enhanced the blog entry (especially where photos were involved). I've only moved over one recipe so far. My next goal is to finish moving over recipes.

column1: And then on to everything under "photos" in my old site. Yuck. I'm not looking forward to that.
The benefit will be a new look and feel
column2: the ability to add comments to any page
column3: enhanced keyword tags
column4: spam-blocking
column5: cool new slide shows
column6: forward-to-a-friend
column7: search-engine-optimized pages
column8: and eventually a section of business and creative work.

column1: I hope you like the site! Let me know what you think or if you find a bug by leaving a comment.
"Photography Class";"personal/blog/learning/photography-class";"I just finished taking a month long photography class. I had been talking to my friend
column2: Tom
column3: about my photography skills. I felt that after I got a high-end DSLR camera
column4: that my photos actually got worse. I had no idea what all the buttons were for. Every time I tried to figure out f-stop and shutter speed
column5: I'd take lousy photos. I really needed a class to get me into shape.

column1: We looked at a few classes in the city. In the end
column2: we took a "Digital Photography Workshop" from NYU. The instructor was Emmanuel Faure (http://www.emmanuelfaure.com/).
in that it forced me to understand everything that my camera does and why you would pick particular settings over others. The teacher also gave us a lot of advice on composition
column3: framing
column4: and other artistic ideas.

column1: The latest photos on my site were all done during or after the photography class. I've definitely noticed a night-and-day difference. I would occasionally take a good shot before
column2: but now I can hit it with much more reliability. And when I'm not hitting it
column3: I know what I can do to fix it.

column1: This is a photo of our class
column2: taken by the instructor.

column1: "Some Hiccups";"personal/blog/technocrat/some-hiccups";"The new blog has been up a while. There's still no progress on moving over all the old content to the new site. It's feeling like a herculean task right now.
And I found a few hiccups.
If you browse the site with IE 6
column2: it looks terrible. I make no apologies. UPDATE YOUR BROWSER! I toyed with the idea of putting a big block on the site just for IE6 users to upgrade their browser
column3: but then I figured I didn't want to waste time making any concessions for IE6. It's an old browser and it's not compliant. Everything will look better if you use a newer browser (preferably Firefox).

column1: The other big hiccup that I found is that Google Analytics was not turned on correctly. So I have no idea if anyone actually browsed the new blog pages. And seeing that no on has left a comment yet...well it's left me in the dark.
Please don't hesitate to leave a comment if there's something about the site that's not working correctly.";"1212014777";"textile"

column2: I decided it was time for a spa visit. My friend Sara insists that I have been sorely lacking in my spa-attending duties
column3: so it was high time I booked myself for an appointment. I had originally thought a massage and a waxing would be a good idea (Yes
column4: yes
column5: men can get waxed too. It really helps cool off for the summer.) I booked an appointment at Nickel (http://www.nickelspanyc.com)
column6: which is just a block away.

column2: I decided I really didn't want a waxing. So I decided to try something different
column3: I got a massage followed by a body scrub. I didn't know what to expect and decided to be surprised
column4: rather than ask anyone what it was like.

column1: The massage was great. It was with a masseur that I had not had before. His name was Omar and he was gargantuan. I had signed up for a sports massage
column2: so I expected him to really work any tension out of my muscles. Mission accomplished.

column1: He did the body scrub as well. He started by putting warm
column2: wet hand towels over my front (I was lying down). Then he poured warm water over the towels. One by one he took the towels away and scrubbed the skin with a loufah. The only area of my skin that was a bit sensitive to the scrubbing was my lower legs. I had a brief moment when he started scrubbing my sides that I was going to break out in ticklishness
column3: but I held my composure. After he did the front
column4: I flipped over and he did the same thing to my back half. At the end
column5: I was covered with soapy water. He showed me my robe
column6: a clean towel
column7: sandals
column8: and pointed me to the shower down the hall.

column1: The treatment is certainly not for people that are drip-phobic. There was water being poured all over the place. A was a big sudsy mess by the end of it. There's something very child-like to having someone scrub you while you just lay there.

column2: my skin was soft and smooth afterwards. I would definitely sign up for another one.";"1214256026";"textile"

column1: "Out at Buck's Lake";"personal/blog/family/out-bucks-lake";"We drove almost directly from the Sacramento airport to Buck's Lake. It's about 45 minutes from Sacramento to Yuba City and then another 2 hours to Buck's Lake.
It did not occur to me to call David while in Yuba City. It wasn't until I got to Buck's Lake that I realized there was no internet or cell phone reception. Yikes! At first
column2: I thought I'd be fine with the break. It turns out that I was wrong. During the second day at Buck's Lake I took my iPod Touch for a walk around the lake until I found internet access to poach. I must have looked quite out of place with my sunglasses
column3: Kenneth Cole jacket
column4: and iPod sitting on a stump and sending email.

column1: Buck's Lake is beautiful. The cabin has been in the family for a long time - my mom played in the lake when she was a child. Her first honeymoon was in the cabin.

column2: my uncle Parke has significantly altered the cabin: he rotated it 90 degrees to get a better view
column3: he's expanded it both out the sides and on top.

column1: The first night and day we had Aunt Catherine
column2: Uncle George
column3: and Uncle Parke as company. We built a fire at night and gave Lorenz his first s'mores. His face was smeared with chocolate and marshmallow in no time.

column2: Uncle Chris arrived with Dad. We had a great visit. It's a good place to unwind and talk.

column1: Lorenz was unfortunately not so comfortable there. We had a hard time getting him to relax and go to sleep. At one point
column2: Sis and I took him out on the boat. There must have been something about the rumble of the motor
column3: because he went out like a light as soon as we got out in the water. Sis and I put a blanket over him so he didn't burn and had a nice slow circle around the lake.

column1: We took Lorenz out another time and he stayed awake. This time I took the boat fast
column2: which scared him at first. In no time
column3: he was asking to go faster.

column1: "At Beth & Charlie's";"personal/blog/family/beth-charlies";"For most of the rest of the week
column2: we stayed at Aunt Beth's & Uncle Charlie's.

column1: Uncle Charlie has spent most of his life working at John Deere. Hence
column2: there is a LOT of John Deere paraphernalia around the house.

column1: Charlie took Lorenz on a ride on a "gator". For you city folk
column2: it's a four-wheeled utility vehicle made by (whom else) John Deere. Here's more information: http://www.deere.com/en_US/ProductCatalog/GC/category/GC_UV.html. Lorenz went NUTS getting to ride in this. Just about the only two words that he said crystal clear the whole weekend were "marshmallow" and "gator".

column1: And Lorenz wasn't the only one. Beth and Charlie's dog Coda was ecstatic for the ride. And Aunt Catherine's glee is quite visible as well. Charlie seems to be the only keeping his cool.

You may also notice the fetching pink swimsuit with a frilly skirt and multi-colored daisies. It was the only life vest that Lorenz. He didn't mind wearing it. We'll see if he retro-actively minds having worn it when these pictures are shown to future prom dates. Thank god for the internet - these photos may be here for a long time!
"Visiting Uncle Scott and Aunt Grace";"personal/blog/family/visiting-uncle-scott-and-aunt-grace";"Sis and I got a chance to visit Uncle Scott (from my father's side) and his wife
column2: Grace
column3: while we were there. This is only the second time I've seen him in the past ten years.

column1: They took us for a drive through the Buttes (my first time driving through them) to a restaurant/bar on the Sacramento river called "Lovey's". It was a great location that had it been anywhere else in the world
column2: would have been packed with boats and swimmers. Thank god there are still places like Sutter County in the world.

column1: We had a great visit and got to get a picture in as long as it somehow featured Scott's boat.
"The Sutter County Cemetery";"personal/blog/family/sutter-county-cemetery";"On the way out to Lovey's
column2: Scott drove us by the Sutter County cemetery and pointed out that our birth father and grandparents are buried there. After lunch
column3: both Sis and I wanted to drive back and see Keith Sr's grave. I had never seen it and Sis had only been when she was very young.

column1: We thought that we could locate it by finding the cemetery's office
column2: but that was closed with no directions. We thought we could locate it by walking around
column3: but it became quickly clear that a cemetery
column4: no matter how small it looks
column5: is a big place. We wandered for a while where we thought we would see it with no luck. I was becoming increasingly discouraged - not to mention depressed by looking at all the tombstones. I couldn't help creating little stories in my head about the people buried there or wondering what had happened to them.

column1: Then I remembered that one of the first things I did when Google first became popular was to Google my own name. The first thing that came up was the Sutter County cemetery records for Keith Sr's grave. I used my phone to search for that page again and found the location of his grave. It turns out that we were no where near it. We got back in the car and found it.
I was not in the right state of mind when we found it - staring at everyone else's graves had put me in quite a funk. Still
column2: I'm glad that we did it. I don't know why I'm glad and I don't know what it was I was hoping to get by finding it. Truth be told
column3: it put me in a funk for the rest of the trip - one that has slightly lingered to this day.

column1: I never knew that he made it to be a doctor.
Here's a link to the picture if you're curious.";"1214344970";"textile"
"Kellie & Paul's Wedding";"personal/blog/family/kellie-pauls-wedding";"And now for the big event: Kellie & Paul's Wedding!
The big debate leading up to the wedding was "Who's Wearing a Tie?". Well
column2: shockingly few men wore a tie. Or not so shocking
column3: considering the Everetts. I was one of the few wearing a tie. I had a nice linen suit for summer events
column4: so I figured it would be silly not to wear it to an event in Yuba City. And I wasn't going to schlep a suit all the way to California and not wear the whole enchilada.

column1: I guess I looked the part of a New Yorker
column2: because several people said to me "Coming to Yuba City from New York must be a big culture shock!" Did I have a wide-eyed blank stare of fear and confusion? I hope not.

column1: The wedding was beautiful. And thankfully the ceremony was not overly long because linen suits do not "breathe" as much as advertised and it was a typical Yuba City day of pounding sun with not a cloud in the sky.

It was a great reception. There's never quite enough time to connect with cousins and catch-up. I keep thinking there will come a day when I'll finally get to sit down and hear what people have been doing with their lives
column2: but before you know it
column3: another 5-10 years have passed by.

column1: "Retouching Photographs";"personal/blog/photography/retouching-photographs";"I've started playing around with Photoshop to enhance my photos.
I was looking at the wedding photos done by the professional they hired for my cousin's wedding. They were fantastic. You can view them here: Kellie and Paul's Wedding. Her composition is excellent
column2: the pictures are sharp
column3: and she certainly gets a great sense of playfulness from her subjects.

column1: There's also a lot of post-processing in her photos. I don't know everything she's doing
column2: but I can that there are adjustments to color and saturation for starters.

column1: I decided to play around with some of my existing photos to see if I could breathe some life into them.

column2: an unsharp mask
column3: and vignetting in Photoshop to alter the image below.

column1: Here's the original (You definitely want to zoom in to the photo. It looks a lot better close-up):

I went to "curves" in Photoshop and modified the red and green channels to have a slight "s" curve. I left the blue channel as it was. I then applied an unsharp mask to the image. I aimed for a radius of 50 on the unsharp mask and played with the other settings so that it wasn't too severe. Next
column2: I added a filter of an "inner glow" and changed the color to black. That gave it a soft vignette.

column1: When I look at the after photo
column2: I start thinking that I didn't too that much
column3: but when I go back to the original
column4: I see how washed-out the original now appears.

column1: Let me know what you think.
"A Trip to Yuba City for Kellie & Paul's Wedding";"personal/blog/family/trip-yuba-city-kellie-pauls-wedding";"In June 2008
column2: Mom
column3: Dad
column4: Sis
column5: Lorenz
column6: and little old me rendezvoused in Yuba City. The event that brought us there was the wedding of my cousin
column7: Kellie Everett (Parke's daughter). It gave us a chance to visit Buck's Lake
column8: where Parke has a cabin that's been in the family for decades
column9: hang out in Yuba City
column10: visit Uncle Scott
column11: and have a good ole Everett time.

column1: You will notice that Aunt Catherine is in more than her fair share of photos. That's because she's a ham. Plus
column2: she's photogenic.

column1: "Aunt Beth's Garden & Greenhouse";"personal/blog/family/aunt-beths-garden-greenhouse";"On recent trip to Yuba City
column2: CA
column3: I took some time to take photos of Aunt Beth's garden and greenhouse. I should say - take photos of a small fraction of her garden and greenhouse. There are lots of vegetables
column4: herbs
column5: and fruit trees there - unfortunately
column6: I was there a bit early in the season before the plants had a chance to get going. I was still able to get some good shots.

column1: The orchid greenhouse is amazing. Aunt Beth told me that there was very little in bloom this time of year. What I saw was still enough to amaze me. It seemed that every time I turned around
column2: there was another orchid bloom that I had missed. Each one was more strange and wonderful than the last.

column1: I have no idea what kind any of these are
column2: so they are all labeled generically.

column1: "Oz Organizes Comic Books";"personal/blog/comic-books/oz-organizes-comic-books";"I've been having a hard time lately with a few comic book series. I've been obsessed with Batman lately - it's one of the best comic series I've read in years. I was talking to a friend saying that I was enjoying it
column2: but that it was hard to follow. He summarized his favorite parts of the story and it was all new territory to me. I had no idea what he was talking about. Then I went back and noticed that i was missing about 3 issues over the past year. That's a lot.

column1: I looked at another series that I like called "The Twelve" and it was a similar story: missing issues.
So I decided it was time to organize my comic books again. There are stacks of books all over the house. When I look for a missing issue
column2: I have to go into 4 different rooms to look through stacks.

column1: I went to the comic store and got some boxes
column2: bags
column3: and boards. I figured that 100 should be enough. As I went through the stacks to organize them
column4: I realized that I hadn't organized my comic books since the series "52" ran - which was about two years ago. They had a comic book a week for one whole year. That series alone was 52 issues. I probably had about 200 - 300 comic books to bag
column5: board
column6: and organize. Yuck.

column1: So today's goal changed into "let's at least organize and stack the comic books and then figure out what to do". I made it that far and stood up to take a break. Oz either liked the warm spot that I left on the rug or felt like he needed some attention
column2: because he grabbed my spot as soon as I got up. Here's a photo of him.
childhood is not something I want to experience all over again. I didn't like the general helplessness
column3: lack of knowledge
column4: the clashes with authority - and of course
column5: the waiting. The endless waiting for...say
column6: The Return of the Jedi to come out. I think I was in a 2-3 years depression as a small child knowing that Han Solo was frozen
column7: Luke was missing a hand
column8: and the Empire was still on the march. I don't think kids in general are good at waiting. Well now I get to relive all that waiting again.

column1: WILL THE IPHONE 3G JUST HURRY UP AND COME OUT ALREADY!?

My friend Sara and I have made plans to stand in line at 7am on Friday morning at the AT&T store. We predict that this iPhone release won't be as much of a zoo as the first release. I don't know what we're basing that on. Maybe we just assume that the rest of the world isn't as superficial materialistic as the two of us.

My current phone is beautiful (It's an AT&T 8525). It's been my favorite phone by far and has been leaps and bounds ahead of most everyone else's phone. I've loved it - until they announced the iPhone 3G. Now every time I look at my current phone
column2: I have this "oh
column3: you again" response to it. There are plenty of glitches in Windows Mobile
column4: the browser sucks
column5: I can't sync reliably
column6: and I reboot almost once a day. I can't wait to ditch it.

column1: The real kicker is that I know that Apple is working my ultimate device: an iPhone that has a physical keyboard and 32GB. Once I get one of those
column2: I can die a happy man. Every few days I tell myself that I should just wait until that one's ready. It's only 6 months to a year
column3: right? But I can't wait. I'm helpless against wanting an iPhone. Every time I check email on my Windows Mobile phone
column4: I think about how much easier it's all going to be on an iPhone. Then I settle it with the thought that I promised my current iPod to Rogrido when the new iPhone came out. Poor Rodrigo doesn't have any iPod
column5: so it's really selfish of me to NOT get an iPhone and give him my hand-me-downs.

column1: At the beginning of the week I thought that the time would fly by and that Friday would arrive sooner than I could expect. I was wrong. The week is dragging by. Is this why they say time flies when you're older? Because when you're a kid
column2: you're trying to kill time waiting for the next shiny new thing to come out.
s=s]";"1215615493";"textile"

Apple! I don't need your stupid iPhone!";"personal/blog/apple/screw-you-apple-i-dont-need-your-stupid-iphone";"Today was the big day: the release of the iPhone 3G. We had a multi-tiered plan - I was going to check out the Apple Store near my house at 7am
column3: Sara was going to check out the AT&T store nearest her
column4: and her friend Morgan was going to check out the Union Square AT&T store. Whoever had the shortest line would grab a spot and we would all meet there.

column1: The Union Square store won - although the Apple store near my house looked like the most fun. The people in line had giddy faces
column2: there was a camera crew
column3: and the windows of the store were covered in black fabric.

column1: I went to Union Square and we all waited in line. About an hour and a half into the waiting
column2: someone that knew Morgan came to say hi
column3: saying that he was further back in line from us. We chatted for a bit and then he said the inevitable: "So do you think I could join you guys in line?"

column1: Silence. Sara and I looked to our feet. Morgan murmured something like "I don't think anyone would say anything." The guy said that he'd be right back and returned with his female business partner. It turns out no one said anything about them butting ahead in line
column2: and they were great company - but I had started rehearsing in my head what I would say if anyone else tried to join us.
with the exception of the first person to walk out the door (who did a cheer)
column3: everyone was leaving the store in a dour mood. We figured that people should be excited that the fruits of their waiting labor were finally ripe. People just seemed to be slinking out of the store with a bland look on their face.

column1: We got into the store after about a 2.5 hour wait in line. I assumed that it would go smoothest for me since I was the only existing AT&T customer
column2: and I have already checked that I was eligible for the upgrade to an iPhone. The salesperson took my information
column3: then said that she had to talk to the manager. Apparently
column4: the AT&T computer said I was eligible
column5: but iTunes had said that I was not. Why it mattered what iTunes had to say was beyond me - I think there were some competency issues. Especially considering that the guy that had my sales agent before me had the exact same issue. They asked me to step aside while they checked it out.

column1: I actually don't think they did that munch to fix the issue. I waited for about 20 minutes. My sales agent went through two more customers while I waited. Sara got her iPhone
column2: but they were not able to activate the service. They told her to wait as well - but that it should activate sometime in the next hour or so.

column1: I talked with the manager who tried to care about my situation
column2: but couldn't do anything to help. Customer service had flown out the window. I was a drop in the bucket of iPhone consumers. I could leave an unhappy customer and they wouldn't bat an eyelash. So I decided to leave. God knows how long I would have had to stand there in the store with no resolution.

column1: While I was standing there debating leaving
column2: Sara and I were playing with their demo models. For some reason
column3: a piercing store alarm went off on my demo iPhone. The little cord that keeps you from stealing it started flashing a red light. They had to have someone come over
column4: open up the panel
column5: and manually shut off the alarm. I was embarrassed at first
column6: then slightly glad it happened. I toyed with the idea of doing it again in the hopes that they would give me an iPhone just to have me out of the store.

column1: Sara and I left with those same bland and dour faces that we saw on everyone else. I had no iPhone and hers was unactivated. We had coffee at Taralucci y Vino. I felt better about my iPhone-less existence.
I stopped by two AT&T stores on the way home. Both of them were sold out. It was only 11am. How had I so seriously misjudged my fellow Americans ability to participate in a consumer frenzy?
I thought I'd swing by the Apple store on the way home. Maybe the line wasn't that long? It wasn't outrageous in the morning when I stopped by...

It was ridiculous. It snaked back and forth and went halfway to the river. They had handed out Apple umbrellas to people standing in the sun. I heard that they had even given out cookies! Clearly I had picked the wrong line.
Then the sour grapes started setting in. I didn't need a stupid iPhone. Maybe this was God's way of telling me to wait for the 32GB version? If so
column2: thank you God for caring about my technological well-being. And maybe I shouldn't be so gung-ho about something this popular. When did Apple go from underdog to market crusher? Suddenly
column3: I started feeling like a Jonestown member complaining that my cup was empty - "Don't tell me you're out of Kool-Aid! That's not fair!"

column1: Maybe I'll wait for the Google Android...

It looks like I'll try again at the Apple store tomorrow morning. There's a slight chance that the line won't be bad and that they may still have phones left and that they had worked through my eligibility problem. Not bloody likely
column2: but worth a try.

column1: I went home and the plants on the front steps needed water. It was a good reminder - plants need water to live. Water is a necessity. iPhones are not.";"1215794227";"textile"

"Um...I take it all back...";"personal/blog/apple/um-i-take-it-all-back";"So...this morning I stood in line again for an iPhone. Am I being masochistic? Do I really not have anything better to do with my time?
These were some of the nagging questions chattering in my mind that I squelched as I stood in line hoping to get an iPhone.

I decided to try my luck at the Apple Store because they stood a better chance of having everything in stock and their employees seemed nicer and smarter. When I got to the store a half hour before opening
column2: the line was even longer at opening time than it was the first day. After the first hour of waiting in line
column3: my mind did a big "What are you doing wasting another 3-4 hours? Just wait a week and there will be no line! There's no guarantee that you'll even get an iPhone!" I justified that if I left now
column4: that would be completely wasting a full hour. If I stuck it through
column5: I would at least make the waiting worth it.

column1: I was visited by Jeff and Scout
column2: then Kevin
column3: and finally David. I waited in line a bit over 4 hours. I won't say the time went by quickly
column4: but it didn't feel quite as bad as four hours.

column1: The final line is on the second floor. They let 6 people go up to the second floor at a time
column2: where you wait for an agent. Luckily
column3: David showed up right as I was given the pass to go upstairs
column4: so he got the fun of the purchase without the pain of the waiting. There really is something to be said for waiting for something for 4 hours. By the time I ascended the glass stairs
column5: I felt like I was entering heaven (although getting an iPhone was feeling a lot more difficult than getting into heaven). In a couple of minutes
column6: a sales agent came over and introduced herself.

column1: Her name was Erica. She smiled. She asked me how long the wait had been. She said that they're getting better - yesterday it was an average of 7 hours wait. She only asked me a few questions and then went to get my iPhone. Gone was the disarray of AT&T
column2: the confusing responses that the computer wouldn't let my order go through
column3: the general dismissal of my needs. I got the sense that Erica was going to get me an iPhone no matter what. She was looking out for me. We chit-chatted about the neighborhood. Her cousin has crashed on her futon for the past week. Erica was cool.

column1: I asked her how the system was going to transfer my phone number over. Didn't she need to switch my SIM card? She had only asked my name and phone number. How could it figure out who I was? She walked over to a Mac
column2: plugged in the iPhone
column3: and two text messages to me from Jeff came up on the iPhone. It found me already. I couldn't figure out if I should be creeped out or amazed. Where were the 2 hour activation times I had been hearing about? This was instantaneous. Sara got her iPhone at AT&T over 24 hours earlier and it had still not activated.

column1: Erica kept talking politely at this point and was holding my iPhone (it was now mine. - mine mine mine - gimmee gimmee). I was trying to be polite
column2: but really
column3: I wanted to snatch it out of her hands. David kept up the conversation as I stared intently at my iPhone. Eventually
column4: she gestured in a way that could have been interpreted as offering me the phone and I grabbed it. She wished us well and went on to make someone else's day.

column1: When we descended the lucite stairs to leave
column2: I felt like I had to leave the place with a smile. I had seen so many people leaving the AT&T store disgruntled. I owed it to the people still standing in line (hundreds of them
column3: in fact)
column4: that yes
column5: there is an iPhone at the end of their journey and it will be worth it. I beamed a smile. I cheered. It turns out the people in line didn't care about me at all
column6: but the other employees cheered with me and opened the door for us to leave.

column1: I've been playing with it for a few hours. I can't explain what's so great about it
column2: but it's the coolest gadget I'ver ever owned. What's so great about it? Everything. Every little detail makes you go "neat!" and "wow!" and "they've thought of everything!"

column1: That's what's so great about Apple products
column2: they inspire this weird possessive/personal/devotion response to electronic devices. You can almost hear yourself saying to the Gods of Apple: "You can make me wait in lines for ever and I'll still be there for you."";"1215903996";"textile"

column1: "..Across the Fruited (and apparently slick) Plains!";"personal/blog/beauty/across-fruited-and-apparently-slick-plains";"I saw this blurb about the latest Miss Universe pageant:

<cite>AP - Miss Venezuela was crowned Miss Universe 2008 on Monday in a contest marked by the spectacle of Miss USA falling down during the evening gown competition for the second year in a row.</cite>
I immediately stopped what I was doing and searched for videos of our proud Miss USA spilling out for both 2007 and 2008. Granted
column2: it wasn't the same person (that would have been hysterical if it had been the same girl - cursed to a life of slipping on stage during inopportune moments). Still
column3: it's funny that it should happen to us.

column1: Are they going to change the Miss USA competition? Maybe they should add a "walking on difficult surfaces" portion to ensure that we have able walkers for the Miss Universe contest.
Here's the video from both years:
Miss USA 2007 definitely wins the "total unrecoverable wipe-out award". Were there ball bearing in her heels?
Miss USA 2008 does a great job of recovering. She applauds herself. You almost suspect that she's drunk.

column2: future Miss USA 2009 - you have some mighty wobbly shoes to fill.";"1216055732";"textile"

"4 Nights in Fire Island";"personal/travel/fire-island/4-nights-fire-island";"The past two years
column2: I've rented a place on Fire Island for a week - specifically
column3: in Cherry Grove. Previously
column4: I had taken the pups out
column5: got a 2 bedroom unit
column6: and attempted to get work or writing done.

column2: I decided to bag the trip to Cherry Grove for a few reasons: finances were tight
column3: we had a lot of travel this year
column4: the dogs kind of drive me crazy out there
column5: I never got any writing done
column6: etc. On 4th of July weekend
column7: it all of a sudden hit me that I'm supposed to be walking on the beach with the sand between my toes and the surf running over my ankles. I went on craigslist and found a studio apartment on the bay for only during the week for a reasonable rate. No pets allowed - so sorry puppies
column8: you have to stay with David.

column1: I scheduled it to coincide with a trip that Kevin and Jeff were making to Bellport (a 15 minute drive from the Cherry Grove ferries). They were staying for a few days at the house of Kevin's doctor who had graciously offered them his house for some needed R&R. I spent the first day and night with them
column2: then we all went to Cherry Grove together the next day where I stayed for the rest of the week.
I can't really tell you what I did. Without any puppies or a phone that could get reception I slept. A lot. Pretty much every activity was followed with a half hour nap.

column1: And actually got some writing done! A few times every day
column2: I sat down to the computer and plotted out a script.
I usually went to eat at a restaurant on the ocean and then to one of the bars for a drink or two before bed.

column1: I think I could have stayed a whole additional week. I did miss David quite a bit
column2: and the puppies
column3: of course.

column1: FYI - These photos are the first ones to be taken with my new iPhone. Not bad for a camera phone
column2: I think.

column1: "Does Liking Mika Make Me a 9 Year Old Girl?";"personal/blog/music/does-liking-mika-make-me-9-year-old-girl";"My friend Claudio's 9-year-old daughter
column2: Carmen
column3: recently had a birthday party in New York City. I asked Sara if she had any information on something that might be appropriate to get her. Carmen likes Mamma Mia and Madonna. At first I thought I'd get her a Cyndi Lauper CD. Then I texted Jeff to see if he had any ideas. He was with a friend that recommended Mika's album Life in Cartoon Motion.

column1: I checked it out on iTunes. Yes
column2: it's appropriate for a 9 year old girl. A lot of the songs of bubble-gum pop
column3: it's catchy
column4: it's upbeat. And the album cover is beautiful. It was so enjoyable
column5: I got it for myself as well.

column2: size=m
column3: class=center]

column2: I'm just a 9 year old girl at heart. Who cares...some of the songs on the album are too fun to worry about such things.

column1: "Jott Has Changed My Life";"personal/blog/iphone/jott-has-changed-my-life";"You can expect to start seeing some entries on really cool iPhone apps. The latest and greatest one is Jott (http://jott.com). It's a lot more than an iPhone app
column2: but that's how I discovered it.

column1: I had started using the built-in "Notes" application for the iPhone. When I tried to transfer the notes I had taken to my computer
column2: I discovered that you couldn't. Apple hadn't built that yet. Grrr. So I started looking for a new application for taking simple notes.

column1: Jott seemed to fit the bill and had some sort of voice recording feature
column2: so I downloaded it and started playing around. It turns out that it's a lot more than just taking notes. It's a speech-to-text application
column3: but instead of loading a ton of software on your computer and bogging down your system
column4: it sends the piece of recording to its servers
column5: translates
column6: and sends you back the results. It keeps their applications small and lightweight.

column1: I tested it out and it was pretty accurate. When I decided to really push it by speaking however I felt like
column2: it started having problems. It's definitely best to speak clearly and a little slowly. If you come across a word that you think it wouldn't know (like a proper noun)
column3: you can say the word and then spell it out. It figures out what you're doing and spells the word correctly.

column1: Now comes the cool part. They have a toll free number that you can call. From that number
column2: you can do more than just take notes. You can send a text message to someone
column3: you can send an email to someone
column4: you can add items to any type of list you can think of
column5: you can add events to your Google calendar
column6: and much more. It's incredible.

column1: I set up a "To Do" list for myself. David uses it all the time if there's something he wants me to take care of. He calls the number
column2: it asks "What would you like to Jott?"

column1: And then he says something like "Call Kaback K-A-B-A-C-K to schedule repair of air conditioner".

column2: it shows up on my iPhone's to-do list.

column1: I also set up a list for groceries. So if there's something I need to get
column2: I call the number
column3: say "Grocery" and then the name of the item. When I go shopping
column4: I have the list on my iPhone and can check off items as I shop. It's pretty cool.

column1: They also have a website so I can easily type lists of items if I want - as opposed to calling the number.
We've used it for our shared Google Calendar. David set up a day that we are going to Philadelphia to visit his family. I called the toll free number
column2: said "Casa de Gogo" (which is the name of our shared Google calendar)
column3: and said "August 31st
column4: Reich R-E-I-C-H Pool Party". Done.

column1: You can send email as well through Jott
column2: but so far I haven't done that. There are some things that require a personal touch.";"1218279102";"textile"

column1: "Some changes to the site...";"personal/blog/technology/some-changes-site";"I've been steadily making changes to the site. This weekend I had some time to really go to town. It seems like I really didn't do all that much - I don't know where the time goes when I program. I suppose it's because I use my own site as a test ground for changes
column2: so when I work on something
column3: I may spend hours going down a path that I realize was not the right way to go. I chalk it all up to learning experiences.

column2: here's the list of recent additions:

column1: <li>Add a twitter feed. This makes it easy for me to send little snippets about my day to the site.
<li>Add a search box to every page.
<li>Changed the definitions for recipes so I can more easily migrate content from my old site over.
<li>Added boxes on the right for "Recipes by Dish" and "Recipes by Ingredient".
<li>Cleaned up some layout and display issues.
<li>Installed sitemaps and submitted them to the major search engines
Now that I wrote that all down
column2: it does some like a lot for one weekend.

column1: "Lemonade";"personal/recipes/dish/beverages/lemonade";"Today's the day that I got all the recipes moved over from my old site to my new site. So let's celebrate by adding a new recipe!
This summer I've been getting into homemade lemonade. It's really easy to make and is significantly healthier than anything you could buy. And you can make a million variations
column2: so I've had fun experimenting.

column1: Take 2 of the lemons and using a vegetable peeler
column2: peel off the zest in thick strips. Place it in a small saucepan with the sugar and water. Bring everything to a boil. Let it boil for about a minute
column3: then turn off the heat and let the syrup marinate while you juice the lemons. The syrup will turn a little yellow and the zest will turn slightly translucent.

column1: I've made a few variations: I used a grapefruit in place of two of the lemons. I've replaced two lemons with 4 limes. I've put a couple of star anise seeds in the syrup to marinate. They were all successes
column2: but the simple lemonade is the best.
I put a splash of citron vodka in the bottom of the glass before pouring in the lemonade.

column1: "The Marriage of Bette and Boo";"personal/blog/theater/marriage-bette-and-boo";"I saw the Roundabout Theatre's production of The Marriage of Bette and Boo. It was a great production and several days after seeing it
column2: I'm still thinking of it quite a bit. It's one of the few plays I think I could see again and again.

column1: I had seen a production when I was in high school at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival. I still think that production was the best you could possibly see of the play. They absolutely nailed it in every way. However
column2: the Roundabout's production had very different goals and it achieved them
column3: so I can't fault the Roundabout too much. Their production was less of a caricature and more of a real
column4: grounded play. And it works both ways.

column2: I wouldn't recommend a Christopher Durang play to too many people. They are darkly comic
column3: sadistic
column4: and often painful things. The Marriage of Bette and Boo is certainly no different. However
column5: all of his other plays end in total chaos and absurdity. This one always stays so close to home that you can't escape it.

column1: I had remembered a lot of the lines. I could recite almost entire scenes. However
column2: once it got to the end
column3: it all felt new. There were certain scenes I had no memory of whatsoever. I think they are the sort of concepts that someone young could simply never understand. For instance
column4: at the end of the play
column5: the main characters are in a hospital room and reminiscing on their lives together. After watching these characters at each other's throats the entire time
column6: I don't think I understood when I was younger how you can look back on something like and laugh. I didn't understand how a couple could go through a divorce and still call each other during difficult emotional times. Christopher Durang is making a joke at the end by showing them laughing at what are genuinely horrific moments in his childhood. But there's something existential there as well. What are we supposed to do? Harbor resentment that these awful things had happened? Consider our lives a waste because they didn't live up to our expectations? Even if you hated the person you spent the majority of your life with
column7: at the end
column8: it's still the person that you went through life with. Who else are you going to turn to?

column1: It was during this scene I could have easily burst out sobbing for the rest of the play. David and I were with two of our friends
column2: so I had to keep my composure.

I highly recommend going to see The Marriage of Bette and Boo. There are few people that would not recognize some of their family in the play. It feels good to laugh at people for whom I normally would have lost all sense of humor. And if you're willing to go on the emotional journey
column3: the play brings one to a beautiful catharsis.";"1218537921";"textile"

column1: "Triumph the Comic Insult Dog at Comic-Con";"personal/blog/comedy/triumph-comic-insult-dog-comic-con";"Aah...Triumph the Insult Comic Dog. He needs no introduction other than to say that if you are easily offended (or under age 13) you probably shouldn't watch this.
"Photos from Class 1";"personal/blog/photography/photos-class-1";"It took me a while to post these
column2: but here are photos from our first photo walk. We took a stroll around Grand Central Station and the Chrysler Building. Our instructor
column3: Emmanuel
column4: would give us little assignments - such as "set your shutter speed to 1/250 and give me a reading as to what the aperture should be". On some assignments
column5: he gave us all the settings and just told us to take pictures. That allowed us to see how the settings affected the quality of the photo and also to allow us to focus on composition.

column1: We did one exercise at a construction site. The light was catching the bright yellow equipment in an interesting way
column2: so we tried to capture that quality. A family passed by staring at us in confusion. I heard the wife say "it's a photography class" and the husband responded with "yeah
column3: but what the hell are they taking a picture of?"

column2: we were right across the street from the Chrysler building. Emmanuel pointed out that the Chrysler building was reflected in the plain building across the street. The class immediately looked away from the Chrysler building and started taking photos of the reflection. A few tourists were completely baffled as to what we were taking pictures of and kept scanning the building for something interesting.

column1: My photos from this session varied wildly from good to awful. I really wasn't happy with any of them when I got home and was dreading the critique at the next class. However
column2: I was happy with the critique I got. I think my expectations were too high for the first class.

column1: "Photos from Class 2";"personal/blog/nyc/photos-class-2";"Here are photos from our second photo walk. This walk was done in and around Bryant Park. The clouds were wreaking havoc with our settings
column2: so we had to be nimble - and many of my photos came out too dark.

column1: We spent a lot of time working on portraiture in real light situations. Emmanuel showed us various lighting techniques
column2: such as using a reflector. We also experimented with using slow shutter speeds around a fast moving subject for effect.

column1: After the formal part of our class
column2: we were given time to wander around the park and take candid shots. That is not an easy task. I'm not very fast with the camera yet
column3: and people get very uncomfortable if they see you staring a camera at them for a good 30 seconds. A lot of us developed a technique in which we would aim the camera just to the side of the subject
column4: get the settings right
column5: and then quickly point at the subject and take the shot.

column1: I was very happy with a lot of these photos. I even caught a picture of Tom Sproat smiling! That's more rare than any National Geographic nature shot.

"Photos from Class 3";"personal/blog/nyc/photos-class-3";"This week was tough. We had a guest teacher - someone whose name I can't remember. He is a famous street photographer. He gave us his general philosophy about photography and especially street photography. For instance
column2: he suggested that once we feel like we have the shot
column3: step into it the shot by taking a step 1 - 2 feet forward. It makes a big difference. All of a sudden
column4: you feel close to your subject.

column1: Then we went to Times Square to take street shots. I found a young couple making out and decided to take a shot
column2: I had everything ready
column3: then decided to take a big step forward. All of a sudden they stopped making out a looked at me like I was crazy. I hadn't gauged the distance between us very well and I was standing literally right next to them. I couldn't take a shot. I sheepishly left.

column2: I was trying to take a purposely blurry shot of people passing in front of a theater. I was calmly waiting with the camera up to my face for enough people to pass. It seemed like fewer and fewer people were passing by. Then I lowered my camera and realized that tourists had lined up outside of my shot thinking they didn't want to interrupt my photo. I said "thank you" and everyone started passing by again. This time I waited with my camera down
column3: and when enough people were passing by
column4: I quickly got my shot.

column1: It's really hard to take photos in Times Square. There's just too much activity to single out something. I thought I had taken some good photos
column2: but when I got back home I found that most of them were unusable.

column1: There's also one photo of some lighting experiments we did in class.

column2: we went mostly indoors. We went to the apartment of one of the class members for some experiments in indoor portrait work and then some night shots from her balcony.

column1: I didn't come up with any great shots from this class
column2: though I took the most photos from this class out of any of the others. Especially with the night shots
column3: it was hard to determine how the shot was going to turn out. So there was a lot of trial and error.

column1: "The Wrong Losers";"personal/blog/project-runway/wrong-losers";"What is going on with the judges for this season of Project Runway? This is the second week in a row where they sent the wrong person home.
Last week they sent Emily home with her "colorfully exploding breasts" dress. I understand that it wasn't great
column2: but I thought Keith's dress was hideous - no shape
column3: no skill in execution
column4: no real design. And Emily said as much during her exit interview. She knew that her dress was not the real losing dress.

column1: Then this week they sent Kelly home. How can that be? I agree
column2: the outfit was awful. But Blayne's was just as bad and he had a terrible attitude. Every week I think that his 15 minutes of fame are over and he manages to squeak by again. I hope he doesn't end up being the one that clearly doesn't deserve to be in the final three but somehow ends up there anyway.

column1: I've noticed that you can survive a bad week by mouthing off to the judges. Santino got through a couple of challenges that he clearly lost by refusing to admit that there was anything wrong with his outfit. Blayne squeaked by using the same technique.

I think we've entered the phase of the competition where the people that may have wowed me in the first couple of episodes are not able to keep up. And I feel like I have several designers now that I would happily see go.";"1218723823";"textile"

column2: I've been slowly cleaning up my diet.

column1: It started a few months ago when my friend
column2: Sara
column3: and I started eating at Pure Food and Wine about once a week (we plan on eating there once a week
column4: but it probably averages out to every other week). For those of you who don't know
column5: Pure makes solely raw
column6: vegan food. No meat
column7: no dairy
column8: no wheat
column9: no soy
column10: no rice
column11: no cooking anything above a particular temperature. I always love it when I tell people about it and they respond with "What's left?". Uh...fruits

column1: And it's delicious. And not "health food" delicious
column2: but really delicious.

column1: The first few times we went there
column2: I would look forward to it every time I went. Then after a couple of months
column3: it started happening that the morning of our Pure date I would think "Boy
column4: I could really go for hamburger today. I wish we had planned lunch at Pure for tomorrow." I didn't give it much credence
column5: I just went away. It turns out
column6: that's the part that really needed to happen. I think that was when my brain started re-patterning
column7: because the craving for junk food got replaced "I had healthier food and I feel a lot better."

column2: David and I went to our favorite sandwich shop for lunch. I realized that the things I loved about their sandwiches were the vegetables
column3: cheese (I still love cheese)
column4: and their herbal mayo. So I got a veggie sandwich. David asked me if I was detoxing. I said that I honestly crave the veggie sandwich and didn't want the meat. And it was great. I haven't ordered a sandwich there with meat for a while now.

column1: I started making more raw food at home. I started making my own almond milk. The odd thing is
column2: at no point did I miss the old alternatives. Every now and then
column3: I would try the old version of something (like milk in a protein shake) and it would taste "off". It would make me feel heavy and dull-headed.

column1: I should say that I'm still eating meat. I'm still having dairy and I'm still having coffee. I'm still eating sugar and lots of other processed foods. If I get a craving for something
column2: I make no bones about having it. I have no rules about what I will and won't eat. I'm just becoming more and more aware of how I feel afterwards - and unhealthy foods have started dropping by the wayside.
I was home by myself for dinner. That was usually the night I would order barbecue - so I did. I felt LOUSY. I couldn't even finish it. I got cranky. I had a hard time sleeping. And the next morning
column3: my body was doing it's best to evacuate everything in my system.

column1: Geez. Was my system really used to this kind of food at one point? It's a little frightening.

column2: I had lunch at Pure and stopped at the farmer's market on the way home. I made a great salad and we grilled corn and salmon for dinner. Last night I slept great and woke up earlier than usual
column3: bright-eyed and bushy-tailed.

column1: A little side note: I had taken a friend to Pure yesterday for his inaugural visit. I ordered a Strawberry Blond smoothie: it had strawberries
column2: bananas
column3: pineapple and some other delicious things. My friend ordered a ginger shot. He saw the look on my face and said "what? is that bad?" I said absolutely not
column4: it's just kind of advanced for someone that's new to raw food. It cracks me up how people will go to a place like Pure and then order something that is - frankly - difficult to enjoy when the menu is full of genuinely delicious foods that are also healthy. I had a sip of his ginger shot. I had expected it to be pretty strong and intense. It was LIP-SEARINGLY STRONG! My sinuses burned from the tiny sip I had. Then he had a sip of my smoothie and the look on his face said it all. He thought he was drinking the most amazing milkshake of his life. I said "It's okay to eat healthy and enjoy yourself at the same time."

column1: FYI - This post was inspired by reading Renee's beautiful blog: http://reneesrandomthoughts.blogspot.com";"1218727908";"textile"

So here we are. 218 W 15th St. Formerly the Bowery Mission Women's Home. To our east is a Catholic nursery. To our west is a building similar to ours
column2: but broken into a million tiny apartments. David said that during the demolition
column3: several people stopped by and said how happy they were to know that the house was being used as a family residence again. I guess those Bowery Mission Women were not the best neighbors.

column1:
"The New Kitchen";"personal/house/post-renovation/new-kitchen";"

Shortly after finishing the new kitchen
column2: we saw a commercial for Martha Stewart. We were stunned to realize that we had unknowingly (I swear!) built Martha Stewart's kitchen....except we have a better countertop. But in terms of "look and feel" Martha and ourselves are in agreement. This is either very good or very bad. After spending any amount of time in the kitchen
column3: you will be forced to agree that we nailed it. Especially on a summer day
column4: the doors open to the backyard
column5: everyone hanging around the island without me having to yell
column6: "GET OUT OF MY WAY! I'M COOKING." You will soon forget you are in Manhattan. Let's take a tour through the kitchen with David
column7: shall we?

column1: There are two main lighting fixtures in the kitchen. We got both of them at aplace in Soho with hundreds of different lights. You don't buy any individual light
column2: you point out the lights that you like and they make them from scratch for you. That way you can mix and match various styles. For instance
column3: the lighting fixture in the store that matched the one over the island had three lights and we asked for two.

column1: Appliances were a big deal. We cut corners on some items
column2: but not on the appliances. Since David has more experience with high end appliances
column3: he made a lot of the decisions here. The centerpiece (in my opinion) is the double convection oven. A convection oven has a fan in the back to circulate the hot air so that there are no cold spots in the oven - everything cooks evenly
column4: cakes don't rise in the center
column5: and everything cooks faster. It's kind of a miracle. And now we have two of them. Occassionally
column6: I'll be making a big dinner and think
column7: "I'll prebake the tart crust
column8: then put in the chicken and when the chicken is done
column9: I'll put in the...wait. I have two ovens."

column1: When the kitchen was pretty much finished
column2: I said to David
column3: "I'm sorry that I bulldozed every decision into getting my perfect kitchen." David replied with
column4: "What do you mean? I got everything I wanted." ACtually
column5: the base design came from a kitchen place that we lived next door to when we had an apartment on the east side.

"The Creamsicle Room";"personal/house/post-renovation/creamsicle-room";"

When we first renovated the living room
column2: we had picked out a color called "milquetoast" that was very plain beige on the swatch. By the time we got to painting the living room
column3: we were exhausted with renovations. The painters first got paints that were the same number from a different paint manufatcurer. It came out very dark olive green. David came home and said
column4: "wrong
column5: wrong
column6: wrong!" The next day he came home and they had painted a panel with the rigth color
column7: but on the wall it came out very peachy. I didn't say anything because I figured David would tell them the color was wrong. However
column8: the color was right and David was too tired to pick a new color. So our living room became "The Creamsicle Room".

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Gogo poses in front of the hole in the wall that will be the fireplace." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/living_room/old_gogo_fireplace.jpg">
Gogo poses in front of the hole in the wall that will be the fireplace.
Whenever we told people that we weren't sure that the color worked
column2: the response was always "Oh
column3: no
column4: it works great for this room. Don't change anything." When we put in the fireplace we had to repaint and we decided that enough was enough. As soon as we started telling people that we were repainting
column5: the response was always
column6: "Good. This peachy-orange doesn't work."

column1: Here are some pictures with the new paint job.
You can see a close-up of the floor in this picture.
In this is the new centerpiece of the room...the fireplace. It's from the same time period of the house taken from another Manhattan townhouse.
Take a tour of the living room.

column2: false
"myself"
somewhere
column3: I got the idea in my head of creating a bathroom that was almost entirely composed of glass mosaic tile. I figured I could take any image
column4: scan
column5: and use photo editing software to transfer the image into a mosaic. David and I spent a couple of months trying to come up with a good image. I eventually decided that comic book panel would make a good image because the colors are bold
column6: the concept is fun
column7: and we wouldn't lose a lot of details in reducing the image quality down.

column1: I started scouring old X-Men comic books that I had when I was younger. I spent some time tracking down old copies on E-Bay and then trying to find an appropriate image. I settled on a panel from the

Next we had to transfer that image to a workable matrix for laying out the tile. We decided to go with Carter Glass Tile which had a palette of 50 colors. I used those colors to reduce the size of the image down to what we needed to fit the bathroom. There were a lot of conversion and re-measurements. The image below shows the finished product that we used to create the mosaic. The mosaic was built in grids of 15 tiles by 15 tiles. Each square in that image represents approximately 13 inches when assembled.
The other nice thing about Carter Glass tile is that they sold plastic grids so you could build your own mosaics. If we hadn't found that grid
column2: I don't think we would have been able to do the project. The grid is a big plastic waffle of 15 tiles by 15 tiles that you drop the tiles into. Once you have the grid filled
column3: you put contact paper on the tiles and lift the tiles out. That grid then gets labelled and set aside.

column1: We would zoom into each 15x15 square and then turn on one set of colors at a time
column2: using that to build the grid. The image below shows what it looked like to us on the computer. This section is the square that makes on the right eye of the guy in the center.
456 tiles. It took us about 3 weeks to make all the panels. Here are some shots of us putting together the panels.

column1: And this is what it looked like layed out on the floor. Each night we would lay out the day's work as a little reward.
Take a tour of the bathroom under construction.
Take a tour of the bathroom almost finished.

column2: I need to remind myself what the bedroom looked like before. It's one of those things that the memory of the bedroom disappeared about a day after we tore it apart.

column1: The master bedroom was one of the last great rooms in the house that still projected "women's dormitory". It had the industrial grey carpeting
column2: a tiny door frame
column3: and the outline of flourescent lights on the ceiling. Despite all these reasons to renovate
column4: I think the main reason we renovated was because Gogo just did not want to be house-trained in this room. The carpet had so many layers of old carpet
column5: carpet padding
column6: and carpet squares that anything spilled on the floor got permanently absorbed into the floor.

column2: I didn't really want to leave the top floor bedroom. It was cozy
column3: it was simple
column4:
and it was closer to my X-Men bathroom. I was worried that the new master bedroom was a little too fancy.

column1:
"A Renovation in Progress";"personal/house/pre-renovation/renovation-progress";"

We've just begun the final renovation. I've started comparing it to childbirth. Everytime we prepare for renovations
column2: I'm all excited about the final work. Then the demolition starts and I think "Was I crazy for looking forward to this? I want this OVER!" And as soon as the renovation is ended
column3: I think "that wasn't so bad. When's the next one?"

The wall with the windows. So many wires for our high-tech room!
One of the not so wonderful aspects fo this renovation is that we had to do the demolition in two parts. We did the main demolitionof the two rooms on the second floor
column2: then a week later
column3: we had demolition on the first floor. So basically
column4: about the time that the major dust and trauma of the first demolition was over
column5: we got hit with a second dose. Not fun. And now whenever you come into the house
column6: a little bit of dust and plaster falls on you from above. It's quaint
column7: really.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The downstairs hallway without walls" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/hallway.JPG">

Gogo loves the construction for some reason. She always says hello to the guys in the morning and she loves to wander into the construction zone. When they were settting up for the second round of demolition
column2: Gogo and I were still in the bedroom. I was just finishing getting dressed. The workers were taping up all the entrances to minimize the flow of dust into the other rooms. They started to tape up the bedroom
column3: and I heard someone say (do this in your best Brooklyn accent) "Don't tape up that room. Gogo and that guy are still in there.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="More of the first floor hallway" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/hallway_2.jpg">
More of the first floor hallway

column2: false
"myself"

column1:
"Keith's Office";"personal/house/post-renovation/keiths-office";"

Keith's Office (aka The Anti-David Room) has been done in a 70's/Blaxploitation theme. I found some fantastic vintage wallpaper on the internet
column2: a lamp from E-Bay
column3: and pulled out the Pam Grier movie posters that David had never let me hang on the wall.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A shot of Gogo amongst the pieces that will soon be the room." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/office/swanky.jpg">
A shot of Gogo amongst the pieces that will soon be the room.
<a class="thickbox" title="Gogo enjoying the shag carpet in the finished room. No furniture yet." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/gogo-carpet.jpg">
Gogo enjoying the shag carpet in the finished room. No furniture yet.

"The Bollywood Room";"personal/house/post-renovation/bollywood-room";"

The Bollywood Room is done! This was a VERY large project. Building a home theater is certainly not anything new
column2: but somewhere
column3: somehow
column4: I got it into my head that I wanted a Bollywood room. I think this is left over thoughts of wanting a Turkish room that never materialized. But in hindsight
column5: it makes perfect sense - create a home theater celebrating the country that has the biggest film industry in the world.

column1: David and I quickly realized that we were in over hour heads with the technology of it all. We shopped around and decided to go with AV Transformations to help us make decisions and purchase equipment. We also had to figure out how to decorate the room
column2: and once again we thought we were in over our heads. Eventually
column3: with help from Sis and ABC
column4: we found ourselves not needing a special decorator. Whew!

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Here's the layout of the room." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/bollywood/floorplan.gif">
Here's the layout of the room.
<a class="thickbox" title="And these were the main colors and styles we were going for." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/bollywood/colors.jpg">
And these were the main colors and styles we were going for.

column2: let's talk technology. For anyone that's ever tried to plan a home theater
column3: my heart goes out to you. I was practically paralyzed with endless decisions. The audio/visual knowledge that you have to accumulate to make a simple decision is staggering. I constantly changed my mind as to what we wanted. David originally wanted a plasma screen
column4: but I convinced him that front projection is the way to go. We are DEFINITELY happy with the quality of the system. I won't go into all the details of the system. We got a JVC D-ILA projector since it is supposed to match real-life color most accurately. We went with a DENON receiver and DVD player and a 5.1 surround sound system. Yes
column5: it's all as impressive as you would want it to be. And we had a gazillion cables run through the walls.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Here's the screen. David is going through the left closet which has our DVDs. The right closet has all of the A/V equipment." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/moviescreen.jpg">
Here's the screen. David is going through the left closet which has our DVDs. The right closet has all of the A/V equipment.
<a class="thickbox" title="A closeup of the right closet." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/right_closet.jpg">
A closeup of the right closet.

<a class="thickbox" title="This is the projector on the opposite wall of the screen. It is mounted to the wall above and behind the sofa and chair." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/projector.jpg">
This is the projector on the opposite wall of the screen. It is mounted to the wall above and behind the sofa and chair.

Now let's talk design. David and I went to look at furniture and fabric samples several times with no luck. I liked silk designs - he said no silk because it stained too easily. I showed him busy patterns - he didn't like busy. We were going nowhere. Then my sister came to visit and while I was at work
column2: the two of them went to ABC. David called me all excited about the silk paisley pattern that they picked out. I was baffled
column3: but ultimately happy that my sister convinced him where I had failed. And everything is uber-comfortable.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Here's a snapshot of the sitting area." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/streetside.jpg">
Here's a snapshot of the sitting area.
<a class="thickbox" title="A nightstand in between the sofa and chair." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/nightstand.jpg">
A nightstand in between the sofa and chair.
<a class="thickbox" title="The chair. It's soooo comfortable." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/chair.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The coffe table is from India. It was made from an old window shutter." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/coffeetable.jpg">
The coffe table is from India. It was made from an old window shutter.
Now on to lighting. This was a bit of a sopa opera. We got a Morrocan-style chandelier a few months ago for the Turkish room. We thought it would go well in the Bollywood room
column2: so David spent a couple of hours moving it. After a couple of weeks
column3: we realized it didn't go
column4: and David moved it back up stairs. On a trip to ABC
column5: before we had planned anything in the room
column6: we got four lights. Two of them are smaller
column7: pomegranate-shaped lights that we thought would go near the screen on each side
column8: and two larger chandeliers. And best of all: they were CHEAP
column9: CHEAP
column10: CHEAP!!! At one point we thought that we were being too extravagant getting four lamps
column11: but at the prices that we got for them
column12: we would have been fools to not grab them while we had the chance. They are nice
column13: but we later saw the PERFECT chandelier and it actually goes well with the ones we already bought.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="You'll notice the shutters on the windows. These block out all external light so we can watch a movie during the day." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/streetview.jpg">
You'll notice the shutters on the windows. These block out all external light so we can watch a movie during the day.
<a class="thickbox" title="And this ended up not making the cut. How sad." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/pomegranate_light.jpg">
And this ended up not making the cut. How sad.

column2: but up new lights
column3: etc
column4: my friend Sara came to visit and her first comment hit me to the core with my greatest fear: It Was Too Tasteful. So the next weekend
column5: I went and got some artwork for the walls
column6: a new window topper
column7: and some more pillows. It's getting closer in that it's cluttered to start to feel authentic. I'm sure we will eventually get it cluttered to the point of offensive - at which point I'll be REALLY happy.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The topper over the entrance." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/entrance.jpg">

column2: with a carving from India (via Uma
column3: one of my co-workers)
column4: and some brass sculptures from David's parents." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/sideboard.jpg">

column2: with a carving from India (via Uma
