column4: and some brass sculptures from David's parents." src="/files/photos/renovation/sideboard.jpg" width="177" height="200">

column2: with a carving from India (via Uma
column3: one of my co-workers)
column4: and some brass sculptures from David's parents.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A beautiful ganesh carving" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/renovation/ganesh.jpg">
"The Day the Lights Went Out in Manhattan";"personal/blog/blackout/day-lights-went-out-manhattan";"In August of 2004
column2: there was a blackout on much of the Eastern seaboard of the United States. We were in Manhattan when it hit. At first it was a bit exciting
column3: but as the evening approached and we realized we'd have to go through a hot August night without even a fan
column4: I lost my taste for this little adventure.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="So many people walking." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/blackout/walking_home_2.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="There were hundreds of people walking. You can't tell from this picture." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/blackout/walking_home_1.jpg">
There were hundreds of people walking. You can't tell from this picture.

column2: someone would open their car doors and leave their radio on loud enough for other people to hear the news.

column1: Here's an interesting note that I found taped to a door. FYI - Queens is a LONG WAY AWAY! (Don't forget to click on the little magifying glass to see the details)

"The Night the Lights Went Out in Manhattan";"personal/blog/nyc/night-lights-went-out-manhattan";"

What was quite exciting and novel slowly descended into hell by night. It's extremely disorienting to walk around New York City with absolutely no lights on at all. Even after living through it
column2: I can't imagine New York without lights. David thought I was crazy
column3: but I took a brief walk with Gogo after the sun went down. You could hear people all around
column4: and you could see flashlights
column5: but you couldn't see anyone. Gogo was very unnerved.

column1: The night was like a Carribean island. People had brought makeshift drums out on to the street to play music and dance. We tried to read by candle light
column2: but it turns out that candle light is pretty inadequate for reading. We spent most of the evening just lying on the sofa and listening to the handheld radio for news. It was unbelieveably hot.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Gogo enjoyed the heat" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/blackout/candlelight_gogo.jpg">
I went to bad that night expecting to hear the electricity to go on at any minute. I was looking forward to the bright lights
column2: loud radio
column3: and most importantly...THE AIR CONDITIONING! Imagine my disappointment when I woke up at 8 the next morning to the same stultifying heat and humidity in sweat soaked sheets.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Gogo and David snuggle" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/blackout/candlelight_snuggle.jpg">

New York had enjoyed the novelty of the blackout the night before. The thought of a second night of a blackout had everyone pissed and grumpy. Chelsea was one of the last neighborhoods to get their electricity back. David
column2: Gogo
column3:
and I were going to go for YET ANOTHER walk when the electricity finally returned. The news had told us not to turn air conditioning on right away. We decided not to follow that advice.

";"1091336400";"textile"

column1: "A Trip to Ithaca";"personal/blog/family/trip-ithaca";"David and I drove to Ithaca
column2: NY on Monday to help Sis and Lorenz move in. They had not even been here 24 hours by the time we arrived
column3: so it was a chance to catch the two of them before they had settled in. Sis still had a few large pieces of luggage in the car and could not figure out how to get the orange U-Haul straps off the car
column4: so almost immediately after hugs and hellos
column5: we went to work.

column1: Her apartment is nicer than I had expected. It's spacious - considering that's only the two of them for most of the year. Lorenz has a great bedroom. There were a number of things to fix around the apartment and Sis had already started a list. After arranging some things
column2: we put Lorenz in the stroller and headed to the downtown area for dinner.

column1: Ithaca is a very crunchy town. It wasn't until day two here that I found out THE Moosewood Restaurant was founded here. We passed several organic grocers and vegan restaurants. The Ithaca Commons (which is a string of stores and pubs where cars are not allowed) is filled with acoustic musical groups and hacky sack players. David had never heard of hacky sack to which Sis and I expressed reluctant belief.
We found a Mexican restaurant with outdoor seating. The meal was cut short by a passing downpour - but by that time
column2: all I had to do was chug my margarita and run for cover.
we decided to tackle the list of things to fix around the apartment. Sis had a pretty lengthy list that covered things like utensils (she had forgot to bring knives
column3: forks
column4: and spoons)
column5: bed rails for Lorenz
column6: curtains and curtain rods
column7: etc. There is a Target in town. David and I had never been in a Target (to which Sis expressed reluctant belief). I have to admit
column8: Target was pretty amazing. The choices of things to get were actually pretty nice and the prices were shockingly low. Sis wanted to get a $99 sofa
column9: but when she saw me sit in it
column10: she realized it was probably too small. So instead we got a sofa cover for existing large and mildew-smelling sofa.

column1: We got some items for Lorenz as well - a Play-doh set and a Spider-Man lunchbox and thermos.

column2: we took Sis to the "other" daycare center. Sis had gotten accepted
column3: but she had decided to go with another daycare center and was racked with indecision. We took her there so she could check it out. It was a more modern daycare
column4: filled with plastic toys and efficiency. Although everyone was very nice and they had a huge waiting list that Sis had somehow gotten around
column5: Sis felt like she had made the right decision taking Lorenz to Namaste Montessori instead - which is more in the country
column6: uses only toys made of wood and metal
column7: and has other vegetarian kids.

column2: we took sometime to explore the campus. It's up on a hill
column3: over-looking the rest of Ithaca. There's a beautiful river cutting through campus so there are waterfalls and bridges. Sis got us some cool Cornell fashions since today was a bit breezier than we had expected. We saw the building with her office
column4: which looked to be one of the nicer and more character-driven buildings (at least form the outside).

column1: After that we went unloaded the car. I put on the bed rails for Lorenz
column2: David hung up the new curtains. At one point
column3: David said that he felt like he was hanging up curtains for his theoretical daughter. I asked him what he meant and he said "I'm at the age where if I had gotten married and had kids
column4: they would be at the age right now where they'd be going off to college and I'd be here hanging up their curtains in their dorm room."

column1: I told him that we were happy to satisfy the needs of his biological clock.

We drove to Namaste Montessori to pick up Lorenz. The school was very small and cute. The teachers all seemed extremely kind and competent. I could see that Lorenz was in good hands. We drove to the nearby Buttermilk Falls and did a bit of hiking around. Lorenz was in a crabby mood from being both tired and hungry
column2: so we skipped the next waterfall and went for dinner.
so we went for Japanese instead. Lorenz was a lot more pleasant to deal with after he got some food. And we got cold sake to share - making jokes that we were going to change from uncles to drunkles.
we took them home (Lorenz LOVED his Spider-Man lunchbox) and went back to the hotel to crash.

column1: Although I am the Capricorn of the family
column2: I fell like my sister is the true sea-goat. The idea of the Capricorn is that with the front of a goat and the tail of a fish
column3: it stubbornly refuses to accept its limitations and climbs mountains regardless of its lack of hind legs. How my sister could pack up her son and just enough items to get by
column4: drive across the country to rent an apartment she'd never seen in a new town is beyond me. It's of course a good career choice
column5: but it's quite a sacrifice and not an easy road. Things will be easier when her husband Mark comes to visit but that's several months away. I don't think I could ever make the choice that she did.

column2: brother-in-law
column3: and uncle of the year award for taking care of Sis. And I told him as much. ";"1219234383";"textile"

column1: "The New York City Waterfalls";"personal/blog/nyc/new-york-city-waterfalls";"Last weekend was one of those perfect summer days in NYC - blue skies
column2: billowy clouds that show off every last detail
column3: and not too sweltering. Mr. R and Benji were in town
column4: so I asked them if they wanted to go on a short cruise to see the NYC Waterfalls. The answer was yes and David agreed.

column1: We headed down to South Street Seaport to get tickets from one of the cruises that leaves from down there. Apparently
column2: we were one of several hundred other people that had the same idea. The lines were long and didn't move. We quickly bagged the idea of the cruise and decided to just look at the waterfalls from afar
column3: which still ended up being a good idea.

column1: I think one's first reaction to the waterfalls is "meh". But the more you look at them
column2: the more it helps you appreciate the fact that New York is an island with all of these great waterways with their own life. The one at the Brooklyn Bridge seemed to be the best because the bridge blocks the wind. The other two that we could see were being blown so strongly that it was more of a mist-producer than a waterfall.

column1: After the viewing we went for ice cream and then to the TKTS booth
column2: where Benji and Mr. R got tickets to The Marriage of Bette and Boo.

column1: "Photos of Ithaca";"personal/blog/family/photos-ithaca";"I posted my photos from my first trip to Ithaca.
There are a lot of pictures of taking Lorenz out on his tricycle. Then photos of his day care - Namaste Montessori. And finally
column2: pictures form a trip that David
column3: Sis and I took to Lucifer Falls.

column1: "A Trip to Ithaca: Part 2";"personal/travel/ithaca-ny/trip-ithaca-part-2";"So...I was just in Ithaca. But Mom flew out pretty much right after I left to help take care of Lorenz. It would have been a shame that Mom had traveled all that way and we wouldn't have been able to see each other - so I packed a bag and drove to Ithaca again. At least this time I knew the scenic road to take. And since David wasn't with me this time
column2: I could crank up the music and shout/sing to my heart's content.

column1: A lot of time was spent just hanging out at the house. The second day I was there
column2: Mom and Lorenz and I drove around Cayuga lake
column3: stopping at wineries and other local sites. It was stunningly beautiful. At one stop
column4: Lorenz saw a necklace with wine corks and fake grapes. He went bonkers for that necklace. I tried to take some photos
column5: but they didn't capture his squealing glee and ecstasy that came from the necklace. We almost bought it. We decided for 8 bucks
column6: it was worth the entertainment value. But he lost interest in about 30 seconds so we skipped it.

column1: On the morning of the day I left
column2: we all went to the Ithaca Farmer's Market. There was a ton of fresh produce
column3: some homemade pastries (like apple-poppy seed strudel)
column4: musicians and all sorts of modern hippie goodness. Honestly
column5: Ithaca is the sort of town I think I could settle into.

column2: I went on the American Kennel Club website and started poking around. I hadn't even thought of getting another dog. However
column3: I noticed that it eased the pain to look at pictures of other dogs and think that maybe someday
column4: in the future
column5: I would get a new dog. At the time
column6: I felt like I let months pass before I started researching breeds with the intention of another dog. In hindsight
column7: it was more like a week.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Lucy and Her Litter" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/litter.jpg">
David and I had decided that we wanted to get a puppy. And if we were to get a puppy
column2: we would either have to know someone whose dog we liked that was having a litter or we would have to get a breeder. Considering that we wanted to take the new dog to play with kids
column3: we had to know that the dog we were getting was friendly. So I started systematically going through the AKC website and researching breeds.

column1: I can't even remember now what my original attraction was to Canaan Dogs. I suppose it was the easy grooming
column2: the good health records
column3: the "dogly" disposition and the intelligence. So I contacted Parker Flowers (I got his name from the CDCA as a contact in Rhode Island) and he suggested I come out to Renee's house to meet her recently born litter and her gang of adult Canaan Dogs.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="As close to a show position as she'll ever get. This was the best of three photos." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/stacked.jpg">
As close to a show position as she'll ever get. This was the best of three photos.

Renee is a proud owner (most of the time) of many Canaan Dogs. You can check out her whole pack at Renegade Canaan Dogs. Before I came to Renee's both she and Parker warned me about how aloof Canaan Dogs can be with strangers and that the reaction I get at the beginning is not what they're like once they get used to you.

column2: three of her dogs came right up to me to check me out. They said hello and hung around for a little attention. Both Parker and Renee said that this was atypical. Later
column3: when they brought Lucy out
column4: they mentioned that she was hormonal and may act rather strange and aloof. She came up to me wagging her tail and was very affectionate. Once again
column5: not the usual reaction. Luckily
column6: one of Renee's dogs
column7: Oren
column8: did live up to the stand-offish reputation that Parker and Renee promised.

column1: She then brought out all the little furballs. They seemed to have no idea where they were. One of them would be standing in the middle of the room and would start crying for no reason. (I'm pretty sure that was Gogo). Anyway
column2: after meeting the whole gang
column3: the mother
column4: and some other adults
column5: I knew I had stumbled onto to something great
column6: and put a deposit down on a pup.

column2: Petunia." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/gogo_and_petunia.jpg">
Petunia." src="/files/photos/gogo/gogo_and_petunia.jpg" width="384" height="256">
Petunia.
it was a matter of waiting. I was still quite sad about Dorian
column3: and was not ready for a puppy quite yet. David was putting pressure on me to wait
column4: because we were scheduled to get Gogo the week before we moved. Luckily
column5: I had friends that talked me out of waiting. What is a good time to get a new puppy? Always. I thought of it as a wonderful way to break up the monotony of packing and moving. Plus
column6: that was when our apartment was two blocks from my job
column7: and I was hoping for a leg up (so to speak) on housetraining.

column1: I did get a chance to drive out to New Jersey to meet the litter again when they were eight weeks old. At this point
column2: we pretty much figured that I was getting Gogo. Renee had taken them all for personality tests and she seemed like the best match for me. I now know that what Renee meant by that was that Gogo was a trouble-maker. I also told Renee that we were probably going to name her Gogo. It didn't fly with Renee. Luckily
column3: Parker was there and thought it was an appropriate name.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The whole clan at eight weeks. Gogo is the left-most puppy." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/eight_week_litter.jpg">
The whole clan at eight weeks. Gogo is the left-most puppy.

"When I Met Gogo";"personal/blog/gogo/when-i-met-gogo";"

Little Gogo was born on January 9th. Her mom's name is Lucy. My mom's name is Lucy. Do you feel some cosmic force at hand? I do
column2: too.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This photo was taken by Renee on the day I picked Gogo up." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/greeting.jpg">
This photo was taken by Renee on the day I picked Gogo up.
My sister drove with me out to Renee's to pick Gogo up. The ride back was fairly uneventful. When we left
column2: Gogo started shivering for a while
column3: but eventually calmed down. No crying. Sis is very good at comforting puppies.

column1: We got home and David was there packing. We all played with Gogo and she seemed quite happy. Lots of frolicking.

column2: I thought I'd get her used to her crate and put her in while I went to take a shower. There was a little crying. No problem. Never let a crying dog out of a crate. The crying turned into screaming. This is difficult
column3: but I'll be strong. The screaming turned into sounds I never heard come out of a dog before. It was the sound of a dog losing its mind. At its height
column4: it turned into the sound of a hyena. Out of sheer panic and torture from having to hear those sounds
column5: I let her out of her crate. Gogo wins.

column2: when I would leave for work
column3: I would begin to hear her cry as I left. However
column4: a couple of times I came home a few hours later and she was still crying. It happened once that a friend of ours was at the apartment packing and happened to call me at work. I could barely hear him from the sounds of Gogo in the background. I ran right over and she just seemed out of her mind with grief.

column1: These pictures of from that first week with Gogo and the last week in our old apartment.
The one time Gogo's crying has worked to an advantage is the first night we tried to have her sleep in her crate. The crying started. The crying turned to screaming. Eventually
column2: David said "I know I'm going to regret this for the next fourteen years
column3: but..." and let Gogo out and put her on our bed. And she's been hogging the bed ever since.

column1:
"Gogo In the New House";"personal/blog/gogo/gogo-new-house";"

So then we moved into the new house. She spent a lot of time riding in my gym bag (finally a good use for it) on trips to and from the new house.
<a class="thickbox" title="Her head isn't as big as it seems in this picture." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/big_head.jpg">
Her head isn't as big as it seems in this picture.
There's a small room on the second floor that we had declared Gogo's Room. It faces the street
column2: so I figured
column3: when she got older
column4: she could sleep on a chair in the room and look out the window at people passing by. How quaint. Of course all she did in her room was scream and rip up the carpet. A man across the street left notes about how much she cries and was concerned about her well-being. He talked to our dog-walker
column5: Melanie
column6: one day and threatened to report us to the ASPCA. She explained that Gogo has her own room
column7: bigger than a lot of other people's rooms in Manhattan. I did meet him one day
column8: and I think he was disappointed to find out that I wasn't an ogre.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Gogo chewing something. Imagine that." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/chewing.jpg">
It was also around this time that I took Gogo to a puppy playgroup. It was sponsored by my vet for puppies under the age of 16 weeks
column2: since puppies that young shouldn't be out on the street or going to the dog run. Everyone had their sweet little fluff balls with them. I figured that Gogo came from such a big family
column3: that she would have no problems socializing. She sat on my lap and wouldn't move. If a puppy came up to us
column4: she would growl and bare her teeth. Eventually
column5: she stepped off my lap and everyone said
column6: "Oh good
column7: she's coming out of her shell!" They soon regretted her new found confidence as she began systematically bullying every dog there. She would run up and pounce on other puppies
column8: corner them and nip at them
column9: knock them over - anything to prove her superiority. Now add to this new Gogo sounds - snarling
column10: barking
column11: growling; when they do sound effects in movies for vicious dogs
column12: it doesn't sound this frightening. I tried to smile and say the typical bad owner phrase - "She's usually not like this." And to be honest

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Gogo helping out with the housecleaning." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/dust_pan.jpg">
Gogo helping out with the housecleaning.
<a class="thickbox" title="Girls and their shoes." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/shoes.jpg">
"Gogo: Queen of the Jungle";"personal/blog/gogo/gogo-queen-jungle";"During the summer of the first renovation
column2: Gogo's favorite spot to hang out was in the backyard. It happened once that she figured out how to get loose from the top floor and wandered through a construction zone down three flights of stairs to hang out in the backyard. From then on
column3: we asked the guys on the ground floor if they would mind just keeping an eye on her in the backyard.

"Gogo the Moray Eel";"personal/blog/gogo/gogo-moray-eel";"

I recently went into our bedroom looking for Gogo. She was nowhere in sight. As I looked around for her
column2: I heard a thump and saw a paw quickly flash out from under the bed. Gogo was having a grand time doing her impression of a moray eel. I grabbed the camera and documented her performance.

"President's Day Weekend 2002";"personal/blog/gogo/presidents-day-weekend-2002";"

Evan and Renee came by for a visit on President's Day Weekend. They came with Isaac and Elena (I guess they felt like having all blonde dogs). Gogo loved having everyone visit. She wanted to show off her tennis ball catching skills
column2: but when I threw the tennis ball
column3: Isaac appeared out of nowhere and snatched it in mid-air while Gogo was patiently waiting for it to come right to her. I gave a chew treat to Isaac after I got him to speak. I got a chew treat ready for Elena
column4: and when I asked
column5: "What tricks does Elena know?"

column2: Renee
column3: Evan
column4: and Elena walking with the Empire State Building in the background." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/presidents_2002/empire_walking.jpg">

column2: Renee
column3: Evan
column4: and Elena walking with the Empire State Building in the background." src="/files/photos/gogo/presidents_2002/empire_walking.jpg" width="450" height="335">

column2: Renee
column3: Evan
column4: and Elena walking with the Empire State Building in the background.

column1: Both Evan and Renee said at the same time
column2: "Elena doesn't know any tricks."

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Evan and the poopy-paw girl." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/presidents_2002/evan_elena.jpg">

column2: I thought. That's not like Renee to not teach her dogs any tricks." This was clue number one that Renee is really a softie.

talked and relaxed. Elena came over and put her paws in my lap for some attention. I noticed that I now smelled like dog poop. Elena was tracking it all through the house. Evan took Elena in the bckyard to clean off her paws
column3: Renee grabbed some cleaner and started cleaning the floor
column4: and I went to change my pants. When I got back
column5: Renee started grilling me:"

column2: this smells like kibble poop. Are you feeding Gogo kibble?"
Renee. I have never fed Gogo kibble."

column1: "What's that bag on the shelf? That's a bag of kibble!"
"We've had that bag as long as you've known us. It's the same size as it always is. It's leftover from our previous dog and we keep it in case of an emergency."

column2: I remembered that Gogo had spent last weekend at a kennel
column3: and was fed kibble. I was off the hook as far as Renee was concerned. I was actually glad that it was kibble poop
column4: becuase we could locate it via smell to clean it up.

column2: I was anxious to get all the dogs out fo the house. We went for a walk along Chelsea Piers. It was then that I saw my second clue that Renee is not the tough-mama that she claims to be. ISAAC PULLS ON THE LEASH AND RENEE DOESN'T DO ANYTHIGN ABOUT IT!! How many times has she teased me for being a softie and letting Gogo walk all over me? Well
column3: I captured it all on camera.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This photo is blurry because Isaac was pulling SO HARD that the camera couldn't capture it." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/presidents_2002/pulling.jpg">
This photo is blurry because Isaac was pulling SO HARD that the camera couldn't capture it.

We also had a fun little adventure when we first got to the water front. There's a four foot high concrete wall between the sidewalk and the water that's 10-15 feet below. Gogo wanted to see over the edge
column2: so I lifted her up to look at the ducks and the water. Evan said
column3: "Up
column4: Gogo." and all of a sudden
column5: in one leap
column6: Isaac jumped up and over the wall. Renee screamed and held on to his leash and was afraid that she was now strangling him as he was dangling over the edge of a concrete wall. However
column7: on the other side of the wall
column8: is about one foot of space that Isaac had managed to land on. Isaac is very
column9: very lucky.

column1: After that we had a relaxing walk through the piers. Renee still insisted on teaching Isaac agility commands and had him jumping over benches and walking up and down steps. I started teaching Gogo a little bit of walking and jumping. And no one taught Elena anything - she just enjoyed the day.
<a class="thickbox" title="Gogo having an Evan appreciation monment." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/gogo/presidents_2002/gogo_evan.jpg">
Gogo having an Evan appreciation monment.

Evan and Renee playing with their camera.

Gogo's a little nervous being so close to water. Water is evil.

"A Night at the W";"personal/blog/gogo/night-w";"

The first night of the fire
column2: we had to stay at a hotel. Luckily
column3: the W Hotel at Union Square accepted dogs.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Trying to get the little princess to calm down." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/w-hotel/on-the-floor.jpg">
Trying to get the little princess to calm down.
The was Gogo's first experience with post-modern decorating and she was clearly tantalized by it. As soon as she got into the room
column2: she started running around like a crazy person. I don't know if it had anything to do with the fact that the comforter was down
column3: but when she jumped on the bed
column4: she crouched down and started chewing aimlessly. Go figure.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Gogo distracted from chewing" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/w-hotel/bed-distracted.jpg">
She did eventually calm down and the second night we actually felt refreshed when we woke up.

"Daddy's Girl";"personal/blog/gogo/daddys-girl";"

There's just no denying that Gogo knows how to show favoritism. Although I'm usually the one that gets attention
column2: Gogo definitely knows how to snuggle up to David and say "I'm a Daddy's Girl!"

"And then there's Oz!";"personal/blog/oz/and-then-theres-oz";"

As fate would have it
column2: in the summer of 2005
column3: we adopted little Isaac
column4: Gogo's younger half-brother. He was raised in the city
column5: and seemed to enjoy coming back after living at Renee's place for a few weeks. We re-christened him "Oz"
column6: since that was the name we were going ot give Gogo if we had gotten a boy. We've since discovered that it's a good name for him
column7: because he's got the courage of the Cowardly Lion
column8: the clumsiness of the Scarecrow
column9: and he's as squeaky as the Tin Man. He whimpers at just about everything.

Gogo spent the morning destroying a stuffed animal in the Bollywood room. The room was completely dark. We turned on the light and saw nothing but white fluffy carnage.

"Fun with Wide Angle Lenses";"personal/blog/gogo/fun-wide-angle-lenses";"

David got me a new camera - a Konica Minolta DSLR
column2: with a wide-angle lens. Although these aren't as extreme as I was hoping to get
column3: I still had fun. Here are some shots of the dogs with a wide angle lens.

column1:
"Trip to Oregon: Dinner at Home";"personal/blog/family/trip-oregon-dinner-home";"

The next day
column2: we decided to take it easy
column3: make a nice dinner at home
column4: and invite friends over. We started with a look at the grill. I knew we could do much better
column5: so Mom and I went to Home Depot and we got ourselves a new charcoal grill. And of course
column6: there's no sense in throw the same old briquettes on a charcoal grill
column7: so we got a starter chimney and some real wood charcoal. Man
column8: what a difference it all makes in the flavor.

column1:
"Trip to Oregon: Day at Lincoln Beach";"personal/blog/family/trip-oregon-day-lincoln-beach";"

One of my goals during my unemployment was to get back to Oregon for a visit. And if I was going to get everything I could out of Oregon
column2: that meant a trip to the coast.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Dad and I along the beach" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/oregon/images/dad_keith_beach.jpg">
Dad and I along the beach

column2: Dad
column3: and I left after lunch and took a lazy drive to Lincoln City. We were hoping to stop at the Sea Gypsy motel and walk along where they fly kites
column4: but it must not have been windy enough because we didn't see any kites. Instead
column5: we went to the Salishan lodge and walked a nature trail to the beach. Unlike the East Coast
column6: the Oregon coast is not a mob scene. There were a few people here and there that would pass by - some savouring the introspection that comes with a walk on the pacific coast and others gleefully saying hello
column7: excited by the good fortune of the weather. Unlike most days on the Oregon coast
column8: there was barely a cloud in the sky. There was a mildly cool breeze blowing off the ocean. In the distance
column9: we saw a helicopter inspecting some boat off the coast.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Mom and I along the beach" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/oregon/images/mom_keith.jpg">
Mom and I along the beach
<a class="thickbox" title="Mom putting on her shoes" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/oregon/images/mom_shoes.jpg">

column2: we went up to Charlene's for a drink. She has a brand new house in Salishan - very serene and picturesque. There was a squirrel taking full advantage of the bird feeder on her porch. He munched on sunflower seeds the entire time we were there. Next
column3: I went to Michael's house (also in Salishan) to check out his home theater. Unfortunately
column4: we didn't have time to see anything in action
column5: but I got some good advice when it's time for me to build my home theater.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A squirrel on Charlene's patio" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/oregon/images/squirrel.jpg">

column2: we met at the Bay House on the ocean. The food was great and we caught a fantastic sunset over the water.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="At the Bay House" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/oregon/images/restaurant.jpg">

column2: the Reich family spends the second to the last week in a villa on top of St John in the Virgin Islands. I have been lucky enough to be invited have spent four years now vacationing in the Carribean.

column1: A welcome spelled out in shells was waiting for us when we drove up to the villas. I can't remember what it spells out at the bottom. I believe it's Sunset Ridge Villas
column2: which is the name of the time share.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Even the shells welcome you..." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/welcome.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The door to one of the villas" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/reich-door.jpg">
The door to one of the villas
<a class="thickbox" title="The view to the south over looking St John" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/patio.jpg">
The view to the south over looking St John
<a class="thickbox" title="The view south east. It was more impressive in person." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/patio-view.jpg">
The view south east. It was more impressive in person.
<a class="thickbox" title="Ben and Batya drying off after a swim. You can see St Thomas in the background." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/pool.jpg">
Ben and Batya drying off after a swim. You can see St Thomas in the background.
<a class="thickbox" title="I believe this was the fifth screening of 101 Dalmations." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/dalmatians.jpg">
I believe this was the fifth screening of 101 Dalmations.

We always take one day to go out sailing with a local sailing tour captain by the name of Captain Phil. He takes us out to remote snorkeling locations. This is usually the trip that makes me forget about my life in New York.

Here's a picture of Captain Phil. We're just beginning to leave the St. John harbor. We've always been very lucky weather-wise on our boat excursions. I believe that one year we had a little bit of ran on the way back
column2: but it always returned to sunny very quickly.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Here we are leaving the St John harbor. That's Captain Phil." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/capn-phil.jpg">
Here we are leaving the St John harbor. That's Captain Phil.
Here's a picture of David as we're anchoring near an island.
<a class="thickbox" title="Here we are at anchor at one of our stops." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/st-james.jpg">
Here we are at anchor at one of our stops.
These photos were taken during a day at our favorite beach spot
column2: Trunk Bay. It's right next to the more exotically named "Cinnamon Bay"
column3: so I've used that name for the journal entry. We found this bay one day when we were at Cinnamon Bay and David and I rented a kayak and paddled over here. The water is not too rough
column4: it's not too crowded
column5: the snorkleing's not too bad...this would definitely be the beach that Goldilock's would pick.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Our camp is set up." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/cinnamon-bay-day.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="Everyone's relaxed. It's hard not to be." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/stjohn/images/cinnamon-bay-camp.jpg">
Everyone's relaxed. It's hard not to be.
The favorite Reich Family dining destination is Chateau Bordeaux. It's a little French restaurant in the middle of the island at the top of a mountain.
I never seem to get tired of snorkeling in St. John. Unfortuantely
column2: these photos do not capture how much there is to see underwater.

column1: This pictures probably look like no big deal. It's a shame because I was looking at hundreds of fish of the brightest colors I had ever seen. Apparently
column2: the magnificence of tropical fish doesn't show up when using a disposable underwater camera. Go figure.

Lorenz: One Week Old";"personal/blog/lorenz/my-nephew-lorenz-one-week-old";"

Is this the most flattering picture in the first week of Lorenz' life? No. Is it accurate in that Sis' eyes are closed
column3: Mark looks exhausted
column4: and Lorenz is barely holding off a crying jag with a look of "if you don't feed me in five minutes
column5: I'm having a meltdown"? Yes! Zoom into the photo to get the full effect. I was in Minnesota to capture some moments in Lorenz's first and second week.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Smile! You have no choice." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/PICT0070.jpg">

column2: let me say that it is exceedingly cruel to take pictures of such a newborn baby and post them. The poor guy didn't have a lot to say except "feed me". When I first arrived
column3: he was barely opening his eyes. By the time a left
column4: he was starting to look around and recognize me as "Not Mommy". It might have been my imagination
column5: but his wild limb flailing seemed to be more controlled. And of course
column6: he was starting to hold his own head up after just a week and a half! What an incredible baby!

column1: This is a familiar sight. Sis is looking like she just woke up or she's about to fall asleep. Which was pretty much always true. More shocking than seeing my sister as a mother was seeing her awake so damn much of the time! Also
column2: I should note that when I first showed up
column3: the dogs were not allowed on the furniture anymore. After several days of realizing that Sis and Mark would have to enforce that rule
column4: they gave up. This picture came late in the trip when Mel and Eugene were allowed back on the furniture. And speaking of Mel and Eugene
column5: I took some pictures of just them so they wouldn't feel left out.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Eugene with a chew toy." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/PICT0044.JPG">

Mel under the table - one of his favorite spots.
<a class="thickbox" title="Mark holding Mel - the ORIGINAL baby" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/PICT0045.jpg">
Mark holding Mel - the ORIGINAL baby

column2: you're probably saying to yourself
column3: "I came here for baby pictures. Where are the baby pictures?" Well
column4: they're coming. Unfortunately
column5: only half of the photos that I took actually turned out. David got me a new camera recently and I have to actually learn the fundamentals of photography to really use correctly. So the majority of the baby pictures didn't turn out. Here are some that did.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="In his diaper changing bed. He HATES having his diaper changed." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/PICT0042.JPG">

In a beautiful hat and sweater knitted by Mary Lou Reich.
<a class="thickbox" title="We took a picture because he looked like all butt." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/PICT0075.jpg">
We took a picture because he looked like all butt.
And I'm saving the cutest photo for last. Sis and Lorenz often fell asleep on the sofa together. In this photo
column2: they fell asleep 180 degrees from each other.

Lorenz » A Trip to California";"personal/blog/lorenz/my-nephew-lorenz-trip-california";"

Lorenz and Sis recently went to Yuba City
column3: California for Aunt Beth's 50th Birthday party. I believe that most everyone of the Everett clan was there
column4: so it was a chance for Lorenz to see what he's in store for him. And also for Sis to see her relatives and probably get teased for being short. Unfortunately
column5: I wasn't there
column6: so I don't have the full scoop. But Mom sent me these pictures of Lorenz. And the other big unfortunate is that there is a great picture of Lorenz with a huge smile
column7: but the photo came out blurry. He's about 6 or 7 weeks old in these photos.

column2: my sister
column3: Christine
column4: came to New York for a conference with my five month old nephew
column5: Lorenz. We got him to ourselves over the weekend
column6: so we hired a baby-sitter: the sitter of a friend of ours
column7: Rhonda. And to add to the excitement
column8: Gogo and Oz's breeder came to town on Saturday with her husband and their 8 month old baby
column9: Ian. It was to be known as...

column1: To make life a little more difficult
column2: Gogo had come home from knee surgery on Thursday. She was still pretty dopey that weekend
column3: but was coming along nicely.

let me say that Lorenz at 5 months was about the easiest baby I've ever seen. He almost never cried
column3: and when he did
column4: it didn't last more than a minute or two. He was occassionally a little cranky at feeding time
column5: but nothing too bad.

<a class="thickbox" title="Gogo in the sun smiling at David" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/Baby-Invasion/Happy-Gogo.jpg">
Gogo in the sun smiling at David

Just the walk to the river had done us in. The heat was really sweltering. We all hung out in the shade on the pier. Oz was having a hard time walking on parts of the street that were dark because the pavement was hurting his paws.

column2: exhausted from the heat." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/Baby-Invasion/Wiped-Out-From-Heat.jpg">
exhausted from the heat." src="/files/photos/lorenz/Baby-Invasion/Wiped-Out-From-Heat.jpg" width="600" height="400">
exhausted from the heat.

column1: We got back to the house and had a bit of a crash. Lorenz went upstairs to nap. Ian crashed on the New York Times chair.

column2: which was delicious. Ian woke up and had a bit of a begging episode with David. He was determined to have more peaches. You can see that he was quite good at charming some food out of David.

column1: Gogo took a little nap from the safety of underneath the piano.
I like to say that Oz was bred to blend in with Ralph Lauren furniture.
That was the big baby invasion. We still had several days of Lorenz and Sis.
Oz seemed to appoint himself the babysitter. He never really got close enough to Lorenz to let anything happen. Near the end of the week
column2: he would saunter up to Lorenz for an attempted lick
column3: but most of the time he would park himself near Lorenz
column4: but not close enough for Lorenz to touch him.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Lorenz and Oz in the Living Room" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/Baby-Invasion/Lorenz-and-Oz-in-Living-Room.jpg">
Lorenz and Oz in the Living Room
Gogo loved having Sis around. She slept with Sis almost every night that she was here. Whenever she could
column2: Gogo would try to get some sympathy from Sis.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Lorenz in the Backyard" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/Baby-Invasion/Happy-Lorenz.jpg">

column2: that I felt that I had to capture a picture of him crying
column3: just to prove that he does it. Here's a picture that you can show a future prom date:

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Gogo and Oz keeping an eye on Lorenz from a respectful distance" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/lorenz/Baby-Invasion/Lorenz-Oz-and-Gogo-Outside.jpg">
Gogo and Oz keeping an eye on Lorenz from a respectful distance
Here's a nice series of Sis playing with Lorenz. I could pick a favorite photo
column2: so I've included all of them.

column1: "A Dream from Israel";"personal/blog/learning/dream-israel";"I'm writing this from Israel. Once again
column2: Israel has totally knocked my socks off
column3: but in an entirely different way. When I was here before I was primarily struck by all the religious sites. This time
column4: I'm struck more with the people. Israelis generally have the reputation of being loud and pushy people. Yes
column5: that's true.

column1: While David and I were in Tel Aviv I pointed out that not only is everyone in exceedingly good shape
column2: the majority of the poopulation moves with a natural grace and vitality that I've never seen before in a whole country. Everyone has incredible posture and moves with athletic ease. I asked him if he thought it was the compulsory military training that did it. His theory is that first of all
column3: it is largely an outdoor-loving people. They are active and appreciate what life has to offer. Secondly
column4: Israeli children are not born with the same restrictions placed on them as American children. Even the teenagers run a little wild - but not wild in a malicious and loud way
column5: but in a "do as you please" sort of way. They are treated as adults - with more than a few lectures
column6: I'm sure - and are not controlled.

column2: most of David's colleagues that we've met here are incredibly interesting people. We met one colleague that makes his own wine in his basement. He showed us his set up in the basement where wine is pressed and stored in barrels for a year at a time. He bottles his own beer. He took us hiking in the desert. We met one of David's colleagues here in Tel Aviv. She talked about how she goes bicycling along the Mediterranean. She's taking salsa classes. None of these people seem bogged down by life or by a daily grind at all.

column1: Last night I had vivid dreams about it all. I was at a writer's conference at one point
column2: and I was my usual self - reserved about showing my work and letting other people take the spotlight. At one point
column3: an instructor came up to me and said "There are no consequences here. Be bold." - which by that he meant no bad consequences. So put yourself out there!

column1: So I've made up my mind: when I get back to the states
column2: I'm taking a class in photographic lighting (to continue by photography hobby)
column3: I'm starting swimming again
column4: I'm sending off Betsy Stevens to publishers
column5: I'm writing - I'm done being bogged down with limitations and exceptions. ";"1221536750";"textile"

column1: "My Folding Bicycle";"personal/blog/nyc/my-folding-bicycle";"I came from Israel with many goals. One of them was to lose my extra weight. It's gotta go. Another goal was to enjoy more of NYC. I was definitely in a day-to-day rut. So I decided that one of the things that I could do to combat both of those was to ride a bicycle around town more often. I talked to my friend Jeff about starting to trade out days at the gym with long bike rides. We could bike along the water-front
column2: we could bike to new neighborhoods
column3: etc.

column1: Jeff has a folding bike and loved it. I decided to get one
column2: too
column3: so that I could keep it in the entryway for easy access. I fell in love with it almost instantaneously. Since it's a folding bike
column4: I can take it on the subway with me. We could go to Brooklyn and bicycle around Prospect Park or Ocean Bay or wherever. And folds down small enough to fit underneath our coat rack.

column2: let me just say that seeing pictures and reading a journal of someone else's trip is like trying to imagine what a meal tastes like by seeing pictures of the food. It doesn't even come close. Especially on a trip to Turkey and Greece - not only do the photos not do justice to the sites
column3: but they do not capture the 99% of everything going on between the photos. To experience the Old City of Rhodes at night
column4: for instance
column5: you have to go there and experience it. So go there and see it because everything on this trip was worth it.

column1: One more caveat - I took most of this journal on my palm-top and so there may be glitches in the hand-writing recognition software.

column2: we got very lucky with the weather - we only saw a few clouds in Istanbul and the rest of the trip was clear blue. Although you didn't want to hang out in the hot sun
column3: there was usually a breeze to come through to prevent it from being too much. So
column4: here's the journal...

column1: We're about to take off from JFK. They also let us hang out in the Admiral's club and gave us each 2 drinks. David and I got upgraded but we can't sit together. We thought we could trade seats but we have two middle seats and I'm sitting between two large businessmen that would no way want to give up their aisle for middle seats. Personally
column2: I feel a little petite in these huge new business class seats. I'm looking right now and David doesn't have anyone to his right. We may still get lucky. American Airlines has been good to us.

column1: We didn't get lucky. David says that the woman that didn't move got a bad case of the hiccups as divine retribution. The flight was very calm with excellent service. Hopefully
column2: Heathrow will have a paper showing who won Survivor last night. We are scheduled to land in a half hour.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This will soon be us!" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/ship1.jpg">

"Arriving in Istanbul (formerly Constantinople (formerly Byzantium))";"personal/travel/turkey/arriving-istanbul-formerly-constantinople-formerly-byzantium";"

I think I might have just blown out the charger for my palmtop. I had it plugged in to the evil
column2: foreign outlets and there was a puff of smoke from the charger. Hmmmm....

column1: It's the Morning after arriving in Istanbul. I had a hard time sleeping. I kept dreaming about work and Survivor.
When we drove in from the airport I was struck at just how foreign this culture is to ours. At first
column2: the taxi ride was playfully dangerous. After we passed an accident
column3: it wasn't so playful. The cab driver did not speak English. He offered us a cigarette. Take that New York. The road took us around the edge of the city along the water. Istanbul is closer to a third world city than I expected. It's not as European as I was expecting
column4: but I've not been to other Middle Eastern cities.

column2:
we called our tour guide and went to a shish kebab place for dinner. The food was very good and covered with olive oil. Most everyone here is very thin. Go figure.

";"962946000";"textile"

column1:
"First Day in Istanbul";"personal/travel/turkey/first-day-istanbul";"

The hotel is very nice. For breakfast there was a fresh honeycomb dripping honey and next to it
column2: three different types of honey. The food in Turkey is great.

column1: I'm finding if hard to describe my first full day in Istanbul. We went to a very old Byzantine church
with beautiful mosaics on the ceilings. Our tour guide was very good and pointed out many of the intricacies of the artwork that I'm sure I would not have noticed otherwise.
<a class="thickbox" title="This is the base of one of the pillars in the cistern - an upside down sculpture of the head of medusa." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/cistern_medusa.jpg">
This is the base of one of the pillars in the cistern - an upside down sculpture of the head of medusa.

After that we went to a Synagogue. Our Muslim tour guide taught some things to David about Hebrew and Judaism (bima vs. teva - he still insists that he's right). I was fading pretty hard at this point because I didn't sleep too well the night before. We went on to the

column2: which is a church that was built on top of a Roman basilica
column3: and then was converted to a mosque and is now a museum. If you think that the structure was a bit confused through all of its transformations
column4: you're right. The inner courtyard had the remnants of Christian mosaics and when you walk in there are giant discs hanging from the wall with Arabic writing. Near the front are two large columns whose tops look as if they had fallen off. It turns out that they were giant candles. I can't possibly do this structure justice
column5: so I'll stop here.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Another column in the cistern - this one with a teardrop pattern." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/cistern_teardrop.jpg">
Another column in the cistern - this one with a teardrop pattern.
After Hagia Sophia it was more than lunchtime. Inci
column2: our tour guide
column3: seems to know everyone - wherever we go. I suppose she just always takes people along the same routes. Anyway
column4: lunch was great. David and I had the chicken version of gyros and a green salad. Inci explained to us that the Greeks have stolen a lot of Turkish culture and claimed it as their own - gyros being on that list. In Turkey
column5: it's called "doner" meat. I also had my first real Turkish coffee (In Greece
column6: the same thing is called "Greek coffee"). It comes in the size of an espresso cup
column7: but is very thick and muddy. It's also fairly sweet. After lunch I had no problems staying awake.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The entrance to the Blue Mosque." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/blue_mosque.jpg">
The entrance to the Blue Mosque.

column2: after lunch was the

column1: . This is a palace built in the 15th century that closely resembles most people's ideas (or at least my ideas) of what Istanbul must look like. It is filled with tiles and complicated geometric patterns. There are an awful lot of jewels and artifacts - such as a gold throne embedded with emeralds. Mohammed's sword was also in this palace.
<a class="thickbox" title="I was trying to capture some of the detail from the ceiling of the courtyard of the Blue Mosque." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/blue_mosque_courtyard.jpg">
I was trying to capture some of the detail from the ceiling of the courtyard of the Blue Mosque.

After that was an underground cistern in the style of a large basilica. People can walk around on platforms above the water. Some of the columns were in a special design. It finally dawned on me that I should be taking pictures. We were getting dripped on quite a bit since the whole structure was designed to collect and contain water
column2: so David mandated that we leave.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This is a composite of three photos of the Blue Mosque. The man you see is praying." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/blue_mosque_prayer.jpg">
This is a composite of three photos of the Blue Mosque. The man you see is praying.
After that we took off our shoes and went into The Blue Mosque
column2: which is Istanbul's premiere mosque. There isn't much to say
column3: other than that it was enormous and exquisitely beautiful. I could spend a week in there taking notes on the various designs and colors. By then I was in high picture mode (not to mention high Turkish coffee mode). Hopefully
column4: the pictures captured some of the beauty.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The ceiling of the Blue Mosque." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/blue_mosque_ceiling.jpg">
The ceiling of the Blue Mosque.
After that was a trip to the Grand Bazaar
column2: which is just what you would imagine it is - a giant market selling rugs
column3: clothes
column4: chessboards
column5: etc. David helped me bargain something down
column6: but eventually I said
column7: "that's fine" and paid for it. Both David and the Inci gave me chastising looks for giving in on the bargaining too early.

column2: we said farewell to the tour guide and went back to the hotel for a nap. It was about 6 o'clock at this point and we were beat. Dinner was at seven
column3: and it was great. We had some sort of sour cherry wine for an aperitif. Dinner was some sort of grilled ground beef with cheese. It's hard to do Middle Eastern food justice with words - it's all in the spices and they are impossible to describe if you've never had them.

column1: After dinner we went to a Turkish bath. Our tour guide gave us a brochure for one that we showed to the cab driver. The driver took us to a different one and when we said it's not the right one
column2: he said
column3: "it's okay" over and over. Since I recognized it from the guidebook
column4: I figured it was still good
column5: so we went in. It turned out we were the only ones there
column6: so we got very good treatment. A Turkish bath consists of sitting in a hot steamy room
column7: getting a vigorous massage
column8: and then getting a loufa-like scrub followed by soap and rinsing. You sit on a marble floor while they scrub you and throw buckets of water on you. It's quite jarring but a lot of fun. Somehow
column9: after an exhausting day and a relaxing massage and bath
column10:
David and I had trouble sleeping. Jet lag can be a terrible thing.

";"962946000";"textile"

column1: Today was a lot less hectic. We started off going to

column2: which is a more modern (19th century) palace for the sultan. It was much more along the lines of a typical European palace with chandeliers and grand carpets. The wooden floors were spectacular with their intricate Turkish geometry. There was also a nice art collection throughout the palace.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The front entrance of the Dolme Bahce." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/dolme_bahci.jpg">
The front entrance of the Dolme Bahce.

After that we went on a ferry that took us north up the Bosphorus Straits. The ride was uneventful but relaxing and had a group of musicians playing Turkish music. We went to a local family beach area and had fresh fish for lunch right on the water. This gave us a glimpse of the Black Sea. We got into a cab and headed back to the hotel. Luckily we got in the cab just before rain started
column2: and it stopped right before we arrived.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="David and our tour guide
column2: Inci
column3: having Turkish tea on the ferry." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/turkish_coffee.jpg">

column2: Inci
column3: having Turkish tea on the ferry." src="/files/photos/cruise2000/turkish_coffee.jpg" height="318" width="467">

column2: Inci
column3: having Turkish tea on the ferry.

column1: We gathered up our things and headed to the ship. The ship is quite nice. Similar to last year's
column2: although there's one less cabin deck and less open deck space. They had champagne and mimosas waiting for us when we arrived. All in all
column3: we relaxed and watched the departure from port.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A group of Turkish musicians on the ferry." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/turkish_musicians.jpg">
A group of Turkish musicians on the ferry.

The big surprise is that David presented me with an engagement ring. We laughed and I showed him the ring l got him. This story is too cute.

";"962946000";"textile"

"Istanbul to Athens: Day at Sea";"personal/travel/turkey/istanbul-athens-day-sea";"

I won't spend too much time talking about the day at sea as all we did was lay in the sun and read. The sea was fantastically calm. Half of the time I didn't even know we were moving.
<a class="thickbox" title="A picture of our ship." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/ship2.jpg">
We did meet someone on the ship - That night we were enjoying the bough of the ship as we sailed into the night and a blond woman carrying a book
column2: a glass of wine
column3: and a cigarette came out to where we were and we got to talking. Her name is Pam and she's here with a large group
column4: many of whom are anesthesiologists. Later in the trip
column5: Pam became an invaluable source of gossip and amusement about a leathery
column6: blond woman who was at least 50% silicone that walked around in a yellow thong bikini. We all had different names for her - Pam called her "Barbie
column7: others on the ship called her Miss Las Vegas" and David and I simply called her "Boobs." I wish I had a good picture of her
column8:
but I could never work up the guts. She and her husband were often in the gym.

";"962946000";"textile"

column1: This stop is merely an excuse to see

. We met Inci and got in a car to drive a half hour out of town. Our first stop was the house of Mary the Virgin Mother. It was found from a dying nun in another country that was having visions of talking to Mary. Eventually
column2: someone started taking notes
column3: and later a group of scientists set out to disprove the notes and discovered a monastery with a house that described the nun's description of Mary's house. The house was very small and simple and there was something calm and sacred about the house and the whole area (a monastery was nearby).

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The ruins of Ephesus." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/ephesus.jpg">

After that we headed off to the ruins of Ephesus. I imagine we spent about two and a half hours going through the ruins. Inci was once again full of information. She apparently used to work at the ruins and so took us through some back areas - showing us places that most tourists were not getting to - and explaining how it all fit together. The ruins were far more extensive than Pompeii. The main centerpiece was the library
column2: since the facade of this two-story building remained almost entirely intact. Perhaps the other reason I enjoyed it much more than Pompeii was that we took a tour guide and so got a better layout of the city and how it all fit together. She also showed us the first recorded advertisement
column3: which was an engraving in the main walkway that gave directions to the brothel.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The theater at Ephesus. It is still used for rock/music concerts." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/ephesus_theater.jpg">
The theater at Ephesus. It is still used for rock/music concerts.
Next we went to the Basilica of St. John the Baptist. It was mainly in ruins
column2: but she walked us through the layout and how it must have been built. And then the grounds keeper offered to show us his garden of fruits
column3: flowers and vegetables
column4: since they apparently knew each other. In general
column5: the fresh produce in Turkey has been about the best quality I have ever seen.

column1: : This was our first stop that contained one of the former ancient wonders of the ancient world -
The Temple of Artemis at Ephesus
. All that remains now is one pillar.
<a class="thickbox" title="Hadrian's Arch - one of the ruins of Ephesus." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/hadrians_arch.jpg">
Hadrian's Arch - one of the ruins of Ephesus.
Our final stop was the museum of Ephesus which had many artifacts taken from the ruins at Ephesus. I must admit that I was very tired by then. There were a couple of great statues
column2: though. The most impressive was a statue of Artemis that looked more Egyptian than anything.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The view of Ephesus from St. John's Basilica." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/ephesus_view.jpg">
The view of Ephesus from St. John's Basilica.
We went back to Kusadasi after that and did some shopping. I slept most of the way back. That Inci is a taskmaster - and I had not yet had that first sleep that signals that jet lag is over.
That evening before dinner we spent some time in the lounge talking to Jim
column2: a gentleman who is here with his traveling companion
column3:
Bob. And that night after dinner we had the sleep that we'd been waiting for.

";"962946000";"textile"

column1:
"Rhodes";"personal/travel/greece/rhodes";"

Today we were at port in Rhodes before we awakened. We had break fast and headed into the city. Rhodes has the reputation of being the Florida of Europe. I think it's specifically the South Beach with a medieval section.

<a class="thickbox" title="A picture of the mosaic floor of the synagogue at Rhodes. Most of the walkways in Rhodes were made of small stones - although usually not in this ornate of a pattern." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/rhodes_stones.jpg">
A picture of the mosaic floor of the synagogue at Rhodes. Most of the walkways in Rhodes were made of small stones - although usually not in this ornate of a pattern.

We set off to walk into town and a woman that we met on the ship stopped us and asked if we wouldn't mind if she walked with us. She's 82 and was ditched by her daughter. What can you say? So she walked in with us but we wore her out in a half hour.
<a class="thickbox" title="David under a lime tree in the garden where we had lunch." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/rhodes_lunch.jpg">
David under a lime tree in the garden where we had lunch.
The old City is a medieval town with areas where merchants have setup storefront tourist shops. We walked into the palace
column2: which was restored for Mussolini
column3: but l don't think he ever got a chance to use it. The Italians did a great job on the restoration. Pretty much every room had a fantastic mosaic that had been taken from another location. The Italians are big on recycling
column4: as Benji would say.

column1: We also went to a synagogue and Jewish museum. The Jewish population was quite strong is Rhodes before the Holocaust. And the only ones allowed in the old city used to be Turks and Jews.

column2: and we found a small hole in the wall that was basically just someone's garden. They make only a few dishes a day
column3: and so we had a little of everything. Real Greek Salad tastes much better than the American version. And the garden was lovely. We ate under lime trees.

column1: Since we did not have the task master tour guide
column2: Inci
column3: we went back to the ship for a nap. After getting back to the city
column4: David bought another rug at a place we had passed earlier. I just found out that David only brought one pair of shorts. What was he thinking? The other homosexuals came into the shop when David was bargaining and said hello. They may join us in Bodrum. We took a trip up to the old Clock Bell tower where there was a fantastic view of the city. There was a similar tower in Rab
column5: Croatia with narrow
column6: rickety steps. You just have to take a deep breath and assume that if the structure has survived this long
column7: it will last another fifteen minutes.

column1: For dinner we went to fish restaurant that was recommended by the guy that sold us the rug. Very good food. The walk through the noncommercial area at night was wonderful. With the quiet and the lamps along the narrow cobblestone streets
column2: you really did feel transported to another time.
nothing is left.

column1:
"Bodrum (formerly Halicarnassus)";"personal/travel/turkey/bodrum-formerly-halicarnassus";"

Yesterday was our last day in Turkey
column2: and so our last day with Inci. We were joined by a Jim - the southern gentleman we met on the ship. Our first trek was through the Bodrum Castle
column3: which
column4: like many structures around here
column5: started in the ancient world and then changed throughout the ages. They had some particularly interesting exhibits of underwater excavations. And the views throughout the castle were great.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This is the view from the castle at Bodrum. You can see the minaret from the mosque in the castle and the row of red Turkish flags." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/bodrum_turret.jpg">
This is the view from the castle at Bodrum. You can see the minaret from the mosque in the castle and the row of red Turkish flags.
Before going to the next Site we had a fantastic lunch. The Turkish food is really quite good. Lots of grilled meats and tasty fresh veggies.
. Next we went to the remains of the Mausoleum
column2: one of the seven wonders of the ancient world. This is where our word "mausoleum" comes from
column3: although in this context
column4: it was King Maussollos' tomb.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This is our tour guide
column2: Inci
column3: from the castle. In the distance is our ship." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/bodrum_Inci.jpg">

column2: Inci
column3: from the castle. In the distance is our ship." src="/files/photos/cruise2000/bodrum_inci.jpg" height="259" width="300">

column2: Inci
column3: from the castle. In the distance is our ship.

column1: After that we did a bit of shopping for knick-knacks and then rented a boat. He took us around to a few bays and then to a special spot called
column2: "The Aquarium." It's supposedly called that because the water is so still and clear. I took a swim in the Aegean and then we went back to the docks.

column1: We said our goodbyes to Inci and went back to the ship for a couple of very strong pina coladas. For dinner
column2: we ate with Jim and Bob and two Brits
column3: Brian and Neil. It was a very enjoyable dinner and we agreed to do the same the next night. We also had the first bits of rocky water
column4:
although it was not as bad as we had last year.

";"962946000";"textile"

column1:
"Santorini";"personal/travel/greece/santorini";"

It took David and me a while to get into the rhythm of the day. He was a little spacey and draggy and I was crabby and snappy. Mainly because I had to go to an Internet cafe to handle a call from work. After that we rented a car and drove around the island. There were fantastic views all around
column2: but I was not seeing what was so wonderful about the island until we got to the very north end to a town called Eio. This town is mainly at the top of a cliff
column3: with the houses and Villas along the top and working their way halfway down the side. When you see cigarette ads for people dressed in white linen on a white patio over looking the water
column4: this is the place. We took a long walk down to a thin rocky beach and had an iced coffee with baklava. Iced coffees in the Mediterranean are much creamier and dessert-like than in the U.S.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The view from the restaurant where we had lunch in Santorini." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/santorini_lunch.jpg">
The view from the restaurant where we had lunch in Santorini.
David talked me into hiring a donkey to take us back up the steps. There were a couple of other Americans that did it with us. The owner comes up behind and smacks the last donkey in the rear
column2: so they all go somewhat quickly.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A church in Santorini." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/santorini_church.jpg">
We walked around the town a bit more and then went back to the car. After returning the car
column2: we went back to the Internet cafe to finalize the work stuff and return to the ship.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The place where we walked down for coffee. This is a typical honeymoon spot." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/sanorini_io.jpg">
The place where we walked down for coffee. This is a typical honeymoon spot.
Dinner that evening was a BBQ on the pool deck. Our table Consisted of David and I
column2: the two Brits - Brian and Neil
column3: Jim - the Southern gentleman
column4: and his traveling companion
column5: Bob. We had a wonderful dinner
column6: both in food and in company
column7: looking up to the town of Thira atop the cliff beside us. Jim and Bob eventually went to bed
column8:
but the remaining four of us waited until the ship sailed away to see the lights of the villages dotting the top of the island.

";"962946000";"textile"

column1:
"Mykonos";"personal/travel/greece/mykonos";"

The last day of the cruise. Getting the bill in the room is a real slap in the face. Although David and l have both said that we're ready to return
column2: it still has been so wonderful that we don't want it to end.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The main town of Mykonos. David
column2: Brian
column3: Neal and Earl Bobby of Memphis." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/mykonos.jpg">

column2: Brian

column2: at dinner we decided to rent or car and head to the naughty

column4: somewhat gay

Pretty much everyone was at the 7:15 debriefing so that they would know how to get off the ship. The captain gave a long speech about the whole trip. The brits taught us a new phrase - they said the captain is a bit of a "Jack the Lad" - meaning that he's a rambunctious boy at heart.

column1:
"First Day in Athens";"personal/travel/greece/first-day-athens";"

Athens is hot. So very hot. Our hotel is a bit of a fleabag. Actually
column2: it's a flea sauna. We're supposed to be here for two nights.
"At nine in the morning. How hot could it be?" and went to the Acropolis. It was very hot. We asked around for a guide at the entrance
column3: but luckily there wasn't one. A tour guide would have been added torture.  The Acropolis was grand; we took some pictures
column4: and got the hell out.

column1: Next we walked to the National Museum
column2: which had some very good examples of sculpture and statue. Lunch was much needed
column3: as I was fading pretty hard in the museum
column4: despite a little water break in the cafeteria. We made a stop at an Internet cafe and then headed back to the hotel room.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Another Athens dog. They're everywhere!" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/athens_dog2.jpg">
David announced at the hotel that the heat was too much. We called British Air about going to London early and they said we had a ninety nine percent chance of making the next flight. Well
column2: she was ninety nine percent wrong. We waited on standby for about three and a half hours. The Athens airport is a pit. We went back to the hotel with our tails between our legs and checked back in. For dinner
column3: we went to the Plaka
column4: which is the tourist section with restaurants and shops
column5: and had a great dinner at a place called Diogenes (named after the philosopher). Once again
column6: the heat was getting to David since we were sitting outside along a park. So we went back to the hotel.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="One of the non-Parthenon temples of the Acropolis. I can't remember which one. It was too hot to take notes." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/cruise2000/athens_acropolis.jpg">
One of the non-Parthenon temples of the Acropolis. I can't remember which one. It was too hot to take notes.

"Last Day in Athens";"personal/travel/greece/last-day-athens";"

We left the air conditioner running on high all night and my sheets were wet with sweat when we woke up. The first thing I did was go to get a bottle of water out of the mini-bar
column2: but it was empty. We are changing hotels. Other people on the boat had mentioned the Sheraton
column3: so it was off to the Sheraton we went.

column1: The Sheraton was much more luxurious and most importantly - WELL AIR-CONDITIONED! The other big plus about the hotel was that there were other people from the ship staying there. In particular
column2: Pam's group was there and we often ran into them in the lobby. David and I agreed that we want Pam's travel agent from now on.

column1: We took a trip to the
. This was much more bearable since there were trees and therefore
column2: shade. Actually
column3: the Temple of Hephaistos
column4: while not as large as the Parthenon
column5: was in much better shape. Frankly
column6: we were getting a little "over-ruined" and although it was interesting we weren't spending as much time on this as would if it were at the beginning of the trip.

column2: ran into some people from the ship
column3: and they recommended an air-conditioned restuarant. When we got there
column4: we ran into Pam's group
column5: so clearly
column6: this was the place to eat. The food was good and a crash was imminent. We went back to the hotel for reading and napping. I took a little stroll around the town before dinner for some pictures and ran into a bead stores
column7: where I picked up some "Turkish Eyes."

column2: we asked the hotel for a a simple
column3: nearby recommendation and they sent us to a true Greek diner. The waitstaff looked to be in their seventies and very pleasant - the atmosphere looked to be from the 1950's - and the food was good.

column1: The rest of the trip was uneventful. We were ready to be home. We were on the flight the next morning and spent the whole day in the air.

which is a walled city that was once the home of the French popes-back in the 1300's
