"The Trip to the Czech Republic";"personal/travel/prague/trip-czech-republic";"

Our first day in Prague was really two. We left the house a little late
column2: and than found out that we were dealing with rain
column3: holiday weekend
column4: and Friday afternoon traffic. We got to the airport as they were boarding the flight - in fact
column5: it was mostly full when we got there. So we got two middle seats. For an over night flight. Yay. However
column6: the flight to Zurich went relatively quickly. we had a five hour layover in Zurich
column7: and we saw something about day rooms. So we decided to check them out. They were very white
column8: sterile rooms with a communal toilet and Shower down the hall. We were so dead tired
column9: we decided to rent one. And it turns out they made quite a difference. Waking up was sheer torture
column10: but once I was up
column11: I felt distinctly better. Also

column1: The Swiss Air flight was a wonderful welcome to Europe. They served a fantastic smoked ham and herb cheese sandwich followed by Swiss chocolates. I looked at David and commented on the food in Europe. He said
column2: "Low fat. What's that?"

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A Long Layover" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/dayroom.jpg">

"First Day in Prague";"personal/travel/prague/first-day-prague";"

We took a cab to the hotel. The driver reminded me of Kornblum from "Kavalier & Clay." the hotel was nice and didn't have one of those funny "shelf" toilets that I see in Eastern Europe. We unpacked and decided to head to the "Old Town." lt took us about 20 minutes and two trips to the subway station and back before we were on our way.
<a class="thickbox" title="The first cafe we visited - Namesti Republiky." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/namesti_republiky_int.jpg">
The first cafe we visited - Namesti Republiky.
<a class="thickbox" title="The view from the outside." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/namesti_republiky.jpg">

column2: the first day in Prague was a bit of a blur. We were operating on only a few hours of sleep. The subway took us near the Old Town
column3: and we started walking. There was no great destination in mind. We came across Tulla and her Finnish associates. Tulla was looking vivacious. But her colleagues didn't recognize that we existed. I had a list of cafes in Prague
column4: and so we headed to one on the list. It was a beautiful art deco building. We sat outside
column5: listening to their musicians and had an iced cappucino - which had no ice
column6: but a lot of cream
column7: and some sort of syrup or liquor. We headed over to the old Town Square
column8: checked out the churches and architecture
column9: and waited for the Astrological Clock to chime. As I had read about the various machinations that the clock goes through
column10: it seemed sort of fun or cute
column11: but when I saw it happening
column12: I realized it was quite haunting. The second I saw the apostles start to parade past the open windows

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Church of Our Lady" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/church_of_our_lady.jpg">
We continued walking down to the river. The river was full of people that had rented row boats. I thought about taking a picture
column2: but I knew I would never translate.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Eveyone is waiting for the automatons to play." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/astrological_clock_2.jpg">
Eveyone is waiting for the automatons to play.
We walked across the Charles Bridge. I will have to do that again
column2: because the sun was in our eyes and I was quite tired. We found a restaurant that was popular with the locals in the Little Quarter. My meal was big
column3: but David's was enormous. We both had beer. After a heavy meal
column4: beer
column5: and jet lag
column6: we stumbled out of the restaurant drunk and found a cab. We later realized that the cab driver recognized drunk tourists and significantly over charged us.

column1:
"Excursion to Kutna Hora";"personal/travel/prague/excursion-kutna-hora";"

I had heard a lot of the ossuary at Kutna Hora. So we found an excursion to take us there. The town is an old mining town
column2: which used to act as the mint for the Czech Republic. The town ranks high on the "quant scale"; but unfortunately
column3: our tour guide was not so great. At our first stop
column4: a beautiful church
column5: she simply read from the english text that they give all tourists. She also added extra prepositions to the text and occassionally asked for help with words like "apron". Worse yet
column6: we found out that the tour would not be stopping at the ossuary. So instead of going back to Prague with the tour
column7: we went to the ossuary on our own. It was a beautiful day and the walk was only a few kilometers.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="St. Barbara's Cathedral in Kutna Hora" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/st_barbara.jpg">
St. Barbara's Cathedral in Kutna Hora
<a class="thickbox" title="The walk along the old wall in Kutna Hora" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/kutna_hora_road.jpg">
The walk along the old wall in Kutna Hora

column2: but quite amazing. the pictures do it some justice
column3: but it's better to see it in person. Oddly enough
column4: it did not seem morose. And only macabre from a distance. Up close
column5: it was amazing beautiful. The chandelier has at least one of every bone in the human body.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A stack of bones" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/ossuary_stack.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="An urn made of bones" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/ossuary_urn.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="A coat of arms" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/ossuary_coat.jpg">

<a class="thickbox" title="This is a part of the coat of arms. It's an image of a bird picking out an eye of a Turk to celebrate the defeat of the Turks." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/ossuary_turk.jpg">
This is a part of the coat of arms. It's an image of a bird picking out an eye of a Turk to celebrate the defeat of the Turks.

column2: we walked a little further to the train Station.

column1: We almost didn't realize that we had to transfer trains
column2: but everything worked out well. We went back to the hotel - I relaxed and David went to the meeting for a bit.
David and guest were invited on a river boat with dinner and music. Granted
column3: it was a bunch of doctors
column4: but it turned out to be a lovely evening. The boat took us from one side of Prague to the other
column5: with two stops in a lock. Looking at Prague at night was magical. There have been many times on the trip so far that I have thought
column6: "So this is what they mean by Bohemia." I've been searching for words to describe it. It's more than just an epicurean lifestyle. That word always mates me think of France
column7: where they take epicurianism very seriously. The Czech enjoyment of the pleasures in life is somehow devoid of hedonism. It's youthful without being immature. And it's entirely unselfconscious. More than Paris
column8: this is a city I can imagine myself staying in - writing in journals
column9: attending concerts
column10: sitting by the banks of the river naively enjoying life.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A chandelier using at least one of every human bone" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/ossuary_chandelier.jpg">
A chandelier using at least one of every human bone

"Food Hangover";"personal/travel/prague/food-hangover";"

I'm having a hard time this morning
column2: because I'm having a bit of a food hangover. We went out with friends of David to a place that turned out to be a tourist trap. It's called "U Kalicha" and is based on a popular Czech novel
column3: "The Good Soldier." It was a stereo typical Eastern European event
column4: complete with an accordion player and a tuba player. As soon as they sat us down
column5: they looked at us and said
column6: "Beer?" We said yes and they brought us each the biggest mug of beer I have ever seen. It had to have been at least a liter. Then
column7: while we were looking over the menus
column8: they came around with Slivovitz and asked it we wanted shots. My stomach lining begged for mercy. I was afraid that dinner was going to be over the top
column9: but it was typical Czech food. We had an appetizer with a lot of pork and cheese
column10: and all the men ordered roast goose and the one female ordered a salad. I think with the combination of food and beer
column11: I have a bit of a food hangover this morning.

column2: let's backtrack to earlier in the day. David made an appearance at the conference after breakfast
column3: while I wrote and read. We headed off to Prague castle first. I got the bright idea of walking through the gardens to enter
column4: which entailed a very hearty trek up the side of a hill. There were may school groups waiting outside the castle. One of the groups was a group of about 20 preteen girls. One of them said hello to us quite loudly. David said hello back. Then all 20 of them said hello to us in unison. The first girl
column5: the ring leader
column6: asked us where we were from. We said "New York" and all 20 girls started screaming with excitement. We figured that they must be from some small German town and were practicing their English.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="On the wall of the castle" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/castle_wall.jpg">
On the wall of the castle
<a class="thickbox" title="One of the palace courtyards" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/palace_courtyard.jpg">

So back to the castle. The highlight of the castle is the cathedral. It's enormous and beautiful. I think the only church that I've seen that's more impressive is St. Peter's in Rome - and no one will ever top that one. It is also interesting to note that there were some relatively recent pieces of art as part of the cathedral. Especially beautiful was an art nouveau stained glass window. I always tend to think that its a shame that they can't build modern buildings to be as majestic as they used to be
column2: but this cathedral helped show that something doesn't have to be old to be beautiful.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="An outside mosaic on St Vitus'" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/palace_cathedral_mosaic.jpg">
An outside mosaic on St Vitus'

Next we went on to a palace. There were many great halls and a room where two discs were pushed out of a window - setting off the Thirty Years War. The palace had a few large entrances especially designed for people riding in on horseback.
<a class="thickbox" title="The main hall of the palace" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/palace_hall.jpg">
The main hall of the palace

column2: we ventured on to a small street where Kafka lived for a short while with his sister. The houses were all painted in pastels. It looked too quaint and cheerful for Kafka's residence.

column1: We left the castle and ventured across the river into the Jewish Quarter. We saw the Old-New Synagogue
column2: which is really centuries old and is where the Golum is supposedly still resting. Right around the corner is the Jewish Cemetery. l was quite moved when we got to Rabbi Leow's grave - the rabbi that created the Golum. I've been thinking a lot about Kavalier & Clay.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="More of the Jewish Cemetery" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/cemetery_2.jpg">

column2: we went in search of an English bookstore. I bought David "I Served the King of England" and we had a coffee. The bookstore and cafe felt very communist era. I imagine that life must have been very quiet for the average person back then - and extremely boring. As it stands now
column3: capitalism has not taken too strong of a foothold here. There are people selling shot glasses and T-shirts with images of Prague
column4: but there's surprisingly little advertising. There is a calm silence that has remained.

column2:
we went back to the hotel for a nap and then on to the dinner that I've already told you about.

";"1051765200";"textile"

column1:
"On My Own in Prague";"personal/travel/prague/my-own-prague";"

David was at conferences most of today
column2: so I did some exploring on my own. I started off near the Prague Castle to check out some of the "Little Quarter". My first attempt at reading the map resulted in a wrong turn. Once I re adjusted
column3: I was fine for the rest of my excursion.

column1: My first stop was at Wallenstein Palace. It is essentially a senate house with large public gardens. It was full of statues
column2: frescoes
column3: and had a little area that housed some owls. There was also this very large
column4: bizarre wall called "The Grotesguery" that's made to look like limestone stallactites. It did look like that
column5: but I couldn't figure out what the points was.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="More of Wallenstein Palace" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/wallenstein_gardens.jpg">

column2: I wandered around the neighborhood and ended up by the Church of St. Nicholas. Once again
column3: I was not prepared for how majestic the churches would be in Prague. The picture here does not do it justice. I should have taken more pictures
column4: but I always feel tacky taking pictures of a church. Well
column5: I feel tacky taking pictures all the time. So in this picture
column6: compare the size of the people to the size of the church. Along the altars are giant white marble statues of saints and patrons of the church.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Church of St Nicholas" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/st_nicholas.jpg">

I came back down to the river and walked along Kampa Park which is a park along the river. It's not known for anything in particular except that it's relaxing and pleasant and off the tourist path somewhat. I sat on a bench and enjoyed looking at the locals enjoy a tranquility in life that you just don't see in the U.S.

I went back to the Old Town via the Charles Bridge. I took a picture of people rubbing a stature for good luck. The statue has two brass reliefs: one of a man and his dog and one of a saint leaping off a bridge. People had started touching the falling saint for good luck and at some point
column2: I assume after the lines for touching the saint got to be too much
column3: people decided that touching the dog was good luck too. So now both the saint and the dog are shiny from everyone touching them.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The goodluck charm on the Charles Bridge" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/prague/charles_bridge_goodluck.jpg">
The goodluck charm on the Charles Bridge
On the way back to the hotel
column2: I stopped by the river
column3: made a wish
column4: and threw a coin into the river. I'll let you know if it comes true.

column2: David and I went to a small restuarant behind a convent. It was partially outside and the night was perfect for semi-outside dining. I have to admit that the heavy eastern european food was starting to get to me at this point. We stumbled back to the subway after dinner
column3:
going through side streets and trying to walk off the heavy food. We saw nuns in the convent fixing up their rooms. We listened to the sounds of classical music in people's apartments.

";"1051765200";"textile"

column1:
"Sad to Return";"personal/travel/prague/sad-return";"

So we got to the hotel and packed. Nothing too eventful. The flight home was a little trying. The flight to Zurich was in front of two blabber mouths that couldn't talk below a shout. And American Airlines didn't have us sitting together on the way home. We were persistent in our complaining and eventually got two seats together. The flight felt very long on the way home.
It turns out that I brought a friend home from Prague in my stomach. I couldn't go to work the next day - it felt like I swallowed glass. But after a day of rest
column2: I was ready to go back to work. Well
column3: as ready as I was going to get.

column1: I left a lot of things yet to do in Prague. I found an antique map shop for David that he didn't have time to visit
column2: so there's something calling David there
column3:
too. I will never pass up a trip to Prague.

";"1051765200";"textile"

column1:
"Long Weekend in Prague";"personal/travel/prague/long-weekend-prague";"

When I was at marchFIRST
column2: David asked if I would join him on a trip to Prague. I said yes at the time
column3: but then a major project at work was scheduled to go live near the time of our trip
column4: so I backed out. Then marchFIRST went bankrupt. I vowed never to pass up a vacation for work again. Well
column5: Century 21 scheduled a project to go live within a month of my trip
column6: and I said "screw it
column7:
I'm going!"

";"1051765200";"textile"

column2: Italy comes up a lot. I always mention Rome which still stands out in my mind as a place I could see myself happily trapped in. A standard response I get is "Have you been to Florence? You haven't seen nothing yet."

column1: David and I were trying to plan our big trip for that year. We looked at several options but either the timing didn't work out
column2: or the flights getting there and back were too difficult
column3: or the whole thing would have been too expensive. Then
column4: all of a sudden
column5: we over looked the obvious. Why don't we just go to Florence and spend a week driving around Tuscany? It was the perfect plan and ended up being one of the most perfect vacations I have ever been on.";"1096606800";"textile"

column1:
"Torre di Bellosguardo";"personal/travel/tuscany/torre-di-bellosguardo";"

It turns out that getting in and out of Florence is not so easy. We decided to fly to Rome
column2: take the train to Florence
column3: and then take a cab to our hotel. So
column4: yes
column5: that meant that the first day of travel was kind of hellish. However
column6: the hotel that greeted us at our arrival was WELL worth it! I think it was more than just the jet-lag - our hotel (the Torre di Bellosguardo) felt like a dream. And I don't mean to say that it was idyllic (although it was)
column7: it was like a dream when you're in a big house with hallways and stairwells going all different places. When the porter took us to our room
column8: I got lost. I couldn't find any other hotel rooms! Our room was off of an old banquet hall and there didn't seem to be any other guest rooms off of it. (I did some exploring later in the week and we did find a few more rooms.)

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The entrance to the hotel" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/hotel_front.jpg">
The entrance to the Torre di Bellosguardo
<a class="thickbox" title="The ceiling of a room just off the lobby." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/hotel_ceiling.jpg">
The ceiling of a room just off the lobby.
<a class="thickbox" title="David standing in the hotel entrance." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/hotel_doorway.jpg">
David standing in the hotel entrance.
<a class="thickbox" title="A view of the lobby and the parrot that lived there" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/hotel_lobby.jpg">
A view of the lobby and the parrot that lived there
<a class="thickbox" title="Another view of the lobby...and the parrot" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/hotel_lobby2.jpg">
Another view of the lobby...and the parrot

And that takes us to our room. It was magnificent. It's the only hotel room that I've ever missed when I left. Everything was antique - even the artwork on the walls was medieval. We had two windows. Out of one window was an unbelievable view of Florence. Out of the other window was a view of the gardens. We could only hear two sounds really: an occassional church bell from Florence and a braying donkey. The donkey lived on the property. We went looking for him one day
column2: but we never spotted him.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The view of Florence" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/hotel_roomview1.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The view of the gardens" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/hotel_roomview2.jpg">
One day we took some time to explore the gardens of the property. It took us a while. They grew all their own fruits and vegetables. There were plenty of birds flittering about. There was also a pool
column2: but we were more interested in exploring than hanging out by a pool. Also
column3: October weather was not so hot that we felt the need to cool off by the water.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The tower where our room was as seen from the gardens" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/hotel_tower.jpg">
The tower where our room was as seen from the gardens
<a class="thickbox" title="A view of misty-morning Florence from the gardens" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/hotel_view.jpg">
A view of misty-morning Florence from the gardens

"Florence";"personal/travel/tuscany/florence";"

David signed us up for two walking tours
column2: which ended up being a very good idea. Our first day in Florence
column3: we had a four hour walking tour that covered most of Florence
column4: followed by lunch
column5: and then a tour of Michaelangelo's David.

column1: The walking tour gave us an excellent overview of Tuscany: who are the Medici's
column2: what are these crests we keep seeing on buildings
column3: etc. The tour guide had a seemingly limitless supply of stories about the city. I started becoming suspicious at all the commonly known phrases that seemed to originate from Florence. For instance
column4: "saved by the bell" comes from the story of a woman that buried alive
column5: but was able to ring a bell so that someone could hear her and dig up the grave. The phrase "I ate at a little hole in the wall" refers to the small doors next to the kitchen where wealthy families would hand out scraps to beggars. You get the idea. Regardless of their authenticity
column6: all the stories were captivating.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This is a famous boar fountain that supposedly tells you how long it will be until you return to Florence." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/florence_boar.jpg">
This is a famous boar fountain that supposedly tells you how long it will be until you return to Florence.

We heard many stories of tempermental artists. Donatello was high on the list of divas. There was a story that he had made a statue and he was showing it to the patron on a rooftop. The patron made some criticisms of the statue and Donatello said
column2: "You're right. It's junk." and shoved the stature off the rooftop and letting it shatter to a million pieces. My hero.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Front of the Duomo" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/florence_duomo_front.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The inside of the Duomo. This should give you sense of the size." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/florence_baptistry_int2.jpg">
The inside of the Duomo. This should give you sense of the size.
<a class="thickbox" title="A Statue of Medusa in one of the main squares" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/florence_medusa.jpg">
A Statue of Medusa in one of the main squares

column2: we had two major events for which unfortunately
column3: I cannot show any photographs: Michaelangelo's David and the Uffizi Gallery. Both were breathtaking. I have had experiences in the past in which I looked at a major piece of artwork and said "I don't get it." Not the case with Michaelangelo's David. Our guide also did a very good job explaining the context and what Michaelangelos was attempting to do with the sculpture. It really is one of those "run
column4: don't walk" kind of things.

column1: And the Uffizi had some amazing pieces of artwork: Several Botticelli's including "Birth of Venus"
column2: Michaelangelo's Pieta
column3: and many others.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The ceiling of the entrance to the Uffizi" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/florence_uffizi.jpg">
The ceiling of the entrance to the Uffizi
The one place that I could get a lot of photos that actually turned out well was in the baptistry of the Duomo.
<a class="thickbox" title="The doors of the baptistry" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/florence_baptistry_doors.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The ceiling of the baptistry" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/florence_baptistry_ceiling1.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The ceiling of the baptistry" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/florence_baptistry_ceiling2.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The ceiling of the baptistry" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/florence_baptistry_ceiling3.jpg">

column2: we were ready to hit the road and see more of Tuscany. In general
column3: I found the Tuscans drove quickly
column4: but fairly. Of course
column5: we wouldn't dare driving in the actual towns. Usually
column6: the goal was to park just outside the medieval walls and walk in.

column1: San Gemignano is built on a hill and looks like a small mideival Manhattan with towering spires. They had one main church with incredible murals
column2: but one is not allowed to take photographs.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A view from outside the walls of the old city" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/sangemignano3.jpg">
A view from outside the walls of the old city

"Lucca";"personal/travel/tuscany/lucca";"

I feel repetitive saying that this Lucca is a beautiful
column2: medieval town. All of these towns have their own personality and should be experienced. This town has a cosmoploitan heart to it. Once we hit the main area
column3: we found that it was full of small streets with shops galore.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The main church in town" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/lucca_cathedral_3.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The main church in town" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/lucca_cathedral.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="Artwork in the church" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/lucca_cathedral2.jpg">
Lucca is the birthplace of opera composer Giacomo Puccini (he wrote Madama Butterfly
column2: La Boheme
column3: and Turandot for all you cultural heathens). The had a museum of his house which was more interesting than one would imagine. David bought a first print of a score there.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A statue of Puccini" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/lucca_puccini.jpg">

"Pisa";"personal/travel/tuscany/pisa";"

The subtitle of a trip to Pisa should be "Come for the Tower. Stay for the Cathedral.". Honestly
column2: I don't know why everyone gets so excited about the tower. Especially when the cathedral and the baptistry were stunning.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Piazza del Duomo" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The Piazza del Duomo from another angle" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa2.jpg">
The Piazza del Duomo from another angle
We walked around the tower. Even making Pisa the first stop of the day
column2: there were plenty of tourists. I can only imagine what it would be like to hit Pisa later in the day. We were not prepared for how stunning the cathedral is. Apparently
column3: Pisa was a center in the area for the moors
column4: and it shows in the artwork. There is an odd mixture of Arabic geometric designs with Catholic iconography. It's especially noticeable in the baptistry. Here are a ton of photos of the cathedral.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The entrance to the cathedral" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_cathedral10.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="More of the inside" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_cathedral2.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="Trying to give you some perspective as to how big the place feels" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_cathedral4.jpg">
Trying to give you some perspective as to how big the place feels
<a class="thickbox" title="An intricately carved marble pulpit" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_cathedral6.jpg">

column2: the pulpit
column3: the chandelier" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_cathedral7.jpg">

column2: the pulpit
column3: the chandelier" src="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_cathedral7.jpg" height="200" width="150">

column2: the pulpit
column3: the chandelier

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Another corner of the cathedral" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_cathedral8.jpg">

column2: we get to the baptistry.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The outside of the baptistry" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_baptistry.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The entrance to the baptistry" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_baptistry2.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="You definitely see the Arabic influence" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_baptistry4.jpg">
You definitely see the Arabic influence
<a class="thickbox" title="More stunning marble work" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/pisa_baptistry5.jpg">

column2: we drove up to Carrera (the place with the marble!). Once again
column3: quaint medieval town. Unfortunately
column4: most everything was closed there. We saw some workers carving marble and took a picture. They let us know that that was not cool. Obviously
column5: we looked like tourists
column6: so they weren't too worried
column7: but I did put the camera away.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A view of the mountainside. That's marble you're seeing on the side - not snow." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/carrera.jpg">
A view of the mountainside. That's marble you're seeing on the side - not snow.
<a class="thickbox" title="A statue dedicated to workers that died in the marble mines" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/carrera_statue.jpg">
A statue dedicated to workers that died in the marble mines
<a class="thickbox" title="The picture we weren't supposed to take." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/carrera_workers.jpg">
The picture we weren't supposed to take.

column2: we took the scenic route to our next stop. That meant driving up and over one of the Italian Alps. The views were fantastic. We didn't take any pictures. The road was dotted with occasional road-side hotels
column3: but for the most part
column4:
there was absolutely no one around.

";"1096606800";"textile"

column1:
"Garfagnana";"personal/travel/tuscany/garfagnana";"

As we came out of the mountains
column2: we settled into an area called the Garfagnana. This is where I want my Italian home. It was serene
column3: luscious
column4: the homes were beautiful
column5: and we were close to Lucca for shopping.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A medieval bridge known as \"The Devil's Bridge\" for its odd shape" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/garfagnana_devilsbridge.jpg">
A medieval bridge known as "The Devil's Bridge" for its odd shape

column2: we went to some villas in the area
column3:
but we decided to come back to the is area for dinner and ate along the river.

";"1096606800";"textile"

column1:
"The Villas";"personal/travel/tuscany/villas";"

This area has several old villas that are not in use anymore
column2: but allow visitors to tour the grounds. We got to the area a little late
column3: and had to do a little convincing of the man and wife that let people in that we would be quick. They let us in and we were free to wander around. We were not the last to leave. The first villa that we saw was Villa Reale.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A small house on the grounds" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/villa_reale1.jpg">
A small house on the grounds
<a class="thickbox" title="This must have been servants quarters" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/villa_reale2.jpg">
This must have been servants quarters
<a class="thickbox" title="The \"wet\" house? Usually for cooling off in the summer." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/villa_reale4.jpg">
The "wet" house? Usually for cooling off in the summer.
<a class="thickbox" title="A line of shrubs leading to the orangerie" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/villa_reale6.jpg">
A line of shrubs leading to the orangerie

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="We weren't allowed in the main house" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/villa_reale11.jpg">
We weren't allowed in the main house
There were two other villas in the area. One was definitely closed. The other was perhaps not as nice
column2: but the woman let us in to wander around. There were a couple of dogs that followed us. I made the mistake of petting one
column3: and he decided he didn't want me to go and clamped onto my wrist and wouldn't let go. After a couple of minutes of trying to coax him into letting go
column4: I started to get a little nervous
column5: and we shouted for the woman that let us in. He did loose interest and we were free to roam the grounds.

"Sienna";"personal/travel/tuscany/sienna";"

Although I'd be hard-pressed to pick a favorite city in Tuscany
column2: a couple of people told me that they thought Sienna to be one of the most beautiful cities they've ever been to. It certainly ranks quite high. We set today to be almost exclusively dedicated to Sienna. There's a breathtaking cathedral
column3: wonderul shops
column4: local cuisine
column5: and great history.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Starting the day off right with a cappucino" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/sienna_morning.jpg">
Starting the day off right with a cappucino
<a class="thickbox" title="Sienna is a sister city with Rome
column2: so we saw several images of Romulus and Remus (the supposed founders of Rome) feeding from a wolf. Here are several images of the main square." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/sienna_wolf.jpg">

column2: so we saw several images of Romulus and Remus (the supposed founders of Rome) feeding from a wolf. Here are several images of the main square.

The main square in Sienna. It's much larger in person. I could only capture about half of it.
<a class="thickbox" title="Fonte Gaia in the main piazza" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/sienna_fonte_gaia.jpg">
Fonte Gaia in the main piazza
I know I said that the cathedral at Pisa was incredible. Well
column2: the cathedral in Sienna was incredible
column3: too. There's something about Sienna that feels "lived in". In some ways
column4: you could see yourself living in Sienna i na way that you can't imagine yourself in other cities. And on the other hand
column5: there are ways in which you realize that you could never belong to Sienna because it only belongs to its locals.

column1: This was a good place for tourist tchotchkes. It was also a good place for local food. One of my favorite recipes is a Sienna Tart that I got from one of my first cookbooks. It's based on "panforte" from Sienna. We bought several to give to friends and eat for ourselves. For lunch we ate at a local place. I don't think I mentioned this before
column2: Sienna is very hilly. We got quite a workout walking around this city. You can see how they've levelled the tables and chairs for the outdoor seating in this restaurant.

column1:
"Last Day in Florence";"personal/travel/tuscany/last-day-florence";"

We just couldn't get enough of Florence
column2: so we changed our plans somewhat to spend our last day in Florence before getting on the train home. We did a little sightseeing
column3: had gelato at one of the world famous gelato places
column4: and then went to our respective shopping excursions.

column2: one of the churches
column3: Snata Croce
column4: was closed. We went back and it was open. There are several famous Florentines buried here.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A shot of the ceiling" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/tuscany/santacroce_ceiling.jpg">

column2: it's taken me weeks to get over a sadness that I can't start every day with a cappucino and a pastry
column3: staring at rennaisance sculpture and architecture. There are many things here that aren't documented: the Italian Alps
column4: the palace at Florence
column5: the city hall at Sienna
column6: the restuarants we went to
column7: and countless of other details. Everyone deserves as much time in Tuscany as you can muster. Run
column8:
don't walk. This was a vacation I will not forget.
