column2: David and I had a rendezvous in Zurich and flew to Israel for a week. This was probably David's 8th trip there
column3: but it was my first. What was I expecting? I don't really know. Pushy people on crowded streets
column4: perhaps; hot
column5: arid weather; and so many armed guards as to make one constantly nervous. Boy
column6: was I wrong.

column2: the security was heavy
column3: but it was far more unintrusive than I was expecting. It was comforting more than alarming. I get he same sort of safe feeling in New York. The weather was surprisingly moderate. It was sunny and warm everyday and as long as I wore a hat and sunglasses outside
column4: I was fine. And the people were not nearly as pushy as I thought. Well
column5: I take that back. The merchants in Jerusalem were to a level of pushy that I had never seen before - but the average citizen merely maintained a reasonable level of frankness.

column1: We had three nights in Tel Aviv (on the coast) and three nights in Jerusalem (in the desert). I had two days on my own in Tel Aviv. I arrived with almost no plans whatsoever. I only had two carry on bags and no coat when I left New York. The only thing that had prepared me for this trip was a dream that I had a couple of months ago about visiting Israel which ended up being oddly prophetic.";"1125550800";"textile"

"Tel Aviv & Jaffa";"personal/travel/israel/tel-aviv-jaffa";"

David and I met in Zurich and flew together to Tel Aviv. He had flown from Australia and I had flown from New York City. Needless to say
column2: there was some jet lag - especially on David's part. The first few days
column3: we were staying in Tel Aviv for a conference. When we got to the hotel
column4: they didn't have a room for us
column5: even though David was an invited guest speaker. The hotel across the street didn't have a room either. After about 2 hours of a cab ride and some mild shouting
column6: we got a room at the Crown Plaza. It was significantly better than the hotel at the conference. We had heard from other people at the conference that the other hotel had air conditioning problems. Our hotel was like a refrigerator. So it turned out to be a blessing in disguise.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A view of the Tel Aviv beach from our hotel room." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/telaviv-hotel-view.jpg">
A view of the Tel Aviv beach from our hotel room.
Tel Aviv is a mostly modern city
column2: so there isn't much to see in terms of tourist spots
column3: other than museums and such. However
column4: there's so much to see in the rest of Israel
column5: that I took tours to other parts of the country while David was at the conference.

column2: which is a small neighborhood at the southern end of Tel Aviv. It's filled with small art galleries and other shops. It's particularly beautiful at night. David got a recommendation to go to a restaurant owned by the Israeli version of Emeril LaGasse. The food was excellent. I'm still dreaming about my dessert which was chocolate-cardamom ice cream with a caramel sauce.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A street in Jaffa at night" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/telaviv-jaffa-1.jpg">
A street in Jaffa at night
<a class="thickbox" title="An old building in Jaffa" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/telaviv-jaffa-2.jpg">

column2: I took a tour to the Sea of Galilee to see spots that are famous in the New Testament. Our tour guide was Solomon Golan and there were two other guests on the tour. Our first stop was to Nazareth
column3: where we visited the Church of the Annunciation. This is the spot where the angel Gabriel told Mary what she was going to give birth to Jesus. Unfortunately
column4: the original church that was built there is long gone. You learn quickly in Israel that almost everything was destroyed by either the Romans
column5: the Syrians
column6: the Turks
column7: or the Crusaders. However
column8: there were still some remnants of the old church left.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The front of the Church of the Annnunciation" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-annunciation-front.jpg">
The front of the Church of the Annnunciation
<a class="thickbox" title="Inside the church you can see a bit of the original church left over" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-annunciation-inside.jpg">
Inside the church you can see a bit of the original church left over
<a class="thickbox" title="The outside of the Church of the Annunciation" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-annunciation-back.jpg">
The outside of the Church of the Annunciation

column2: we went to a little shop where I had some Turkish coffee (yea
column3: caffeine!) and some date juice (never had that before). Our guide
column4: Solomon
column5: stopped at a "tabboun" and got some fresh pita bread. The bread was about the size of a pizza and covered with olive oil and spices. Since it was fresh from the oven
column6: we had to wait to let it cool down
column7: which was fine because the traffic out of Nazareth was very slow. This was also my first realization that there are plenty of areas in Israel where Jews and Arabs live with little to no conflict. Nazareth is an arab town and Solomon was on good terms with everyone there. In fact
column8: most of the area that we drove around was populated with Arabs.

column2: where Jesus performed the miracle of the loaves and fishes. There is a beautiful little church built there to commemorate the event.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A mosaic of loaves and fishes" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-loaves-and-fishes.jpg">
A mosaic of loaves and fishes

Also in Tabgah is the Church of the Primacy of Peter which is where Jesus appeared to the Apostles after his resurrection. In the middle of the church is the rock where Jesus told Peter that he was the rock on which to build the church. There are pictures on the wall of various Popes that have come to kiss the rock. This was the first place that
column2: to me
column3: felt like a "holy" site. There was something ethereal about this location above and beyond the other spots that we had visited so far. The grounds around the church are lush
column4: well kept and rather beautiful compared to the desert-like landscape just beyond the church.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The rock of the Church of the Primacy of Peter" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-rock.jpg">
The rock of the Church of the Primacy of Peter
<a class="thickbox" title="A view of the Galilee" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-walk-on-water.jpg">
Our next stop was Capernaum. It was the home of several of the apostles and has a synagogue dating back to the 4th century B.C.
<a class="thickbox" title="The Roman ruins of Capernaum" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-synagogue.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="Another shot of the synagogue" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-synagogue-3.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The remains of Simon Peter's House" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-jesus-house.jpg">
The remains of Simon Peter's House

Our next stop was lunch. We stopped at a resort town along the Galilee called Tiberias. There were kids swimming in the water. We had a fish called "St. Peter's Fish" which comes from the Sea of Galilee. I later found out that it is a variety of tilapia.

Our final stop before heading home was at the Yardenet Baptism Site. This was supposedly the location where John the Baptist baptized Jesus Christ. No one knows for sure exactly where the event took place
column2: but they know how many days Jesus walked from a certain location and have estimated that this must have been the place. In any case
column3: it's a beautiful location. People still come to be baptized all the time. No one was there to be baptized the day I was there
column4: but I included a picture from the internet of what it looks like when people are there.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Facing south from the location" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-baptism-1.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="Facing north from the location" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-baptism-3.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The site of a baptism" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/galilee-baptism.jpg">

"Masada & the Dead Sea";"personal/travel/israel/masada-dead-sea";"

My second full day in Israel
column2: I was on my own for the day again
column3: so I signed up for another tour. This one was to Masada and the Dead Sea. There were seven tourists on this trip.

column1: Masada is a mountain-top fortress built by King Herod around the 2nd century BC. It was also the final stronghold of the Jews of the Zealot sect who were the last remaining Jews in Israel against the Romans. This fortress was under siege for 2 years before the Romans were able to breach the walls. When the Romans arrived
column2: they found that all but a couple of the inhabitants had committed suicide. This is where the phrase "better to die free than live a slave" came from. They suppose that the only survivors were left to tell the story of Masada because they were old women they would not be of use as slaves.

column1: The fortress is 1300 feet up a pretty steep cliff. To get to the top
column2: you could either hike up a snake trail (it takes about an hour) or take a cable car. Either way
column3: it's not good for people afraid of heights. I hadn't really figured that part out until it was too late. But I smiled and didn't look down and was on top of the mountain in no time. The trip was fascinating and I couldn't possibly go into all the details of things we learned on the trip.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A view from the top of the Dead Sea" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/masada-dead-sea.jpg">
A view from the top of the Dead Sea
<a class="thickbox" title="A shot of the grainery in Masada" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/masada-cable.jpg">
A shot of the grainery in Masada
<a class="thickbox" title="Some of the original mosaic" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/masada-mosaic-1.jpg">

column2: we stopped for lunch and then went to the Dead Sea. It's called the Dead Sea because it's so full of salt and minerals that nothing can live in it. It's supposed to have healing powers and be great for your skin. You can splash around in the mud
column3: but I skipped that and just went to the water. Our tour guide gave us a HUGE list of things to be afraid of about the Dead Sea: if you swallow any of the water
column4: you could die; if the water gets in your eyes
column5: it stings TERRIBLY; because you're so bouyant
column6: it's difficult to move around in the water and you may PANIC and swallow water. At one point
column7: I did get water in my eyes and it didn't sting THAT badly. And I did swallow some water and became paranoid that I was going to pass out later
column8: but nothing happened. Mainly
column9: I just floated around in the water. It was very relaxing and my skin did feel great afterwards. Also
column10: in my dream I had before coming to Israel
column11: we had visited the Dead Sea. Once I saw it in person
column12: I realized it related to the dream.

column2: we stopped to take pictures of the caves where they found the Dead Sea Scrolls. I'm not going to try to describe their significance here. We also saw a few bedouin camps along the way. They are small tribes of people that live in the desert without many (if any) modern conveniences. And we saw a real Canaan Dog at one of the camps. Unfortunately
column3: I was too slow with the camera to get a picture.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Caves of Qumran: Where they found the Dead Sea Scrolls" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/masada-deadseascrolls.jpg">
Caves of Qumran: Where they found the Dead Sea Scrolls

"Jerusalem";"personal/travel/israel/jerusalem";"

Our trip to Jerusalem started with a visit to the Model of the Second Temple Period. This gives one a nice perspective on what Jerusalem looked like before the destruction of the temple by the Romans. The model covered all of Jerusalem in 1:25 scale. It helps get a bearing on what one is about to see.
<a class="thickbox" title="The Model of the Second Temple Period" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-secondtemple.jpg">
The Model of the Second Temple Period
<a class="thickbox" title="The Model of the Actual Second Temple" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-secondtemple2.jpg">
The Model of the Actual Second Temple

column2: the David Citadel Hotel. It is gorgeous - one of the nicest hotels I've ever stayed at. Our room overlooked the pool
column3: which I swam in once while we were there. We had a great view of the old city. One night
column4: we woke up at around 10:30pm to the sound of sharp explosions. There was one loud "bang" and then a smattering of more. We assumed that it was gunfire. Then I went to look out our window and saw fireworks. It was part of a sound and light show over David's Citadel.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The view from our room of the pool and David's Citadel" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-hotel-pool.jpg">
The view from our room of the pool and David's Citadel
Since our first day in Jerusalem was only a half day
column2: we did sightseeing on our own. We primarily walked around the markets
column3: went to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre
column4: and had Turkish coffee. We were lucky enough to meet a tour guide at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre named Jaliel. He seemed to know what he was talking about
column5: so we decided to sign up with him for a tour the next day. I can't go into everything we saw and learned on the tour. It was amazing. We went to parts of the Via Dolorosa (which traces the 14 stations of the cross) that most other tour groups seemed to miss. We visited an Ethiopian monastery on the roof of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. And everywhere we went
column6: Jaliel exchanged hellos to the locals whether they were Greek Orthodox fathers or the local Arabs. He was an excellent tour guide.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The old walls of Jerusalem leading to Jaffa Gate" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-oldwalls.jpg">
The old walls of Jerusalem leading to Jaffa Gate

We started off walking around the walls of the old city into the Mount of Olives. Jaliel pointed out recent excavations along the walls of ancient Roman houses. You could see the changes of the rocks in walls where they had been fortified by different periods
column2: from Roman to Byzantine periods.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Kidron Valley featuring Tower of Absalom and surrounded by Jewish graves" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-absalom.jpg">
Kidron Valley featuring Tower of Absalom and surrounded by Jewish graves

The first big stop on our tour was Gethsemane. There's a very beautiful church there called The Church of All Nations that has some of the most fanciful mosaics I've seen in a church. I was hoping to come back to the church later in the trip because it's the kind of place that you could stay for hours meditating
column2: but unfortunately
column3: there was never time to come back. I guess I'll have to wait for another trip to Jerusalem.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Church of All Nations" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/gethsemane-outside.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The Garden of Gethsemane" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/gethsemane-garden.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="Inside the Church of All Nations. Check out the mosaic of flowers on the ceiling." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/gethsemane-mosaic.jpg">
Inside the Church of All Nations. Check out the mosaic of flowers on the ceiling.

column2: we walked to the Tomb of the Virgin where Mary is buried. Our guide
column3: Jaliel
column4: emphasized this by saying it twice
column5: the actual tomb where the mother of Jesus Christ is buried. For some reason it felt tacky taking a picture of such a holy site
column6: so I didn't. It's a beautiful church
column7: though
column8: and should be experienced. There was a line to walk into the actual tomb which can only fit about 3 people. I was able to see in and that was enough for me.

column1: As we were outside the old city walls
column2: Jaliel pointed out Golden Gate. It is currently bricked over so that no one can use it. The Golden (or Mercy) Gate appears in the legends of all three religions. An early Jewish tradition holds that it is through that gate that the Messiah will enter Jerusalem. According to Christian tradition
column3: Jesus made made his last entry to Jerusalem through the Mercy Gate. The Muslims refer to it as the Gate of Mercy and believe it to be the gate referred to in the Koran
column4: through which the just will pass on the Day of Judgment.

column1: After touring outside the old city walls
column2: it was time to cross into Old Jerusalem. We came in via the Lion's Gate in the Muslim quarter. Our tour started at the first station of the Via Dolorosa and went in sequential order. Early on
column3: my camera pooped out
column4: so I don't have most of the pictures from this part of the trip. The Via Dolorosa follows every spot of Christ's steps leading to his crucifixion and burial. It starts with the Ecce Homo Arch where Pontius Pilate is said to have declared "Behold the Man". It actually starts with where he was condemned to death
column5: but that is now a Muslim school.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Monastery of Flagellation (the 2nd Station)" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-viadolorosa-1.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="A Garden at the Monastery of Flagellation" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-viadolorosa-3.jpg">
A Garden at the Monastery of Flagellation
<a class="thickbox" title="The Crown of Thorns Site" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-viadolorosa-2.jpg">
It was around this time that my camera went kaput for the day. I was able to salvage it later at the hotel. Anyway
column2: we saw the rest of the Via Dolorosa
column3: Jesus' prison
column4: where he stumbled
column5: etc. We went onto the roof of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre and down through it. There's no way we would have seen even half of the things that we saw without our tour guide. He seemed to know everyone. A couple people on the street told us that we had a very good guide and I agree.

column2: we were exhausted. David took a nap and answered email. I went swimming in the hotel pool and read. I was able to get my camera functioning again and took other photos in Jerusalem on other days.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A nice view of Jerusalem in the Muslim Quarter" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-alley.jpg">
A nice view of Jerusalem in the Muslim Quarter
<a class="thickbox" title="Another pretty shot of Jerusalem" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-unknown.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="A mosaic in the Jewish Quarter" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-jewishquarter-mosaic.jpg">
A mosaic in the Jewish Quarter
<a class="thickbox" title="The Dome of the Rock and the Western Wall in Jerusalem" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/jerusalem-dome-of-the-rock.jpg">
The Dome of the Rock and the Western Wall in Jerusalem

"Arab Markets";"personal/travel/israel/arab-markets";"

Jerusalem is more than just the land of religious epiphanies. It is also full of the most cut-throat market owners I've ever seen. The shop keepers will do anything to get you in their store. You are constantly hounded as you walk down the streets of Jerusalem. They will even stand in front of you as your walking so that you can't pass quickly. We knew enough to ignore them
column2: but they had some sneaky tactics. Several times we would ignore them and keep walking
column3: and they would shout "excuse me!" after us as if to say
column4: "how could you be so rude as to ignore me!"

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A street in the Christian Quarter" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/market-1.jpg">
A street in the Christian Quarter
<a class="thickbox" title="Another street in the Christian Quarter" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/market-2.jpg">
Another street in the Christian Quarter

column2: David and I stopped for turkish coffee and baklava. At that point
column3: we asked someone for directions to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. They boy that we asked turned out to plague us the entire trip. I came to dread seeing him. He was very helpful
column4: but we ended up in his father's shop
column5: which was actually pretty good. We did most of our souvenir shopping there. However
column6: whenever he saw us for the rest of the trip
column7: he would come over to us (or just me if I was alone)
column8: offer to buy us tea
column9: and try to get us to go to his father's shop.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="We stumbled into a square looking for turkish coffee" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/market-david.jpg">
We stumbled into a square looking for turkish coffee
<a class="thickbox" title="A view of where we stopped" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/market-coffeebreak.jpg">
A view of where we stopped
<a class="thickbox" title="The shop owners that we made very happy. The kid that found us is in the center." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/market-petracaves.jpg">
The shop owners that we made very happy. The kid that found us is in the center.

"The Church of the Holy Sepulchre";"personal/travel/israel/church-holy-sepulchre";"

Out of everything we saw on the trip
column2: the Church of the Holy Sepulchre was by far my favorite. I went there three times: with David on our first day
column3: with our tour guide Jaliel on the second day (and he took us some areas that we never would have found on our own)
column4: and at the end of our second day to visit the inside of Christ's Tomb. I could talk on and on about the church
column5: but you should just go there and see it for yourself. It is divided up by six different denominations: the Greek Orthodox
column6: the Armenians
column7: the Franciscans
column8: the Ethiopians
column9: the Christian Arabs
column10: and I think the Syrians have a section in there too. I forget.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The steps that lead to Golgotha." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/holysepulchre-1.jpg">
The steps that lead to Golgotha.
<a class="thickbox" title="The Stone of Unction where Christ's body was annointed and wrapped." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/holysepulchre-rock.jpg">
The Stone of Unction where Christ's body was annointed and wrapped.

I have to admit that I had a bit of a freak out when we first went to the church. It's hard to describe. I've grown up hearing and reading all these stories and all of a sudden I was staring at the hole in Golgotha where Christ's crucifix went and it stopped being some faraway story. I've written several sentences just now that I've deleted and decided that one's reaction to this church is very personal. I'm not going to describe what I felt
column2: but I will say that it moved me very deeply every time I went. These pictures pale in comparison to what it's like experiencing the real thing.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The entrance to Christ's Tomb. It's only big enough for 3 or 4 people
column2: so there's a line to get in." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/holyspeulchre-chiststomb.jpg">
so there's a line to get in." src="/files/photos/israel/holyspeulchre-chiststomb.jpg" height="200" width="150">

column1: <div class="journalCaption">The entrance to Christ's Tomb. It's only big enough for 3 or 4 people
column2: so there's a line to get in.

column1:
"Bethlehem";"personal/travel/israel/bethlehem";"

The morning of our last full day in Israel
column2: I went to Bethlehem. This was a big deal for a few different reasons. First of all
column3: it's the birthplace of Jesus Christ. Secondly
column4: it was the place that I had a dream about several months prior to visitting it. And thirdly
column5: it was in the West Bank under Palestinian control. Israeli tour guides are not allowed to go into the West Bank for security reasons
column6: so if you want to go
column7: you have to figure out how to get there. There are tours that go there
column8: but I couldn't find any. You will occasionally hear someone on the street say that they are willing to take you to Bethlehem
column9: but I don't want to go with a stranger for obvious reasons. Our tour guide from the Via Dolorosa
column10: Jaliel
column11: offered to take me
column12: so I took him up on it. David did not go because he did not want to make himself a target to angry Palestinians. However
column15: been a target for terrorism in Israel.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Nativity Square in Bethlehem" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/bethlehem-square.jpg">
I met Jaliel in Old Jerusalem. He took me through into East Jerusalem
column2: the muslim part of town
column3: to get a shared taxi that would take us to the West Bank. A shared taxi fits between 10-20 people. It's a little bigger than a mini-van. I was quite obviously the only non-arab on the taxi. Although Bethlehem is only a 15 minute drive away from Jerusalem
column4: we had to go through Israel checkpoints to get there and since the wall had been built
column5: we had to use an indirect road to get into Bethlehem. Before the Israeli guard got on the bus to check passports
column6: Jaliel asked me to NOT say that I was going to Bethlehem. He told me to say that we were visitting friends in Gosh Etsyon. He said that the guards don't like to hear that tourist are going to Bethlehem
column7: but I think there was some other reason. Still
column8: I was already nervous at that point and the thought of being told to lie to an Israeli guard in full military gear was not making me feel at ease. Luckily
column9: the guard didn't ask. The shared taxi went on for a while and we got off at a non-descript stop in the street. There was no sign
column10: no house
column11: it just seemed like a dirt road. But we found a taxi right away that took us to Bethlehem where I met a certified Palestinian tour guide that took me to the Church of the Nativity.

column1: And now on to the Church of the Nativity. First of all
column2: it's the ONLY church in Israel that was not destroyed by the Syrians in the 6th century. When the Syrians came to destroy all the churches
column3: they saw the mosaics in the Church of the Nativity and saw the wise men in Syrian dress and thought it was a Syrian church. Secondly
column4: the visit to this church was right out of my dream. As soon as I saw the entrance to the church
column5: I had a slight freak-out
column6: because it was right out of my dream. You have to duck to go into the church to make you humble and to keep camels and horses out of the church.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The entrance to the Church of the Nativity" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/bethlehem-entrance.jpg">
The entrance to the Church of the Nativity
<a class="thickbox" title="The mosaics from the original church. They are now mostly covered to protect them
column2: I guess." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/bethlehem-mosaic.jpg">
I guess." src="/files/photos/israel/bethlehem-mosaic.jpg" height="200" width="150">

column1: <div class="journalCaption">The mosaics from the original church. They are now mostly covered to protect them
column2: I guess.

column1: The inside of the church is beautiful. Unfortunately
column2: almost every photo I took came out incredibly blurry. I don't know if this is God's doing or Sony's. My guide took me down to the area where Christ was born. He said we only have a few minutes between the Catholic mass and the Armenian mass to visit the birthplace
column3: which we did. Once again
column4: I felt the vibrations of being in a holy location. It was incredible. And I had another moment of seeing something that was in my dream.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The original Black Madonna" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/bethlehem-blackmadonna.jpg">

column2: we went back to a souvenir shop (whenever you have a tour guide
column3: your tour will end up at a souvenir shop)
column4: I bought some things to support the local economy and had some mint tea. The Palestinians were extremely friendly and less pushy than I had been used to. I think they were a little beat down that tourism had come to a near standstill for the past five years. Most of the shops in the town were closed. Apparently
column5: the Pope had come to bless that Church of the Nativity in 2000 and a bunch of people bought shops thinking that the Pope's visit would promote tourism. Then the Intifada started and everything came to a halt. It's quite sad. We got lucky on the way back in that we found an Israeli taxi that was willing to take us over the border and back to Jerusalem.

column1:
"Western Wall";"personal/travel/israel/western-wall";"

The second half of our last full day in Israel was dedicated to the Western Wall. The Western Wall is the only remaining portion of the Temple Mount that King Herod built for the Jews. The Temple Mount was destroyed by the Romans. It is now the location of the muslim Dome of the Rock (where Muhammed left the earth to talk with God)
column2: and it is also supposedly the rock where Abraham was commanded to sacrifice Isaac
column3: so you get to see the problems that people have about which group has more claim to the land than someone else. You almost expect to see a sign posted that says "No more religious epiphanies in this area
column4: please". The Western Wall also functions as an open air synagogue. There are always people praying. I had that look of "easy convert" on my face and was approached twice by people trying to convert me to some particular sect of Judaism. All along the Western Wall
column5: people write prayers on paper
column6: fold them up
column7: and place them in the cracks of the wall. Although it's most prevalent here
column8: I saw this being done as far north as the Sea of Galilee.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Visitors to the Western Wall" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/westernwall-prayers.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="A close-up of the prayers written in notes in the stone cracks" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/westernwall-notes.jpg">
A close-up of the prayers written in notes in the stone cracks
David and I took a tour that takes you underneath the city of Jerusalem and walk all along the Western Wall. Apparently
column2: they have concerts and other events underneath the city in this area.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The very bottom of this pciture is one big stone that is estimated to weight 600 tons!" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/westernwall-stone.jpg">
The very bottom of this pciture is one big stone that is estimated to weight 600 tons!
<a class="thickbox" title="This picture doesn't really capture the grandeur of the height of the tour." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/israel/westernwall-hall.JPG">
This picture doesn't really capture the grandeur of the height of the tour.

"Farewell to Israel";"personal/travel/israel/farewell-israel";"

WAAAH! I don't want to leave! Luckily
column2: we had to get up at 2 am to catch a taxi to the airport
column3: so I was too sleepy to get emotional about it. If you've ever thought about going to Israel
column4: then GO! Don't put it off. These pictures are nothing compared to experiencing it firsthand. Now is a good time to go because there aren't a huge amount of tourists.

column1: Getting through the Ben Gurion Airport was relatively painless. We got asked a lot of questions about the nature of our visit. We had to come out to the security guard interviewing us. She eventually asked me
column2: "So. You've been living together for five years and this is your first visit to Israel? What took you so long?" We got into the airline lounge because we were flying business class. David knocked over the glass jar of candy at the front desk and it made a very large crash and shattered into a million pieces. Then I saw a very pushy man trying to be first on the plane and in his rush he tripped over luggage and did one of those slow motion falls where you repeatedly think he's going to catch himself but then eventually fell flat on his face. I was too tired to respond to all of this early morning slapstick
column3: but once the coffee kicked in I was giggling all the way to Zurich about David knocking over the candies and this pushy man losing his dignity in front of everyone.

column1:
I can always tell if it's a good trip because I have no jet lag on the way there and I have a lot of jet lag when I come home. This was one of those trips.

";"1125550800";"textile"
"Chiapas!";"personal/travel/mexico/chiapas";"David and I scheduled to take a tour with Maya Sites (http://www.mayasites.com) through the southern area of Mexico for the fall of 2005. Unfortunately
column2: David took a trip of his own on 23rd street and broke his foot weeks before our vacation. So we postponed that trip and re-scheduled it with the same company for their "Festivals of the Highland Rainforest Maya". And I'm so glad that David broke his foot because this trip that we took instead was amazing!";"1141192800";"textile"

column1:
"Villahermosa";"personal/travel/mexico/villahermosa";"

Our flight went from La Guardia in New York
column2: to Mexico City
column3: and then to Villahermosa. We left a lot of time in Mexico City since we had to go through customs. For some reason
column4: we got through customs RIDICULOUSLY quickly and we were left with a long layover in the Mexico City airport. Unfortunately
column5: it's not the best airport to get stuck in. Now that I know it a bit better
column6: I would have found the one upscale area and spent some time shopping. We didn't know better at the time
column7: though
column8: and so we just hung out in the main waiting area. Time seemed to pass at an all-time slow. It didn't help that we had gotten up at something like 4 in the morning and the airport was not air conditioned. There's nothing like being tired
column9: hot
column10: and wearing warm clothes because you jsut left a place that's still in winter. We were also somewhat lucky to make the connection to Villahermosa. We had been listening carefully and heard the gate being called about 15 minutes prior to our flight taking off. We never saw a gate being posted on the electronic boards throughout the airport - even when we arrived at the gate. I think the locals that take that flight all the time know the gate. Anyway
column11: the flight there was pleasant and uneventful.

column1: We checked into our hotel and unwound. Our hotel was next to the Hyatt and I believe were the only two upscale hotels in that area. There's not much to see in Villahermosa other than the Olmec heads. We asked at the hotel for a good place for dinner. They (and the guidebook) suggested VIPS. I had a vague recollection of a VIPS in northern California. I thought they were more in the category of a Denny's than a nice restaurant. David double-checked and said something along the lines of "Are you sure it's a good restuarant?" The person at the hotel smiled and ensured us that it was a good restaurant. It turns out that I was right. Vips is a Mexican Denny's. We had to do some shopping first for bottled water and bug repellant
column2: so we passed VIPS. We ended up eating a Sanbourne's which we suspect was better than VIPS - but who can tell. It was probably a toss-up.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Our hotel had a nice lobby - including a Mayan-inspired mural that covered one wall." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/villahermosa-lobby.jpg">
Our hotel had a nice lobby - including a Mayan-inspired mural that covered one wall.

<a class="thickbox" title="This is the courtyard where our room was located. I didn't know the person in the shot until later. Her name is Kelly and she was part of our tour group. You have no idea how good it feels to see this in the middle of a New York winter." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/villahermosa-courtyard.jpg">

This is the courtyard where our room was located. I didn't know the person in the shot until later. Her name is Kelly and she was part of our tour group. You have no idea how good it feels to see this in the middle of a New York winter.
<a class="thickbox" title="David relaxing in the hotel room after a long day of air travel." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/villahermosa-david.jpg">
David relaxing in the hotel room after a long day of air travel.

"Bonampak / Yaxchilán";"personal/travel/mexico/bonampak-yaxchil-n";"

Today we had an early start. We met at 6:30 to visit all the stops. And it's a good thing
column2: because we had some surprises later on the trip that delayed us for a few hours. We started off with about a 45 minute drive to lunch spot. I forgot to ask for the details of where we were
column3: but looking back at the map now
column4: I think we were at Rio Chancalá. It was a small tourist stop on the road with excellent homemade breakfasts under a thatched roof. There was a large German tour bus that stopped for breakfast at the same time we did.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Breakfast at Rio Chancalá. David is at the left of the table. Although he looks like he's focusing on the conversation
column2: he's really contemplating having another quesadilla." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-breakfast.jpg">
he's really contemplating having another quesadilla." src="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-breakfast.jpg" height="266" width="400">

column1: <div class="journalCaption">Breakfast at Rio Chancalá. David is at the left of the table. Although he looks like he's focusing on the conversation
column2: he's really contemplating having another quesadilla.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="We passed a sign warning us that we were entering Zapatista territoy. I was blissfully ignorant of the details of the sign." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-zapatista.jpg">
We passed a sign warning us that we were entering Zapatista territoy. I was blissfully ignorant of the details of the sign.

column2: we climbed aboard the van
column3: hit the road
column4: and...didn't get very far.

column1: About 15 minutes into the next section
column2: the traffic all came to a stop. The local Mayans had blocked off the road as a protest to the government. And that is the only road that takes us from where we were to where we wanted to go. In fact
column3: if it hadn't been for the Zapatista revolution
column4: there wouldn't be a road at all because the government paved roads so that they can easily get the military into towns and control the locals. Our van driver went to talk to the locals. Apparently three men had died in a fight over land the day before. The locals had been asking the government to intervene for some time and put down clear ownership of the land. Our van happened to be stopped right in front of a house where they were holding a funeral for one of the deceased. There were women showing up in traditional Mayan dresses
column5: followed by a lot of crying and singing
column6: a small dingy white truck showed up and they loaded a casket onto the truck and drove off. The government made a big show - helicopters flew over head
column7: police rode up
column8: and then the military drove up in riot gear. It didn't make any difference. Each time a new group showed up
column9: it looked like the protesters were going to leave
column10: but they kept their ground. Our tour guide was clearly worried. We found out later that they have sometimes blocked the road for days without letting people through. Eventually they got some positive response from the government and they started letting people through. Our van driver was right
column11: wait a couple hours and they'll let us through as long as we pay 200 pesos. And that's what happened.

column2: we were back on the road to Bonampak. We had another hour and a half
column3: I suppose
column4: before we got there. Our tour guide said that the locals at Bonampak were one of the Mayan groups that had mostly given up their Mayan way of life and tried to survive on the tourist industry. Unfortunately
column5: the tourist industry isn't enough to support them. They did not seem to be as healthy as the other Mayan groups that we had encountered up until that point who were poor
column6: undoubtedly
column7: but self-sufficient. The site of Bonampak was quite amazing. The murals are still quite colorful
column8: but had clearly lost a lot of color over the past fifteen years (our tour guide had photos of what they used to look like). Once upon a time
column9: they were covered by a dust that had preserved them
column10: but when the archeologists uncovered the dust
column11: the murals started fading. So run to Bonampak! These murals won't be around for long!

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This is our group having just arrived at the site of Bonampak." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-site.jpg">
This is our group having just arrived at the site of Bonampak.
<a class="thickbox" title="A Room at Bonampak" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonamapak-mural.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="A Room at Bonampak" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-mural-1.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="This mural depicts a captured and bleeding warrior in the bottom" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-mural-2.jpg">
This mural depicts a captured and bleeding warrior in the bottom
<a class="thickbox" title="A Room at Bonampak" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-mural-3.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="A Room at Bonampak" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-mural.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="A Room at Bonampak" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-room.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="One of the more impressive reliefs." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-relief.jpg">
One of the more impressive reliefs.
<a class="thickbox" title="Another very large relief at Bonampak" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/bonampak-relief-1.jpg">
Another very large relief at Bonampak

column2: it was back to the van and an hour drive to Yaxchilán. Since we were late getting to Yaxchilán from the road block
column3: we skipped lunch and grabbed some snacks at a small store before getting on the boats to Yaxchilán. You cannot reach the ruins by car
column4: you have to take a small boat to the ruins. It's about a 45 minute trip up the river.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A shot of the boats to go to Yaxchilán" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/yaxchilan-boats.jpg">
A shot of the boats to go to Yaxchilán
<a class="thickbox" title="The front of our boat" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/yaxchilan-boatfront.jpg">

<a class="thickbox" title="David started singing \"Proud Mary\" quite loudly (\"ROLLING! ROLLING! ROLLING DOWN THE RIV-ER!\") Just kidding. I think I caught him pre-sneeze." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/yaxchilan-proudmary.jpg">
David started singing "Proud Mary" quite loudly ("ROLLING! ROLLING! ROLLING DOWN THE RIV-ER!") Just kidding. I think I caught him pre-sneeze.
The ruins at Yaxchilán are impressive. They weren't as monumental as Palenque
column2: but there was some very dramatic sites. Also
column3: since the site is so hard to get to
column4: it's a lot less invaded by tourists. Our first stop was through a temple of the dead - which is a structure to honor the underworld. There wasn't a lot to see because it's primary function was to be completely dark on the inside. Even walking up to it
column5: it felt as if we had walked into a set for an Indiana Jones movie. At the entrance
column6: our guide pointed out some bats hanging from the ceiling. I went in last of our group since I was fiddling with the camera. As I walked in
column7: I heard the guide say "There's a wolf spider on the wall. See that?" I didn't know what a wolf spider looked like
column8: but I didn't really want to find out. I sort of instinctively took a few steps back outside and into the sunlight. I decided that I was being a wimp
column9: so I started to walk back in (it was pitch black inside with the exception of the guide's flashlight). Then I heard our guide say "Wait. Where did it go?" I thought about not going back in. Wolf spiders sound bad enough. Jumping wolf spiders I can do without. I was comforted when I heard the guide say "that's not a very big wolf spider". I started to step back in and heard him say "Now there's a big wolf spider." Okay. We're now plural. And we had reached a large size. The part of me that has no interest in hanging out with large spiders said "Why do you want to hang out in a dark
column10: cramped space with spiders? No thank you. And I stepped back out. Out in the sun
column11: all fears of spiders left. I felt like an idiot. There were old women on our tour with more bravery than me. This was ridiculous. So I started to go back inside. And heard the guide say "See overhead? Those are vampire bats." At that point
column12: I decided I was actually the smart one by hanging back. What do I benefit from hanging out with bats and spiders? I'll pass
column13: thank you. And I happily waited outside for the group to finish. I asked David later how big the big wolf spider was. He said "Well it wasn't only a couple of inches tall." Sensing that he was leaving something out
column14: I asked how long it was. "About this long": and he held up his hands to be about a foot long. I praised the part of my brain that told me to give up on a false sense of masculinity and just stay outside.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Walking up to the Temple of the Dead" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/yaxchilan-deadroom.jpg">
Walking up to the Temple of the Dead
<a class="thickbox" title="Coming out the other end of the temple" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/yaxchilan-deadtemple.jpg">
Coming out the other end of the temple

The tour of Yaxchilán was great. It was one of the highlights of the trip. There are some incredible temples at the top of hills. The reliefs were fascinating. Many of them featured blood-letting rituals. The women would pierce their tongues and run thorny vines through the hole. The king would pierce his foreskin. We also got some time walking through the jungle to some of the largely unexcavated areas of the ruins.
<a class="thickbox" title="Climbing up to the basketball court" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/yaxchilan-ballcourt.jpg">
Climbing up to the basketball court
<a class="thickbox" title="A good hike up to the ruins" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/yaxchilan-climb.jpg">
A good hike up to the ruins
We walked through the jungle a bit and then took the boats back to main road. Our guide took us to the local cultural center that also acts as a restaurant in the evening. We were in a bit of hurry
column2: because we wanted to get home before it got too dark. Mainly because people and dogs wander along the road. He said that he didn't want to hit any pigs on the way home
column3:
but we assumed he was saying "pigs" instead of "dogs" so as not to worry anyone. There were dogs walking all along the road all day. It's a miracle that we didn't hit any (thank God).

";"1141192800";"textile"

column1:
"Palenque";"personal/travel/mexico/palenque";"

Today was our first real touring day
column2: although it started off with a long car drive. We got up relateively early to prepare for the trip. A car was picking us up and taking us to Palenque to visit the ruins. We met two of our group - a young woman named Kelly from Washington D.C. and an older woman named Melanie from Sacramento. We made polite conversation
column3: but it ran out quickly considering we didn't really know each other. It was about 2 and a half hours to Palenque. It was good to adjust oneself to the fact that we were in Mexico. That area was particularly lush and green. As we got closer to the ruins
column4: our driver pointed them out from a distance. It was quite exciting to see how large they were from a distance.

column1: There was some initial confusion when we first showed up at Palenque. Apparently
column2: our tour guide had already started walking around the site with the three people that were part of our tour that were already in Palenque. So we met the rest of our group: a British couple named John and Teresa and a former Brit/current Norwegian Mike. They were on a several week tour of most of southern Mexico. This trip landed in the middle of their overall tour.
it's humungous. Not only are the ruins themselves quite large
column3: but it's very extensive. There are also some 1
column4: 400 structures identified at Palenque. We only went through the most prominent ones - about eight of them. The tour was very thorough hitting everything from the ancient bathrooms
column5: to how they built the wall
column6: to the carvings. It's silly of me to try to go through every detail that we explored there
column7: so I won't. Here are some photos.

column1: After a few hours of walking the grounds
column2: we went to a place about 15 minutes down the road for lunch. There was a small collection of restaurants and hotels called El Panchán. We ate at a restaurant called "Don Mucho's" and is owned by the brother of our tour guide. We later found out in our guide book that our tour guide's family is something of local royalty.

column1: After lunch there was more exploration of the ruins at Palenque. We got more detail on Pakal's palace
column2: walked through a tomb of an unidentified woman
column3: and then headed off to the museum at Palenque to see some of the items that were taken out of the ruins and preserved. David and I kept hearing this loud occasional roaring from the forest just outside of the ruins. It was occasionally quite loud. It sounded as if someone had a special effects record of a roaring animal - like a jaguar or tiger. We didn't think much of it at the time because it did sound like it was coming from a stereo system
column4: but a few days later at Yaxchilán
column5: we asked someone and they told us that it was howler monkeys. I decided that if a single monkey could make that sound
column6: I didn't want to run into that monkey.

column2:
we checked into our hotel in Palenque where we'd be staying for the next three nights. The hotel was nice enough. We took a walk into the main part of Palenque after settling into the hotel and ate dinner in a restaurant off of the town square - which was hopping at night.

";"1141192800";"textile"

column1:
"Tenosique";"personal/travel/mexico/tenosique";"

Today was our first "festival" day. We went to a town called Tenosique where they have been having this very bizarre festival for hundreds of years. It's a bit hard to describe. It takes place every Sunday starting in January and ends with lent. A few select people dress up as jaguars - they paint their body orange
column2: use a Coke bottle to make black spots on their skin
column3: and drape an actual jaguar pelt over their back. We got access to where some of those people were preparing to get some good pictures.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A couple of jaguar dancers" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-jaguars.jpg">
The majority of the participants dress up as someone called Cojo. They dress mostly in white
column2: wrap banana leaves around their ankles
column3: wear masks
column4: capes
column5: and hats with tall pointy leaves in them. Our guide said that the story that they're enacting is a little vague
column6: but supposedly it has to do with Cojo drawing out the evil jaguar and taming it. I don't really know. He said that people generally think that the Cojo character represents a Spanish conquistador
column7: but David pointed out that they look more like a giant ear of corn.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Our guide trying on a Cojo mask" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-preparations.jpg">
Our guide trying on a Cojo mask
<a class="thickbox" title="A family preparing and posing for us" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-preparations-1.jpg">
A family preparing and posing for us
<a class="thickbox" title="Mom is helping the family prepare" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-preparations-2.jpg">
Mom is helping the family prepare
<a class="thickbox" title="David is the one wearing a mask" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-davidmask.jpg">
David is the one wearing a mask
We waited along the street for the action to heat up. The Cojo characters have small boxes with holes in the top. They will come up to you
column2: shake the box and grunt at you. This is a sign that they want you to drop a couple of pesos in the box. I learned early on that I should not pull all of my change out of my pocket and pick out one small coin in view of the person demanding money. They will not be satisfied with one measly peso! Several times
column3: David went to buy a piece of candy and ask for change to give the Cojo people. It's sort of like Halloween. Most of the people dressed as Cojo are kids.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="People are starting to gather for the dance" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-cojos.jpg">
People are starting to gather for the dance
<a class="thickbox" title="A pair of Cojos" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-cojos-1.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="David posing with a Cojo" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-davidandcojo.jpg">

column2: a small kid (about 10) stopped by and started talking to us in very good English. His name was Alessio. He often came up to us later in the day to talk to us. He was holding something in his cape that David noticed a little later. A giant phallus. Our guide warned us that there were going to be some sexual/suggestive elements in the dance. I guess I wasn't expecting kids to be walking around with large phalluses. I tend to think he was hiding it in his cape when he talked to us because he knew we would think it was weird.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Alessio and his friends" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-alessio.jpg">

We hung out with a group preparing and then went into the festival. There's a moving dance that is somewhat controlled by a drummer and a flag waver. The dance moves very slowly through the town and stops to go through a dance cycle periodically. I couldn't figure out the stages of the dance
column2: but the drummer would change the beat and everyone would slow down
column3: scatter
column4: form a circle
column5: or speed up.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Part of the ritual that I didn't understand" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-dance-3.jpg">
Part of the ritual that I didn't understand
What makes the day REALLY fun is that while the dancing is going on
column2: they throw flour at you or squirt you with water. For some reason
column3: most of our group was pretty much left alone
column4: but David and I were pelted with flour. I'm still cleaning flour out of my camera bag.

column1: After following the dancing for a couple of hours
column2: went to a restaurant for lunch. There were a couple of guitar players and singers that played for us while we waited for our food.
one of our group
column3: and David at lunch" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-lunch.jpg">

column2: one of our group
column3: and David at lunch" src="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-lunch.jpg" height="266" width="400">

column2: one of our group
column3: and David at lunch

column2: we went back to festival. It had moved into the public square and was at full force. They upgraded their arsenal from simple fistfulls of flour to hollowed out eggs full of flour. I took one on my jaw that exploded all over David. I was trying to be a man about it
column3: but it really hurt! Things were really chaotic by this point. We ran into Alessio and he was clearly exhausted. It was clear that young women were the targets of the flour. The prettier the girl
column4: the more covered with flour she would be. David and I decided that we should be flattered that we were the only ones in our group to be targeted. After about a half hour
column5: we got to the van and rode back to Palenque for a shower and a quiet dinner.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="You can't really see how crowded the public square is. I didn't want to get close enough for fearing of having my camera pelted." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tenosique-afterlunch.jpg">
You can't really see how crowded the public square is. I didn't want to get close enough for fearing of having my camera pelted.

"The Road to San Cristóbal";"personal/travel/mexico/road-san-crist-bal";"

We left Palenque today and headed to San Cristóbal. Palenque is at an elevation of 80 meters (~260 ft) and San Cristóbal is at an elevation of 2160 meters (~7000 ft)
column2: so we had a ways to go. And it was
column3: of course
column4: a tiny
column5: winding road. Although we were looking forward to getting out of the warm lowlands and head to more temperate weather in the mountians.

column1: Our first stop was at a waterfall called Miso Ha. There was nothing particularly cultural or historical to see. The natural beauty of the falls spoke for itself. This is apparently one of the prime locations featured in the movie Predator.
<a class="thickbox" title="The view from when you first walk up to the falls" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/misoha-panorama.jpg">
The view from when you first walk up to the falls
<a class="thickbox" title="Showing a person in the image gives you an idea of how large the falls are" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/misoha-perspective.jpg">
Showing a person in the image gives you an idea of how large the falls are
<a class="thickbox" title="Here's David trying to pretend that he doesn't mind being wet" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/misoha-david.jpg">
Here's David trying to pretend that he doesn't mind being wet
Our next stop was another set of waterfalls called Aqua Azul. There had been heavy rains the night before
column2: so the falls were stronger than usual. Unfortunately
column3: they were not blue - they were brown. We were reassured that they are normally quite blue. Oh well. We parked at the base and worked our way up the falls.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="David still pretending that the wetness doesn't bother him" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/aquaazul-david.jpg">
David still pretending that the wetness doesn't bother him
<a class="thickbox" title="Keith posing and actually not minding the wet" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/aquaazul-keith.jpg">
Keith posing and actually not minding the wet
<a class="thickbox" title="The next point up" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/aquaazul-midpoint.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="David preparing to cross a very rickety bridge" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/aquaazul-davidbridge.jpg">
David preparing to cross a very rickety bridge
<a class="thickbox" title="David crossing to the very tip" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/aquaazul-thetip.jpg">
David crossing to the very tip
Our next big stop was a site of ruins on the way to San Cristóbal - Tonina. The ruins are built into a cliff
column2: so there was a lot of climbing. The steps were so steep that it felt as if you were climbing a wall. Tonina is known for having very good reliefs about the capture of warriors and a tribute to the god of the underworld. I decided that I was going to brave the room of the dead - reagardless of spiders. Luckily
column3: there were none.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A shot of the site before the climbing" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tonina-preclimb.jpg">
A shot of the site before the climbing
<a class="thickbox" title="Walking into the room of the dead" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tonina-entering-1.jpg">
Walking into the room of the dead
<a class="thickbox" title="Reliefs depicting the fate of captives" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tonina-captors.jpg">
Reliefs depicting the fate of captives
<a class="thickbox" title="The tribute relief of the god of the underworld. Be sure to zoom into this picture to see the skeleton-like god
column2: the upside down heads." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tonina-godofthedead.jpg">
the upside down heads." src="/files/photos/chiapas/tonina-godofthedead.jpg" height="266" width="400">

column1: <div class="journalCaption">The tribute relief of the god of the underworld. Be sure to zoom into this picture to see the skeleton-like god
column2: the upside down heads.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A view from the top. It was actually a pleasant day despite the heavy clouds." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/tonina-view-1.jpg">
A view from the top. It was actually a pleasant day despite the heavy clouds.

column2: we stopped at a place for homemade quesadillas and then drove the rest of the way to San Cristóbal. We noticed that most of the signs on the road had large holes in them. We all assumed that they were bullet holes
column3:
but our guide pointed out that the government drills holes in them because the locals steal the road signs to cook tortillas on. Drilling holes in them makes them useless as stovetops.

";"1141192800";"textile"

column1:
"San Juan Chamula";"personal/travel/mexico/san-juan-chamula";"

I'm going to put all of San Cristóbal on hold for a second and talk about what happened the next day because it was one of the most bizarre experiences I've ever encountered. We celebrated "Fat Tuesday" in a small mountain town called San Juan Chamula. Unfortunately
column2: the one experience that is the most difficult to describe is the one place we were absolutely not allowed to take pictures. The locals strongly believe that it steals your soul. There were signs posted as we got to the main square saying "NO PHOTOS ALLOWED AFTER THIS POINT". There were men with sticks that would knock a camera out of your hand if you even lifted one up.

column1: San Juan Chamula is a place that has mobined ancient Mayan religion with Catholicism. They have a modified crucifix that looks more like an ear of corn. David once heard that the Chamulans believe that Jesus Christ died on the cross to become the Sun God. They also highly prize Coca Cola because they believe the carbonation releases evil spirits and it's one of the few things they can't produce themselves. Their version of Fat Tuesday doesn't really resemble anything the Catholic church would endorse. They sacrifice bulls in the town square. The day is unbelievably chaotic and surreal. I will do my best to describe it
column2: but this is something that has to be experienced.

our guide ran into a local guide named Chip who has been living in San Cristóbal for many years and knows the locals. He got us into the mayor's house for a special glimpse of the preparations. It was a small and relatively modest house. All along the walls were the male town elders - small
column3: old men that did not talk. There was a man changing into white ceremonial clothes clsoer to the center. I saw only one woman there. She was attending to a shrine in the middle of the room. There was a huge amount of incense being burned and god only knows what else. The room was filled with smoke. There were candles everywhere and banners hanging from the ceiling. I would have liked to have stayed maybe a little longer
column4: but I felt like I was intruding on their festival and I was concerned that I was inhaling something I would later regret. (I later found out that the locals often do hallucinogenic drugs as part of religious ceremonies).

column1: We wandered up to the main square. There were people everywhere running around. We saw many older children dressed in brightly colored clothes wearing black pointed hats with red
column2: yellow
column3: and green streamers hanging from them. We later found out that the black hats were made from the skin of howler monkeys. Many of this kids had horns that played two very dissonant notes at once. Some of the kids had drums. Also in the town square
column4: they were setting off extremely loud firecrackers. Our guide wanred us not to go near the firecrackers because sometimes they fire into the crowd. You could lose your hearing or worse.

column1: After waiting in the public square for a bit
column2: we went into the church. The church is especially sacred and no pictures are allowed. For a Catholic church
column3: it was not ornate - well
column4: not ornate in the way that one would expect. There were corn husks hanging from the walls. There were large banners strewn across the ceiling woven by the natives. There must have been thousands of candles throughout the church - on tables
column5: on the floor
column6: and along the wall. People would come in with candles
column7: light a few
column8: and simbply plant them into the stone floor and start praying. We saw some people praying fervently
column9: bowing on their knees
column10: and holding coke bottles up to their forehead as an offering to God (remember that they value Coke and they are preparing to give something up for Lent). All along the walls were glass cases with saints inside. The name of the saint was usually painted on the glass. All of the saints were ornately dressed and usually had a mirror hanging around their neck to ward off evil spirits. The saints looked more like large (some of them were almost life-size) porcelain dolls. Their faces had been painted to have disarming expressions. Some had a look of suffering
column11: some looked like they had just seen God
column13: some looked at peace. Walking around the church and looking at the saints was one of the most bizarre experiences I've ever had in my life. They had an air of real people - I kept expecting to see one of the saints move - and yet the whole atmosphere was fantastical at the same time. Add to this the sound of the drums
column16: and some sort of very strong incense. I stopped in front of the statue of the Virgin Mary (who had multi-colored chaser lights around her glass box) and meditated on what I was experiencing. I thought of places I had been where the barrier between this world and the next is very thin - like a veil that you can almost see through. I tried to "look through the veil" in this church and I saw chaos. I don't know how else to describe it.

column1: Our group went back out to the main square. David and I decided to break off from the group and explore on our own. We could see something happening in the corner of the square. There were men in black lamb tunics. We saw them holding onto ropes. Occassionally
column2: the crowd would shift and the kids would come running in our direction for a moment and then crowd back to where they came from. We eventually realized that they were dragging a bull into the town square with the rope. The bull would start charging and all the kids would run away for a second. Part of the "game" was for the teenage boys to jump onto the bull's back and ride it for a few seconds. They were slowly dragging the bull into the center of the square to sacrifice it. Along with the realization of what they were doing to this poor bull
column3: I realized that I must have inhaled something along the way
column4: because I started having mild hallucinogenic reactions - my perception was starting to go two dimensional and my jaw clenching. I told David that we should get out of here and have something to eat (we hadn't had lunch and it was past lunchtime). We found a place to have a coke and some churros. I felt a little better.

column1: We wandered around a bit more. Luckily
column2: we didn't see any of the bulls actually get sacrificed. They sacrifice five of them. It was explained to me why
column3: but I can't remember it now. Our gruop eventually gathered up and went to a nearby textile town to see how the locals weave textiles by hand as they have done for thousands of years. The home where we went also made us some tortillas
column4: but I was feeling quite out of it and passed.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This is what they use to set up the \"loom\"" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/chamula-weaver-1.jpg">
This is what they use to set up the "loom"
<a class="thickbox" title="Making tortillas in her kitchen" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/chamula-tortillas.jpg">

"Na Bolom";"personal/travel/mexico/na-bolom";"

Our hotel in San Cristóbal was pretty incredible. We spent three nights at Casa Na Bolom which is a short walk from the center of town. Casa Na Bolom is a cultural center
column2: a restaurant
column3: a museum
column4: a garden
column5: a hotel
column6: and a historical icon. All the rooms are individual and scattered throughout the estate
column7: down hallways
column8: across courtyards
column9: up steps
column10: etc. It's a huge area that I would stroll around and constantly find new little buildings or gardens hidden around a corner.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The front entrance of Na Bolom. At night
column2: you have to knock on the door to be let onto the grounds. The floor is made with upside down wine bottles embedded into cement." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/nabolom-entrance.jpg">

you have to knock on the door to be let onto the grounds. The floor is made with upside down wine bottles embedded into cement." src="/files/photos/chiapas/nabolom-entrance.jpg" height="400" width="266">

column1: <div class="journalCaption">The front entrance of Na Bolom. At night
column2: you have to knock on the door to be let onto the grounds. The floor is made with upside down wine bottles embedded into cement.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="This is the room we stayed in for the first two nights." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/nabolom-firstroom.jpg">
This is the room we stayed in for the first two nights.
<a class="thickbox" title="Some iron work along the hall" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/nabolom-courtyard-1.jpg">
Some iron work along the hall

The view of the courtyard directly outside our room.
<a class="thickbox" title="David built a fire in our room. Being in the mountains
column2: it got quite cold at night." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/nabolom-roomfire.jpg">
it got quite cold at night." src="/files/photos/chiapas/nabolom-roomfire.jpg" height="266" width="400">

column1: <div class="journalCaption">David built a fire in our room. Being in the mountains
column2: it got quite cold at night.

on the last night we asked if we could try another room. We specifically asked for the room that Diego Rivera slept in on his trips to San Cristobal. It was another great room with a view of a garden.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Diego Rivera Room - although that's not what the hotel calls it." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/nabolom-diegoriveraroom.jpg">
The Diego Rivera Room - although that's not what the hotel calls it.
<a class="thickbox" title="A picture of one of our group admiring the beautiful day." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/nabolom-kelly.jpg">
A picture of one of our group admiring the beautiful day.

"San Cristóbal";"personal/travel/mexico/san-crist-bal";"

We spent two and a half days in San Cristóbal. It's a beautiful town to sit back and relax. The people couldn't be nicer and it's a blend of local culture and Western tourism. David and I had a great time just stroliing around the city. It's one of those places that didn't really get good until we exhausted all the major tourist destinations and just wandered around.
<a class="thickbox" title="The street that we would walk down from Na Bolom to the center of town." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-street.jpg">
The street that we would walk down from Na Bolom to the center of town.

We loved the banners in the street and looked around for places to buy them. We went into at least 10 different stores asking for those banners and had the exact same story every time. David would ask for "banners" in Spanish ("banderas"). The clerk would look at him confused. David would describe them in Spanish. Eventually
column2: they would understand what he was saying. Once they understood
column3: David would ask them what they called them and they would nod that he was correct and say "banderas". No one ever carried them
column4: but they always said that a paper store closer to the zocalo (town square). We tried what felt like every paper store in town and never had any luck. I later found them on 8th Avenue in New York just up the street from us.

column1: One of David's favorite things to do in a Mexican city is to check out the local market. There's no possible way to capture everything that you see there - people holding onto a group of live chickens by the feet haggling over price
column2: the fresh produce
column3: the kids
column4: etc. I was aware that we were in an area where they did not always appreciate photgraphs
column5: so I took it easy. We ended up asking one man for a photo and paying him. David and I were on our own. We later found out that the rest of our group could not find anyone to consent to a photograph in the markets.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A man selling all sorts of grains in the market." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-grain.jpg">
A man selling all sorts of grains in the market.

<a class="thickbox" title="This market stall had all sorts of local herbs and plants for medicinal purposes. They each had a name and a list of symptoms they cure. We noticed that many of them were listed as a cure for diarrhea." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-medicines.jpg">

This market stall had all sorts of local herbs and plants for medicinal purposes. They each had a name and a list of symptoms they cure. We noticed that many of them were listed as a cure for diarrhea.

column2: the one really beautiful facade was under repair and surrounded in scaffolding. Oh well. Something to go back for. The interiors were beautiful as well
column3: but often very dark.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="One of the main churches on the zocalo" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-church-1.jpg">
One of the main churches on the zocalo
<a class="thickbox" title="A beautiful interior of Santa Domingo" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-insidechurch.jpg">
A beautiful interior of Santa Domingo
<a class="thickbox" title="A striking statue of one of the 12 stations of the cross" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-christ.jpg">
A striking statue of one of the 12 stations of the cross
<a class="thickbox" title="A beautiful statue of the Virgin Mother unlike any I've ever seen." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-saint.jpg">
A beautiful statue of the Virgin Mother unlike any I've ever seen.
<a class="thickbox" title="This beautiful church wasn't even on the guide book map - we found it by accident." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-bluechurch.jpg">
This beautiful church wasn't even on the guide book map - we found it by accident.
<a class="thickbox" title="The interior of the church." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-bluechurchinterior.jpg">
Despite the pictures of the local spots
column2: San Cristóbal is surprisingly "Western". There were great restaurants
column3: hip hotels
column4: streets without cars and lined with tourist trap shops
column5: more internet cafes than you can shake a stick at
column6: and good cafes. We found a great little dessert shop that we stopped at more than once after dinner to share a slice of cake.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="For a country not known for great desserts
column2: this place was pretty fantastic." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-desserts.jpg">
this place was pretty fantastic." src="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-desserts.jpg" height="266" width="400">

column1: <div class="journalCaption">For a country not known for great desserts
column2: this place was pretty fantastic.

we went one night to a small steakhouse. I had been feeling not so great and was probably dehydrated. We ordered something simple - sopa azteca and a New York strip steak. David and I commented at how cheap the food is in Mexico. The food arrived
column3: we ate. The waiter came back asking us what we wanted next. We said just the check. He left confused. Then the owner came over to our table to ask if everything was okay and why we didn't want to order more. We eventually realized that it was an "all you can eat" steakhouse and we were supposed to keep ordering more steak. We had severely under-estimated how good of a bargain our dinner was. Since we were full and had not been feeling so well
column4: we assured them that the food was delicious but that we filled up and would take the check.

column2: of course
column3: it wouldn't be a trip abroad unless you ran across some New Yorkers. The day that we went to San Juan Chamula
column4: we met the famle half of a couple that has a house right behind Casa Na Bolom where we were staying. Our last full day in San Cristobal
column5: we went over to their house for coffee. We also met Chip there
column6: the guide that had taken us to the mayor's house in San Juan Chamula. They are a couple that lives in New York most of the year
column7: but vacation San Cristóbal and the Adirondacks. Small world!

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A beautiful convent garden that has been converted into a cultural center" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/sancristobal-conventgarden.jpg">
A beautiful convent garden that has been converted into a cultural center

"Cañón del Sumidero";"personal/travel/mexico/ca-n-del-sumidero";"

On our last day in San Cristóbal
column2: we decided to get an early start
column3: drive to Chiapa de Corzo
column4: and take a tour of the Cañón del Sumidero before heading to Tuxtla Gutiérrez. It's a very striking canyon that you tour via speedboats that take you up the river to look at the dam and back. To get there
column5: we took the most harrowing ride of my life.

column1: We hired a local cab driver to take us to Tuxtla Gutiérrez and drop us off to see the Cañón del Sumidero for a couple of hours. Kidnappings or robberies of tourists has been on the rise
column2: so I was a bit on edge to begin with. About 15 minutes into the trip
column3: I realized that kidnapping was the least of my worries. I was far more likely to die in a car wreck
