column4: tumbling down the side of the mountain. Although they are building a super highway (two lanes in each direction!) from Tuxtla Gutiérrez to San Cristóbal
column5: the road was only available for the last 15 minutes of the ride. The first part of the trip was on an extremely winding road along the edge of the mountain. Our cab driver was not in favor of waiting for anybody or anything. He did not slow down on curves
column6: he sped up (I'm not joking!). If a large truck was moving slowly in front of us
column7: he would pass the truck on a blind curve. At least twice he had misjudged passing a car in front of us and slammed on the brakes to avoid having a head-on collision with the car in front of us. Every 500 feet
column8: there was another sign that read "CURVA PELIGRASO" (dangerous curves) or "NO MALTRATE LAS SENALES" (don't disregard the signs). There were small shrines along the side of the road of people that most likely had driven over the edge and down the edge of the mountain. I eventually tapped into my inner Buddha and told myself that if I was meant to die on the road to Tuxtla Gutiérrez
column9: then so be it. It would at least be a quick death. Oh...and there were no seat belts in the car.

column1: We made it to Chiapa de Corzo and immediately got on a bus for a tour of the Cañón del Sumidero. We kind of lucked out and got on a group that was primarily comprised of a bunch of middle-aged Mexican women touring together. Although they generally didn't speak English
column2: they were a hoot. They had one American travelling with them - a retired gentlemen from Madison
column3: Wisconsin
column4: who had moved here so that his wife could be closer to her family. He had decided to tour with this group of women more because they were so much fun. They would cheer
column5: take pictures of each other
column6: and in general have a great time. The canyon was very impressive. The pictures don't do it justice.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A grand view approaching the canyon." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/canyon-bestview.jpg">
A grand view approaching the canyon.
<a class="thickbox" title="The only bridge over the canyon." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/canyon-bridge-1.jpg">
The only bridge over the canyon.
<a class="thickbox" title="A crocodile we saw along the banks." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/canyon-crocodile.jpg">
A crocodile we saw along the banks.
<a class="thickbox" title="The crocodile started coming towards us. Some of the women screamed." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/canyon-crocodileswimming.jpg">
The crocodile started coming towards us. Some of the women screamed.
<a class="thickbox" title="Look carefully and you'll see monkeys in the trees" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/canyon-monkeys.jpg">
Look carefully and you'll see monkeys in the trees
<a class="thickbox" title="There were vultures everywhere along the canyon" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/canyon-vulture.jpg">
There were vultures everywhere along the canyon
In the middle of the canyon is a small cave that our boat drove up to. You cannot reach this area by land
column2: you have to use a boat. There's a small ladder up to a ledge where shrine was built to the people that discovered the area and worked to keep the local wildlife protected.

column1: We drove to the dam and instead of going right back to the spot that we left from
column2: our driver took us to a small restaurant along the river for drinks and snacks. Unfortunately
column3: we learned first hand the meaning of "tourist trap". It was obvious that our boat driver either owned the restaurant or was getting a lot of money from the owner for bringing tourists. We were in the middle of the river with no way to get out. Everyone ordered a full lunch. We were stuck in the restaurant for about an hour and a half. David and I started becoming worried because our cab driver had been told that it would be a two hour trip. It ended up being a four hour trip. On the plus side
column4: there were a couple of cute parrots at the resturant that were very social.

column1: We were very relieved to get back to our starting point and see our cab driver there and not overly pissed off that we took two hours longer than we originally thought. We went to Tuxtla Gutiérrez
column2: had a nice lunch at the airport cafe
column3:
and headed on to Mexico City for the final portion of the trip.

";"1141192800";"textile"

column2: The Four Seasons Hotel. Rustic charm is nice
column3: but a private and clean bathroom is a rare thing in a third world country. David and I arrived quite tired and there was a line to check in at the Four Seasons. I overheard some conversation that there was renovation going on during the day on the 6th floor
column4: so I was prepared to not accept a room on the 5th
column5: 6th
column6: or 7th floors. When we got to the front desk
column7: the clerk was taking a very long time to find a room. It was several minutes of watching her type into a keyboard and click her mouse repeatedly. She called over the manager and they clicked and stared at their screens for a while. I began to worry that they were going to downgrade us on the room
column8: so I said "Is there a problem?" - which was intended to sound inquisitive and reassuring but David insists came out like acid. The manager said there was no problem and within a minute said that they had upgraded us to a nicer room on the 8th floor. Woo-hoo!

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The room was huge. It took us forever to figure out how to work the remote control - it was JUST THAT FANCY." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/mexicocity-room.jpg">
The room was huge. It took us forever to figure out how to work the remote control - it was JUST THAT FANCY.
<a class="thickbox" title="The view of the courtyard from the 8th floor." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/chiapas/mexicocity-courtyard.jpg">
The view of the courtyard from the 8th floor.

column2: so we ordered room service and hung out in the room the first night. The next day
column3: we went to the antiques market. I started having my usual reaction to Mexico City - weak
column4: bleary
column5: short of breath
column6: and unable to focus. I lasted a while at the market
column7: but evenutally headed back to the room. We got a hand-painted offering box for the kitchen and David ended up getting about a dozen or so ex votos.

column1: I have to admit that a lot of my visit to Mexico City is a poor-air-quality blur. We went to a couple of antique stores looking for more ex votos. We found out that they are easy to replicate and hard to authenticate
column2: so most dealers don't carry them. Which is fine by us. They're cheap and look nice
column3: so what's the big deal if they're replicas?

column1: We had a wonderful evening with Pastor Luna
column2: a colleague's of David that lives in Mexico City
column3: and his wife
column4: Anna Laura. They took us to a wonderful Italian restaurant in the hip and trendy part of town.

column1: Our last full day in Mexico City
column2: we went to the Franz Mayer Museum and took our time walking back to the hotel part of the way. We finally ate at a VIPS (remember from our first night) and it was all I dreamed it would be. The thing that always strikes me about Mexico City is that so many of the neighborhoods clearly had their big day once upon a time. We drove through a couple of pretty rundown neighborhoods that had fantastic architecture. I kept thinking that if there's ever an economic boom in Mexico
column3: that Mexico City will be one of the most sought after cities in the world.

column2: an incredible trip over all
column3: but I was so happy at the thought of going back home
column4:
having a regular old salad and letting my digestive system recover. I suppose it's good that Mexico is only for true travelers. It seems so rare these days to go some place that is truly unspoiled.

";"1141192800";"textile"

column2: David became concerned that he wasn't going to make platinum this year. He always operates under the assumption that he doesn't travel much. We planned a short week in London as an easy way to rack up some miles and figured we could see some shows
column3: visit the countryside and bum around London.";"1149570000";"textile"

column1:
"Arrival in London";"personal/travel/england/arrival-london";"

David and I took the day flight to London
column2: as opposed to the red-eye
column3: to help with jet lag. Our flight was around 8:30pm
column4: it's about a 6 hour flight
column5: and you arrive in London around 8:30pm. I can't think through the math right now to know if that's right. Perhaps I'm conditioned from many previous red-eye flights
column6: but whenever I arrive in Europe
column7: I'm exhausted. I don't know what it is about sitting on a plane for more than a few hours.

column2: we took the Heathrow Express train (15 minutes from airport to London!) to Paddington Station. Our hotel was a 5-10 minute walk from the train station
column3: which was much appreciated after a long flight.

column1: It took us a few tries to get the hotel room right. The first room had a sink that didn't drain well and the towel rack came off when I tried to dry my hands. The second room was nice
column2: but didn't have an internet connection. And the third room was just right. Goldilocks would have picked this room. I've learned not to expect much from British hotels
column3: so was pleased that our hotel was somewhat spacious
column4: clean
column5: and was facing an inner courtyard.

column2: we decided to go get something quick to eat. We passed several places on the walk to the hotel
column3: so we headed back out. We ended up at a little place called "The Chicken Stop" and decided to get something and bring it back to the room. Most of the restaurants on the block were run by Arabs since that seemed to be the mode of the neighborhood. There was another man in "The Chicken Stop" that was talking to us about the wonders of fried chicken. He claimed that people made fun of him for drinking Diet Coke and then having fried chicken
column4: but that he couldn't help himself because fried chicken is so delicious. He also recommended KFC.

column1: We went back to the hotel room with our chicken
column2: fries
column3: and soda. We ate
column4: finished unpacking
column5: and went to bed.

column1: There is nothing like that first night of jet lag to give you a good sleep. We slept about 10 hours - all of it wonderful.

We had decided that tomorrow would be all about Kent.

";"1149570000";"textile"

"Canterbury";"personal/travel/england/canterbury";"

David and I got up relatively early to catch a train to go to Canterbury. It felt like we could have slept for days. England has a fantastic train system. You can get pretty much anywhere you need to get to by train and they run on time. The only drawback on taking the trains going south during the summer is that you're getting family beach crowds. We got stuck next to two loud groups on the train
column2: but that didn't stop us from getting a little nap in on the way there.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="David Asleep on the Train" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-david-sleeping.jpg">
I was expecting Canterbury to be very similar to York
column2: but it turns out that it's a more modern city. It seemed to be a big destination for teenagers - there were lots of kids hanging out in the park
column3: and lots of families strolling around the shops. We headed right to the cathedral
column4: which is the big attraction.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Gateway Arch to Canterbury Cathedral" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-arch.jpg">
The Gateway Arch to Canterbury Cathedral

column2: you get a glimpse of just how large the cathedral is...

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A Side View of Canterbury Cathedral. This is still only about half of the full size." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-sideview.jpg">
A Side View of Canterbury Cathedral. This is still only about half of the full size.
<a class="thickbox" title="An interesting spire on the outside. Notice the heads along the crest." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-spire.jpg">
An interesting spire on the outside. Notice the heads along the crest.
David got a map of the cathedral and we were on our way inside.
<a class="thickbox" title="David at the Entrance" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-david-entrance.jpg">
The cathedral is largely known for its stained glass. Unfortunately
column2: a lot of the stained glass was bombed out in World War II. In fact
column3: the only reason that the cathedral is still standing is because the Germans had poor maps of England. The locals in Kent would also light fires out in the middle of nowhere to try to trick the Germans into thinking the targets were in a different place.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The stained glass at the entrance of the cathedral." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-frontglass.jpg">
The stained glass at the entrance of the cathedral.

column2: there was nothing to do but wander around and look.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Apse in Canterbury Cathedral" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-apse.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The Tomb of the Black Prine" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-blackprince.jpg">
The Tomb of the Black Prine
<a class="thickbox" title="A Stretch of Ceiling in Canterbury Cathedral" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-ceiling.jpg">
A Stretch of Ceiling in Canterbury Cathedral
<a class="thickbox" title="A Side Chapel in the Cathedral" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-chapel.jpg">
A Side Chapel in the Cathedral
<a class="thickbox" title="A beautiful example of medieval painted word work." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-tomb.jpg">
A beautiful example of medieval painted word work.
<a class="thickbox" title="A marble tomb of a king and queen (can't remember who)" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-marbletomb.jpg">
A marble tomb of a king and queen (can't remember who)
We wandered around the back. We came across a room called "The Treaty Room". It was the room in which France and England signed the contract to build the chunnel together.
<a class="thickbox" title="The monk's entrance in the back." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/canterbury-tower.jpg">
The monk's entrance in the back.

column2: we went to a place for lunch called "The Custard Tart". It was a tiny little shop in a back alley that was recommended by the guide book. We had a light lunch and grabbed some sweets for later.

we were going to take the train further south to Dover. The man at the ticket window in Canterbury was trying to save us some money on the fair and was taking forever to calculate and sell us a ticket. As we sitting there
column3: our train rolled into the station. We eventually politely asked him to just sell us a simple ticket to Dover and we ran for the train. The conductor held the train a minute to let us on
column4: but we got the sense that they barely ever hold trains for people.

column1:
David and I both fell asleep on the half-hour trip to Dover.

";"1149570000";"textile"

"Dover";"personal/travel/england/dover";"

Our next stop was Dover to see the castle and the white cliffs. It looked from the map that we could wakl to the castle. However
column2: when we got to Dover we had two obstacles: although we could clearly see the castle from the middle of town
column3: we couldn't figure out how to walk to it; and secondly
column4: it looked like quite a hike up a cliff to get to the castle. We were already pretty tired
column5: so we hired a cab. We learned that our fears were well founded. We never would have found it and the ride was pretty long and steep.

column1: The entrance to the castle was pretty empty. We were concerned that it was closed. We later learned that almost everyone takes a car to Dover Castle and parks on the other side. We must have been one of the few or only visitors to come in through the pedestrian entrance.
<a class="thickbox" title="The Pedestrian Entrance to Dover Castle" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/dover-castleentrance.jpg">
The Pedestrian Entrance to Dover Castle
We definitely wanted to see the Wartime Caves
column2: so we paid ahead for tickets to that. The man at the ticket booth told us to hurry to make the next tour. Our walk took us up to the top of the castle grounds and then back down the other side to the entrance of the caves. We did our best to avoid any sight-seeing so as not to delay our trip. We ended up arriving quite early
column3: so I had some water in the cafe.

column1: The trip through the caves was a lot of fun. The caves are a three level system of underground caverns built into the cliffs. Dover was a major air base during WWII
column2: so they had used the caves for intelligence
column3: living quarters
column4: and makeshift hospital. The tour was conducted by a single individual that would press buttons throughout the caves that would simulate bombs being dropped above us - the lights would flicker
column5: we'd hear thunderous sounds
column6: and the air raid sirens would go off. There was one small girl that took the whole thing very seriously and became quite afraid. You lose all sense of direction in the tunnels.

column1: We weren't allowed to take any photos
column2: but there was one stretch without a guide and I quickly pulled out my camera and took a shot without a flash.
we walked around the castle some more
column3: then got directions on where best to see the cliffs. There's a 3 mile walk along the cliffs
column4: but I was getting pretty tired of walking at this point
column5: and it seemed that we wanted to see the cliffs from below
column6: not walk on them. We decided to walk down to the piers and get a view of them from below - possibly from a tour boat.

column1: The area along the water was...not the nicest beach I've ever been to. It seemed to be the sort of place where only the locals hung out. We almost made a tour boat
column2: but when I saw that it was packed and full of little kids
column3: I vetoed the idea. We could admire the cliffs from where we were standing.

column2: my camera ran out of battery power
column3: so I couldn't take a photo.

column1: The walk back to the train station and the wait for the train was long and uneventful. We were glad to be back in London.

column2:
we went to our favorite restaurant in London - a middle eastern restaurant called Özer.

";"1149570000";"textile"
David was chomping at the bit to go to Oxford. I told him that there was no way were getting on a train and fighting weekend crowds again. I would be up for a boat ride
column3: but we had a hard time finding a boat trip that would go that far up the Thames.

column2: we decided to go the opposite direction and catch a boat to Greenwich. I'm still not clear on whether Greenwich is just a neighborhood of London or an outer borough or what. Anyway
column3: it's south east of London and you can get there via boat since it's right on the Thames.

column1: On the way to the ferry station
column2: we passed by Buckingham Palace. There was a big crowd gathering just outside. We asked some people what they were waiting for. The first people we asked said that they saw the crowd and stopped but they didn't know either. Someone eventually told us that it was the Queen's 80th birthday.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The gardens outside Buckingham Palace" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/buckingham-garden.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="A View of Buckingham Palace from the Front" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/buckingham-front.jpg">
A View of Buckingham Palace from the Front
<a class="thickbox" title="The Parade for the Queen's Birthday" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/buckingham-parade1.jpg">
The Parade for the Queen's Birthday
<a class="thickbox" title="More of the Parade" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/buckingham-parade2.jpg">
We continued to walk through the park and got some interesting shots. From this view
column2: you can see the London Eye and Big Ben poking over the trees in the background.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Some Very Tame Pelicans" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/buckingham-pelicans.jpg">
We got to the ferry station just in time to catch a trip down the Thames. Although he claimed he wasn't a licensed tour guide
column2: there was a crew member that was very entertaining and knowledgeable manning a microphone on the tour down the river.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A View of St Paul's from the River" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/thames-stpaul.jpg">
A View of St Paul's from the River

The next photo is pretty much just for my mom. This photo shows a little canal off the Thames. It's the place in the novel "Oliver" where Bill Sykes dies. The movie filmed the scene in that location as well. It's now built up into condos. How sad.
<a class="thickbox" title="Where They Hung Bill Sykes" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/thames-oliver.jpg">

"Greenwich";"personal/travel/england/greenwich";"

The Thames boat ride stopped in Greenwich where we disembarked. Greenwich is a small community with cafes
column2: shops
column3: an antiques market
column4: the Royal Observatory
column5: and a whole bunch of other things. You can visit this website for more information.

column1: We didn't do half of the things listed there.

We started off by having lunch because it was around 2:30 and we were starving. We went to a place serving very English food and had a good lunch. While we were there some obnoxious older American gentleman came in
column2: demanded attention
column3: and then was talking to his guests about how hard it is to find polite people in the U.K. Ugh.

column2: we headed to the antiques market. I've learned that "antiques market" in Britain really means "flea market". There really wasn't anything of interest there.

column1: Our plan was to visit the Christopher Wren buildings in the Old Royal Naval College and then work our way up the hill to the Royal Observatory.
Our first stop was the Painted Hall. It's called that because the walls and pillars are flat but painted to look ornate. It was
column2: indeed
column3: very impressive.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Entrance of the Painted Hall" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/greenwich-paintedroom1.jpg">
The Entrance of the Painted Hall
<a class="thickbox" title="The Main Room of the Painted Hall" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/greenwich-paintedroom2.jpg">
The Main Room of the Painted Hall
<a class="thickbox" title="They set out mirrors so that you can examine the ceiling without straining your neck" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/greenwich-paintedroom3.jpg">
They set out mirrors so that you can examine the ceiling without straining your neck
<a class="thickbox" title="A Section of Ceiling of the Painted Hall" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/greenwich-paintedroomceiling.jpg">
A Section of Ceiling of the Painted Hall

column2: we went across the courtyard to the Chapel
column3: also designed by Christopher Wren. It's the plaster work that's impressive here. I don't know if it's really captured in this picture.

column1: After that we started heading up to Royal Observatory. When people refer to "Greenwich Mean Time"
column2: this is the place they're referring to. You can stand on a line and have one foot in the eastern hemisphere and one foot in the western hemisphere. In the picture below
column3: you can see The Queen's House in the center and just above to the right is the Royal Observatory. The walk there is a bit steep at the very end
column4: but through a park that was full of people enjoying their Sunday afternoon.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Looking Towards the Queen's House" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/greenwich-grounds.jpg">
It was hard to get a picture at the observatory because it was fairly crowded. You can just barely make out central London in the distance. I tried taking some pictures but none came out too well.
There was an interesting museum at the observatory featuring many old clocks with the guts exposed. And visiting the observatory itself was fascinating.

column2: we walked back down to the town. We had spotted an antique map store. I dropped off David and went to get an iced coffee. On my travails
column3: I went back to the main pier. There were many street performers - most of whom did not seem to be asking for money at all. Next to where I sat came two people dressed like colorful 1950's shysters with a peep show box. They played music and encouraged people to come up and take a look in the peep show box. The man was saying harmless but lewd things about what you'd see if you looked. Both children and adults were smiling and laughing after they looked
column4: so I decided to get in line and have a look myself. It was a gyrating puppet of an old woman with tassels on her breasts and tiny underwear.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A Peepshow at the Pier" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/greenwich-peepshow.jpg">

column2: I found the much better open market in Greenwich. David bought a map
column3: I took him through the market
column4: and we took the train home.

column1:
Dinner that night was a Malaysian restaurant in the neighborhood of the hotel.

";"1149570000";"textile"

"Kensington";"personal/travel/england/kensington";"

The next two days in London were dedicated to shopping. And also to relaxing a bit. We had toured pretty hard
column2: and we were now starting to settle into vacation mode.
we focused on Kensington. We wanted to do Harvey Nichols
column3: Harrod's
column4: and try to find an antique map store that David had been to a few years ago. We started our journey with a walk through Hyde Park and Kensinton Gardens.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="A Peter Pan Statue in Hyde Park" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/hydepark-peterpan-1.jpg">
A Peter Pan Statue in Hyde Park

We walked through Harvey Nichols relatively quickly. Several of the floors are dedicated to women's fashion which can be quite dull if you're a male. The men's clothes were in the basement. Little did we know that they were in the middle of a 70% off sale! David and I each got some designer shirts for bargain prices. I was happy. We next went to Harrod's and wandered through confusedly. This is a department store to get lost in.

column2: I had to find David's map shop. I can't remember how we found it in the first place. I think I was the one that originally saw it on a side street on our first trip to London together. It wasn't too hard to find. I dropped David off and headed back to Harrod's. The had put a "La Duree" (a famous French cafe) in a section of Harrod's and I was set on having coffee and a pastry.

column1: It's a little nerve-wracking going to a fancy French cafe by myself. I certainly was dressed well. I wasn't allowed to take pictures
column2: but La Duree has photos on their website. I ordered a cappucino and a pistachio religieuse (a puff pastry filled with pistachio cream and icing on top). It was magnificent. It also gave me the courage to go back to Harvey Nichols and get a fantastic bow-tie and cumberbund set for David that I saw.
I got message on my phone that David was ready
column3: so I went to pick him up. We grabbed some lunch (I had a salad to off-set the pastry) and went to the Victoria and Albert Museum. The museum is huge and
column4: as I said
column5: we were more interested in having a relaxing experience at this point. We decided that we would do the India Arts rooms and the Raphael rooms and see how we were doing. Even that was a lot to take in and we were ready to head back to the hotel after that.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Lobby of the Victoria Albert Museum. A mix of history and ultra modern." target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/hydepark-victoriaalbertmuseum.jpg">
The Lobby of the Victoria Albert Museum. A mix of history and ultra modern.
After taking a nap and reading at the hotel
column2: we went to our favorite restaurant in London
column3: Sofra
column4:
and saw Evita on the West End. I had never seen the show before and enjoyed it much more than I thought I would.

";"1149570000";"textile"

column1:
"Last Full Day";"personal/travel/england/last-full-day";"

When David and I were first planning our trip to London
column2: I commented that this is the first time we've gone to London without the need to purchase any antiques. His response was "well...there are those side tables in the living room...".
our trip to London would not be complete without a visit to The Furniture Caves. It's a collection of about 8 - 10 antique and reproduction stores where we've bought the armoir in the bedroom
column3: a small dresser
column4: a side board in the living room
column5: and a secretary-like bookcase. They've treated us well.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="Poor David leaving the Furniture Caves Empty Handed" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/furniturecaves.jpg">
Poor David leaving the Furniture Caves Empty Handed

column2: on this trip
column3: we came up empty-handed. There just wasn't anything that spoke to us. However
column4: we did visit someone that had some interesting things from India. He gave us a suggestion of where we might be able to find more India imports.

column1: We took a bus into Chelsea and found the Indian place
column2: but it was all ultra-modern merchandise. What's the point? We checked out anothe antiques market in the area and had a good time walking around Chelsea. We ended up walking into a no-man's-land looking for a lunch place. After many map consultations and a few "I have a good feeling there will be a lunch place down this street"
column3: we ended up at Harrod's. We went in and ordered lunch at one of their counters.

column2: we took it easy again. We went back to the hotel
column3: read
column4: caught up on email
column5: and napped.

column1: That evening we went to see "Sunday in the Park with George". I've seen the version that was taped for PBS plenty of times and am a huge fan. This was the first time seeing it live. I enjoyed it immensely. David
column2:
on the other hand...not so much. He was a little bored and lost with it while I was having an apotheosis.

";"1149570000";"textile"

column1:
"Last Day - St. Paul";"personal/travel/england/last-day-st-paul";"

We didn't have much time on our last full day. I wanted to do just a little bit of shopping and David wanted to visit St. Paul's Cathedral. We decided that we could easily do both.

I had found a store on the internet that sold Indian things and there was a music store that specialized in musicals and soundtracks that were near each other. We took the underground to close to the neighborhood
column2: but left a lot of time for walking. It was a nice day for it.

we stumbled across a house that was known for two famous writers: George Bernard Shaw and Virginia Woolf. I took a picture. I wanted to go knock on the door and tell the residents that we expected great literary achievements from anyone that lived here
column3: but David stopped me.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The House that George Bernard Shaw and Virginia Woolf Lived In (at separate times)" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/shaw-woolf-house.jpg">
The House that George Bernard Shaw and Virginia Woolf Lived In (at separate times)
We found the Indian store. Or rather
column2: we found the remnants of it. It had apparently closed the previous December. Oh well. And we made it to the music store but I wasn't feeling too inspired to buy anything. So it was on to St. Paul's.

column1: I don't have many pictures of St Paul's because you're not allowed to take pictures once you're inside. However
column2: I found a little section where there were no monitors roaming around and the view was too beautiful to resist taking a picture.

column1: I had been to St. Paul's many years ago by myself - on a long layover. I remember being not that impressed. What the hell was up with me that day? It's a beautiful cathedral. I think there must have been some construction or renovation going on to stop my from seeing all of it
column2: because I was mightily impressed going through it with David.

column1: <a class="thickbox" title="The Entrance to St. Pauls" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/stpauls-entrance.jpg">
<a class="thickbox" title="The Ceiling of St. Pauls" target="_blank" href="/files/photos/london/stpauls-ceiling.jpg">

column2: we grabbed lunch and sat in the gardens outside the cathedral and ate. It was another beautiful day. We have been blessed with good weather in London.

column1: I was quite surprised how this long weekend in a city that I have visited several times really turned into a great vacation. Every time I go back to London
column2:
I enjoy it more.

";"1149570000";"textile"

column1:
"Welcome to Keith Marran's Website";"welcome-keith-marrans-website";"

You've reached the website of Keith Marran - and by extension
column2: David Reich
column3: Gogo
column4: Oz
column5: and a slew of friends and family that maybe aren't so excited to see pictures and embarrassing stories of themselves on the website.

column1: In the early days of the web
column2: I swore to myself that my website was not going to be like everyone else's website and just be repository for pictures of my dog
column3: house renovations
column4: and recent vacations. After several years of fighting that constant lure
column5: I've decided that God invented the internet just for that reason. After all
column6: if technology can't save us from boring home slide-shows
column7: then what good is it?

column1: document.writeln("If you want to contact me
column2: I love to get email. You can reach me at ");

David and I were lucky enough to attend the wedding of Sejal and Alex. Alex is one of David's colleagues at the hospital. He is of German descent. Sejal is of Indian descent. They agreed to have a traditional Hindu wedding at the Hyatt Regency on The Hudson in Jersey City.

column1: The ceremony was beautiful. They had handed out cards explaining all the parts of the ceremony which involved lighting a small fire
column2: washing feet
column3: flowers
column4: blessings
column5: and more.

column2: I didn't bring my camera. I was kicking myself the entire time. So I grabbed my iPhone and tried to take some shots - some of which turned out okay.

column1: The lunch and dinner were excellent. It was not your typical NYC Indian meal. The flavors were more unique and interesting. I don't know what kind of spices they used
column2: but both David and I had vivid dreams that evening. In fact
column3: David was shouting in his sleep and kicked me more than once.

column1: "Total Immersion Swimming Workshop";"personal/blog/nyc/total-immersion-swimming-workshop";"I have always wanted to be a better swimmer. I can manage to splash about and get somewhere when I need to
column2: but I never really took to the water. A few years ago
column3: I got a weekly swim instructor. He definitely helped
column4: but I still felt like I struggled with the water a lot. And it was exhausting. I could only do a few short laps at a time without stopping to wheeze. I didn't know how people could swim lap after lap without stopping. A friend told me that I should learn to relax in the water and not try to swim so fast. Whenever I tried
column5: I would sink
column6: get water up my nose
column7: etc. I only knew how to sprint in the water. I developed a routine of doing two freestyle laps and then a breast stroke on the third
column8: because the breast stroke felt free and natural with lots of time to breath.

column1: I read Terry Laughlin's Total Immersion Swimming. While everything made sense
column2: I just could not really apply the lessons to my swimming. First of all
column3: you have to have someone that knows what they're doing help you get the right positions in the water. It's very much based on all sorts of body awareness that I just flat out don't have. Secondly
column4: it's based on doing drills. And there are very few people that will sit down and do the drills required to really change your swimming. You need an instructor to force you to go through things systematically.

column1: I saw that they offered workshops in Queens
column2: but they emphasized bring a buddy since some of the class will be partner based. Somehow
column3: I managed to talk Jeff into going with me. I was really excited about the workshop until I read someone's blog about attending the workshop in Queens. She said that both her and her husband took the workshop and were both triathletes. And most everyone in the workshop was a triathlete as well. Yikes! I am not a triathlete. I was intimidated to say the least. Plus
column4: I had heard that they would be videotaping us in the water for review.

column2: Jeff and I went. The workshop started at 8am both days (Saturday and Sunday) and finished around 4pm. About the half the time was spent in the pool. Starting off was difficult - especially in the morning. The last thing you want to do at 8am is get into a cold pool. But once we got moving in the water there was a lot to concentrate on. And the constant movement warmed us up.

column1: I could write pages about the things we learned in the workshop. The swimming technique really breaks everything down from the beginning. Some lessons came easier than others. There were a couple of times where I got quite frustrated with myself and the technique
column2: but those moments were always followed an hour later with a big revelation and breakthrough.
I got the amount of strokes it took me to cross the pool from 24 to 17!

column1: And though there were some triathletes in the class
column2: it was not intimidating at all. Pretty much everyone was starting over learning the technique so it's not like there were some people that were perfect and some people were horrible. I didn't even mind the videotaping. On the final videotape review
column3: I was actually looking forward to seeing how I did.

column2: I now feel significantly more comfortable in the water. I have not yet made it back to the pool at the gym
column3: though I have no anxiety about doing so. I have a list of things that I know I need to work on and look forward to doing so.";"1223394337";"textile"

column1: "Photographic Lighting: Week 2";"personal/blog/photography/photographic-lighting-week-2";"The first review of my homework for my photography lighting class went well. He gave me a specific challenge: to photograph objects instead of people. I clearly enjoy photographing people and he wanted us to start working outside of our comfort zone.

I also decided that I wanted to focus on indoor lighting where I control the light source. There was a person in our class that had done a great series of photographs of a sweet potato under various lighting sources. I wanted to recreate that look.
In trying to decide what object to use
column2: I thought I would try for organic objects. But I have to admit that I was feeling a little uninspired just photographing plain old objects. I wanted to pick an object that was going to be fun. So I went to a comic book store and looked for action figures. I found a Magneto doll that was highly posable. Then I bought a bunch of produce. I thought it would be fun to photograph Magneto relating to produce with stark lighting.

column1: The photos came out pretty closely to what I had envisioned. We'll see how they go over in class.

"The Simpsons Are Hysterical";"personal/blog/television/simpsons-are-hysterical";"The Simpsons have not been as consistently funny as their early years in a long time. But clips like this one prove that they when they're good
column2: there's no beating them. <!--break-->

column1: This is a preview of this year's "Treehouse of Horror" featuring a segment on voter fraud. I hope it's not prophetic.

column2: David was scheduled to speak in two conferences: one in Tel Aviv and one in Berlin. He asked me if I wanted to join him and I responded with jumping up and down shouting "ISRAEL ISRAEL ISRAEL!". <!--break--> Since he didn't have a lot of time
column3: we went a few days before the conference to spend sometime together. Then after the conference
column4: he went to Berlin and I stayed. A colleague of David's in Israel
column5: Yoram Shapira
column6: organized a trip to Jordan for me and a few other anesthesiologists and their spouses.

column1: I had been to Israel only once before
column2: and it was a very different trip. I visited mainly religious sites: Nazareth
column3: Bethlehem
column4: Jerusalem
column5: etc. This trip was more about nature and archeology. It hit me just as hard as my first trip
column6: but in a very different way. I think I must have lived in the Middle East in a past life. I took the desert so happily. Sure
column7: I was ready for a week of rain by the time I got home
column8: but my time in the desert was food for the soul.

column1: I took 657 photos. It's taking me a long time to go through them all. So please come back every week or so to see the updates. Don't stop checking until you see the dramatic conclusion to my trip in Jerusalem!";"1223731308";"textile"

column2: we rented a car at the airport and drove to the Ein Gedi Kibbutz on the Dead Sea.<!--break-->

column1: The flight to Israel was not as bad as we expected. We flew El Al on an overnight flight (coach
column2: no less!). There was someone sleeping in between us. Luckily it was a small female that was probably on a "birth right" trip. The GPS device in the car wasn't going to take us the way we wanted to go - which drove a little bit through the West Bank. But everyone in Israel goes that way. The GPS route would have added an hour and a half to the trip.

column1: As is typical with traveling east
column2: the room wasn't ready when we arrived. We wandered through the garden like zombies until the room was ready.

column1: The plus side on a trip to the desert is that in the first few days of jet lag
column2: you'll be wide awake for the early hours of the day when it's cool. So our first day
column3: we went to Ein Gedi - which is a natural spring. There's a kibbutz near there where we stayed. And there's a spa on the Dead Sea that is run by the kibbutz.

column1: We arrived at Ein Gedi as soon as it opened. David politely said "You are wearing your hat and drinking 2 liters of water on this trip because I'm not carrying you back to the car when you faint from heat exhaustion." Thank you for caring
column2: David.

column1: Along the walk were little prairie-dog like animals called Hyrax (Hyraxes? Hyraxi?") They loved to sun themselves and climb the trees to eat the leaves. I don't know how they got so pudgy on a vegetarian diet. There were also Ibex (Ibexes? Ibexi?) - which were deer-like animals grazing for grass. Neither of the animals seemed bothered in the least by people.

Along the walk were occasional pools caused by the waterfalls. We stopped at one that was empty for a swim break. The water was pretty warm for a natural spring. It was only 9am by the time we got to the first pool and it was already extremely warm
column2: so the water felt great.

column1: At the top of the walk is the main attraction: a very big waterfall (I think called David's Waterfall). We got there just before the tourists descended upon us.
There was more that we could have hiked up to see
column2: but we weren't feeling that adventurous so we headed back to the car. A two minutes drive from Ein Gedi is a site of an ancient synagogue called
column3: appropriately
column4: The Old Synagogue. There's a tent covering the ruins where you can see some very well preserved mosaics.

column2: we went back to the room and napped.

column1: "Kibbutz Ein Gedi";"personal/travel/israel/kibbutz-ein-gedi";"David and I stayed in Kibbutz Ein Gedi for 2 nights (or was it 3?). It's a great location for a total retreat. From there
column2: we were able to go to Ein Gedi (the spring) and the Ein Gedi Spa (for mud baths
column3: the Dead Sea
column4: massages). <!--break-->

column1: Our room was very private. I never heard anyone around our area of the grounds. The closer you got to the pool
column2: the more you would hear kids playing. There were certain times of day when the pool was packed with kids
column3: but there were also times when I had the place almost to myself. And it was so hot there
column4: that just about any time of day was a good time to go to the pool.

column2: who usually does not get wet at all
column3: was a water fiend. He went swimming in the natural pools of Ein Gedi
column4: he stuck his head in the waterfalls
column5: he swam in the Dead Sea
column6: and went in the kibbutz pool several times. It was like living with a labrador retriever!

column2: David asked if they had any special rooms available. They gave us the honeymoon room. I think the only thing that made it "honeymoonish" was a large jacuzzi for two. We spent so much time in water that it seemed silly to take a bath. So it went unused.

column1: The grounds of the kibbutz were beautiful. At first glance
column2: they seemed dry and lifeless
column3: but as I wandered around (early in the morning as opposed to the heat of mid-day) I saw a huge variety of cactus life. There was a 7:30am tour that you could take of the gardens
column4: but we didn't want to commit to any times - especially so early in the morning.

column2: they had a big cafeteria that served breakfast and dinner - buffet style. The food was surprisingly good - especially considering that it was kosher.

column1: "Photographic Lighting: Week 3";"personal/blog/photography/photographic-lighting-week-3";"The third week of photography lighting class
column2: we worked on beauty lighting. We set up two stations with a tripod and a strobe light. We later added umbrellas to the mix to see how that affected things.

column1: The teacher really made the class this week. Our group was having fun taking photos
column2: checking the exposures
column3: etc. We had all adopted the habit of counting 3..2..1 before taking the picture. The instructor came over and said "Something is very wrong here! Can anyone tell me what it is?" We all shrugged in silence. He said "This light is at eye level. It's boring! I want excitement! Drama!" and he moved the light up. He told us to stop counting down. He grabbed someone's camera and started making banter with the subject
column4: taking various photos. He basically infused a whole bunch of adventure into our rather boring photo session. After he left to go back to the other group
column5: we got continually more creative. Standing on seats
column6: crazy poses
column7: and playing with reflectors. He came back later to infuse some more creative chaos later.

column1: I've included my favorites of the portraits that I took.

I've also included my favorites from my homework. I wanted to explore photographing food. I had done some research and several people suggested not getting fancy with lighting food. Natural light is generally best. I went a photographic store and bought a light reflector (for capturing as much natural light as possible) and I went to The Cupcake Cafe to get a small cake as a subject. I took these photos at noon
column2: to try to get as much natural light as possible. Unfortunately
column3: my subject started sweating half-way through the session. Still
column4: I like the photos. Half of the photos use the reflector and half just use the single light source of the sun.

column2: I complained regular to anyone who would listen about the horrible state of espresso drinks in New York City. You only had a few choices: Starbucks
column3: Your Local Deli
column4: and restaurants. There were a few places in the village or Little Italy where you could maybe get a decent espresso
column5: but you couldn't count on getting the good barrista on any given day - and without a good operator
column6: you can only go so far.

column1: I was so vocal about it
column2: that someone forwarded me an article about why the espresso will never be good in NYC (the water has low calcium content) and the author's efforts to find a decent cup of espresso. He had the same comments I had - maybe your could find a good one here and there
column3: but eventually the work would be handed off to a newbie barrista and the skill would be lost.

column2: I noticed that things have changed. The city is turning into Seattle. There are quaint little mom-and-pa coffee places everywhere now. There used to not be any local coffee choices in my neighborhood
column3: now there are two great ones within a couple of blocks: Grumpy's Cafe and Irving Coffee Company. Then
column4: just yesterday
column5: I saw them putting up a new independent coffee place on Greenwich:

column1: Hallelujah. The Starbuck's locations are dwindling and these independent cafes are on the rise. Finally. Now maybe we can start thinking about adding bookstores back to the city.
"The First Visit to the Dead Sea";"personal/travel/israel/first-visit-dead-sea";"While we stayed at Ein Gedi
column2: we took a trip to the spa. The spa had all sorts of treatments that you could get: mud treatments
column3: ayurvedic massages
column4: swedish massages
column5: hot stone therapy
column6: you name it. I got an ayurvedic massage and David got a mud massage. There were plenty of things to do if you didn't want to get a treatment. You could hang out at their big
column7: blue pool; you could take trip down to the Dead Sea and go swimming; you could give yourself a mud treatment; or
column8: you could stay indoors and hang out in the Dead Sea waters (they had piped up the water from the sea).

column1: David and I took a trip down the Dead Sea itself. It's not something you can do for very long. If you have any open sores
column2: you'll feel them burn a little due to the minerals in the water. David didn't last that long. He said his whole system starts to get agitated by the water. You can see in the photos that the floor of the sea is like walking on solid salt. There's also a photo of a wooden pole that was placed in the water and the culture of minerals that has grown on it.

column1: I didn't take any photos of the spa until the last half hour. I decided to leave my camera in the locker and just experience the spa for a while. But my massage finished a half hour sooner than David's
column2: so I grabbed my camera to take pictures of the water
column3: the lifeguard
column4: and people in mud.

column2: we left the Ein Gedi Kibbutz and headed to Be'er Sheva. It's a major city located in the Negev Desert. David drove us up the cliffs of the Dead Sea to the desert. It was a bit of a culture shock. There were large stretches of barrenness with an occasional Bedouin village. I was not a fan of the Negev desert on our first day.

column1: We checked into our hotel in Be'er Sheva
column2: relaxed a bit
column3: and got ready for dinner. We went to a suburb to have dinner with Yoram Shapira
column4: chairman of the hospital in Be'er Sheva. His backyard had a great garden with all sorts of fruit bearing plants. The patio was covered by an arbor with grapes that he uses to make his own wine. We got a tour of the basement where we saw his process for making wine - every step entirely by hand.

column2: he took us around some areas of the Negev Desert. What I had originally thought was a barren landscape came alive. Yoram showed us how they had created areas of the desert to collect rainwater (there are only a couple of inches of rain per year) and build small groves of trees. They had imported various types of trees that could survive the arid landscape.

column1: Our first stop was Ein Avdat National Park. It's a wadi (a canyon formed by a spring) near the home of [w:Ben Gurion]
column2: who David had described as the George Washington of Israel. We walked through the canyon to the source of the river (which was very small). Along the way
column3: we saw many Ibex. They were not shy around humans at all. We got very close and if we came up on any on the path
column4: they did not stop what they were doing.

column2: we went to [w:Mitzpe Ramon] - the site of the largest crater in Israel. It's hard to capture the expanse of the crater in a photo. My wide angle lens couldn't take it all in - and you still don't get a sense of how deep the crater is.

column1: I felt like the day was a great introduction to the Negev. I could myself returning someday. And honestly
column2: even though it was extremely hot
column3: it didn't bother me really. I guess I got used to wearing a hat and drinking a lot of water.

column2: you should go see Wig Out! at The Vineyard Theater.

column1: It's a hard show to describe. It helps if you've seen the movie Paris is Burning
column2: since that's kind of the source material. It's essentially a fictional account of a "family" of drag queens competing at a ball in Harlem. There's dancing
column3: singing
column4: performance art
column5: snappy dialogue
column6: high drama
column7: and lots of fantastic drag outfits. And this are not your silly
column8: campy drag queens. These are your hard-code
column9: tough-as-nails
column10: steal-your-credit-card-so-they-can-buy-a-versace-outfit drag queens.

column1: It's playing until November 16th. It's been extended twice. I hope it gets extended again. It's the sort of show that should reach a wider audience.
"Photographic Lighting: Week 5";"personal/blog/photography/photographic-lighting-week-5";"I missed the 4th week of photography class
column2: so I'll jump right into week 5.
we started using soft boxes - which are big boxes of fabric you put over a light to direct all the light in one direction. There's a flat white part where the light emits
column3: which diffuses the light.

column1: After we had gotten the hang of taking photos with the lights
column2: the instructor came over and told us to start playing with the edge of the light. Essentially
column3: this means positioning the soft box so that the light is not focused (in the least) on the subject. You end of just catching the edge of the soft box light on the subject. It was a really nice effect.

column2: we were to focus on subjects in motion - either capturing blur in the photo or stopping action in progress. This turned out to be very difficult for me. I spent an afternoon at Union Square. It turns out this wasn't so smart. It was midday
column3: and in order to take a blurry shot
column4: I had to use a long shutter speed. There was too much natural light to pull it off. I went to the dog run hoping to catch some dogs playing
column5: but all the dogs were sitting serenely at their owner's sides. I looked for skateboarders
column6: but there was only one. I got a couple of shots for class anyway
column7: but I threw away the vast majority of photos I took.

column1: I also tried an evening photo shoot of Kevin lighting a cigarette. It didn't come out at all like I thought. I thought I was going to get these great streaks of light. It didn't happen. I was happy with one of the photos none-the-less
column2: but not because it was a great example of motion photography.

column1: "Caesarea";"personal/travel/israel/caesarea";"I had the fortune of going to [w:Caesarea] two days in a row. The first visit was with David and our friend
column2: Idit. She had decided to take us there to see some new films and exhibits that had been installed there and for lunch. She had been married at Caesarea
column3: so it holds a special place in her heart.

column1: We saw some of the new exhibits and films about the area. They gave an excellent slice of history about the area and also gave you a sense of how huge the original location must have been. We were commenting after the exhibits how many people had come through and laid claim to the area over the past few thousand years. What's next or Caesarea? Does it stay in Jewish hands from now until forever? Will they have to update the films someday to talk about how the Martians landed there and took it for themselves? It's definitely a location that inspires to think about the passage of time in a grand scale.
Idit treated us to a wonderful lunch on the water
column2: watching fishermen out on the ancient remains of the rampart walls.
I took a tour from the hotel that went up the western coast of Israel. Our first stop was Caesarea
column3: but we saw a different side. We visited the stadium where a flautist was showing off the incredible acoustics. We saw the arena where they held chariot races. Overall
column4: I don't think we were there more than an hour - and it's a huge site - so I'm glad I had some time during the preceding day to enjoy the site.

column1: "The Baha'i Temple Gardens";"personal/travel/israel/bahai-temple-gardens";"Our second stop on my organized tour was to the [w:Baha'i] Temple Gardens in Haifa. I thought we were going to have more time in Haifa - which is considered by many to the most beautiful city in Israel. We only had about twenty minutes
column2: which was disappointing. They droves us to the top of the gardens
column3: let us out to take pictures
column4: then we drove off to the next stop. Bummer - but at least I was able to see some of the gardens.

column1: One of the major tenets of the Baha'i Faith is on making things that are beautiful. The gardens are meticulous and well manicured. You are only allowed in the gardens if you are a member of the faith. Hence
column2: all of these shots are taken from roughly the same - at the top overlooking the wall of the garden.
I hope to see more of the garden.

column1: "Photographic Lighting: Week 6";"personal/blog/photography/photographic-lighting-week-6";"I'm a bit behind on my posts about photography class. Week 6 was all about black and white photography. I was hoping to bring in some male nudes
column2: but all of my friends were shockingly prudish! I'm trying to figure out if that's because in the age of the internet
column3: people just don't want someone to take nude photos of them. Or perhaps none of my friends trust me. Or perhaps the younger generation just isn't as comfortable stripping for art. Hmmm...

column1: So instead I went to [w:Abingdon Square] in New York City. People had donated several carved pumpkins to the square for Halloween. They made great subjects.
I also finally learned to use my new on-camera flash successfully. It's wireless
column2: so I was using one hand to hold and angle the flash. I exposed the camera without the flash first
column3: to get a very underexposed shot of the background
column4: then used the flash to make the pumpkin take the focus. I think the effect worked.

column2: I converted the images to black and white using Aperture. They have a tool called "Monochrome Mixer" that helps you convert images to black and white. You can assign each RGB value a different percentage of the total black and white. So
column3: for instance
column4: if you want the green values to be more dominant
column5: you would mix the image to weigh the green values more heavily in the black and white image. This allowed me to make sure the pumpkins stood out more
column6: by mixing the image for an "orange" filter.

column2: our assignment for class was to photograph food. He gave us the general guideline of using natural light in the background and a reflector in the front to capture the light. I think I did pretty well at getting the subject to really pop with the reflector. I took some shots without the reflector for comparison and they came out a little too contrast-y - and not in a good way. The reflector gave the food a nice glow to it.
here I come.

column1: "Acre";"personal/travel/israel/acre";"The main event of our tour was [w:Acre
column2: Israel]. It's an ancient city several layers deep. Like many of the sites in Israel
column3: it's had many different rules at different times: Greeks & Romans
column4: Arabs
column5: Crusaders
column6: Ottomans
column7: etc. The British used it as a prison for a while. There are several layers to the city
column8: meaning that underneath the main city
column9: they discovered a temple. And underneath that temple that discovered an older temple. They are still digging and finding more levels underneath what they've already found.

column1: Some of the pictures include a view of Knight's Hall. There's evidence that the French ruled during the building of it because there's a fleur-de-lis engraved into a column.

Off of the Knight's Hall is a small passage that was originally built for royalty to escape the fortress. The passage gets steadily smaller until it empties out into the graveyard. It all felt very "Da Vinci Code".

column2: we stopped into a shop that sold copper and silver plates. The designs were quite impressive - better than the usual gift shop fare. They didn't want me taking photos
column3: though.

column1: We passed by a mosque on the way out
column2: but we didn't go in.

column1: "Rosh Hanikra";"personal/travel/israel/rosh-hanikra";"Our final stop on our day tour is a locale at the very northern tip of Israel: the [w:Rosh HaNikra grottoes]. You take a small tram down the side of a cliff to get to the grottoes. The cliffs are a beautiful white chalk and the Mediterranean feeds into the grottoes
column2: making for great tourist photos. <!--break-->

column1: Rosh Hanikra was the site where Israeli and Lebanese officials negotiated and concluded an armistice in 1949 which ended the Lebanese-Israeli component of the 1948 War of Israeli Independence.
You're essentially at the border of Lebanon. So I took a photo.
"Photographic Lighting: Final Class";"personal/blog/photography/photographic-lighting-final-class";"We had our final photography lighting class. The assignment was quite open ended:
It is now time to take all that you have learned up to this point and put it together into strong evocative images. Images that show you can control the mood and voice in your lighting technique.

I went through many iterations of ideas for images. I had to immediately rule out spontaneous photos since that's not really about lighting. I had to think of images that were pre-meditated and planned. I had a few ideas here and there
column2: but nothing that stuck. I went to see Slumdog Millionaire and fell totally in love with it. Every single shot was breathtaking and felt quite "real". However
column3: it left me even more frozen as what to do.

column2: I tried to recreate an idea I had while trying to fall asleep in Amsterdam. I thought of someone being visited by hypnagogic images of figures while unable to fall asleep.

column1: I invited some friends over for dinner and the photo shoot
column2: rented some lights
column3: bought some animal masks
column4: and we had a good time. I honestly could not tell if the photos were interesting or weird in a sort of bad-undergraduate way. In the end I was quite happy with them. They certainly stood out as different
column5: which counts for a lot
column6: I think. And the teacher really liked them. So Mission Accomplished.

column1: For the rest of the class
column2: we focused on taking shots of products - meaning wine
column3: fruit
column4: and cheese.

column1: Also in the set are some photos I had taken in the previous class.

"Gogo at Christmas";"personal/blog/gogo/gogo-christmas";"I had been looking for this photo to show Mom while she was in town and I didn't have it handy. But now here it is: Gogo at Christmas. This was done a few years ago when David and I went to St John and left Gogo at a kennel. They dressed her up in a Christmas collar and somehow convinced her to smile for the camera. Though I don't approve of dressing up dogs for photos
column2: this will go down as one of my favorite Gogo photos.
a=center]";"1228959317";"textile"

column1: "The House Tour";"personal/blog/house/house-tour";"If you want a virtual tour of the house
column2: this is the place to start.
it was the Bowery Mission Women's Home. Even though it's been privately owned for 8 years now
column3: we still occasionally get visitors to the house hoping that it's still a mission home. Sad
column4: I know.

column1: You can start with the pictures of what the house looked like before we got it
column2: and then move on to the finished product. And one of these days
column3: I'll take new photos of what it looks like now.";"1229875359";"textile"

column1: "The First Round of Renovations";"personal/house/first-renovation";"The first renovation included the kitchen (since the only kitchen is in Benji's unit)
column2: the living room
column3: and one of the bathrooms.

column2: my sister planned to get married in our house that summer. She would often stop by
column3: talk to the workers
column4: and remind them that she was getting married there. It helped keep the project on track. We didn't have counter tops in time for the wedding
column5: but Dad went down to the local lumber yard (yes
column6: NYC has lumber yards) and had some plywood cut to fit and we placed table cloths over it. All in all
column7: we were shockingly ready for the wedding.

column2: our only kitchen was on the top floor. We had a hot plate
column3: a microwave
column4: and a mini-fridge on the top floor. And we only had one bathroom which we shared with the construction crew. Looking back on it
column5: I don't know how we managed during this phase of construction. I had taken the attitude that it might never end and we could live like this for our entire lives. I was then pleasantly surprised when it was all done.";"1229875876";"textile"

column1: "The Last(?) Big Renovation";"personal/house/last-big-renovation";"One of the last big renovations was the Bollywood Room and my office. As I'm sitting here writing this
column2: it's hard to believe that this room sat full of junk for years. It's hard to remember that the carpet was ripped up by the door from Gogo trying to escape. It feels like my own personal cave. I never want to leave.
after give tours of the house and listening to everyone rave about the X-Men Bathroom
column3: David decided to trust me on my plan for a Bollywood Room. Not because he liked the idea
column4: but because he would do anything to stop people gushing about the X-Men Bathroom. I think he realized that the Bollywood Room had the potential to be the coolest room in the house.

column1: It's close...but there's no beating the X-Men Bathroom. No Way.";"1229876398";"textile"

column2: Sis and I are both in New York
column3: so we got to spend Christmas together. She came down for Thanksgiving
column4: so we decided it would be appropriate if we came up for Christmas.

column1: I think this was Lorenz's first Christmas that he had some awareness of what it was and that he was getting presents. I thought for sure that he would not be able to wait opening his presents
column2: but Sis explained several times to him the schedule that presents are opened after breakfast on Christmas morning
column3: and he was cool with it. In fact
column4: he didn't really understand that he was getting a bunch of stuff until he was about half way through the present unwrapping.

column1: I had a hard time picking out a gift. Sis had various criteria. She would prefer a gift that was nurturing
column2: designed to spark the intellect
column3: and preferably had animals - and more specifically whales. I ignored all that and got him three Playmobil dinosaur sets. I have to admit - they were super cool. There was one set with a car and people
column4: and the car had a big cage on wheels that you could tow behind that had a velociraptor in it. Super neat. And another set had a Triceratops
column5: a baby triceratops
column6: and they all lived in a volcano that you could explode with a button. Oh my god. I get excited every time I think about it.

column1: Lorenz took a bit to get really excited about it. That was partly due to the fact that there was a lot of assembly involved. David tried to act like he was put out by doing so much assembly
column2: but the truth is that as soon as he saw all the little pieces and an instruction book
column3: he seized them all and made himself a little workstation - all the while complaining about how much work it was.

column2: we got in the car to go see a movie. We drove about 30 minutes out of town to see Bolt
column3: but it turns out the web had lied and that the theater was not open and if it was open on Christmas
column4: Bolt wasn't playing. I realized that we had worked so hard to get Lorenz excited about the movie in order to leave his new toys behind
column5: that we had another crushing disappointment on our hands. So we went back to Ithaca and saw "The Tale of Desperaux"
column6: which he liked. He's all business when he watches movies and is extremely well behaved. They had a photo booth in the movie theater which we used for great hilarity.

column2: we made a delicious Mexican dinner - Sopa Azteca and Mushroom/Spinach Enchiladas. It was so good
column3: I made a variation a week later when David and I were back in New York. For dessert
column4: I had made a pumpkin tart. It was good
column5: but a little too sweet and dense. I'll have to look for a recipe that lightens everything up.

column2: I was anxious to take some shots of the great outdoors. We had seen some great views of frozen waterfalls on the way up. So we all went to Buttermilk Falls and Ithaca Falls. The former was a bit of disappointment because instead of looking grandiose it just looked dirty. I think the best time for shots of the waterfalls is during the spring when all the snow from winter is melting.

column1: This year actually had put me back in the Christmas spirit. I have been a real scrooge in recent years. I'm just not that into Christmas. But the winter drive to upstate New York
column2: hanging out with Sis in her collegiate apartment
column3: and seeing Christmas through the eyes of a 3-year-old renewed my faith in the holiday.

column1: "New Year Resolutions";"personal/blog/learning/new-year-resolutions";"It's time for New Year's Resolutions! I usually don't do New Year's resolutions - I do vacation resolutions. It's on a trip that my head clears and I have some time to think about what I'd like to change in my life. This year
column2: though
column3: for some reason
column4: I have a ton of New Year's resolutions. And I have to admit
column5: I'm pretty excited by them.

column1: I originally twittered this as a joke. But I followed it for a couple of weeks
column2: and I realized how much I needle myself with negative comments and discredited myself. I need a regular
column3: healthy dose of self-love. Like an internal cheerleader. In theory
column4: if I follow this one to its fullest
column5: I can forget all other resolutions.

column1: David specifically requested this one. I made a great Mexican vegetarian dinner and it was like the old days when I would have a nice home-cooked meal most nights. I don't know how I got so far off the path of home-cooked meals.
I think one of the hardest things for me is coming up with ideas for dinner
column2: and then getting the shopping done in time. So I've developed a plan of coming up with a rotating one-month menu. On Friday night
column3: I'll put together the grocery list for next week's food. That way
column4: I don't have to think about what the individual dinners are - I just follow the monthly plan. The plan can always change - but it helps if there's a plan to start with. That also helps me make sure I'm not repeating foods too frequently.

column1: 3. Spend some time at The Tibet House

I really think group meditation could be a really good thing. And it's something to get me out of the house. I've talked about doing this for years - and I actually went there with my friend Sara once. The place is beautiful and the people were as friendly as could be. I think a regular dose of group meditation is the sort of thing that would help me stick with all of the other resolutions. And help me not be so crabby.
4. Do photo shoots around the city
Specifically: start reading Time Out New York for odd things around the city
column2: go to the events
column3: and take photos. The Brooklyn Cop had told me a story about a Santa Claus Pub Crawl where there were hundreds of people dressed in Santa costumes crossing the Brooklyn Bridge. Why was I not there taking pictures? I have no idea where any of this would lead
column4: but it would be fun and make me a better photographer. And if I could sell some of the photos someday
column5: that would be great.

column1: 5. Write at least one play - preferably two.
The candidates are "Gay Men Behaving Badly" and "Randy & Sheila's Guide to Extramarital Relationships".
6. Swim at least once a week
No explanation necessary here. I love swimming. It's good exercise. I have time for it. It's a no-brainer.
7. Get over my fear of social swing dancing
It's time to just bite the bullet and start going to Tuesday night dance practice and Frim Fram on Thursday nights. No ifs ands or buts. Once again
column2: it's good exercise
column3: it's fun. No brainer.

column1: We're starting to get into the dregs of resolutions. I doubt this one will happen - but it's definitely something I'd like to do.

column2: I have no tech aspirations.

column1: There's a lot more there than I thought. It's all do-able - and if I were to accomplish all of that
column2: I would be the happiest boy in the world. ";"1231089674";"textile"

column1: "Shortcrust Dough";"personal/recipes/dish/desserts/shortcrust-dough";"This dough has a higher butter and sugar content than a classic flaky dough
column2: resulting in a sweet
column3: crisp
column4: yet crumbly tart shell reminiscent of a butter cookie (known as pâte sablée in France or pasta frolla in Italy).

column1: Taken from Cindy Mushet's <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Desserts-Mediterranean-Flavors-California-Style/dp/0684800543/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1231776370&sr=8-5" target="_blank">Desserts: Mediterranean Flavors
column2: California Style

column1: Yields: enough dough to line a tart pan up to 10 inches in diameter
One 9-or 9 1/2-inch fluted tart pan with removable bottom
A piece of heavy-duty foil and enough pie weights to fill the tart shell to the top for prebaking
Rice and/or dried beans may be used instead of metal pie weights
column2: but note that rice and beans used in this manner are no longer suitable for eating (though they may be used over and over again to prebake tart shells).

column1: 1 stick (4 ounces) cold (not frozen) unsalted butter
column2: cut into 1/2-inch pieces

column1: To mix using a mixer: Place the flour
column2: sugar
column3: and salt in the bowl of a standing mixer fitted with the paddle attachment. Mix on low for 1 minute to blend the ingredients. Add the butter pieces and mix on medium speed just until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs
column4: about 3 to 4 minutes. In a separate bowl
column5: whisk together the yolks
column6: vanilla
column7: and 1 teaspoon of water. Add this to the dry ingredients and blend just until the dough begins to form large clumps. Test the dough by squeezing several clumps in your hand-they should hold together. If not
column8: add the remaining water
column9: 1 teaspoon at a time
column10: until the dough coheres. Remove the dough from the bowl and knead it gently 2 or 3 times
column11: just to finish bringing it together. Shape the dough into a round disc about 3/4 inch thick and 5 1/2 inches in diameter. Wrap tightly in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes before proceeding.

column1: To mix using a food processor: Place the flour
column2: sugar
column3: and salt in the bowl of a food processor fitted with the metal blade. Pulse 5 times to blend the ingredients.

column1: Add the cold butter pieces and pulse 6 to 8 times
column2: just until the butter is the size of large peas. In a separate bowl
column3: whisk together the yolks
column4: vanilla
column5: and 1 teaspoon of water. Add this to the bowl of the processor
column6: then process just until the dough begins to form small clumps-do not let it form a ball. Test the dough by squeezing a handful of clumps-they should hold together. If not
column7: add the remaining water
column8: 1 teaspoon at a time
column9: until the dough coheres. Remove the dough from the bowl and knead it gently 2 or 3 times
column10: just to finish bringing it together. Shape it into a round disc about 3/4 inch thick and 5 1/2 inches in diameter. Wrap tightly in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes before proceeding.

column1: To mix by hand: Place the flour
column2: sugar
column3: and salt in a medium bowl and blend well with a whisk. Add the cold butter pieces and toss until they are lightly coated with the flour. Use your fingertips
column4: 2 knives
column5: or a pastry blender to cut the butter into the flour until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. If at any time during this process the butter softens and becomes warm
column6: place the bowl in the freezer for 10 minutes before continuing. In a separate bowl
column7: whisk together the yolks
column8: vanilla
column9: and 2 teaspoons of water. Add this to the dry ingredients and toss between your fingertips 20 to 30 times to evenly distribute the moisture. The dough will still look very crumbly
column10: but if the mixture is squeezed in your hand
column11: it should hold together. If not
column12: add the remaining teaspoon of water and toss to blend. Turn the dough out of the bowl onto your work surface and knead it gently 5 or 6 times
column13: just to finish bringing it together. Shape it into a round disc about 3/4 inch thick and 5 1/2 inches in diameter. Wrap tightly in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes before proceeding.

column1: To roll out the dough: It is easiest to roll this dough when it is at cool room temperature. This means that if it has been refrigerated for longer than 30 minutes
column2: let it sit on the counter for 10 to 15 minutes before rolling it out (if it is too cold
column3: the dough will crack as you attempt to roll it).

column1: Place the disc of dough between two 12 inch pieces of plastic wrap. Roll the dough into an 11-inch round as shown
column2: rotating it clockwise slightly after each roll to create an even round. Remember to roll from the center outward and to lift the rolling pin at the edge rather than smashing the edge down. As you roll
column3: the plastic wrap will wrinkle and resist. When this happens
column4: peel it off and replace it smoothly
column5: then flip the dough over and repeat with the plastic on the other side before you continue rolling. You may need to do this several times during the rolling process. (Experienced pastry makers may wish to roll the dough out on a lightly floured work surface
column6: turning the dough as you roll and dusting the work surface and dough with extra flour as needed to keep it from sticking. Before transferring the dough to the tart pan
column7: brush any excess flour from the surface
