column8: then flip it over and brush the flour from the bottom as well. Transfer the dough to the tart pan by rolling it around your rolling pin
column9: then unrolling it into the pan.)

column1: Transfer the dough to the tart pan by removing the top piece of plastic wrap. Leave the bottom piece on to hold the dough together while you lift it and flip it over into the tart pan (remaining plastic side should be up)
column2: centering it as best you can as shown. Remove the top layer of plastic wrap and press the dough into the corners of the pan using your fingertips. Patch any tears by simply pressing the dough together
column3: then build the edge of the tart slightly above the rim of the pan by reinforcing each flute. To do this
column4: press the index finger of one hand against the dough inside the curve of each flute to push the dough upward while at the same time pressing the dough from the outside of each flute with the thumb and index finger of your other hand in a pinching position. The dough should rise about 1/4 inch above the rim of the pan all the way around. Place the tart pan
column5: uncovered
column6: in the refrigerator for 1 hour or in the freezer for 30 minutes.

column1: To prebake the tart shell: Preheat the oven to 375°F. Position an oven rack in the lower third of the oven. Line the chilled tart shell with heavy-duty foil
column2: pressing the foil firmly into the corners of the pan. Fill the pan with metal pie weights
column3: dried beans
column4: or rice. The center layer of weights may be thinner
column5: but be sure to push the weights all the way up the sides of the pan to reduce shrinkage and to ensure the edges are straight.

column1: To partially bake the shell: Bake for about 10 to 12 minutes
column2: or until the edges and center are set and no longer stick to the foil when you try to remove it. Remove the foil and weights and return the pan to the oven for another 8 to 12 minutes
column3: or until the crust is a pale tan color. Place on a rack to cool completely before filling the shell.

column1: To fully bake the shell: Bake for about 20 to 22 minutes
column2: or until the edges and center are set and no longer stick to the foil when you try to remove it. Remove the foil and weights and return the pan to the oven for another 8 to 12 minutes
column3: or until the crust is golden brown all over. Place on a rack to cool completely before filling the shell.";"1231775556";"textile"

column1: "Siena Tart";"personal/recipes/dish/desserts/siena-tart";"Siena is a charming medieval city just south of Florence that is best known for its famous horse race
column2: called the Palio
column3: in which riders wearing the bright
column4: traditional colors and insignia of each of the city's time-honored neighborhoods vie for first place in a thunderous free-for-all around the beautiful piazza. It is a place that takes tradition seriously
column5: in food as well as horse races
column6: which is evident in its dedication to panforte. Every store in the city seems to have its own "best" version of this honey-based cross between a fruitcake and a candy
column7: with a chewy
column8: dense
column9: caramel-like texture packed with almonds and hazelnuts
column10: spices
column11: and candied citrus peels. While in Siena
column12: I tasted many versions-all for research purposes
column13: you understand-and my favorites were those that contained the cocoa
column14: which tempers the sweetness and adds complexity to the flavor. I couldn't help thinking that panforte would be even better packed with those addictive dried sour cherries from Michigan that I adore. This tart is very reminiscent in flavor to a scuro panforte
column15: although it is not the classic cake-like confection. Instead
column16: a crisp tart shell is filled with almonds (both sliced and whole for a contrast of textures) and dried sour cherries coated with just enough honey
column18: and citrus zest to sweeten them. The tart is a gorgeous
column20: the sensuous curves of the nuts and cherries a glistening medley of browns. I serve it during the winter months
column21: when its spicy flavors and chewy crunchiness are most appreciated.

column1: Taken from Cindy Mushet's <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Desserts-Mediterranean-Flavors-California-Style/dp/0684800543/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1231776370&sr=8-5" target="_blank">Desserts: Mediterranean Flavors
column2: California Style

column1: 1 recipe Shortcrust Dough to fill a 9-or 9 1/2 inch fluted tart pan with removable bottom
column2: partially baked and cooled
preferably orange blossom or wildflower
about 1 large orange

column1: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Position an oven rack in the center of the oven.

column2: place the sliced almonds
column3: whole almonds
column4: and cherries in a medium mixing bowl. Sift the powdered sugar
column5: cocoa powder
column6: and spices over them and stir with a rubber spatula until they are evenly coated. Place the honey
column7: orange zest
column8: and lemon zest in a small saucepan and cook over low heat just until the honey is hot to the touch and very liquid - do not let it boil. Remove from the heat and let the mixture sit for 5 minutes
column9: so that the honey is flavored with the citrus zests. Then pour the honey over the nuts and cherries
column10: scraping every bit out of the pan with the rubber spatula. Stir until everything is evenly coated with the honey. At first
column11: it will seem that there is not enough honey
column12: but continue to stir gently (trying not to break the sliced almonds) and eventually the nuts will be thoroughly coated. Be sure to scrape up from the bottom of the bowl as you stir
column13: as pockets of dry cocoa powder and spices tend to form there.

column1: Scrape the filling into the prebaked tart shell and use the spatula or your hands to pat it into an even layer. Bake for 25 to 30 minutes
column2: or until a deep golden brown. Remove from the oven and place on a rack to cool completely.
when cool
column3: center the tart pan on top of a large can (1 use a large can of tomatoes) so that it balances midair as the rim of the tart pan falls to the counter. Leave the bottom of the pan under the tart for support
column4: or slide the tart onto a serving plate by running a large spatula between the crust and the pan
column5: using it to guide the tart onto the plate.

column1: SERVING AND STORAGE NOTES: If desired
column2: dust the surface of the tart with a bit of powdered sugar. Serve at room temperature with a spoonful of honeyed mascarpone. Because the filling’s rather sticky
column3: I find it easiest to cut this tart with a thin
column4: sharp knife that has been lightly coated with a flavorless vegetable oil. Store
column5: covered loosely with foil
column6: at room temperature for up to 5 days.";"1231776503";"textile"

column1: "Obama & Spider-Man";"personal/blog/nyc/obama-sold-out";"Marvel comics has been doign a great job of creating marketing events over the past year or so - which is good because they haven't focused on creating great comic books. This week
column2: on the cover of "The Amazing Spider-Man"
column3: is Barack Obama. For some reason
column4: this is a really big deal. Apparently there's a mini-story in the book involving Spider-Man and Obama. I'm happy for the author
column5: who I think has been one of the more under-rated comic book authors in the past few years. I'm doing him a service by not reading his comics anymore
column6: because whenever I start reading them
column7: they get canceled. Plus
column8: I'm not that big of a Spider-Man fan.

column2: comic book stores have been sold out for over a week and it just got released today. There are all sorts of notices at comic book stores to pre-order and that you are limited to one copy per customer. Maybe someday I'll grumble when I see collector's editions of this issue going for thousands of dollars. But for now
column3: I don't really care.

column1: I keep digressing. This morning I went to my local comic book store. They had only been open an hour and they had already posted a sign on their front door that they were sold out of the Obama issue. And what's even more impressive
column2: is that someone had already put graffiti on the sign.

column1: I'll let the photo speak for itself.
"Westminster Dog Show 2009";"personal/blog/dogs/westminster-dog-show-2009";"A couple of weekends ago
column2: Evan & Renee (Gogo & Oz's breeders) came to New York City for a visit. They had two of their dogs competing in the Westminster Dog Show. I was able to tag along for the Canaan Dog competition.

column1: For those of you that have only been exposed to dog shows via the movie "Best in Show"
column2: in some ways I think the movie's caricatures pale in comparison to real life. There were some real characters backstage with their dogs. And the movie did not accurately depict the look of sheer boredom that the dogs had on their face as they were being prepared for the ring. I felt most sorry for the poodles
column3: who all had a look on their face of "Not this again".

column2: then when the Canaan Dogs were ready to compete
column3: I tried taking shots of the action in the ring. I learned a couple of things about dog shows. First of all
column4: the dogs are only looked at for a minute or two
column5: so if the dog doesn't feel like showing themselves off for a judge at that exact minute
column6: you're done. Secondly
column7: to see why the judges are picking certain dogs
column8: you have to be right up close to them. There's no way you can tell from a TV camera. Yes
column9: some of the winners that I saw definitely had "star quality" - but I don't think it's the sort of thing I would have noticed from TV. (Although
column10: the one photo in my set that I thought was really beautiful was of the dog that ended up winning the Canaan Dog competition)

column1: It was really dark in the auditorium for photography. I was nowhere near close enough for the flash to make any difference. I opted for a long shutter speed and waiting for the subjects to be still. That wasn't such a smart idea. No one wanted to sit still for me. Someday I'll be able to afford a lens with a nice big aperture so I can get away with more low-light shots
column2: but not this year.

column1: "Chocolate Post-Mortem";"personal/blog/food/chocolate-post-mortem";"This was my third year making holiday-time chocolates for friends
column2: family
column3: and co-workers. This year Mom helped me hit a record of 1080 individual pieces of chocolate. Every year I learn a lot about the process and I'm convinced I'll remember it all the following year. And every year I start the process with the same set of questions and frustrations. So this year I'm writing down everything I learned over the process for notes to next year.<!--break-->

column2: here are the finished chocolates:
size=m
column3: align=c]

column1: • German - Cherry and almond cream in dark chocolate
• Turkish - Pistachio and spices in dark chocolate
• Brazil - Passion fruit & guava fondant in white chocolate
• Colombian - Orange and coffee in white chocolate
• English - Milk chocolate caramel in dark chocolate
• Mexican - Cinnamon & pepper milk chocolate in dark chocolate
The good news is that all the flavors were great. I usually change the flavors around a bit every year
column2: but think I've found my permanent list. I wouldn't mind finding another flavor for Asia
column3: but I don't know who I would bump from the current list.

column2: I had to determine the temperatures myself. The milk chocolate was too runny and some of the batches were slightly out of temper by the end. It went into the molds a little too thin. Next year
column3: my final temperature for milk chocolate should be a bit cooler than what the package recommended. And let it dry in the molds a bit more than last year.

column2: the dark chocolate was very thick when it went into the molds. This led to the German chocolates being "the disaster batch". On the dark chocolate
column3: keep the resting temperature of the chocolate a little on the high side and get it into the molds quickly. And when you dump the partially melted chocolate out of the molds
column4: you have to really bang the dark chocolate out.

column2: the idea of chopping up sour cherries and putting them in the chocolates was a big headache and didn't work. In the future
column3: put the cherries directly into the cream and pipe it in.

column1: <li>The big enemy for molded chocolates is air bubbles. One option is to paint the inside of molds first
column2: before pouring the chocolate in. That's very time-consuming. I was able to keep the air bubbles to a minimum if I keep the mold tilted while I pour the chocolate. And pour at the top of the mold so that the chocolate drips down into the crevices. Give everything a very vigorous shake to work bubbles to the top. Pour more chocolate if necessary. Then wipe it all clean with an offset spatula. That should take care of air bubbles. Don't be afraid to bang the mold of chocolates.
use the recipes on my spreadsheet. Don't look for a different recipe. The passion fruit didn't set up at first and took a lot of work to come together.

column1: <li>For fillings that are dependent on white chocolate
column2: melt a bunch of white chocolate first
column3: then add flavoring until you get the right consistency. Don't add melted chocolate to flavoring. It takes forever to know if you have the right consistency.

column1: That's all I can remember. Let's hope that this all makes sense in December when I do it again.";"1239723016";"textile"
"Family Trip to Hawaii";"personal/blog/family/family-trip-hawaii";"I hadn't been to Hawaii in about 10 years. The last time I was there
column2: I was staying in an old coffee shack on the Rosenworld Compound. I have very fond memories of the trip. I did not have fond memories of the never-ending flights home and the resulting jet lag. So I hadn't particularly rushed to go back.

column1: My parents have been going for many years - never waiting more than two years to go there. And recently I believe they had been going every year. So it was no surprise that eventually they would want a family trip to Hawaii together. So David
column2: myself
column3: Sis
column4: Lorenz
column5: and my parents met in Kona on the Big Island for a week of Polynesian goodness. <!--break-->

column2: David and I stayed a night in Honolulu. We couldn't find reasonable flights through American that got us there in one day. It was probably a good idea to have a night in Honolulu. We would have been zombies if we tried to do the flight in one swoop. The airport was swamped with security when we got to Honolulu. I asked David with as much sarcasm as I could muster "Is the President in town or something?" It turns out that he kinda was. Barack Obama was president elect and was on his way out of Hawaii as we were coming in. There went my plans of getting a photo of our President's abs on the beach to sell to tabloids.

we got to the Honolulu airport very early the morning. It turns out I don't like the Honolulu airport. It was full or extremely obese Americans with their ultra-slutty teenage daughters and their mind-numbingly stupid teenage sons. They embodied the image of American terror that strikes the hearts of foreigners everywhere.

I was in a significantly better mood. David and I got ourselves to the time share and were quite surprised at how nice the digs were. Our unit felt palatial. The kitchen was well stocked with utensils and equipment
column3: though David didn't look any further than the coffee machine.

column1: I picked up Mom & Dad at the airport later that day. For dinner
column2: we went up to the Rosenworld compound and picked up Sis and Lorenz. I hadn't been there since they built the new house. I don't even think they call it the new house anymore. It was beautiful. I decided that the next time I come to Hawaii
column3: I'm doing it without family or David and I'm staying at the compound for some peace and quiet. They have every type of fruit on their plantation: macadamia nuts
column4: pineapples
column5: avocados
column6: passion fruit
column7: guava
column8: lemons
column9: grapefruit
column10: papayas
column11: and more. Andy had made a wonderful guava cake with guava mousse. I'm still dreaming about it.

column2: I can't remember the exact order of everything we did on the trip. David
column3: Sis
column4: Lorenz and I took a day to go to the volcano. It rained almost the entire day. I thought Lorenz would be more entranced with the idea of lava tubes and volcanos
column5: but he was in his own world the whole time. We took him to the 15 minute movie they show about volcanos. Once he realized it was a documentary
column6: he turned to Sis and said "This isn't a real movie." Apparently
column7: he had just discovered the soul-crushing reality of documentaries. And when they showed images of volcanoes spewing and gurgling red molten lava
column8: he just said "Yucky".

column1: On the way home we went to a beach to visit giant turtles. And they were quite big. Lorenz started being a pill
column2: then decided he didn't want to wear pants
column3: and then decided he wanted to sit on the sand. David and Sis made him take a mini-shower before getting back in the car. I took a picture should I need to blackmail Lorenz at some future point. However
column4: I have spared his dignity by not posting it online.

column1: I can't remember what we need the next day
column2: but I didn't take any photos. I think Sis
column3: Dad
column4: Benji and I went snorkeling. Which was nice but a little crowded.

column1: David charted a course for the next day. We were going to visit a small little village on the way up the mountain and then visit a coffee plantation. The village was mostly closed and kind of a bust. Then we couldn't find the coffee plantation. It turns out that GPS is not so accurate in Hawaii - as we would repeatedly learn throughout the trip. Just after we had given up on finding the coffee plantation
column2: we decided to go back just ONE MORE TIME
column3: and we found it. They had pigs and geese and cats
column4: so Lorenz was in heaven. They had coffee
column5: so David was in heaven. We bought several bags
column6: and it really is the best coffee I've ever had.

column1: After that we took a trip back down to the beach
column2: with a few wrong turns along the way. We found a place  where there is some beach and then a little walk to visit Petraglyphs. On the way home
column3: we stopped in downtown Kona for some shaved ice and a walk along the beach. Very beautiful.

column1: The next day was a big event. We took a trip up and over the middle of the island on Saddle Road. The goal was to go to Hilo and see some of the big waterfalls. Benji had said that Hilo is his favorite city in Hawaii because it's like the old Hawaii used to be before it was discovered by all the tourists. It rains too much to ever be a popular tourist destination. We totally lucked out. It was sunny and clear the whole time we were there.
We saw many waterfalls. We even found the cheap
column2: fast food place that Mom and Dad were looking for. There some story about it being owned by a relative of someone that they work with. I don't remember the whole story. The food was authentically Hawaiian.

column1: Mom & Dad started showing signs of exhaustion near the end of this trip. For the last waterfall (which was the really big one) they stayed near the car. Since the Saddle Road trip was not a good ride for those that get car-sick
column2: we took a trip around the north of the island to get home.

column1: David and I went home the next morning. I didn't get as much time frolicking in the water at the beach as I was hoping
column2: but that's how it goes. Next time
column3: I'm sure...

column1: "Anti-Advice";"personal/blog/self-improvement/anti-advice";"Tell me if this sounds familiar. A close friend or relative is complaining about an obstacle that they have in life: problems at work
column2: spousal frustrations
column3: backstabbing friends
column4: etc. You listen attentively and politely. You offer productive and easy-to-follow advice. You friend looks at you like you have overstepped some boundaries. They either tell you that your advice wouldn't work and launch into more complaining or they are downright offended that you offered unwelcome advice. And no one ever follows your advice. Ever.

column2: I decided that most people aren't really asking for advice
column3: they are asking for you to sit there in rapt attention while they bitch. You fare better as a friend by occasionally muttering "That sucks" or - even better - "So what are you going to do?"

column1: I have found the answer to giving advice. I call it "Anti-Advice" and I've had a lot of success with it. It goes along the same principle of homeopathic medicine. You don't try to cure the problem
column2: you intensify the symptoms so that the body naturally solves the problem.

column1: Here's an example: Your single friend is complaining about having gained weight recently and claims that it's too hard to lose weight. Here are some responses:
Who wants to lose weight anyway? It's a lot of work with little reward. Let's go for ice cream.
So what if you've been gaining a lot of weight recently. It's a great excuse to buy more clothes!
You look great. Would Kevin James be as popular if he were thin? You're like the Kevin James of [insert person's town or neighborhood].

The key to anti-advice is that you have to really go for it. You can't get caught being disingenuous. Your voice can't be dripping with sarcasm or it doesn't work. Put a smile on your face and confirm their deepest anxieties.
I've found myself liberated from my don't-say-anything approach to complaint sessions. I now politely listen to the complaints and search for the one thing they don't want to hear. When it works well
column2: the complainer is completely stymied. It also frees you from expecting some sort of positive outcome. In order to give anti-advice
column3: you have to divest yourself of an expectation that things are going to change. In fact
column4: you become an advocate of things never changing.

column1: Your boss at work is unable to make decisions and commit to a direction. You have to constantly remind your boss that the wrong decision could have gargantuan ramifications.
A friend finds themselves sexually attracted to their roommates new boyfriend/girlfriend. How about they try to orchestrate a three-way with the roommate and love interest?
A friend is procrastinating and obsessing about how much work they have to get done. Tell them to blow off work and go to the movies. If they refuse but continue to procrastinate
column2: start reading favorable reviews of movies currently playing.

people react so strongly to anti-advice that the subject is dropped. They may actually take steps to fix the problem. Or they realize that you are not mentally balanced enough to be a source of any advice.

column1: One point of warning: anti-advice doesn't work on children or pets. The target person has to have some sort of super-ego in place for this to work.
I probably wouldn't recommend trying it on the criminally insane either - but who am I to try to tell people what to do? After all
column2: the population could stand to be thinned out a bit.";"1239983080";"textile"

column1: "Keith's First Acupuncture";"personal/blog/health/keiths-first-acupuncture";"Today was my first acupuncture session. I had pulled my back out about a week and a half ago. I told myself in Africa that it was time to try acupuncture
column2: but I hadn’t gotten around to it. So with my back out
column3: I decided it was time to make an appointment and try it.

column1: I had heard various stories of people going to acupuncture and the needles having a visceral and sudden effect on their body. Sometimes it was described as a jolt of electricity
column2: sometimes it was described as a sudden withdraw of tension. I wasn’t quite sure what to expect.

column1: I got a referral from my friend
column2: Kevin
column3: to see Jackie at Blue Lotus Healing. I tried finding a website for them to put on this post
column4: but I can’t find one. Maybe someday I can put a few pages together for them - though I don’t think they really need the business.

column1: Jackie had told me to set aside 2 hours for the first appointment. I think we used the whole time
column2: but I was so zonked out at the end that I forgot to look at the time. When I got into the room
column3: I got down to my underwear and got on the table. Jackie is very chatty and easy to talk with - which was good because I was a little nervous. She started by taking my pulse and checking for energy flow. She immediately zeroed into a stiff spot in my abdomen. She told me I had digestive issues (true)
column4: and that I was probably low on energy (also true - the past couple of years
column5: despite diet and exercise
column6: I have not had one of those “limitless energy” days that I used to have). So she put in a few needles. They went all over - abdomen
column7: ankles
column8: arms
column9: hands
column10: etc. I quickly lost track of where they were. It almost felt like I had little thread coming out of me
column11: like a marionette’s strings
column12: and someone was gently pulling on them. She put one into my arm that when in with a bit of a “woo” sensation. The first couple of minutes I thought I was going to mention that it hurt
column13: but soon I had no real sensation of it at all.

column2: I was kind of surprised that I didn’t really feel that much. I gently blissed out for a while. She came back in
column3: took out the needles
column4: and I got a brief back massage. I flipped over onto my stomach and she put needles in my back. I felt these needles even less than the ones on my front. When I was done
column5: she asked me to do a simple stretch (a child’s pose - for you yoga folk)
column6: get dressed and meet her outside.

column1: When I got off the table
column2: I was really hoping that there wasn’t going to be any back pain whatsoever. But it was still there. There was less of it
column3: but it was still there.

column2: I was visibly out of it. People that had seen me before I went in started commenting about me as if I wasn’t in the room - “Look
column3: his eyes are so open now! What a difference!” Jackie said that I was “acu-stoned”. For a while
column4: I didn’t realize what they were talking about. But as I walked outside
column5: I discovered I couldn’t make simple decisions. My perception of time was way off. I felt like I was high.

column1: I went out to lunch with Jeff
column2: feeling giddy the whole time. I found myself blatantly smiling at people
column3: so much so that I would start making jokes with strangers. People were laughing with me. It was kinda crazy.

column1: I got home and took things relatively easily. And I noticed as the afternoon went on
column2: my back got better and better. I felt like I had all-of-a-sudden put my body on the fast track to healing. I’m still kind of marveling at the difference between this morning and now.

column1: I watched the season finale of Lost and my emotions - while not out of control - were so clear and in the foreground. I choked up three times (at least) while watching Lost.
At the beginning of the session
column2: Jackie had mentioned that about 3-4 visits would get my back to return to normal. At the end of the session
column3: she said it would probably be only one more visit. But at this point
column4: I don’t know why I wouldn’t want to go as much as possible.";"1242338330";"textile"

column1: "A Month in Africa";"personal/travel/africa/month-africa";"Did David and I really go to Africa? Were we really gone for 3.5 weeks? It all feels like an ethereal dream at this point.

This first time that I remember seriously thinking about what Africa may be like was at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival. I was watching "Road to Mecca" by Athol Fugard. Two women were talking about South Africa and the landscape that one woman had traveled to visit the other. She referred to the land as "God's Country". I had heard that phrase many times before and I had always interprested it as meaning "a land so beautiful that it was loved by God." In the play
column2: they clarify what they mean by that phrase - a land that was untouched by humanity and incapable of being affected by humanity. As I'm writing about my impressions about a play that I saw over 20 years ago I realize that I could be completely mangling the play. I hope you understand my point anyway.

column1: My other serious consideration of Africa was from reading "The Poisonwood Bible". Unfortunately
column2: I didn't like the book (can't remember why anymore). But it did leave me with an impression that Africa lumbers on with its own rules. It doen't give you
column3: a westerner or an individual
column4: a second thought. I vividly remember the images of the missionaries trying to build American crops in the Congo. When they finally figure out how to work against the floods and the ants and grow crops
column5: the African bees show no interesting in pollinating the strange new plants.

column1: All of this is true. And if you don't really understand what I'm talking about with my vague writing
column2: I urge you to go to Africa. Follow an elephant on foot. Track a lion. Hang out with the Maasai. You'll see what I'm talking about.

size=-]

";"1242492196";"textile"

column1: "One Day in Kenya";"personal/travel/africa/one-day-kenya";"We had a few very circuitous flights in Africa (to say the least). One of them was getting to Tanzania. We had to find flights that were cheap
column2: get us to Arusha
column3: and would get us miles. So to get us to Arusha
column4: we flew overnight to London Heathrow
column5: spent a few hours
column6: then took a flight to Nairobi
column7: Kenya. We spent two nights in Kenya - though we arrived so late and left so early in the morning that it felt like we were barely there. Also
column8: we were so jet-lagged that we didn't really have much functional time.

column2: we got a realtively early start in the morning and got a tour guide to drive us around. He drove us to the Nairobi National Museum
column3: which was a great introduction. Inside
column4: a licensed guide took us around. One of the highlights was a very well-preserved woolly mammoth fossil.

column1: Our next stop was to a giraffe sancutary where you can get close enough to the giraffes to feed them. It turns out
column2: that a couple of the giraffes are shameless beggars and will do anything for food. David got a fair amount of giraffe slobber on him while he was posing for a photo.

we talked with a Canadian that had just finished going on safari. She couldn't stop saying wonderful things about her trip. David and I were still wondering exactly what the trip was going to be like. It's not something you can really imagine until you've done it. And I suppose that each trip varies greatly depending on specifically where you go and with whom.

column1: On the way back to the hotel
column2: we got stuck in the famous Nairobi traffic. We passed by some shanty towns (which are called townships in Africa). It's hard to capture how sprawlingly large the townships can be with a photo. We started getting a taste of the crazy culture clashes in Africa. We were driving on a major highway and right along the side
column3: people were herding cattle. And just past that
column4: there were people in business suits walking to work. When we were completely stopped in traffic
column5: there men selling all sorts of items: fans
column6: stickers of animals
column7: medical supplies
column8: etc.

column1: On the way out of Kenya I was expecting a real headache at the airport. It was just the opposite. Everyone was as nice as could be and really quite efficient on getting us ot the gate. The only drawback is that we had quite a wait for our flight because we got there so much ahead of schedule.
We flew from Kenya and on to Tanziania to start the safari.

column2: we headed to Tanzania for one night in Arusha. The flight to Tanzania was fairly uneventful. On the flight
column3: there was a small contingency of young frat-style guys with a ton of outdoor gear. They were clearly off to climb Mt. Kilimanjaro. David and I christened them “Kilimanjarheads”. <!--break--:>

column2: we were met by Urassa - one of the drivers for our trip. We later learned that his real name is “Goodluck Urassa”. We figured that he went by the name of Urassa because he was tired of all the Americans being confused or making jokes about a name of Goodluck.

column1: We drove about 45 minutes to Arusha. It was dark
column2: so there was not much to see. We would periodically pass a small collection of houses with lights - usually with a bar or restaurant where the locals were congregated. We didn’t see many cars on the road
column3: but we saw lots of people walking or riding bicycles. Since there were no street lights and very few houses
column4: it was pitch black out. I suppose people had to hug the road to make sure they didn’t get lost. I kept thinking that we were so far away from anything
column5: that anyone walking would take hours to get anywhere.

column2: the Serena Mountain Village Lodge. Upon stepping onto the property
column3: there was someone greeting us with warm
column4: wet towels. That seemed nice at the time - later I would realize just how nice it is to be greeted with a wet towel while traveling through East Africa.

column1: We checked into our bungalow and then headed to dinner. We made all sorts of conjectures about who in the dining area was going to be on our safari. There was a very poorly behaved Russian family that had been on the flight with us - arguing with every service person they ran into. They were thankfully not on our safari. I don’t remember seeing anyone in the dining room that night that was on our safari.

column2: we met in front of the lodge as a group. We had the typical introductions and stilted conversations with people you don’t know but will soon be spending every waking moment together. We met our group leader: Sebastian Chuwa. Everyone met the driver that we had last night: Urassa. And we met our third driver: Mustafa Mollel.

column1: Everyone made one final trip to their bungalows
column2: and we were off on safari. Our first day was going to be spent driving through Lake Manyara
Mom and Dad flew to New Jersey
column3: spent a night with me
column4: and then we all drove up to Ithaca for a family weekend. It was billed as a “Pre-Mother’s Day” event - since the timing did not work out for Mom and Dad to visit on actual Mother’s Day. I was only there for a couple of days before driving home. Mom and Dad stayed for longer and flew back from Ithaca.

column1: We had no hard and fast plans for what to do while we were there. Sis and had come up with plenty of options
column2: but we kept it pretty open
column3: since you never know what you’re going to be in the mood for.

column1: Our big trip was driving to Watkins Glen
column2: which is a town at the base of the largest of the Finger Lakes. There is a beautiful gorge there. Unfortunately
column3: we were still on the heels of winter
column4: so some of the paths were closed. Still
column5: we were able to tour much of the gorge and take some nice family shots.

column1: This trip marked a turning point in my relationship with Lorenz. Although he was typically totally nonplussed to see me
column2: we got along great. Sis had given me the suggestion that I buy a Star Wars sticker book
column3: since he talks about watching Star Wars with Uncle Keith. (It turns out he watched it with Uncle David
column4: but I’m happy to take the credit.) When I had gone to Barnes & Noble to get sticker books
column5: I had no idea there were so many. I got a little too excited for an adult when I saw that they had Fantastic Four sticker books. I decided to stay with the original plan and get Star Wars (though I also threw in a bugs sticker book).

column1: The book was a big hit and we played with the stickers over dinner. When food arrived
column2: Sis told him to put the stickers away and Lorenz said no. I told him we would do two more stickers and then it was time to eat. It worked like a charm. No fuss at all when it was time to put the book away.

column1: When we were at the gorge
column2: he found a large stick and was using it like a gun
column3: imaginarily shooting things. Sis hates any talk of guns and was trying to squelch such behavior. Since I needed to reinforce my status as “Bad Uncle” I encouraged Lorenz to shoot everything - “There’s Mommy! Shoot Mommy!” Mark put a positive spin on it saying that Lorenz sometimes says that the gun shoots a cleaning spray. So we then switched to saying “Lorenz! That’s dirty!” and he would shoot it clean.

column1: We tried to get a shot of him shooting a big sign in the gorge that said “Lover’s Lane”
column2: but the chain link fence ruined the shot. Bummer.

column1: After the gorge we went for lunch. Mom and I walked Lorenz along the water
column2: which he enjoyed. And then we all went for ice cream. It was a beautiful spring day and a very “upstate NY” time.

column1: The next day was fairly uneventful. We went to the mall for reasons I can no longer remember. Then we went to the Farmer’s Market. It was a pale comparison to the last time I had been there - which was in the fall. A lot of the booths were empty since there were no harvests yet. I was hoping to take a homemade pie home
column2: but I left empty handed.

column1: Nice weekend. I’m sad to think that it’s probably my last trip to Ithaca since Sis is leaving in a month.

column2: David and I signed up for a CSA - which stands for "Community Supported Agriculture". It's a way for those of us living in New York City to get a weekly supply of organic and locally grown veggies every week. The share is roughly $450 and lasts for 24 weeks. We also signed up for a fruit share
column3: which starts later in the year.

column1: I really had no idea what to expect
column2: except what I heard from a friend that had participated in a CSA last year. We signed up with a CSA for the West Village. Their pickup locations is less than a block away. Their farm is Stone Ledge Farm" and they are an organic farm.

column1: This week was almost all leafy green vegetables - which is what I was hoping for. I don't recognize some of the items. I'm assuming that I can eat most - if not all - of the foods raw. Here's the whole list:
<li>RHUBARB-1 bunch-very tart perennial that is only available for a short time in the spring.
<li>MIZUNA-1 bunch (Green with serrated leaves. Good in salads or lightly cooked)

column2: crunchy stems
column3: dark green leaves)

column1: <li>CHINESE CABBAGE (Rubicon)-2 heads (described in the seed catalog as “sweet
column2: tangy
column3: juicy and delicious”) This makes a great fresh slaw or used in stir fry.

column1: <li>SAGE with Flowers-1 bunch. The flowers are beautiful on the sage which grows as a perennial. Strip the leaves and use with any poultry dish. Enjoy the flowers as a bonus.

column2: it's sort of like an episode of Iron Chef - you never know what you're getting from week to week. The fun of it is coming up with something once you know the ingredients.

column1: "To Milan and the Lake Region";"personal/travel/italy/milan-and-lake-region";"Every time we go to Italy
column2: I say that we don't go to Italy enough. Why does it only happen once every few years? We had dinner with one of David's colleagues in Milan that tells us she goes to Rome twice a year. Granted
column3: she's a hell of a lot closer
column4: but still...we should be going ot Italy more. I haven't been to Rome in over 10 years! What's wrong with me?

column1: So even though it was a short trip (only 4 nights)
column2: and David would be at a conference a lot of the time
column3: how could I pass up a trip to Milan with David?";"1244933024";"textile"

column1: "I've Landed...What's Happening?";"personal/travel/italy/ive-landedwhats-happening";"I flew to Milan by myself. David was coming in from England. So even though I got there ahead of time
column2: David had not taken red-eye flight to get to Milan and he had already adjusted to the time change. I got ot the hotel first and took a nap for a few hours. There is nothing like that first nap when you arrive in Europe from an overnight flight.
he prompted me to get up. The whole thing was helped by the fact that he had got some pastries to help me ease into consciousness. After I pulled myself together
column3: we went to the Piazza del Duomo to see the center of Milan.

column1: We started our tour by buying tickets to get into a broom closet of an elevator to the base of the roof. The Duomo di Milano is one of the few cathedrals that you can climb all over. Well
column2: that's an exaggeration. You can walk all over the roof. And by the time you get to the top
column3: you're pretty high up. There are non-stop carvings along the way. Every where you turn there's a gargoyle or statue - completely unique amongst the others. The top of the Duomo has all sorts of saints placed high on top and facing out towards the city. It is intensely serene to look at the saints as they monitor the encroaching modernity of high-fashion Milan.

column1: David and I made it all the way to the top
column2: but we felt raindrops
column3: so took the stairs down and went inside the cathedral. The fun part abotu visiting cathedrals in Italy is that they are still quite well attended. We saw plenty of people praying or waiting to make confession.

column1: One of the highlights in the cathedral is a statue of Saint Bartholomew
column2: who was flayed alive. The statue has him wearing his skin like a shawl or a toga - and he is nothing but muscle and bone. It's very surreal. There were plenty of saints around the cathedral that had been stabbed with arrows or eviscerated and left for dead.
we walked a bit around the piazza so I could get something to eat. However
column3: we had missed lunch hour and barely anyone was serving anymore. So we went back to the hotel and I caught a nap before dinner.

column1: And dinner that night was at a very well-known restaurant called Bice. It's apparently well attended by high fashion designers. We didn't see any that night. The meal was excellent and we were joined by two colleagues from Israel. We had the full experience
column2: including Santo Vino with Biscotti for an aperitif.

column1: When we got back to the hotel
column2: I slept for something like 12 hours. I was woken by David getting ready. I said "I'll join you for breakfast and then shower when you head off ot the conference." He replied "I've already had breakfast. You slept through all of it."

column1: "West Village CSA - Week 2";"personal/blog/food/west-village-csa-week-2";"I figure I'll get bored of posting the weekly CSA haul
column2: but when I was looking for a CSA
column3: I couldn't find any information about what was in the CSA from week to week. So maybe these posts will help someone else. Also
column4: so far I've had something every week that I have never seen before in my life. So there's some food education going on here as well.

column1: Here's the note from the CSA about this week's produce:
Among the top favorite vegetables that members look forward to receiving each year are Garlic Scapes. They are the long
column2: curly tailed seed head that emerges from the garlic plant early in the season.

column1: The scape will develop seed if left but the seeds are small and take years of planting and re-planting to deliver any sizable garlic bulbs. The preferred method of propagating garlic is each year to save the best bulbs which are broken apart into individual cloves and planted in October. Each clove will yield a garlic bulb the next July. The scapes are removed when they start to curl and the energy that would go into producing seed goes to the garlic bulb.

The scapes have a delicious garlic flavor. Garlic scape pesto is a member favorite. Remove the very end of the scape and the rest of the scape can be used. Look to some of the CSA websites that are listed on the farm website under a previous blog for recipe ideas. There are also more photos of the garlic plants in the Photos section of the farm website.
Enjoy the vegetables-Deborah for everyone at Stoneledge Farm

Summer Spinach-1 bunch-this spinach is a little more resilient than the spinach you may be familiar with. Most varieties of spinach will bolt or send out a seed head early in the season. Summer Spinach will last right into the summer. It has a larger leaf
column2: spinach flavor.

column1: Lemon Balm-1 bunch-lemony mint flavor. Good in tea.
I'm most excited about the Buttercrunch Green Leaf Lettuce which looked extra creamy delicious.
I usually munch a bit on everything as I put it in the fridge. The garlic scape packs quite a bunch.";"1245188018";"textile"

column2: I was a bit more coherent when I woke up. I still didn't have it together to have breakfast with David. He went off to the conference for a bit and I tried to find the Etro store. It was a total bust. The main store was completely intimidating: bizarro fashions in the window with enormous prices. I didn't even bother going in. Then I tried to find their outlet store. It was a very frustrating experience. I think I found it
column3: but I didn't bother ringing the buzzer to go in because I found no evidence of it being an actual store. Oh well. I didn't need to spend any money on clothes that I would rarely wear.

column1: David came back to the hotel just before noon. We went to the nearby airport and rented a car to explore the lakes around Milan. David drove
column2: which was fine by me. We got a GPS. I don't know how we could have done it without the GPS - some of the roads that we ended up in were tiny.

column1: Our first stop was Mantova. You may have heard of the anglicized name of Mantua. God only knows how the English mangled that one. I guess it's not as bad as turning Deutscheland into Germany. Anyway
column2: Mantova is a small village built around three lakes. It's the town that Romeo fled to when he was banished. It's the setting of Verdi's Rigoletto. And it's a beautiful little tourism stop. The palazzos are lined with cafes and gelaterias. There was a rock band that performed in front of the clock tower.

column1: There are a few churches to visit. Once of which is built over the blood of Christ. According to the tradition the earth and blood was brought to Mantua by the Roman centurion Longinus
column2: who had scooped up the bloody earth from Christ's crucifixion.

column1: But the mega-highlight is the Palazzo Ducale. The palace is enormous. After about an hour of wandering through rooms
column2: David and I wondered if we were still in Mantova. With the exception of the gardens
column3: I preferred it to the palace at Versailles.

column1: I think we spend around 4-5 hours in Mantova. I found a spot for us to stop for dinner on the way home. So we set off on the back roads to Cremona. Once again
column2: it's a beautiful little medieval village built along the water. This one was on the shores of the river Po. On the drive out of town
column3: we saw a carnival built along the river. The dinner was exquisite. And it was one of those places where they kept giving us things we didn't ask for: a complimentary martini as we sat down
column4: a complimentary appetizer to whet the palate
column5: etc. I was almost full by the time the meal actually started. And it was here that my love of tortellini di zucca (pumpkin tortellini) was solidified. I'm still dreaming about that meal.

column2: we took wandered through the palazzo
column3: which was full of people drinking
column4: eating
column5: and enjoying the night air. I took a few pictures of David which he will not allow me to post because they clearly show that he has been travelling all day.

column1: The ride how was uneventful - considering that we were only an hour from Milan.
"Bellinzona";"personal/travel/italy/bellinzona";"I've tagged this entry with "Italy" even though Bellinzona is in Switzerland. However
column2: you would really never be able to tell that you left Italy in this part of Switzerland.

column1: David and I got an early start and hit the road to a town called Bellinzona. The ride there was pretty great
column2: too. We drove past Lake Como and all sorts of other lakes. I could see that if you lived in northern Italy
column3: it would be quite nice to have a summer condo on the lake.

column1: Bellinzona is famous for its three castles (Castelgrande
column2: Montebello
column3: Sasso Corbaro) that have been a UNESCO World Heritage Sites since 2000. We had some initial trouble finding the castle - which seems kind of laughable in hind site. It's right in the center of town built on a hill. It is completely unmissable. In the end
column4: we did the smart thing and just parked near the center of town and started walking. We got a heart pumping climb up the rampart walls to Castelgrande.

column1: The castle seemed rather modest at first
column2: but there was plenty to explore. The views of the hills around Bellinzona were magnificent. And the more we walked around the castle
column3: the more the magic started to work on us. You could wander all over the rampart walls which were covered in grass. They had taken the hills of the castle to grow grape vines. The castle has two towers: the white tower and the black tower. You can climb up each of them as long as you don't mind twisting stairs. We went to the museum but there was really nothing to see - especially since most of the items in the museum did not have English translations. There was an interesting painting of a man changing into a wolf - of which I took a picture.

column2: David and I went back to the center of town for something to eat. As usual
column3: we were too late for the lunch crowd and we had a hard itme finding anyone to serve us. About the time I had settled upon the idea of a gelato lunch
column4: we found a Turkish take-out place and got döner kebab.

column2: but we decided to take the long
column3: scenic path around the edge of Lake Maggiore.

column1: "Orta";"personal/travel/italy/orta";"After taking a leisurely stroll down the west side of Lake Maggiore
column2: we were ready to get out of the car. The afternoon rain had passed. We arrived at Orta San Giulio
column3: managed to find parking
column4: and trekked down the hill.

column1: There are no cars allowed in the heart of town. Or more precisely
column2: the town could not fit any cars. It's a labyrinth of tiny little cobbled streets. There's one main drag that most people use to meander through town.
we stopped for a cappucinos. Ah...
we stopped at the main docks. There are boats that take people to San Giulio
column3: an island just off the coast that is right out of a fairy tale. Here's a bit about San Giulio:

column2: the Island of St. Giulio was dominated by a big serpent that destroyed everything. But when St. Giulio
column3: that had the power to command over the waves
column4: the storms
column5: the wild animals and the human beings
column6: arrived near the lake
column7: waving his hand he chased away the dangerous menacing animal.

column1: He reached the Island journeying over the water on his cloak guided by his staff. The big reptile disappeared and St. Giulio
column2: tired and near to his death
column3: thought that the island was the right place to build his hundredth and last church dedicated to the Holy Apostles. The Island of San Giulio is today a place of great mysticism.

column2: David didn't want to make the trek because it looked like there was a huge line for a boat. It turns out that getting a boat did not take long
column3: but it was total chaos. There was a dispatcher that was shouting at all the boat captains and pointing various tourists to each of the boats.

column1: As part of the trip to the island
column2: they take you all the way around the island. You get to see just how beautiful and bizarre the island is. There is only one road and it goes all the way around. If you go in one direction
column3: it's called "The Street of Meditation" and has little signs giving you motivational phrases in 4 languages. If you walk the road in the other direction
column4: it's called "The Street of Silence" and the same signs have writing on the back to encourage an appreciation of silence. Unfortunately
column5: there were a lot of tourists and no one was much into the concept of silence.

column2: we went back ot Orta San Giulio
column3: checked out the local church
column4: and then headed back to the car.

column2: so finding a place that was open for dinner was quite a challenge. We dropped the rental car off at the airport and got a very exuberant cab driver that took us to a couple of places
column3: but they were all closed. We found a place near the hotel to eat.

column2: it was the last day in Milan. Part of this trip was an effort to escape the madness of the renovation
column3: and in that sense
column4: the trip was a total winner. I feel like I've "done" Milan
column5: though I would never pass up any chance to visit Italy again. But I feel like there was a lot of the surrounding area that I would love to come back and explore: Lake Como and Verona are two biggies. I could imagine spending at least a week
column6: casually bopping from one small town to the next.

column2: I visited Castello Sforzesco. The castle is impressive
column3: though there's not a lot to see. David joined me in the afternoon. I took him to the castle and then we went shopping.

column1: It is stunning to wander around Milan and look at the fashions. However
column2: I live in New York City. There isn't that much that you can get in Milan that you can't find in NYC. And with the exchange rate
column3: you certainly aren't getting any bargains. And finally
column4: I didn't really connect with anything. There were some things in the Etro store that I liked (I finally made it in)
column5: but the stuff that I liked was marked "slim fit" and I didn't even want to bother with the disappointment of how far away from "slim" I am. Widt-wise
column6: the salesman was on par with a street lamp. So I decided to forgo a Milan purchase. However
column7: I did enjoy talking David into getting something nice at the Zegna store.

column2: we went to dinner with a colleague of David's from Amsterdam. We had a wonderful meal at the highest recommended restaurant in Milan (by the guide book): Trattorio Milanese. It was excellent. The whole meal tasted like it was made by the Italian grandmother I never had. Perhaps it was also the quality of the company.

column1: It turns out that I picked the same restaurant that our friend's wife's department picked
column2: so we got to meet some others from Amsterdam. We got an invitation to visit which I certainly hope will become something more than an idle nicety.
I will miss you.

column1: And FYI - not only was it a good break from the renovation
column2: since I've been back
column3: it's been much easier to deal with the renovation
column4: so I think we can say that Milan has cured me.

column2: it's been clear that we're going to be eating a lot of salads. The majority of the produce so far has been leafy green vegetables - and in a large variety. So if I was going to be eating a lot of salads
column3: I needed to come up with at least one salad dressing I really loved.

column1: I hate most every salad dressing I've ever bought. Our default salad dressing is a balsamic vinaigrette. It's really more David's thing than mine. I have more fun with it when I get a fun vinegar - like passion fruit vinegar. What I really wanted was to master creamy salad dressings.
I looked for a ranch dressing recipe on the web. A lot of them recommended using MSG to add robustness. MSG?! Doesn't it defeat the purpose of a homemade salad dressing to be throwing in chemicals?
Then I found a recipe posted on chowhound.com for a simple ranch dressing. I tried it and it was excellent. I added in a few touches from some of the other research that I did. I must say
column2: this is one of the best dressings I've ever had. It's one of my staples now and it generally gets unsolicited compliments from guests.
here it is (and I sometimes halve the recipe if I'm just making it for me for the next couple of days):
chopped
thinly sliced

column1: 1 tsp white vinegar (you could use rice wine or white wine vinegar)
It keeps for several days in the fridge.
One commenter on chowhound commented that a real ranch recipe uses dill
column2: to which the poster commented "So add dill." And it's true. You could add whatever herbs you had on hand to customize the recipe. ";"1245400913";"textile"

column2: make a paste of the garlic and salt. Place in a small bowl and add the lemon juice and balsamic vinegar and stir well to combine. Drizzle in the olive oil

"Blue Jays Outside My Window";"personal/blog/nyc/blue-jays-outside-my-window";"I had a treat today. Outside my office window
column2: I was visited by two blue jays. I had been seeing them around the neighborhood recently
column3: but these two hung out for quite a while just a foot outside my window. They didn't even seem bothered by my movement to get a camera and take photos.

column1: I assume that one is male and the other is female. The male is the one with a more pronounced crest. The female seemed to be nesting. She seemed fluffed up and didn't want to move. The male was flitting all over from branch to branch. I couldn't figure out if he was courting her or protecting her.
I'm not usually so easily swayed
column2: but I have to admit that there was some magical qualities about their visit. We don't get much wildlife here in NYC and I rarely see birds other than pigeons. And the fact that they seemed so comfortable outside my window
column3: contributed to the serendipitous qualities of their visit. Let's hope that it's an omen of good things to come.

column2: align=center]
align=center]
I had almost no dairy. There was some milk available for coffee at the hotel
column3: but after that there was nothing. Nothing with cheese on any menu I ever found. No cream sauces. I doubt they used butter to cook with. I think that's why real Chinese food has the wrap that you are hungry a half hour after you eat - because there isn't that dairy to give you an inflated sense of feeling weighed down.

column1: And I did experience the "hungry half hour later" thing. After a meal
column2: there was usually a brief period of hunger followed by several hours of feeling very sated. And the nice thing was
column3: I never got tired after I ate. I'm used to crashing after meals in the U.S. But in Beijing
column4: we would eat and I would be ready to start off on my next round of adventures.

column1: The other big shift is that when I got home
column2: everyone commented that my skin looked so much better. If I felt my skin
column3: then yes
column4: it felt softer and smoother - but mildly so. I never would have guessed that it would have been that noticeable
column5: but it was Rodrigo's first comment when he saw me. I attributed it to the dairy after reading an article about Woody Harrelson's skin and dairy issues: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/09/23/woody-harrelsons-vegan-ac_n_295765.html

column1: The odd thing about having had next to no dairy for a week is that I realized I didn't miss it. If the trade-off is that I have more energy
column2: my skin is healthier
column3: and I generally feel lighter and happier
column4: well that seems like a no-brainer to me. So I've decided to minimize dairy as much as possible. I'm not going to say "never again"
column5: because that usually just means I can't stick with it. And it turns out it's not as difficult as I originally thought.

column1: My first fallen moment came when we had someone over for wine and cheese. I got a fancy cheese to share. I couldn't resist a farmhouse cheddar. And once I had a little bit
column2: I went back a few more times. The next morning I woke up with a headache and a head full of phlegm.

column1: I always find it so odd that when I give up some unhealthy eating habits and then go back to them
column2: what a gargantuan crash I have. Was it always this bad when I had dairy and I just never noticed? Or was body used to all the extra phlegm and coped with it better?

column1: So dairy has been greatly reduced in my life with an end goal of getting rid of it entirely. After only a few days
column2: I have so much more energy. Chronic sinus discomfort or pain? Gone.
just try going one week with as little dairy as you can muster. I think you'll be surprised that you won't miss it and the benefits are tremendous.";"1256306423";"textile"

column1: "A Hammerlock Swing Dance Move with Neat-o Exit";"personal/blog/swing/some-hammerlock-swing-dance-moves";"I've been meaning to write down some of the new dance moves I learn in private class so that I don't forget them. And what better place than a blog for others that might be curious?
The past couple of private lessons have been dedicated to hammerlock positions. While they look incredibly twisty and complicated
column2: it turns out that they're really easy.

column1: The first one I learned starts with a tuck-turn on the leader's right side. At the end of the tuck
column2: you give the partner a good spin
column3: hold onto the hands
column4: and put them into a hammerlock. It helps if you use your right hand on your partner's hip to guide them. Instead of rock-stepping backward
column5: rock-step forward. Then spin them back around into a cuddle position.

column2: Nathan taught me a fun move to get out of it. It's an 8 count move to make it easier on the follower. You rock-step backward and go forward for the first triple. Give the follower a little notice with your arms that something is about to happen. Then on the step-step
column3: create a tunnel with your right arm (which is behind your partner) and lean at the hips and don't go back with the follower. They will get the signal and shoot behind you. At this point
column4: you should still be hold hands and they will be totally criss-crossed. Go with it. Lead a tuck turn and don't let go of the hands. At the end of the tuck turn
column5: you will be magically correct.

column1: Damn. Now I can't remember the other hammer-lock move that Nathan taught me. Well
column2: stay tuned and I'll write it down from tonight's refresher course.";"1258672251";"textile"
my friend Sara asked me about my resolutions that I had for 2009. For some reason
column3: I took it very seriously and wrote a lengthy post about my resolutions. I accomplished most of them to some degree. I'm not going to worry about the ones that I apparently wasn't as resolute on as I could have been. But we both enjoyed the process so she wrote me this year for my 2010 resolutions. And here they are...

column1: * The first one is an important one and one that will shape the rest of the year: **Start thinking big. Big and Fearless.** I'm tired of feeling like I drown in the details of life.
* I did not make as much money this year as previous years. In general
column2: I'm having a "is this where my career should be?" point in my life. As I approach 40
column3: I'm getting too old to compete with college age consultants for building simple websites. But what else should I focus on doing? Hmmm...

column1: * Take photos of all my friends in some sort of photo that represents them. In costumes. Staged. I really want a nice photo book at the end of the year with everyone I know. This requires some long term planning.

* Keep losing weight. I felt like I was on a good nutritional path before the holidays arrived. I can feel it's in my grasp. I just need to keep everything in focus and not get side-tracked. Keep up with my existing routine of lifting weights and running.

* Get my god-damned comic books on my website with donation links and places to buy printed issues. I was so close to get everything up a few months ago and then I got side-tracked. I'd love to do another issue
column2: but without money to hire an artist
column3: it's not going to happen.

column1: * Learn Spanish. Learning a little Mandarin was pretty painless (using Fluenz). As long as I give it an hour or two a week
column2: I make progress.

column1: * It's time for more social outlets. I don't what this would be: a photography group
column2: a gay rights group
column3: a musical group...something.

column1: * I bought t-shirt silk screening supplies over a year ago and I've never used them. Why not? It would be fun to be making my own t-shirts. It's not even that hard
column2: I just need to get over the hump of making the first one.

column1: These are some resolutions that I doubt will ever come to pass but are fun to think about:

* There is news that the Apple Tablet will be coming out soon. I think they will have a new format for printed materials delivered electronically. I'd like to learn that as quickly as possible and try to get in on comic publishing for electronic formats.
* Start a NYC chapter of the Tea Party Movement (I'm only half-joking. This would be hysterical and I could write a book afterwards.)

* On a side note...chairmanswife.com and dearbartender.com are two URLs that I have that are expiring soon. Maybe I should finally do something with them. This past year I laughed at the notion of building a content website. Who would ever visit? Now I'm in a mindset that maybe I should just build it and not worry about the results so much. (Think big
column2: Keith!)

column1: * I had a thought when I was making chocolates this year. I could write a book about all the chocolates. I have recipes now for almost 20 chocolates
column2: each with a flavor from a different part of the world. I could write a few pages about each of the places and their local flavors. I could have copious pictures of the process of making the chocolates. It would all make a cute little Christmas-y book to give to people.

column1: I saw a book on developing your programming career from one of my favorite publishers. Perhaps I should read it and start putting into practice some techniques for growing my career. And on another side note
column2: there's all of a sudden a lot of little work in my lap.

column1: I went to meetup.com and looked for some groups to join. And so I joined the following:
I know it's a little gay-centric
column2: but hey...I like the company of gay men. Meetings start this Sunday
column3: Dec 27th
column4: so I'll be 3 days ahead of schedule on completing these resolutions!";"1261579513";"textile"

column1: "I've Got Kitsch on the Brain";"personal/blog/music/ive-got-kitsch-brain";"Around 12-15 years ago
column2: I discovered a mix tape that belonged to a friend of mine. The tape was called "Schlock Around the Clock" and it was a revelation. I don't think I recognized any of the music on it. It juxtaposed The Cramps with Eartha Kitt. It had movie clips spliced into the songs. I listened to it non-stop and it kicked off years of musical obsessions and CD hunting.

column1: I attempted to make my own version on CD. The first one is called "I've Got Kitsch on the Brain". It contains a handful of songs from the original mix tape and at least one of the movie trailers. It took me forever to track down the original trailer soundtrack from "Astro-Zombies". And I never found a digital copy of "Hot Dog Rock & Roll". I threw in some songs that just about everyone has heard to balance it all out.
I had some qualms about placing this on the internet. Yes
column2: people used to make mix tapes for their friends all the time and no one thought anything of it. So what's the big deal if the mix tape is now in digital format? And what's the big deal if I can now immediately distribute this to ALL my friends instead of just some? To help me justify my guilt
column3: why don't you throw some money at some of the artists on iTunes or Amazon? After all
column4: we could probably all stand to beef up our Sergio Mendes collection.

column2: this music doesn't work well out of context. It's meant to be listened form start to finish - not randomly. And be sure that the files are marked for gapless playback. There are lots of fade ins and fade outs that don't work if there's a gap in playback.

column1: Download "I've Got Kitsch on the Brain"

I borrowed lots of film clips "Beyond the Valley of the Dolls" and "Blood Sucking Freaks". And the music is a bit more focused - clearly hitting more of the late 60's and 70's psychedelia.

column2: I had plans for a third one "I See Kitsch With My Third Eye" that would focus primarily on Bollywood music from the 60's and 70's. We'll see if that ever materializes.

column2: Baby?";"personal/blog/music/got-problems-baby";"If you skipped my other CD mixes
column3: fine. This is the one to download. One night I dragged Benji to see Coffy at the Film Forum - not really knowing what to expect. I was transfixed. It was hard-core
column4: it was sexy
column5: it was righteous revenge
column6: it was ... Pam Grier. She's a better vigilante than Batman. If you haven't seen Coffy or Foxy Brown
column7: you really should. I can honestly say that my sense of entertainment was altered when I saw Coffy.

column2: I don't think people today would be able to make these movies. In fact
column3: I was really excited when I heard Quentin Tarantino was making Jackie Brown. However
column4: it was unbelievably tame compared to her early films. There's a thirst for justice and revenge pumping through her original films.

column2: the music is incredible. I really don't even want to bother trying to explain why it's so great. Just listen to it.

column1: So consider this mix a primer course in blaxploitation films. There are two discs. The highlight is track 9 on the second disc - transitioning from Marlena Shaw into one of my favorite clips from Coffy and then into "Treat Her Like a Lady". It scratches an itch I didn't know I had.
