column1: "A Pomodoro in Time";"personal/blog/nlp/pomodoro-time";"I just finished reading a book called "Pomodoro Technique Illustrated" by Staffan Nöteberg (http://www.amazon.com/Pomodoro-Technique-Illustrated-Really-Minutes/dp/1934356506). I guess it's a little premature to say that it's changed my life
column2: but in my first week of truly implementing the method
column3: I find myself on Thursday and have already accomplished more than I had mentally apportioned to get done for the whole week. A couple of months ago
column4: I had read the free PDF by the original author and decided to test it out
column5: but in typical fashion I sort of did it half-ass. This particular book helped me understand much more why the technique works and modifies it somewhat so that it's inline with other time-management and productivity techniques.

column1: For those that don't know the Pomodoro Technique
column2: it's really simple. At it's core
column3: you work in 25 minute increments. You set a timer
column4: work uninterrupted for 25 minutes
column5: then take a break for 5 minutes. You keep doing that and every 4 "pomodori"
column6: you take a longer break. And the thing is
column7: you can't break up a pomodoro into smaller pieces. If someone interrupts you for more than a minute or so
column8: you invalidate the entire pomodoro and start over. So you quickly learn the phrase "Respect the Pomodoro". You quickly learn to ignore the growing number of unread messages in your inbox.

column1: It was founded by an Italian student that felt like he was working all day and not accomplishing anything. In total frustration with his short attention span
column2: he set a timer and said he was going to do one task for 25 minutes - just to see if it was possible.

column1: I have tried to read other productivity books and they always come across a bit too much like a cult manifesto. And the techniques were just too complex. I always subconsciously knew I wasn't going to be able to modify my habits to the point where I would follow the technique. So one of the big benefit of the techinque is that it's simple
column2: and the benefit of this book is that it's short. When you distill the book down to the actual technique
column3: it's just a handful of pages. He spends the majority of the book talking about how our brains work and what they need to operate optimally. He takes a very matter-of-fact approach that is pretty rare among self-help books.

column1: A few times he talks about the contributing factors to procrastination and he does it in a simple
column2: non-emotional way. I've seen books to help you deal with procrastination where they claim that you essentially need to generate an inner cheerleader - constantly firing you up to ACCOMPLISH THINGS. Nope. Doesn't work in my world. His description and prescription for procrastination fits my particular outlook much more clearly.

column1: When I first read about the Pomodoro Technique
column2: I thought that it was primarily centered around stopping disruptions. And it's definitely that
column3: but I would argue that that's not the reason it works so well. Staffan talks a lot in the book about creating a rhythm for accomplishment. It's almost like you're training your attention span like a professional athlete trains in cycles. You're exercising your ability for productivity. The cycle of 25 minutes on and 5 minutes off puts you into a buzz of focus.

column2: there's always a big push at the end. I'm clear-headed
column3: driven
column4: and I'm crossing everything off my to-do list at a lightning pace. I often thought "I wish I could start every day like this and not just close to the deadline." And I think we tend to convince ourselves that we have to wait for the muse to strike or the adrenaline to kick in before we can really accomplish something substantial. Following the technique allows you to tap into that energy as soon as you set the timer. As soon as I wind up the timer
column5: I feel like I'm on the bonus round of "The $25
column6: 000 Pyramid."

column2: it has shed a big light on my time estimates. When I first read the free PDF
column3: I had no interest in recording my estimates. I just wanted to set the timer and go. After reading Staffan's book
column4: I realized that the time estimates
column5: review and analysis was crucial. It's a real eye-opener to see how I wildly under-estimate certain tasks.

column2: I don't want to go on and on or it will sound like I'm evangelizing. I highly recommend the book. You'll start using the Pomodoro Technique for everything: 25 minutes to clean the kitchen. Go. 25 minutes to organize my desk. Go.

column1: FYI - It took me two pomodori for this blog post.

column2: our good friends Maria & Michael sent us some quince branches. I had never heard of keeping quince branches as a cut flower
column3: but they have turned out to be beautiful.

column1: At first I was a bit intimidated by the size. There were about 5-6 branches and they were 6 feet tall. We didn't have a vase big enough to hold them. I went to our local high-end florist who got us a vase and cut the ends for us - both cutting off the tips and splitting the bottoms to help them absorb water.
Yesterday they started blooming all over. I took some pictures of them in the light of the snowstorm.
Supposedly they will last until spring. I'm so impressed with them that I will have to add them to my list of great gifts to deliver to people.

"Sis & Lorenz Visit NYC";"personal/blog/lorenz/sis-lorenz-visit-nyc";"I just said goodbye to Sis and Lorenz. David was kind enough to use his miles to purchase tickets for Sis and Lorenz for a little winter visit. Looking back on it
column2: it's hard to believe that it was just over two days. I'm surprised Lorenz' head didn't burst after all the activities we threw his way.

column1: They arrived on a Saturday night. Lorenz crashed in the cab ride form the airport and stayed comatose while we caught up with Sis. The next morning
column2: after breakfast
column3: David and I took him to Union Square to play in the park. We gave him the first of his birthday presents: a Fujifilm Instax 210. We told him that it only worked outdoors to help motivate him to leave the house and also to keep it a novelty. There's really just one thing to do: press a button and take a picture. He kept wanting to take pictures of the ground. He got the hang of it and took some really great photos. Of the photos below
column4: there are only two he didn't take.

column1: The rest of that day was largely dedicated to making homemade donuts. Sis had invited some friends over to help eat everything. I was a bit overwhelmed at first
column2: but soon got myself in the rhythm of cranking out donuts: vanilla glazed
column3: cinnamon donut holes
column4: and maple bars. I wish I could make donuts more often
column5: but they just don't fit into a healthy diet.

column2: Lorenz and I spent some quality time playing Lego Star Wars on my PS3. I don't really understand what it means to be 4 years old. He had a hard time understanding the controls and often got too carried away to even work the controls. I tried to keep the video games to a minimum
column3: because it overloaded his system.

column2: we made use of a present that David got for his birthday: a very nice fondue set. I had gone to Artisanal earlier in the week and got a variety of Swiss cheeses. It was my first time making a fondue
column3: but it's not that hard - especially with really great ingredients. Surprisingly
column4: Lorenz was not into the fondue
column5: which was fine since the adults were all having a great time.

column1: The next day was a big day. We took Lorenz to Hayden Planetarium. I was blown away. The show was fantastic. I forget that I live in NYC sometimes
column2: and that living in NYC means you get the very best. The show
column3: with a voice-over by Whoopi Goldberg
column4: was light years beyond the planetarium shows I had seen as a kid. And I think it's one of those shows that you appreciate more the older you get.

column2: we wandered through the Museum of Natural History. Lorenz went cuh-razy looking at all the dinosaur bones. And there were so many more exhibits than I remembered. I would have enjoyed staying and looking at some of the more boring exhibits
column3: but we were constantly flirting with (or managing) meltdowns
column4: so short-circuited trip and took him to the whale room. He was in total heaven in the whale room. I think just the calming dark blue light helped significantly.

column1: As we approached the whale room
column2: and he was looking at the hundreds of animals on the walls and ceiling
column3: you could almost see his brain short-circuiting. As an adult
column4: I know when I'm hitting overload time. I know when it's all getting to be too much and I need to sit and let everything sink in. A child doesn't know how to do that though. I don't know how they compensate. Do they start ejecting information that they can't process?

column1: We got one last look at dinosaur bones and then got back on the subway to head downtown. He was having a hard time not being really cranky
column2: and I was tempted to go straight home
column3: but instead we took him to Max Brenner. It was a madhouse
column4: but he was instantly transfixed by all the chocolate. Everyone got something to take out and we walked home.

column1: Most of us crashed except for Sis and Lorenz (I don't know why Sis hasn't instituted nap-time
column2: but oh well). Dinner was relatively simple.

column1: This morning was pretty low-key. I think Lorenz was starting to break down from being away from home. He was pretty cranky in the morning. I gave him his final present
column2: an iPod Nano loaded with Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck cartoons. He loved it and didn't want to put it away when it was time to go. However
column3: I think he knew that the weekend had been too much. He wanted to go home.

column1: Here are some of the better Instax photos:

"The Hardest Work Out of My Life (thus far)";"personal/blog/fitness/hardest-work-out-my-life-thus-far";"I took a new fitness class today. It was recommended to me by a friend. It's a gym that is only a block or two from my house called AeroSpace NYC (http://aerospacenyc.com). To be honest
column2: I've been meaning to go for months. And this week I finally put my foot down with myself and said I had to go. And even then
column3: I chickened out twice when I got to the front doors. Looking back on it
column4: I have no idea why I was so stressed out about attending. I would have no problems going back - in fact
column5: I'm currently planning to quit my regular gym and just go here.

column1: The gym does not have any weights or machines. It's primarily for classes
column2: though it appears there are some private sessions there as well. The gym centers around boxing fitness. The owner is a former professional boxer. I don’t have any desire to box
column3: but the classes sounded very intense with a low risk of injury. The classes focus on either boxing moves (doing punch and jab sequences)
column4: rope jumping
column5: or toning using weighted bars or small dumbbells. The big inspiration is the owner
column6: who is lean
column7: strong
column8: and fast.

column1: The main part of my intimidation was the fact that most classes have some sort of jumping rope. I had a trainer in my 20’s try to get me to jump rope and it was not fun. Even if I had the coordination
column2: within 30 seconds of successful jumping
column3: I’m ready to heave up a lung. One of the times I had chicken out
column4: I arrived to see a class all jumping rope in perfect unison. They were doing various foot sequences in harmony just to cement their “we’re doing something you can only dream of” status.

column1: And the other part of my intimidation is that it’s New York. It seems like whenever you try to learn something new in NYC
column2: you have to do it with people that have been doing that exact thing for 10 years and are pretty damn alpha about it. I really
column3: really
column4: really didn’t feel like being The Out-Of-Shape Guy in the back while everyone breezes through the workout.

column1: As I raised these concerns to the friend that told me I should go
column2: he kept saying “It’s not like that. Just go. No one can keep up. It’s okay.”

column1: And why I didn’t believe him
column2: I’ll never know.

column1: The instructor/owner could not have been nicer. He came up to me before the class and introduced himself. He said that I should not try any footwork for jumping rope - just do the basics and never do more than 8 in a row until I get more comfortable. He also said that for the lunges and squats
column2: I should make the movement as small as possible until my body says it’s ready for me. So all in all
column3: I felt pretty good.

column1: But what really put me at ease
column2: was the guy in the center of the front row. He was in perfect condition - one of these hardcore Chelsea fitness buffs. And he looked like he had taken the class many times before. As we started warming up (which was quite a warm-up)
column3: he had to stop twice to recover. Within 3 minutes of the class starting
column4: my ribs were aching and I was out of breath. I had no idea it would go that hard that quickly.

column1: After Mr. Perfect in the front row had to stop to recover
column2: I noticed lots of other people having to stop for a few seconds to catch their breath. And it was like that the whole class. Not a single person could follow everything. People took breathers liberally. All of a sudden I relaxed and had more fun. I had no problems taking a breather for a minute and then throwing myself back in the thick of it.

column1: My rope jumping was not so bad. My punching was pretty good
column2: but the instructor came over and corrected me from hyper-extending. I took a water break about 20 minutes into the class. At the 40 minute mark
column3: I was seriously seeing stars. Even the abs section of the class - though very brief - was so intense that I could only do about 4-5 of each exercise. I’ve heard that with perseverance
column4: you can get through the whole class without stopping. I can’t even fathom what sort of shape you have to be in for that.

column1: What amazed me most about the instructor was his speed and agility. The punching sequences were a real wake-up call. I kept thinking that when we would start a punching sequence
column2: that it wouldn’t be as hard as the rope jumping - but I eventually started praying for more rope jumping. I have no idea how you make all those movements for the punch sequences as fast as he does it. And I just didn’t have the mental acuity in the workout to keep doing it. Every now and then
column3: my brain would short circuit and I’d look like a spastic muppet - limbs flailing randomly.

column2: I finished. And yes
column3: I’ve never felt so old
column4: slow and out-of-shape in my life. But damn it was a good workout. The owner came by afterwards to shake my hand and compliment me on my jumping. I left with a feeling of “well
column5: how could I _not_ continue?” ";"1266618841";"textile"

column1: "Fondue";"personal/recipes/dish/main-dishes/fondue";"Ah... fondue. It has the reputation of being hopelessly 70's. David recently received a fondue set for his birthday. How we had gone all this time without a fondue set is beyond me. I've made fondue twice with it now
column2: and the second round was so good

stir to combine the cheeses and cornstarch. While whisking constantly

column1: "No More Store Bought Dog Food";"no-more-store-bought-dog-food";"After Oz's pancreatitis
column2: I've decided that it's not enough that I'm buying healthy
column3: raw dog food. I thought I was making good choices for him
column4: but it comes down to the fact that when it's made by someone else
column5: you don't really know what goes into it. I want to know and be responsible for absolutely everything he eats. I read through the section of Dr. Pitcairn's book on pancreatitis and he listed some foods that aid digestion and the pancreas. So I'm going back to making the dogs' food from scratch. That way I can pick exactly what he needs and make sure he gets human-grade meat. (Really
column6: I should have known better than to trust packaged food after that whole melamine pet food scare from a few years ago.)

column1: And in addition to making their regular food
column2: I'm going to start making their treats from scratch
column3: too. I found a bunch of recipes online: http://www.dogaware.com/diet/treats.html. I'm not really looking forward to having the whole house smell like liver and garlic
column4: but so be it. I'll start small on the batches until I'm sure they like they taste and then start making bulk.

column1: Once I get into the rhythm of making food for the dogs
column2: I'm going to tackle David and myself next. It would be great to never order out for meals again.";"1280072649";"textile"

column1: "So many ways to stay connected";"so-many-ways-stay-connected";"<div class='posterous_autopost'>I'm putting together an exit strategy for Facebook. I love the fact that I'm contact with smart
column2: fun people that I rarely get to see. Unfortunately
column3: the constant privacy concerns are...concerning me. I tried Twitter for many months
column4: but the 140 character limit really gets to me sometimes. And I have been unable to get TweetDeck truly integrated into my weekly routine
column5: so Twitter has fallen by the wayside. I tried Tumblr
column6: which I ay still fall back on
column7:
but it updates Facebook in an odd way. 

So now I'm trying Posterous. Which is designed to be the ultimate tool for updating your various feeds everywhere. We'll see if it's a decent payoff.
";"1280072719";"textile"

column1: "Saw "The Kids Are Alright"";"saw-kids-are-alright";"...and it's a really great movie. Maybe it's just because I'm so bogged down with Oz's recovery or bogged down by the mugginess of NYC right now
column2: but I immediately thought \"I want to move to California and raise kids\". I've had moments in my life where those two thoughts came and went pretty quickly - usually separately. But this was the first time in my life that the idea of having kids actually felt like a good idea. I could see it all and play it out roughly in my head and it felt...doable. It felt right. It resonated with me. I have to not focus on the first 5 years which seems like an unending terror of diapers and crying. Everything after that seems like it would be pretty amazing - rocky
column3: of course
column4: but still like something that challenges you
column5: makes you grow
column6: and allows you to see more of how life works. And to have a family
column7: of course.

column2: I remember my Mom got misty when she dropped me off at college. How did she not bawl her eyes out? Did she cry all the way back to Oregon? Because just watching the movie
column3: I don't think I would have any emotional fortitude at that moment in my life.

column2: California. I was ready to pack up and go within the first few shots of sunny California. Man
column3: living in NYC is hard sometimes. I feel like I'm always fighting crowds or weather or strangers or just the city itself. And as I said
column4: this probably has more to do with Oz's recovery which is weighing pretty heavily on me right now. And the painters in the house. And work. And the constant heat waves. But in all the outdoor shots I could smell California - the eucalyptus
column5: the fresh produce...ah. Maybe someday.

column2: the movie is really fantastic and feels so authentic. The acting is top notch all around. I recommend it to all adults.";"1280074514";"textile"

column1: "Muppet Wedding Music";"muppet-wedding-music";"I'm at a wedding at the Palace Hotel of Gossip Girl fame. A string quartet played "The Rainbow Connection."

column2: Wedding Planner.";"1280090204";"textile"

column1: "Green Tripe to the Rescue";"personal/blog/oz/green-tripe-rescue";"The big hurdle in Oz's recovery has been getting him to eat. The doctors initially warned us about not trying to feed him too much too quickly. In hindsight
column2: that seems laughable that we were concerned about him eating too much. Some days it's better than others and he goes for it
column3: but usually it's a few nibbles and he loses interest.

column1: So I decided to pull out the big guns and order green tripe. For those of you that have never heard of it
column2: tripe is one of the later stomachs of animals that chew their cud (in this case
column3: cows). There's even a website about it: http://www.greentripe.com/. Green tripe refers to tripe that has not been cleaned of contents. In other words
column4: it's animal intestines filled with partially digested food. Yummers! It's supposed to be very good for their digestive system because it has all sorts of enzymes that their bodies can't produce.

column1: It's illegal to sell to humans
column2: but you can sell it to dogs. And I had heard stories of people that had fed it to their dogs. Step #1: put a clothespin over your nose. Step #2: give the green tripe to your dog. Step #3: Watch your dog go insane with happiness.

column1: I ordered green tripe from Oma's Pride (http://www.omaspride.com/) along with many other disgusting and hard-to-find animal items. I had been holding on to it until Oz was a bit more on the mend
column2: but this morning he was barely eating. He had a few bites of the canned food that the vet gave us. He turned his nose up to everything else I had. So I pulled out the tripe.
it smells like manure. It was still partially frozen so the smell wasn't that bad. For half a second
column3: I thought of defrosting it in the microwave
column4: but I think David would have run screaming out of the house if the whole kitchen reeked of microwaved manure. I pulled out the mostly defrosted parts into Oz's bowl and quickly sealed up the remainder.

column1: When I put it down for Oz
column2: there was a tentative sniff. My lips were still curled into a sneer from the smell. Then he gave it a tentative lick. Then he started eating voraciously. He went through two servings and still asked for a third. It was more than he had eaten in days. He lost his appetite at the beginning of the third helping
column3: so Gogo got the rest. She did the same tentative sniff and then went crazy. They licked the bowl spotless.

column1: It's pretty clear that I'm going to have to order more for them. I'm hoping that it does indeed have a great effect on his digestive system which has had quite a blow over the past couple of weeks.";"1280592690";"textile"
"I'm obsessed with pre-fab mini homes";"personal/blog/living/im-obsessed-pre-fab-mini-homes";"Perhaps it was all the news footage of Chelsea Clinton's wedding
column2: but I have become obsessed with the notion of getting a mini pre-fab home in the country. Sara had shown me this site a while ago: http://www.weehouse.com and I can't stop looking at the images. A little house upstate to retreat to...ahh...sounds perfect.

column1: Now I need to figure out where I'm going to get the money for such a house.
My favorites are the McGlasson and the Marfa
column2: by the way.";"1280757450";"textile"

column1: "Packing for China";"china/packing-china";"I'm packing for China now. Well
column2: at least I should be packing instead of writing blog posts.

column1: David had bought tickets in coach flying non-stop from Chicago to Beijing. I was not looking forward to that flight. The good news is that we got upgraded from coach to business! Yippee! And I have 28 hours of video on my iPad and enough Ambien to remain serene
column2: sleepy
column3: and entertained.

column1: So now...what am I doing in China? I was on my won for five days in Beijing last year and I went over board as a tourist. I had crossed everything off my list from temples
column2: to parks
column3: to Peking Opera
column4: to markets
column5: to crazy Chinese medical treatments. I was even one ahead of David on the list of Wonders of the World because I made it to the Great Wall of China before he did. So I naively thought that I would repeat a lot of my successes from the past trip and take David around to my highlights of last year. Foolish Keith. I found a whole new slew ofthings to do:

column1: *The Great Wall of China and Ming Tombs* - Yes
column2: this is a repeat
column3: but David has to see the Great Wall. Also
column4: my tour guide gave me a terrible tour of the Ming Tombs so I feel like I have to go back. I don't think I even saw half of them. I never even went inside the actual tombs.

column1: *Tour of Buddhist Temples* - We found a gay guide that suggested this tour. I had been to the Lama Temple and it's stunning. I'm happy to go back. I'm also happy that there are 7 other temples our guide will be taking us to.

*Moxibustion* - This will be part of my visit to a Chinese health clinic. I'll let this page explain it: http://acupuncturetoday.com/abc/moxibustion.php. The practitioner is also going to give me a "food energetics" session which will outline what sorts of foods I should be eating and which ones to stay away from to "remove the damp from my system" and promote the flow of Qi.
*The Museum of Ethnic Clothes* - This looks a great museum of old textiles and clothes from China.
*Cooking Class* - I'm not 100% sold on this one
column2: but I may attend a class (spoken in English) on traditional Chinese home cooking. I was hoping for a hand made noodle pulling class
column3: but I'm too late for that one.

column1: So I feel like I'm ready to attack Beijing again like a rabid tourist
column2: hungry for new experiences. And I'm with David this time
column3: so I will have better meals than last time.

column1: FYI - I never got around to posting the photos from my trip to China last year
column2: so at some point you can expect to see a whole mess of China photos on the site.";"1284909954";"textile"
Really Nice";"china/hotel-really-really-nice";"So...David and I had a nice flight to China. It went by really quickly for some reason. I'm sure that being in business class helped. And now it's 1am
column3: we're settled into our hotel
column4: and we're wide awake.

column1: We're staying the Hilton Beijing Wangfujing. We had some problems getting here. Specifically
column2: the taxi driver had no idea where it was and didn't speak English. The Google maps that we had printed up helped marginally. Pointing and shouting "zhe ge" also helped.

column1: The hotel is possibly the fanciest place I've ever stayed. We got upgraded to a suite. I wouldn't be surprised to find out that there aren't that many people staying here.

The room is full of mirrors and glass panels. I can't tell when I'm walking into a new space or when I'm about to crash into a mirrored wall. They had three tiers of sweets on the coffee table: chocolates
column2: chocolate covered cherries
column3: and macaroons. They offered to have someone come to the room to massage our legs (I don't even want to know if that was code for something). But the pièce de résistance is that they had a teddy bear on the bed waiting for us. A TEDDY BEAR! I'm tempted to see if there's a "read me a bed-time story" service.

column2: the usual social networking rules apply in China: no Facebook
column3: no Twitter
column4: no ping.fm. So my little site will have to handle all those duties for me. ";"1285002954";"textile"
